HEADLINE: Cost of Malpractice: A Special Report;
Medical Incompetence: A Whispered Factor in Rising Costs

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FORT WORTH, April 5

 BODY:
When John L. Rounsaville Jr., a 44-year-old father of three, checked into a hospital here for routine lower-back surgery, he expected to be released within a day or so and be back at work soon after that. But when he did get out, almost six months later, he was strapped in a wheelchair.
Mr. Rounsaville, who was a rising executive with a Texas military contractor, had suffered catastrophic damage to the brain and the nervous system. He had lost virtually all control of his body, rendering him unemployable and in need of round-the-clock nursing care for the rest of his life. Every day, he had to take as many as 74 pills just to control the seizures. 
 Mr. Rounsaville's operation, at the Fort Worth Osteopathic Medical Center in 1985, was not just the beginning of medical and personal disasters, but legal and financial ones as well. It was nearly five years before a jury concluded, according to the court judgment, that "an incompetent anesthesiologist," Dr. Garry E. Winn, had injected Mr. Rounsaville with 10 to 20 times the recommended dose of a sedative.
After hearing evidence that several of Dr. Winn's colleagues had let him continue to practice even though they knew he had problems -- he had physical disabilities related to a stroke and he admitted drinking a pint to a pint and a half of vodka a day -- the jury further found the hospital and some of its top officials negligent as well.
The jury awarded Mr. Rounsaville and his family $13.6 million.
With the White House and Congress struggling with proposals to overhaul the nation's health care system, Mr. Rounsaville's case illustrates one reason health costs have risen so rapidly. Yet nothing in the Clinton health plan, nor the alternatives, directly addresses the problem of incompetent and negligent doctors.
"Nowhere in the Clinton plan do we see any ongoing monitoring of quality problems," said Andrew Webber, head of the American Medical Peer Review Association. "Clearly, bad medicine increases costs."
 
Ruining Lives, Costing Billions
 Most Americans receive medical care of high quality, perhaps the best in the world. Still, medicine, like every profession, has its share of negligent, even incompetent, practitioners. And as Mr. Rounsaville's case shows, their errors not only can ruin lives; they can be almost uncalculably expensive.
One Harvard University study suggests that tens of thousands of people die every year as a result of medical incompetence; hundreds of thousands of others suffer grievous injury. And though no one has tallied the costs of all this, experts agree that tens of billions of dollars are involved.
The hospital and insurance carriers paid most of the $13.7 million final settlement in the Rounsaville case. In Texas, as in the rest of the nation, those costs are generally passed on through hospital and doctor bills and insurance premiums, increasing health costs for everyone.
Several studies involving thousands of medical records have shown that as many as 99 of every 100 hospital patients generally receive adequate care. But with about 30 million hospital admissions a year, even 1 percent represents 300,000 cases of negligent care, more than 800 every day.
The Harvard study, published in 1991, showed that in one year in New York State, documented negligent care injured more than 27,000 people, killing 7,000 of them.
Each one of these cases can be a personal disaster. As Mr. Rounsaville's lawyer, Darrell L. Keith, said at the trial: "On April 23d, 1985, John's participation in the real, living, breathing, American dream and that of his family turned into a nightmare. And the nightmare continues."
While this case was extreme, it is hardly unique. A review of hundreds of malpractice lawsuits and state disciplinary actions against doctors in Texas over the last five years disclosed many more horror stories.
Among them was a doctor who ran a licensed weight-loss clinic in East Texas and was found to have given his clients weed killer and rat poison, causing severe intestinal injuries. Another doctor admitted to vision problems during a botched stomach operation, but he defended himself by saying good surgery was "just like making love" -- if you know what you're doing, you can can do it in the dark.
 
The Problem
Failures to Report The Incompetent
An incompetent physician can face discipline from several sources. The hospital where the doctor works can revoke his right to practice there, but that seldom happens. The responsibility falls to the hospital medical staff, the doctor's colleagues, and they often do not act, either out of fear of being sued or simply because they do not want to hurt a friend.
Every state also has a medical board charged with ferreting out incompetent doctors and disciplining them or revoking their licenses. But most hospitals seldom share their problems with the medical board. And many boards do not have the power to act or the money to investigate accusations of malpractice.
Nationwide, state medical boards took 2,971 disciplinary actions in 1992, according to figures compiled by the Federation of State Medical Boards, a private group. With 623,378 licensed doctors, that means there were 5 such actions for every 1,000 doctors, leading many critics to argue that there is no way that 99.5 percent of the nation's doctors qualify to escape any censure.
In Dr. Winn's case, some doctors had complained about his diminishing mental faculties before Mr. Rounsaville's operation; several had refused to work with him. Still, they made no effort to curtail his operating room privileges, nor did they alert the Texas Board of Medical Examiners.
Mr. Rounsaville's wife, Sandra, recalls that she never had the slightest thought of questioning a doctor's credentials. She had never met Dr. Winn.
"If you're going to have your car repaired, you want to know if someone has messed up cars before," she said. "You can call the Better Business Bureau and find out if there's a complaint lodged against them. With this hospital, I feel I was naive. I just assumed they were the ones who would be the watchdogs over their doctors."
 
The Operation
Routine Surgery Goes Awry
 The operation for Mr. Rounsaville's back problem, a ruptured disc, is not an easy procedure, but it is generally not life-threatening. What happened to Mr. Rounsaville was a result of Dr. Winn's mistake: that is conceded by the hospital administration, the surgeon who performed the operation and Dr. Winn's former anesthesiology partners.
The only person who asserted that Dr. Winn had acted properly was Dr. Winn himself. He gave a deposition in July 1986 while on a day-pass from an alcohol rehabilitation center. He later declined to attend his own trial.
What happened during the operation, according to court records, was that Dr. Winn gave Mr. Rounsaville a massive injection of sufentanil citrate, also known as sufenta, an artificial sedative that is roughly a hundred times more powerful than morphine. There were indications that Dr. Winn may have confused the drug with a less potent cousin, fantynyl, and that he may simply have injected what would have been a proper dose of that drug.
Even that mistake might not have been catastrophic, doctors say, if Dr. Winn had connected Mr. Rounsaville to a ventilating tube. That would have provided a continuous supply of oxygen and controlled his respiration.
But Dr. Winn did not use the tube when the operation began or as it proceeded, when, according to the attending nurse's clinical notes, the patient began to appear "cyanotic" (he was turning blue) and "apneic" (he was not breathing).
The chief surgeon, Dr. Christopher Hull, testified that as soon as these problems became apparent, he asked for directions from Dr. Winn, who said that it they waited a few minutes, Mr. Rounsaville would resume normal breathing. The surgeon quickly overruled him, and Mr. Rounsaville was hooked to a ventilating tube.
 
Dr. Winn's Memory Lapse
 As these critical moments elapsed -- just two or three minutes, said Dr. Winn, but as many as 12, said the nurse's notes -- Mr. Rounsaville apparently suffered irreversible brain damage. He was unconscious as he was wheeled out of the operating room. Later that day he began experiencing severe seizures.
In his deposition, Dr. Winn said he could not recall just how much sufenta he had given Mr. Rounsaville that day. Shown a black check mark on his medical notes that indicated that he had given Mr. Rounsaville two milliliters -- at least 10 times the normal dose -- he shook his head and said, "I have no idea how that, how that little mark got there."
Mrs. Rounsaville says she will never forget Dr. Winn's face as he came out of the operating room. "He looked real bad, real grim," she recalled.
The supervisory officials at the hospital told her that her husband was in bad shape. But, she said, "They were trying to blame it on his reaction to different things." It was not until months later that Mrs. Rounsaville discovered the problem had been Dr. Winn.
 
The Insiders
Who Knows And Who Tells
 "It's so clear what happened," concedes Earl Harcrow, then a lawyer for the hospital's chief of staff, Dr. Thomas J. Trese, and now a lawyer for the hospital, which has changed its name to the Osteopathic Medical Center of Texas. "The man got 10 times more of a drug than he should have."
But what became a very complex issue at the trial was whether the hospital and the people who worked with Dr. Winn had reason to believe he might commit such an egregious mistake.
The jury found that many of them should have anticipated such a problem, sending a clear message that the whole episode represented a failure in the peer-review process that most members of the public expect to be standard at a major hospital.
Dr. Winn, a 1964 graduate of the Kirksville College of Osteopathic Medicine in Kirksville, Mo., was involved in a serious auto accident in 1968 and had two seizures in the hospital. In 1982, he suffered a stroke, which left him with weakness in his right limbs and temporarily unable to speak. He had always been blind in one eye.
After the stroke, he said in his deposition, he "underwent intensive physical therapy and had about a 95 percent recovery." He returned to practice in Fort Worth.
No problems were reported at first. But by the summer of 1984, nearly a full year before the operation that crippled Mr. Rounsaville, some of his colleagues had begun to believe that something was amiss with Dr. Winn, and at least three of them announced that they would no longer work with him.
His two partners in anesthesiology, Gary L. Neisler and Kenneth C. Ponitz, both testified that surgeons had given them no reason to believe that the complaints had stemmed from questions about Dr. Winn's competence.
"The complaints from the surgeons weren't, 'This is what's wrong,' " Dr. Ponitz testified. "They were vague. They almost made it sound like a personality thing."
Still, by December 1984, enough concerns had been raised that the hospital's chief of staff, Dr. Trese, sent Dr. Winn to Columbia University Medical Center in New York for a full neurological evaluation.
In his patient notes, the New York neurologist who saw Dr. Winn, Dr. J. P. Mohr, wrote that Dr. Trese "gave me to understand" that Dr. Winn "has been thought to have failing mental powers and has been somewhat inattentive and unreliable as an anesthesiologist to the degree that several surgeons have expressed concern about his professional competence."
At the trial, Dr. Trese adamantly denied that he had made such an explicit statement.
 
Artery Blockage Is Found
 Dr. Winn was found to have a blockage of the carotid artery that could hamper the blood flow to the brain. But the examination was inconclusive, and Dr. Mohr recommended that Dr. Winn return for more tests. When he got back to Fort Worth, however, Dr. Winn told his colleagues that he had been given "a clean bill of health." He continued to practice without restriction.
Less than two months later, Dr. Winn was the anesthesiologist for a severely diabetic 36-year-old woman, identified at the trial only as Jane Doe. She suffered a loss of oxygen and respiratory arrest during the operation and died. Dr. Winn had had problems during the operation, according to trial testimony. At one point, asked by surgeons for a heart rate, he told them he could not give it because he had forgotten to plug in the heart monitor.
There was confusion about just what had gone wrong. Some of Dr. Winn's colleagues argued that the woman was going to die in any event.
The surgeons who operated on Jane Doe told the chairman of the hospital's anesthesiology department that they would never work with Dr. Winn again. And a few days later, both Dr. Ponitz and Dr. Neisler confronted Dr. Winn and demanded that he leave their partnership.
He did so, but as both anesthesiologists acknowledged at the trial, they were concerned about a threat that Dr. Winn had made. They said he had vowed to sue them for slander if they moved to have his medical privileges revoked. Nothing more was done, and on April 23, 1985, when Sandra Rounsaville kissed her husband minutes before he was wheeled into the operating room, she had no idea about Dr. Winn's background.
 
The Future
A Plan to Let The Public Know
 After the operation, the hospital ordered Dr. Winn back to New York for another examination. The tests indicated that the stroke had brought "increasing compromise in cognitive functioning."
Later that spring Dr. Winn underwent surgery on his carotid artery. He was allowed to return to work, though a team of fellow anesthesiologists monitored him in the operating room. They reported significant deficiencies in his skills and poor evaluations of patients. Before long, Dr. Winn resigned.
A few months later he checked himself into an alcohol rehabilitation center. After his release he applied for and received general practitioner privileges at his old hospital, meaning he could treat hospital patients though he was no longer allowed to work in the operating room.
 
Stroke Ends Doctor's Life
 But he never practiced at the hospital again; he took a job at a medical clinic near the Mexican border. Soon afterward he suffered a stroke and died in 1989.
Through all this, Mr. Rounsaville's case attracted little notice in Fort Worth, though one doctor's trade journal, Medical Economics, succinctly characterized the lesson for doctors: "The perils of taking action against an allegedly incompetent colleague are well known. This case illustrates that the cost of doing nothing can also be very high."
The Clinton health plan does offer one new source of information for patients. The Administration wants the Federal Practitioners Data Bank opened to the public. Created in 1990, it is a list of 32,000 doctors and dentists sued for malpractice or disciplined by state medical boards. Now, the public has no access to the data. Consumer groups support the step, but the American Medical Association bitterly fought the creation of the data base and now argues that it should not be opened to the public.
Today, Mr. Rounsaville spends his days in a bed or in a wheelchair, though he does get out of the house three times a week for physical therapy sessions.
"Sometimes I look at him," Mrs. Rounsaville said, "and it still doesn't make any sense at all to me. This was a perfectly healthy person going in for routine surgery. I felt we had been robbed of what I always dreamed of for our family."

HEADLINE: Commission Urges Curbing Pay in New Jersey Schools

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 8

 BODY:
The hand-picked advisory panel that reported to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman on Thursday was ostensibly concerned with achieving educational parity for New Jersey's poorest school districts. But underlying the panel's recommendations, its members say, was the desire to apply the brakes to ever-rising salaries and benefits in the country's most expensive public-education system.
Even if their recommendations are watered down, the panel members made it clear in their comments that controlling school costs would require fewer teachers, fewer administrators and more bare-knuckled bargaining over wages and benefits from school boards that until now have been more willing to pay than to fight. 
 Dr. Saul Cooperman, the former Education Commissioner who headed the task force, said as much on Thursday. After recommending to the Governor that budget increases for most districts be limited to the inflation rate, and that districts be required to pay most of the $1 billion a year in teacher-retirement benefits now carried by the state, Dr. Cooperman was asked how the local districts would pay for these burdens.
"I remember when I was a teacher, the teacher-pupil ratio was 1 to 35 and we were fighting for 1 to 25," Dr. Cooperman replied. "Now in some places it's one to 15 or one to 17. So maybe class size is going to have to go up three or four pupils, maybe some extra administrators are not going to be there anymore, maybe some things are going to have to be consolidated."
A member of the commission, speaking on condition of anonymity today, put it more bluntly:
"What's been happening in this state is that for a long time, big money has been flowing down, and everybody got what they wanted. You have elementary schools with 400 kids with the same number of teachers that were there when they had 600. You have high schools with 500 kids with the same number of teachers as when there were 1,000 in there. Now the money is running out, New Jersey is still in recession, and the state is not a cash machine anymore."
Some commission members argued forcefully for the panel to recommend still stronger cost-containment measures, including mandatory consolidation of underused schools.
They said Dr. Cooperman restrained the budget-cutting sentiment to keep the recommendations within the panel's mandate, which was to find how to comply with a court order that spending per pupil in poor districts be brought closer to the level of rich ones.
"It is no secret that I favored making some additional recommendations," said Harold J. Raveche, the president of Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken. "We are the highest-spending state per pupil in the U.S., and yet nowhere can I find that we rank anywhere higher than 12th in math exams. We have over 500 school districts and there are economies of scale to be had from combining school districts, for example, but the response was that it really wasn't in our charge."
Even by questioning a decade's worth of steadily increasing personnel costs, the panel provided Governor Whitman with the political cover she needed to carry through her promise to change major aspects of the state school system, several members of the panel said.
"This state devotes a massive amount of its budget to education, the amount is still growing, and there are parts of that spending, like pensions and Social Security, that are potentially out of control," said David Rand, a Morristown lawyer whose law firm specializes in serving school districts.
 
'Wait a Minute, Guys'
 By making local school boards responsible for retirement benefits, which are linked to wages, Mr. Rand said, board negotiators will be less willing to grant excessive wage increases. New Jersey teachers are the highest paid in the country, making an average of $42,500 per year; the national average is $34,900.
"We are paying teachers $65,000 in the north part of the state," Dr. Cooperman said today. "In small districts, elementary principals are making $80,000 or $85,000; high-school principals are making $100,000, and superintendents $125,000. I say, 'Hey, wait a minute, guys: You get tenure, you get great benefits and great working conditions. Maybe $65,000 for 180 days' work is adequate now.' "
The State Supreme Court has ruled that because school districts rely on property tax revenues for most of their funds, children in tax-poor districts are unconstitutionally discriminated against. The previous Governor, Jim Florio, tried to narrow the gap by feeding large amounts of extra state aid to the poor districts while limiting increases in spending by rich ones.
The commission worked by consensus rather than majority vote, which made it possible for Dr. Cooperman to deflect some members' opposition to the proposed cutbacks and to mold a report.
The consensual approach may have been by design on Governor Whitman's part. She noted on Thursday that a second high-level commission, headed by Albert Burstein, a Hackensack lawyer and former State Assemblyman, and studying the same financing issues, had been working for a year, and was supposed to deliver its recommendations last November, a month before the Cooperman panel was formed.
But the Burstein commission, which is operating by majority rule, has failed twice to agree on a program of controlling costs and raising financing for poor districts. It is torn between a faction led by Mr. Burstein, which favors an approach similar to the Cooperman recommendations, and one led by the state teachers' union president, which calls for a doubling of state aid to school districts.

HEADLINE: Feeling Poorer and Spending Less

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8

 BODY:
The American economy will grow somewhat less rapidly this year and next if stock and bond prices do not recover from their recent plunge, Administration officials and some private economists said today.
They cite higher interest rates, which discourage companies and individuals from borrowing and spending money. Moreover, they cite the so-called wealth effect: many American consumers will likely spend less money if they feel poorer because of the shrinkage of their portfolios. 
 After running various computer simulations of the economy, President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers has concluded that if the stock market falls 10 percent below its peak in early February and stays down, this will gradually knock four-tenths of a percentage point off the nation's expected annual economic output, reducing it by about $26 billion. Growth is now running a little over 3 percent. The stock market is currently trading about 7 percent below its peak.
"There is a wealth effect; it's a relatively small effect but it does require a sustained, that is, long-term reduction in the value of stocks," said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the head of the Council of Economic Advisers. But the braking effect of a falling stock market and rising interest rates on the economy may be hard to notice, if, as may well be the case, it is offset by the economy's generally growing strength. A survey this week of prominent economists by Blue Chip Economic Indicators found that their consensus forecast of economic growth this year had actually risen, to 3.7 percent from a 3.6 percent forecast in early March.
Lehman Brothers, the New York investment firm, estimated that the wealth effect from the stock market's recent retreat would reduce economic growth by only two-tenths of a percentage point if the stock market stayed 10 percent below its peak. But when bond market losses and the economy-slowing effects of higher interest rates are included in the calculation, the harm to American economic output grows to five-tenths of a percentage point this year and seven-tenths to eight-tenths of a percentage point next year, said Allen Sinai, Lehman's chief economist.
The key question, Ms. Tyson and other economists said, is not how deeply the stock market has fallen but how long it will stay down. The reason is that consumers appear to be very slow in revising their spending plans in response to financial losses.
Nobody knows how long the stock market will take to recover from last month's selloff. Mr. Sinai said that he expected the market to recover soon because the overall economy remained strong.
But Mr. Sinai added that he expected interest rates to stay up. As a result, Lehman Brothers has just revised downward its projections of economic growth, but not drastically, he said. Mr. Sinai revised his forecast down to 3.4 or 3.5 percent growth this year from a 3.7 percent forecast a month ago, and revised his forecast for next year down to 3 percent from 3.4 percent.
When the stock market crashed in 1987, many doomsayers predicted that the economy would be severely damaged. They were proved wrong, since the economy grew 3.9 percent in 1988, a rate not equaled for any year since then.
That striking miscalculation set off strong criticisms of the wealth effect theory at universities. The effect now is "something that's not emphasized by academic economists but is emphasized by economic forecasters," said Laurence M. Ball, an economics professor at Johns Hopkins University.
Forecasters are quick to defend their continued reliance on the wealth effect, saying that it plays a limited role in their computer simulations and helps improve the accuracy of their predictions. They contend that when the Fed lowered interest rates after the 1987 crash, the resulting stimulus to the economy outweighed consumers' losses on stocks.
 
A Dwindling Role
 Yet the wealth effect also plays a dwindling role in forecasters' calculations. Mr. Sinai, who specializes in the effects of financial markets on the real economy, said his model now assumed that consumer spending would drop by only 3 cents for every dollar of decline in the value of financial assets.
Before 1987, the model assumed that for each dollar of losses, consumer spending declined by a nickel. The Council of Economic Advisers' model still assumes that the effect is a nickel for each dollar. But other economic forecasters place less emphasis on the wealth effect.
Christopher Probyn, an economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, said that for reasons that were not quite clear, the wealth effect may have been slightly more important in the last several years than before 1987.
Mr. Probyn's statistical analysis today showed that each dollar of losses produced a penny drop in consumer spending from 1961 to 1987 but nearly a two-penny drop since 1987.
Some economic policy makers are dubious of such calculations. Susan M. Phillips, a Federal Reserve governor who is one of the Fed's experts on the workings of financial markets, said in an interview last week that she was skeptical of precise estimates showing how many percentage points economic growth might decline after a stock market selloff.
"I wouldn't put the fine point on it of being able to estimate it within a quarter of a point," she said.
But Ms. Phillips did express concern that the fall in financial markets might prompt many households to review their heavy debt burdens and cut back on consumer spending. High household debt and a low savings rate are more of a problem than fluctuations in the financial markets, she said.
Also at issue is whether many investors ever based their personal spending levels on the bond market peak in October, when interest rates fell to historical lows, or the stock market peak two months ago.
Many investors do not seem to include their most recent investment gains in deciding whether to buy a new car or house, making decisions based on their wealth over recent years, said Harvey Rosenblum, a senior vice president at the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas. "A lot of people don't think it's permanent" when the market spurts upward, he said.
Michael J. Boskin, who was chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Bush Administration, agreed. "Yes, there is a wealth effect, but most household don't mark their portfolio to market every day," he said. "Most people have more of a gradual adjustment."

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Unit Trusts May Appeal To Fretful Bond Buyers

BYLINE: By Francis Flaherty 

 BODY:
FOR municipal bond owners who have turned timid, there's a belt-and-suspenders investment worth considering: fixed portfolios known as unit investment trusts.
When tax-free bond funds dropped 5.3 percent in the first quarter -- a bigger drubbing than any other major fund category -- investors accustomed to a buoyant bond market may have recalled a long-ago lesson. In the words of Marysue Wechsler, a Greenbelt, Md., planner: "Bonds are not meant to be traded as growth vehicles. They're used for income as stocks go up and down." 
 From that premise flows much advice for now-numb bondholders. Shorten bond maturities to preserve principal and to have a crack at higher yields if rates continue to rise. Go to cash for safety; rates on money markets are edging up. And use stocks, not bonds, for growth.
Another suggestion is to "buy and hold" bonds. The investor receives the stated interest periodically, plus the principal upon maturity, and the intervening ups and downs of interest rates do not matter.
But "buy and hold" can be hard to do. By definition, bond mutual funds never mature because their managers are always trading; investors may or may not get their principal back when they cash in. And while investors can hold individual bonds to maturity, they will need about $50,000 to diversify adequately.
Enter the unit trust, with both definite maturities and low minimums.
Long viewed as stodgy investments, unit trusts are fixed bundles of either tax-free bonds, taxable bonds or equities. The tax-free types represent about 80 percent of the $100 billion industry -- a share not likely to drop as investors react to the new, higher tax rates. In April, "we usually see a 25 percent jump in monthly sales," said Ron Toupin, chief manager for unit trusts at John Nuveen & Company in Chicago. "This year, it's about 40 percent." Single-state issues for high-tax states are very popular.
Offered in short, intermediate and long-term maturities, the trusts typically require a $5,000 investment. About 75 percent of all unit trusts are packaged by three firms -- Nuveen, Van Kampen Merritt in Oakbrook Terrace, Ill., and a syndicate of brokers led by Merrill Lynch.
The trusts are sold by brokers for federally regulated fees ranging from 2 percent to nearly 5 percent. At Nuveen, a $10,000 investment in a 3-year unit trust carries a 2.5 percent charge, while a $150,000 investment in a 25-year trust goes for 4.5 percent. The bigger the buy, and the shorter the trust's term, the lower the rate. Trusts also carry a small yearly administrative fee, about 0.15 percent.
What do investors get in return? Like funds, unit trusts are professionally assembled portfolios available for low minimums. And they offer diversity. "Our New York portfolio has general obligation bonds, water and sewer bonds, hospital bonds and housing bonds," said Jack Tierney, vice president at Van Kampen Merritt.
But, unlike funds, trusts give the "buy and hold" investor stable dividends and the assured return of principal upon maturity. (Investors can cash in early, but they run market risk and the risk of not finding a buyer in a thin secondary market.)
A sure income "makes the trusts appealing to older people" and enables investors "to match the payouts to regular obligations," like rent or alimony, said Paul Williams, Nuveen's research director.
But safety has its costs. One is the sales charge -- which brokers will often combine with the trust price in one figure. "Some people don't realize they paid a load," said John Markese of the American Association of Individual Investors.
Missed opportunities are another cost. Through active trading, bond-fund managers profited in recent years as interest rates declined and bond prices soared. But trust investors, with a fixed portfolio, missed out. Nor could they reinvest dividends to profit from market conditions.
The people who monitor unmanaged portfolios may be less vigilant about trouble, too. "Many trusts held 'Whoops' bonds" in 1983, Mr. Markese said, referring to the $2.25 billion default of Washington State utility debt. In contrast, many fund managers saw trouble coming and sold. Critics add that inferior bonds, hard to sell alone, often pop up in trusts.
How do unit trusts stack up against mutual funds in costs? To find out, trust investors should amortize the sales charge of the trust over its life, adding in the trust's minimal yearly fee. This number can be compared to the annual expense ratio of a municipal-bond fund, which is 0.86 percent on average, according to Lipper Analytical Services. If a fund has a load, that charge must also be included.
With front-end loads and light yearly fees, trusts get cheaper the longer one holds. For a bit over four years, the average no-load fund is less costly than a trust with a 3 percent load; after that, the trust is cheaper.
Insurance, available on most trusts, will blunt any default dangers, Mr. Tierney said. But the feature costs up to one-quarter point in yield.
As for missed market opportunities, they are inevitable for "buy and hold" investors. But packagers know they will not want to tie up money for long if rates drop and yields climb. Thus, shorter-term trusts are more common, and some trusts stagger maturities, giving investors a chance to reinvest at better yields.

HEADLINE: TAXES;
Business Owners Get Break on Health Plans

BYLINE: By Carole Gould 

 BODY:
OWNERS of small businesses who are struggling with rising health care costs just got a good reason to put their spouses on the payroll. The Internal Revenue Service will now permit such couples to pay all their family medical expenses with pretax dollars.
By putting a spouse on the payroll and setting up a medical plan, business owners have been able to reimburse their employed spouses for medical costs with pretax money. But these medical plans applied only to employees, leaving the business owners out in the cold. 
 In March, a consultant who operates as a sole proprietor and employs his spouse asked the I.R.S. if his business could set up a tax-deductible medical plan. In a tax advice memorandum, the I.R.S. responded favorably, saying an owner who employs a spouse can be covered as a family member under the employee medical plan.
The new interpretation "is a real benefit for the closely held small business," said Nadine Gordon Lee, tax partner with the accounting firm of Ernst & Young, in New York.
To take full advantage of the I.R.S.'s new position, the proprietor of a business can create a plan to reimburse employees for health insurance and other medical expenses and then deduct those payments as a business expense. As an employee, the business owner's spouse is reimbursed for family medical expenses by the company. Those payments are not taxable income.
"In the past, we used to recommend incorporating closely held businesses to take advantage of medical plans," Ms. Lee said. "But that's not necessary anymore."
Despite the tax advantage of incorporating, many self-employed people have resisted because of the complexity and the cost of paying corporate taxes. Contract workers, freelancers and other business owners who were not incorporated in 1993 could deduct just 25 percent of their medical insurance premiums.
The incentive to put a spouse on the payroll is now strong. In many businesses, husbands or wives already help out on a volunteer basis. Simply paying them a salary and setting up a medical plan for employees could save a family a few thousand dollars.
Certain restrictions apply to medical payment plans. The spouse must be a bona fide employee, doing work on a regular basis that the company would otherwise pay someone else to do. Answering the telephone occasionally is not enough. But someone who acts as office manager, handling paperwork and telephones and dealing with clients, should qualify.
The medical plan must cover nearly all employees, not just the spouse. A short document should describe who and what is covered, and the plan's terms communicated to employees.
And the spouse's salary must be reasonable. Because most married couples file joint returns, shifting some money from profits on the business owner's Schedule C to the spouse as salary usually makes little difference in taxes owed.
An added benefit of putting a family member on the payroll is that a spouse who earns at least $2,000 may contribute to an individual retirement account. The contribution might even qualify for an immediate tax deduction, depending on total family income.
But payroll taxes should not be overlooked. When your spouse is formally employed, you will owe Social Security and Medicare taxes of 15.3 percent of income up to $60,600, 2.9 percent for income above that amount and unemployment taxes. "Depending on the family's medical costs, it might be worth it," Ms. Lee said.
If the business owner earns much less than $60,600, shifting some money to the spouse as an employee will probably not result in higher taxes for people who file joint returns, Ms. Lee said. If the business owner earns considerably more, the family medical costs would need to be $7,000 to $8,000 to justify putting the spouse on the payroll at, say $20,000, she said.
The I.R.S. issued its opinion in the form of a tax advice memorandum. Although the memo is not as firm as a ruling, you will not incur penalties if the agency changes its mind someday. The agency could then collect only the unpaid taxes and interest.

HEADLINE: Arming Pakistan Doesn't Promote Peace

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Disarming the Subcontinent" (editorial, March 29), you seem to contend that resumption of arms sales to Pakistan under certain conditions would actually be a step toward disarming the subcontinent. 
 It is not clear to us how doubling the number of F-16's that Pakistan possesses will help promote disarmament in South Asia. Will not such a step be against every declared United States policy goal in South Asia? Not only with regard to proliferation, but also those aimed at reducing tensions between India and Pakistan, promoting a bilateral dialogue between the two countries, preventing an arms race in the region and strengthening democracy there.
If nonproliferation is the objective, why give Pakistan high-performance aircraft capable of carrying nuclear weapons? Why say that even if the Pressler amendment is repealed, Pressler standards will apply, and then almost in the same breath seek a one-time lifting of the amendment to facilitate arms supplies?
After having given 40 F-16's to Pakistan as a reward for assurances that it will not go nuclear, why should the United States now give it almost an equal number of F-16's as a reward for having gone nuclear?
What is the rationale for the United States to aggravate India's security concerns in a big way while at the same time pressing India to lower its security guard?
India has taken steps in recent months to engage the United States on nonproliferation issues. Last November we co-sponsored with the United States a resolution in the United Nations General Assembly on two key elements of the Clinton Administration's nonproliferation initiative, namely, a complete test ban and cessation of production of fissile material for weapons purposes.
We have had three rounds of talks with the United States on nonproliferation and security matters, which both sides have found productive. At the last round, last September, it was agreed to move on to broader dialogue, and talks on participants and agenda are continuing. Last January we made two major proposals to Pakistan with a view to building mutual confidence. We have proposed that our agreement not to attack each other's nuclear installations be extended to economic targets and population centers (this refers to your concern that India and Pakistan might strike at each other's cities).
We have also proposed that both sides agree on no first-use or use at any time of nuclear potentials against each other. Then why this proposal now?
 
SIDDHARTHA SHANKAR RAY
Ambassador of India
Washington, April 1, 1994

HEADLINE: We'd Better Sign On To Law of the Sea

 BODY:
To the Editor:
William Safire is all wet about the international Law of the Sea (column, March 31). This vast treaty does indeed take the oceans as the common heritage of mankind and sets rules for all countries on offshore territorial limits, rights of naval and maritime passage, protection of the marine environment and safeguarding of fisheries. All of these reflect American interests. While Mr. Safire breezily takes these provisions for granted as "unobjectionable," they were contentious subjects of negotiation. 
 What the United States acknowledged in return was a common interest in the mineral resources beneath the high seas. This is no more alien a notion than American insistence on public rights to minerals on Federal lands or offshore oil. The Law of the Sea does, to be sure, provide a rigid framework for sharing the proceeds from private extraction of mineral wealth, but this is precisely the area where the Clinton Administration has won the assent of developing countries to more workable rules.
It is not surprising that mining companies would prefer to throw the Law of the Sea overboard to maximize their own economic interest. But a President who, at their behest, would ignore the country's broader interests from the environment and the Navy to commercial shipping and fishing would be little more than their shill. Clinton Administration negotiators have struck a good balance.
And just in time. What Mr. Safire ignores is that the Law of the Sea has the 60 ratifications needed and will take effect next fall -- with or without the United States. Americans need Washington to be part of the policy-making as the Law of the Sea is put into effect.
 
JEFFREY LAURENTI
Exec. Director, Multilateral Studies
United Nations Association
New York, April 1, 1994

HEADLINE: How Norfolk, Va., Put Workfare to Work

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Can Workfare Work?" (editorial, March 19) points out that there is nothing easy about transforming welfare into workfare: "A program that appears nearly without cost quickly turns expensive, which is why local governments that start workfare often slip back into simply mailing welfare checks." 
 This has not been the experience of Norfolk, Va. In the last year and a half, the Department of Human Services and the Department of Economic Development put into effect a six-week, 120-hour training program that is matched with Norfolk companies and public organizations ready and willing to hire permanent workers.
This partnership between divergent departments has worked, and the budget has been minimal. Look at these figures: a total cost of $87,842; a success rate of more than 47 percent; a bottom line total of $1,514.52 per job!
"Can Workfare Work?" Here is how one of our jobs program graduates, formerly on welfare, answers that question: "As a welfare mother of five, I've been part of lots of programs, a lot of 'good talk,' but nothing happened, and I'd given up . . . now I'm employed and self supporting . . . and there's no telling where I can go now!"
 
ROBERT B. SMITHWICK
Director, Dept. of Development
City of Norfolk
Norfolk, Va., March 27, 1994

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

The Economy
 
The United States economy will grow less rapidly this year and next if stock and bond prices do not recover from their plunge, experts say, in large part because of the so-called wealth effect: many American consumers are likely to spend less money if they feel poorer because their portfolios have been reduced in value. [Page 37.]
 
A Federal Reserve official denied that the Fed's policy makers had limited the leeway of Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, in changing interest rates. [46.]
 
 
Markets
 
The yields on Treasury securities turned higher, spurred by profit taking at the end of a week that saw moderate gains in the bond market and a rise in concerns about inflation. The price of the 30-year bond was down 17/32 , to 8728/32 , with a yield of 7.25 percent, up from 7.21 percent on Thursday. [37.]
 
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 19 points, to 3,674.26, in restrained trading, as equity traders followed the bond market, where there were worries that more hedge funds were overextended and that the Fed would soon raise interest rates. [38.]
 
Lumber prices plunged the daily trading limit, setting a five-month low, amid speculation that housing demand would not be as robust this year as expected. [45.]
 
The dollar had a slight gain against the yen after Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa of Japan resigned amid unrelenting questions about his personal finances. [45.]

 
International
 
The resignation of Japan's Prime Minister has deprived the Clinton Administration of the agent of change it was counting on to open Japanese markets and has left the White House wondering how it will achieve its trade goals with Tokyo. [A5.]
 
Jurgen Strube has guided BASF through a revamping during the German recession and gained the respect of his peers, many of whom had questioned whether a lawyer, rather than a chemist, could successfully lead the giant chemical company. [37.]
 
Factories in the former Soviet Union are trying to make the crucial transition to independent civilian production by soliciting foreign investment. Failing that, they bolster production by diversifying and bartering. [37.]
 
 
Companies
 
Three bidders are vying for Ford's First Nationwide Bank unit. Ford has set a Monday deadline for offers on the subsidiary, which has 181 branches and assets of $16 billion. [39.]
 
MCI Communications named Gerald H. Taylor president of its worldwide communications business, a move that solidifies Mr. Taylor's position as the most important person in the company after its chairman, Bert C. Roberts Jr. [39.]
 
Pegasus Technologies is negotiating for space 250 miles from the Air Force base in California at which it wanted to do sophisticated repair work using imaging X-ray technology. [39.]
 
 
Your Money
 
Financial stocks are good values, analysts say, and may hold up well in shaky markets. And a stronger economy should push up banks' profits as the demand for loans increases. [35.]
 
Timid municipal bond owners might consider fixed portfolios known as unit investment trusts. [35.]
 
Taxpayers can file for a payment extension if they owe the I.R.S. money and cannot pay the whole amount by April 15. [35.]
 
Adjustable-rate mortgage funds lack a long track record, but they held their ground in a dismal first quarter, reporting a small gain while other mortgage funds declined. [35.]

CORRECTION-DATE: April 14, 1994, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article by The Associated Press in some editions of Business Day on Saturday, about Pegasus Technologies, misstated the family background of the company's chairwoman, E. Anne Eisenhower. She is not a granddaughter of President Dwight D. Eisenhower, but is the widow of a nephew of the former President.

HEADLINE: WHAT WORKS;
The Principals Of Success

BYLINE: By Jennifer Steinhauer 

 BODY:
ASK celebrated principals about the secrets of their success and they are likely to use the lexicon of politicians. There is talk of empowerment and pluralism, the importance of visibility and a stress on reaching out "into the community." Of course, their communities are not town halls but lunchrooms.
So when the National Association of Secondary School Principals recently named Ann Blakeney Clark of Alexander Graham Middle School in Charlotte, N.C., principal of the year, the crucial elements its judges seemed to find in her and in the principals who were finalists were progressive programs that integrate students and parents in campus decisions as well as programs that stress student performance rather than attendance. The organization sponsors the award in conjunction with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. 
 These homey programs and lunchroom strolls do not match the image of principals that burns in the memories of long-ago students summoned to see them: the stern elder statesman at the end of the hall who held a dim view of youthful high jinks and grimaced when approached.
"We have shifted the philosophical focus of this school to one that empowers students," said Miss Clark, who is 35 years old. "All the decisions made now are ones that make life better for students first."
Some changes she has made include the grouping of classrooms along a corridor by grade level and student group, so that teachers who work on various subjects with the same group of children are near one another; the aggressive recruitment of parents to volunteer in schools, and an advisory program in which students spend part of their mornings receiving everything from homework help to counseling.
 
Avoiding Trouble
 All these changes add up to a more effective use of time, Miss Clark said. By grouping classrooms together by grade level rather than by academic subject and by shortening the time between class periods, students have less time to get into trouble, she said.
Parents have been brought in to help in school health clinics, sponsor fund-raising events and help with student recognition programs. "Kids see that if people give you their time, it means they value you," Miss Clark said. This is why she roams hallways in order to see the students face to face.
It may seem like the one-minute manager approach, but Miss Clark's contemporaries agree that this works. "Students crave recognition and the validation of the fact that they are O.K.," said Michael Gilbert Johnson, a finalist from Granger Junior High School in National City, near San Diego.
To give them that recognition, Mr. Johnson has introduced two honor rolls, one for A-average students and the other for those with B averages, which give children an incentive to work hard. He also visits homes, particularly of children having difficulties in or out of school.
"There was a child I was working with whom I visited at home," Mr. Johnson remembered. "I was trying to communicate that school is a place where he can be cared for. I experienced resistance and remember leaving disappointed," he said. But when the Principals' Association came to interview students about Mr. Johnson, that same student talked about how the principal had reached out to him. "It underscored for me that you never know the impact you might have on a child," he said.
These principals also focus on drawing local communities into the schools, working with small businesses or large companies. At Granger Junior High, San Diego State University and a Navy fleet headquarters have volunteered to counsel students.
Grant A. Hosford, another finalist who has been the principal of Spanaway Lake High School in Spanaway, Wash., for five years, thought it was critical to draw in local businesses to help develop curriculum.
 
Business 'Teams'
 He has put together "teams" of business people who tutor and offer career workshops. These teams are brought in for weekly meetings with teachers, students and parents. "We want to let students see how math, sciences and physics are applicable in daily life," Mr. Hosford said.
Principals were chosen as finalists based on their innovative ideas and willingness to take risks when designing programs; occasionally those designs resulted in tangles with school boards.
Tim Westerberg, the principal of Littleton High School in Littleton, Colo., tried converting his school to a performance-based, rather than attendance-based, graduation requirement system. Although Mr. Westerberg said the system worked well, Littleton's Board of Education reversed it.
"My biggest challenge has been to help a fairly diverse group in a pluralistic society to find a shared vision and still protect the diversity," he said.
Miss Clark was recognized by the Principals' Association for her "commitment to helping children from a broad perspective," said Lew Armistead, an association spokesman. She is also active in several youth projects, and founded A Child's Place, a program for homeless children in Charlotte.
Miss Clark said she saw the award as an honor for her entire school. "If I am without my 750 students and 64 staff members," she said, "clearly I am unemployed."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ann Blakeney Clark, principal of the year, with middle school students in Charlotte, N.C. (Duane Hall for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 28; Column 3; Education Life Supplement 

LENGTH: 1449 words

HEADLINE: Going the Self-Help Route

BYLINE: By Tessa Melva 

 BODY:
FOR supporters of public schools, the saying "you get what you pay for" is taking on new meaning. Across the nation, communities impatient with the continuing school financial crisis are digging into their pockets to support sagging school budgets.
Outside an elementary school in California, parent volunteers hawk supermarket gift certificates. At an apple festival in southeastern Kentucky, an eager crowd snaps up $25 chances on a pickup truck. In the New York City suburb of Bronxville, former high school graduates buy $100 personalized bricks for an "Alumni Walk." 
 Behind each of these efforts is a nonprofit community educational foundation formed to raise money for its public schools. While no one is tracking the trend, educators estimate there are between 1,500 and 2,000 mostly independent community foundations in at least 30 states, and the number is growing fast. If it works for Harvard, the reasoning goes, it can work for them.
From its beginnings in California 15 years ago, the community education foundation movement has spread to the recession-plagued Northeast. Nine school districts in New Jersey and 13 in Suffolk County on Long Island are paying between $7,000 and $25,000 for advice from Educational Foundation Consultants, a Williamston, Mich., concern that advises districts on setting up foundations. Kenneth A. Grounds, senior consultant at the company, says, however, that clients typically raise more money in their first year than his firm charges. Residents reluctant to pay higher taxes nonetheless realize that schools need private financing, said Mr. Grounds. "There's a growing realization that public money can't do everything," he said, "particularly if it's something innovative."
 
State Consortiums
 A number of states have education foundation consortiums, including Oklahoma and Florida. In Florida, school districts have initiated some of the state's 45 community foundations with the aid of state legislation that allows schools to contribute personnel and office space to these efforts.
Community foundations have value beyond their ability to raise money, said Susan Sweeney, executive director of the California Consortium of Education Foundations. The 210 members of her consortium, which comprises the vast majority of the state's community foundations, only raised an average of $25,000 each last year, Ms. Sweeney said. "Initially people thought educational foundations would be a Band-Aid operation," she said, "but the effort has gotten large numbers of opinion leaders conversant about public education. Foundations are here to stay."
Community foundations also heighten interest in the school community among residents without children. In Palo Alto, Calif., where 85 percent of the city's population of 60,000 have no school-age children, parents and other residents have contributed $32,000 annually for teacher mini-grants.
"This is as much about community building and increasing public information as it is about money," said Laura S. Selznick, the foundation's co-president. It is also about self-interest; residents tend to support the foundation as a way of keeping real estate values high, according to Ms. Selznick.
Paul Reville, Executive Director of the Alliance for Education in Wooster, Mass., a regional education foundation, noted another aspect of the appeal of community foundations: "People can't be sure where their added tax dollars go, but when you give to a local education fund, you know the money will be spent directly on educational programs."
California's wake-up call came with Proposition 13 in 1978, which took away local control over public education by severely limiting the amount of property tax money communities could spend on their schools. "Communities with good schools had their guts cut out," Ms. Sweeney said.
One of the state's more successful foundations is the Menlo Park-Atherton Education Foundation, which this year expects to exceed its goal of $370,000 to support the four elementary and secondary schools in the district's two communities. Located 40 miles south of San Francisco and adjacent to Stanford University, the district is considered among the best in California.
When state funding reductions threatened to reduce school performance, residents of Menlo Park and Atherton established a foundation, now completing its 11th year. It raises money through solicitations, an auction and the Spell athon, in which parents and grandparents pledge support to elementary school students preparing for a spelling bee.
"The foundation has increased awareness of the way state funds are spent on education," said Mary Pickard, its president. Two years ago a local proposition to impose a special $65 property "parcel" tax assessment passed overwhelmingly, Ms. Pickard said, in part because the foundation had made people more aware of education issues.
Several states, including California, have single statewide foundations that act as magnets to increase corporate support for education. The corporate-sponsored California Educational Initiative Fund, since it began 14 years ago, has awarded $10 million to schools. The eight-year-old Florida Education Foundation raised $300,000 in corporate and foundation grants last year.
In New York's Westchester County, the Bronxville School Foundation has raised $628,000 in two and a half years, much of it from people with no children in public school, who make up a majority of the town's residents. The money also cushioned a four-year, 43 percent cut in state aid in the midst of a continued decline in property tax revenue.
 
Funding Disparity
 Grass-roots foundations often develop in affluent communities unwilling to let their education programs suffer. But in part for that very reason, some worry that the spread of community foundations will increase the disparity between rich and poor districts.
Despite a growing number of school equity lawsuits, there have been no legal challenges to community education foundations. "Community foundations go to the heart of local control," said Paul Minorini, a lawyer with Hogan & Hudson, a Washington firm specializing in education law.
For supporters of education reform, creating foundations that are independent of their school districts is critical. With the help of a $6 million grant from the Ford Foundation 11 years ago, Local Education Funds were set up in 53 low-income and minority school districts to encourage reform. Now spreading to other areas, and coordinated by the Public Education Fund Network in Washington, these professionally staffed foundations rely on corporate and foundation support and local contributions to develop innovative programs the school district will adopt.
The Mary Lyon Fund is a Local Education Fund set up three years ago in nine towns in western Massachusetts. Supported by residents who include Bill Cosby and a retired I.B.M. executive who donated $500,000, the fund sponsors wilderness adventure projects.
Some community education funds are in rural areas. In the Appalachian mountains of southeastern Kentucky, the 1980 census brought shocking news: only 38 percent of the adults living in the 27 counties of the Fifth Congressional District had graduated from high school -- the lowest percentage in the nation.
The district, in one of Kentucky's poorest regions, had the state's lowest property tax base, highest school dropout rate and lowest test scores. A regional study commission concluded that conditions would improve only when schools improved, and when the community got involved.
Seven years ago, the district formed a regional umbrella organization, Forward in the Fifth, to stimulate community education foundations in each county. Since it began, the foundation has raised $700,000 and recruited 2,000 volunteers.
Parents and local businesses raise funds for teacher mini-grants, student field trips, cash awards to schools with good attendance and prizes for students with impressive academic records. And parents' development is not ignored; Forward in the Fifth sponsors workshops to train parents to read aloud and carry that skill into the classroom.
The 1990 census showed that 50 percent of the Fifth District's population are high school graduates, a rate of progress above the national average. "Money helps," said Ginny Eager, executive director of Forward in the Fifth, but she said the greatest difference had been made by communities involved in their schools. The greatest educational gains have come in those counties with the highest number of volunteers, Ms. Eager said, adding, "Having a mother working on educational issues is a big shoulder to lean on."

SECTION: Section 5; Page 12; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 1898 words

HEADLINE: Family Vacations: Ten of the Best

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER; MELINDA HENNEBERGER is a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The Times.

 BODY:
SOMETIMES it's the mini-disasters and unplanned detours that make a family vacation memorable, as when young Gary Montgomery fed a bag of cinnamon rolls to Freckles the dog en route to a camping trip in the Texas Hill Country -- with unfortunate results for the bedrolls.
His mother, Bettye Montgomery, 52 years old, an administrative assistant at a Houston accounting firm, laughs about it now. "Our boys learned a valuable lesson that year: You don't feed dogs cinnamon rolls when you're going on a long trip." 
 Gary is 25 now and his older brother, Michael, is 30, but they and their parents, wives, children -- and dogs -- still meet every year for a week of roughing it on the banks of the Frio River, 90 miles northwest of San Antonio. And every summer, the itinerary is about the same -- swim, fish, tube down the river, visit Uncle Mervle, the old stage coach road, and the second- or third-oldest oak tree in the state.
But despite the occasional mishap, Mrs. Montgomery wouldn't trade those trips for the last chimichanga in Texas.
"We've been doing it for 28 years," she said, "and I still love it."
 
The Vacation As Goal
 Shirley Kaiser was a recently divorced mother mowing lawns to get off welfare when she decided that she and her three daughters -- Melissa, 17, Yvette, 12, and Erica, 9 -- deserved a vacation.
"Our whole life had just changed," said Ms. Kaiser, 43, of Portland, Ore. "I had only been sober for a couple of years and was just starting to single-parent my kids. We'd never gone on a family vacation, and I wanted to take my kids to Disneyland. I wanted to give them things."
Mowing, cleaning houses, and later working as an office temporary for a computer company where, five years later, she is now a buyer, she saved for two years before finally taking her family on their first plane trip, to Los Angeles, in 1990.
"It was just so special because it was a challenge, a goal we could work toward together," she said. "It was something that gave the kids confidence I could take care of them and that gave me the courage that we could do anything we set our minds to. We still talk about it."
Because the Kaisers arrived just before Thanksgiving, Disneyland was relatively empty, and they rode the rides again and again. They were "cutting it pretty lean," Ms. Kaiser said, economizing by walking and taking city buses and eating "hot dogs three for $1 and peanut butter and jelly in the motel room." But they still managed to visit Knott's Berry Farm and Sea World, even renting a car for one day to visit Hollywood and Universal Studios.
And after that day on the Los Angeles freeways, she said, "I wouldn't really have wanted to have had a car anyway."
 
On the Road to Home
 Buck Showalter, manager of the New York Yankees, said the best family vacations he could remember were his childhood trips from the Florida Panhandle to his grandparents' house, "when my parents would load up the four children and head up to Virginia, cutting corners and packing food" for meals on the road. Even then, he said, "A lot of our family vacations revolved around the Cape Cod League, or wherever I was playing."
Now his children, Allie, who is 6, and Nathan, 2, get to visit the usual tourist spots throughout the year -- Disneyland when the team is in Anaheim, and the Smithsonian in Washington when they're in nearby Baltimore.
So, he said, the goal is "going home and spending time as a family" in Pace, Fla., for four months of off-season calm.
"When we get home at the end of the year," he said, "our idea of a vacation is to wake up in the morning and have somebody say, 'What do we have to do today?' and the answer is: 'Nothing!' "
 
Real Family Time
 Dr. T. Berry Brazelton, the nationally-known Boston pediatrician, says his family vacations are no more free of the usual tensions than those planned by the many parents who look to him for advice.
Most summers, he and his wife, their four children and three grandchildren gather at their home on Cape Cod for the traditional family vacation sports.
"We play tennis, we go sailing, we fight and they beat up on me," he said approvingly. "A lot of feelings get worked out."
Because his wife's two sisters also have houses nearby, Dr. Brazelton said, "It's even more layered, real family time, with all the positives and negatives."
But Dr. Brazelton's favorite vacations were when his children were young; they're now 40, 38, 35, and 29. "It's awfully hard to give them up," he said.
 
A Long, Hot Haul
 By eating in the car and limiting even the necessary pit stops, the Mulroys figured they could make the drive home from Colorado Springs to Memphis in 20 hours.
James Mulroy, a lawyer for Federal Express, had combined business with a vacation last May to the Rocky Mountains, where Colin, Catherine and Elizabeth, now 12, 10, and 5, ran with a herd of wild elk. "I'm not even sure that's safe," said his wife, Nancy Mulroy, a graduate student in special education. But the real excitement was the trip home, she said, since they couldn't leave Colorado before Mr. Mulroy's last Saturday meeting but had to be home for Catherine's piano recital Sunday at 2 P.M.
And when the red light on the dashboard showed their Volvo had overheated, they still couldn't stop. To pull heat off the engine, Mrs. Mulroy said, they kept the heater on, full blast, all the way home.
"It was miserable in a way," said Mrs. Mulroy, "but we kept saying, 'We'll never forget this.' And we made it! It was wild." She added with pride that they arrived home with an hour to spare, bathed, changed, and made the performance.
Catherine's debut "was just fine," Mrs. Mulroy said. "I can't remember what she played, though."
 
Educational Africa
 Ryan, Jeremy and Justin Rice, who are 14, 11 and 9 years old, had already been camping in the Costa Rican rain forest and were "quite well-traveled for their age," said their father, Dr. Jeffrey Rice, an oral surgeon in Du Bois, Pa., who shares custody of the boys with his ex-wife.
Then, last year, they took the camping experience a step further, while on safari to Kenya and Tanzania. "It was just us," he said, "on a basic safari with a guide, a cook and a vehicle." They camped, visited small villages and, because it was the dry season, saw thousands of zebras, wildebeests, rhinos and elephants -- "Animals as far as the eye could see," Dr. Rice said -- and they learned a lot as well.
"It really helps them in school, with geography, anthropology, you name it," Dr. Rice said. This year, he's mulling a return to Africa with the boys, but also considering a trip to the Amazon.
"Trips like that are relatively safe" for children, he said. "It's probably safer than New York."
 
Marathon Drive
 "We couldn't have done a trip like that later on, after Dan became Vice President," said Marilyn Tucker Quayle. But back in 1987, "before the notoriety" and way before the Dan Quayle Center and Museum opened in Huntington, Ind., the Quayles took their three children, Tucker, Ben and Corinne, now ages 19, 17 and 15, on a marathon car trip across the country. They fished and hiked in Rocky Mountain National Park and went horseback riding in Jackson Hole, Wyo. "We did the Best Western with the family all in one room," Mrs. Quayle said, and wound up their two-week vacation in Sun Valley, where her husband finally got in a round of golf. "He had gone 11 days," she said.
More recently, though, Mrs. Quayle said her family had their best vacations on the Colorado River, where they took five-day white-water rafting trips in the Grand Canyon in 1989 and 1990.
Initially, "I wasn't keen on sleeping out and not having facilities," said Mrs. Quayle, a camping convert. But she said rafting was an almost sure bet with older offspring, whose enthusiasm for family adventures can be, well, measured.
"To people with teen-age children, I would definitely recommend it," she said. "Kids that age don't want to have anything to do with their parents."
 
On Board to Baltimore
 Pam Hurst has learned that long car trips can be a bit too challenging for her three sons, Geoffrey, Darren and Khory, who are 11, 6 and 4. The best vacation she and her husband, Mark, a Queens real-estate appraiser, have taken them on, she says, was a train trip to Washington and Baltimore.
They not only loved the train, she said, but more: "I was shocked at how much they loved Baltimore Harbor and the seafood. When you live in New York, you think, 'What's one more aquarium?' But they liked it so much we had to go twice."
Mrs. Hurst, a middle-school Spanish teacher, said her view was that where family vacations are concerned, "You always have to have a plan B." En route to Niagara Falls for one getaway, her husband had an asthma attack and the trip had to be scrubbed.
"They were all ready to see water, so I took them on the Staten Island Ferry," she said. "It's a little closer to home, but we still had a good time."
 
The Older Generation
 A trip to Grandma's house is still the ultimate family vacation for many children, including Andrew and Caroline Giuliani, the young children of New York City's Mayor.
Last year, for the third time, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his family took off the week after Christmas, and spent New Year's with his wife's family near Los Angeles. "The plane trip is always pretty exciting for the children, walking up and down the aisles and getting their wings," said Donna Hanover Giuliani, adding that the Santa Monica pier, with its bumper cars, was always a highlight.
But more than anything, Mrs. Giuliani said, her children love the playhouse behind their great-grandmother's house, as did Mrs. Giuliani and her mother before her.
"They just like being with my Mom and Dad," who baby-sit one night so the Giulianis can have a night out to themselves, maybe at the movies.
Then, on New Year's Eve, the family has dinner with Mrs. Giuliani's closest friend.
"We watch the ball drop in Times Square at 9 o'clock, have lobster" and then watch the ball drop again when the station replays it at midnight, she said, though last year they missed midnight entirely. "With everything going on," she said, "we just wanted to have Champagne and go to bed."
 
Out of Character
 Erica Kane of "All My Children" never gets a vacation with her kids. Of course, one daughter is in jail and the other lives with an ex-husband who's still steamed over the affair she had with his brother.
"She makes plans, but they never work out," says the actress Susan Lucci, who plays Ms. Kane on the ABC soap.
Ms. Lucci, on the other hand, takes annual spring ski vacations in the Austrian Alps, usually staying in either Lech or Ischgl, with her Austrian-born husband, Helmut Huber, and their children, Andreas, 14, and Liza, 19. Her husband and children are "spectacular" skiers, who started before they were school-age, she said proudly. And off the slopes, she said, there is skating, curling, and treats like sweet dumplings stuffed with raspberry jam.
Sometimes, at sunset, the family takes horse-drawn sleigh rides to an old farmhouse that has been converted to an inn, returning in the dark with lanterns to lead the way.
"The physical beauty is tremendous, the food, the hotels are spectacular," she said. That beats Erica Kane's last vacation: she was locked in a vault in Budapest.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Trans-Atlantic Flights To Dublin Now Nonstop

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
FROM 1945 until the late 1950's, 80 percent of trans-Atlantic air traffic went through Shannon Airport in western Ireland, a refueling station for planes that did not have the range to travel nonstop between North America and the European capitals. It was at Shannon, in 1947, that the first duty-free shop opened, giving travelers somewhere to spend their money during the stopover.
The advent of more advanced jets ended the need for the refueling stop -- but it did not mean the end of Shannon. Seeking to protect jobs at the airport and among those people dependent on tourism in western Ireland, the Irish Government decreed that all flights to and from Ireland that did not start or terminate at Shannon -- meaning those to and from Dublin, 120 miles to the east -- would continue to be required to stop there. 
 That anachronism has now come to an end. Last summer, under intense pressure from Aer Lingus, the money-losing national carrier, the Irish Government agreed to end the prohibition on nonstop trans-Atlantic flights to and from Dublin.
The new policy went into effect on March 27, when Aer Lingus began its first nonstop flights between Dublin and New York, with a daily service that will run year-round. Delta Airlines, the Irish carrier's major competitor on the trans-Atlantic route, began a four-times-a-week nonstop service between Atlanta and Dublin on April 6.
"Shannon Airport has a special place in aviation history here, and the region out in the west of Ireland needed the protection," said John Brown, a spokesman for the Irish Tourist Board in Dublin. "But there was a lot of pressure to try and change the situation, from the airlines and from tourism interests on the east coast of Ireland who felt they were losing out."
The change will save at least an hour on the ground at Shannon for passengers in each direction. Aer Lingus said its bookings for the new service have already been extremely strong. Airline executives said the new policy could attract more carriers to routes between Ireland and the United States since they now will be able to appeal to business travelers. Most business travelers to Dublin -- and many tourists as well -- have chosen to fly via London, a route that offers a far greater number of flights and more fare competition without taking any longer than flying to Dublin via Shannon.
Not that the airlines are abandoning Shannon, the gateway to the popular tourist regions of western Ireland. Under the new Irish regulations, they are forced to continue flights to and from Shannon in order to win approval for direct flights in and out of Dublin. Aer Lingus, for example, will continue to offer direct daily service between Shannon and New York as well as flights between Shannon and Boston.
As for Shannon, officials there are confident that the area and its airport can more than hold their own.
Shannon Development, the authority set up in 1959 to safeguard the region's economic interests as Europe-bound jets began flying on past, has used the last 35 years to attract new industry to the area, including many high-technology companies, while carrying out more aggressive marketing campaigns to lure tourists to the area.
