HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
When Is A Roof Not a Roof?

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp 

 BODY:
TWO COASTS. TWO ROOFS. TWO major civic projects. Riverbank Park in New York and Yerba Buena Gardens in San Francisco have a lot in common. Both were conceived to placate communities that had been saddled with controversial buildings. Both have resulted in public spaces of high architectural caliber. And both could have gone further in developing the concept on which they literally rest: a roof can be the bottom of a building as well as the top.
Riverbank Park has gained notoriety as the smelly park, the one built atop an offshore waste treatment plant in the Hudson River. First proposed in 1969 as compensation for foisting this classic Not-In-My-Back-Yard project on nearby Harlem, the 28-acre park finally opened a year ago, after 24 years of bureaucratic wrangling. Despite the chemical whiffs that periodically assail the nostrils (the city's sanitation engineers say they are working to eliminate them), the place is a popular success. With its pools, gym, outdoor rink and running track, it may be the most lavish sportsplex in town. 
 And the design, by the New York architect Richard Dattner, is as colorful and trim as the latest gym attire. Constrained not only by the park's $129 million budget but also by the roof's limited capacity to support weight, Mr. Dattner has designed a set of airy pavilions, clad in green and orange tile, inset with translucent panels of Shoji-screen refinement. Synthetic turf on the running track picks up these colors in supersaturated, TV-like tones. Athletes playing here could easily imagine themselves in line for big-league product endorsements.
The landscaping, by the New York firm Abel Bainnson Butz, doesn't fight the flatness of the rooftop site with undue displays of pastoral imagery. Instead, the tree-lined terraces and promenades create a lofty platform for enjoying what New York's early-19th-century planners envisioned as the city's major open space: the Hudson River. With views north to the George Washington Bridge and south to the harbor, this is an ideal spot to watch sky and water dissolve into the river's shimmering light.
Except for that stray whiff, and for the sound of rushing water audible from the park's lower terrace, you'd never know you were atop a sewage treatment plant. But this is not entirely the good thing it might seem. The park's designers have succeeded in separating the park from the unwanted plant. Unfortunately, that separation is symptomatic of the pernicious disconnection between the city and the natural resources that sustain it.
There's nothing attractive about bodily waste. That's why we use euphemisms like "effluent" to describe it. But a plant like this is as vital to the city's operation as the subway system. And, like the subway, it is more than a technical facility. It is a cultural artifact, a monumental instrument designed to mediate between the city and the water supply on which it depends. The park could have provided a place for people to see that instrument in action.
A GOOD EXAMPLE OF WHAT I'M talking about is "Flow City," a project designed in 1984 by the "sanitation artist" Mierle Laderman Ukeles for the 59th Street Marine Transfer Station. The purpose of this project, which was halted when the money ran out, is to provide a public window on the processing of garbage. It's not a dull spectacle, much less a shameful one. At Riverbank Park, there's a handsome multi-purpose "cultural space," complete with an auditorium for performances. What's missing is a window onto the extraordinary aquatic mechanical ballet taking place just beneath.
True, Harlem residents didn't want to see this plant. And they had the right to insist that it be banished from sight. But Riverside Park raises two issues that transcend this particular case. One is the fobbing off of Nimby projects onto poor neighborhoods. The other is whether such projects should be stigmatized in the first place. New "fair share" laws address the first issue. It will now be harder for rich neighborhoods to exclude such projects from their backyards. Design could address the second issue. It could use public works to enrich public spaces.
Yerba Buena Gardens also had its origins in the late 1960's, when people realized that they didn't have to take "urban renewal" lying down. But here it was the smell of money that drove them to action. In 1969, a lawsuit was filed on behalf of several thousand residents who had been evicted from an area south of Market Street by a plan to build a convention center and hotel complex. The Yerba Buena Gardens and Art Center, which opened in October to deserved acclaim, is the long delayed result.
Built on top of the northern extension of the Moscone Convention Center, the eight-acre, $82 million park and arts complex is conceived as a multi-culti Lincoln Center. The center's theater, designed by James Stewart Polshek, and its art galleries, designed by Fumihiko Maki, this year's winner of the Pritzker Architecture Prize, will showcase local artists and community performing groups in programs that reflect the city's cultural diversity. And it is perhaps apt that the architecture harks back to the International Style, an idiom that still affords a wide expressive range. Clad in granite, glass and aluminum, Mr. Maki's silvery visual arts building is pliant, yielding, while Mr. Polshek's auditorium, housed within a vertical composition of white, gray and charcoal cubes, is flinty, a trifle truculent, only reluctantly conceding the monumental gesture to Mario Botta's San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, now nearing completion across the street. Together, the three buildings are San Francisco's strongest ensemble of modern architecture.
Things go awry in Yerba Buena's five-acre garden, though at first it's hard to say why. What could be wrong with such a generous open space in the heart of the city? And this one is pleasingly landscaped, with curving, tree-bordered walks, a waterfall, and a broad lawn for outdoor concerts. But when the garden is not full of people, the place can seem eerie. Suddenly, as you saunter alone along the pathways, you realize that you could be walking only inches above the heads of thousands of conventioneers. The greenery begins to look like the cosmetic cover-up it is. Why has a place that's supposed to stand for innovation reverted to this purely decorative use of nature? And why treat a convention center like a dirty secret?
For it, too, is a cultural artifact. It is not only an economic engine, it is a distinctive form of urban space, at once integral to the city's vitality yet peculiarly alien to its fabric. Here the transient, homogenized culture of Hiltons and Hyatts touches down for a brief rendezvous with urban diversity. The arts center hasn't ignored the conventioneers. It is counting on them to swell its audience. But it has missed the opportunity to create something artistically significant out of the connection -- to create an environment where convention culture and multiculturalism could visibly intertwine.
One solution would have been to incorporate communications technology into the design of the garden. Instead of the sappy granite mural that borders the lawn, the planners might have planted a "virtual garden," a media arcade, where people could try on head-mounted displays and data gloves, step into the Internet, stroll past digital flowers and fiber-optic fountains, and check out how conventions in the not too distant future will be conducted along the information highway.
Such a feature would have reinforced Yerba Buena's mission to present local talent: San Francisco's "wired" community is the most sophisticated in the nation. A convention center already occupies an intersection between urban space and cyberspace. Yerba Buena Gardens could have turned that crossroads into a world-class civic place.
The California planner Peter Calthorpe once proposed linking community fitness centers to electric generators: people could trim their waistlines and their utility bills at the same time. Though the proposal was facetious, it contained an important idea: there are advantages to linking places that we ordinarily isolate in separate cultural compartments. That's the kind of thinking that needs to be introduced early on in the planning of projects like Riverbank Park and Yerba Buena Gardens. Instead of burying a city's vital organs out of sight, design could visualize a place for them on the cultural landscape. Into sight, into mind.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Riverbank Park in Manhattan -- What's missing is a window onto the aquatic ballet taking place beneath. Yerba Buena Gardens in San Francisco, right -- Conceived as a multi-culti Lincoln Center. (Photographs by Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Light at the End Of the Chunnel?

BYLINE: By JOHN BRANNON ALBRIGHT; JOHN BRANNON ALBRIGHT is an editor of The New York Times.

 BODY:
FOR many car-conscious Americans awaiting the opening of the Channel Tunnel, the most disappointing thing to learn is, You won't be able to drive through it. Only trains -- some carrying cars -- will make the 31-mile trip between Calais, France, and Folkestone, England, and exactly when is not certain.
The first train, filled with dignitaries, is scheduled for May 6. The start of regular service is another matter. Testing and late delivery of equipment is causing delays. The tunnel was originally scheduled to open a year ago, in the spring of 1993. Then its opening was postponed to last December. On April 1 Alastair Morton, chairman of Eurotunnel, the British and French consortium that will operate the tunnel, announced that full service would not start until September. 
 When the tunnel does begin operating, there will be two types of service: Le Shuttle, carrying freight and vehicles, and Eurostar, carrying passengers. Mr. Morton said Le Shuttle would begin on a limited basis in June. Eurostar, too, will start on a limited basis, but not before July 1, said Bernard Frelat, president and chief executive officer of Rail Europe, which markets European rail passes in the United States. Eurostar is a venture of the railroads of Britain, Belgium and France.
 
Coaches for Cars
Le Shuttle, a subsidiary of Euro tunnel, will have one- and two-level coaches (as high as 18 feet) onto which motorists can drive cars. During the 35-minute ride, driver and passengers will normally sit in the vehicle, but they can get out to walk alongside other vehicles or go to a restroom. The trip, including loading and unloading, should take about an hour. There will be no telephones or food service. Initially Le Shuttle plans to run one train an hour in each direction.
Eurostar will carry passengers only -- in sleek, new trains between London and Paris and London and Brussels. Plans call for 1 to 3 trains of 18 cars with a capacity of 794 passengers in each direction, increasing to 7 on Sept. 1 and 15 on Jan. 1.
"Rail was purposely selected as the sole means of transport through the tunnel because it provides the highest density and is the most reliable, weather-free, traffic-free form of transport," Mr. Frelat said.
When those who do transport their vehicles reach the other side, they will have to cope with passing while the steering wheel is on the "wrong" side and making turns from an unfamiliar position. Aware that the average American would rather conform to prevailing custom than place an added strain on a vacation, at least two car rental companies will allow an exchange of cars at the tunnel. Hertz has signed a 10-year agreement with Le Shuttle to offer the Hertz Affordable Europe Tunnel Program. It will provide a left-hand-drive car for use on the Continent and a right-hand-drive car in Britain combined with round-trip travel on the car-carrying train. The car exchange, dubbed le swap, will take place at a newly constructed Hertz outlet at Le Shuttle's headquarters in Calais. Hertz will also have a depot in Folkestone, for initial rentals, not an exchange. The price will not be announced until Le Shuttle begins, according to a Hertz spokeswoman.
Avis, too, will offer cars in Calais and in Dover, about 10 miles from Folkestone. An Avis spokeswoman said it would be possible, if the renter preferred, to keep the same car -- by notifying Avis ahead of time and arranging for special insurance, called a green card. The cost of the card will depend on the size of the car and the length of the rental period.
Avis officials say, however, that they think most Americans will prefer to take Eurostar, the passenger train, and rent a car at an office in one of the three capital cities or in a city in the countryside. The expected Eurostar train time will be 3 hours between London and Paris, 3 hours and 15 minutes between London and Brussels. Eventually, when high-speed tracks are finished between Brussels and Lille, France, and Folkestone and London, faster speeds will be possible.
As sensible as it sounds to take Eurostar rather than Le Shuttle, Americans planning a trip this summer may find it difficult to get a Eurostar reservation, especially if the start of service is delayed and rolling stock is slow to arrive. So far, about 5,000 Americans and more than 10,000 Europeans have put their names on the waiting list for reservations. Le Shuttle will not require reservations, operating on a first-come-first-loaded basis.
Fares on Le Shuttle (figured at $1.50 to 1) will range from about $195 for a two-day introductory round trip through July 21 (a date set before the latest delays were announced) to $465 for a less restricted round trip in summer. A winter round trip of about $330 has also been announced.
Eurostar has not announced its fares, but they are expected to be competitive with regularly scheduled airlines, which charge about $200 one way between London and Paris in economy class, $240 in business. (Round-trip flights offer discounts, and one-way flights as low as $70 are advertised in London magazines.)
But the cost of getting to the airport must also be considered: a train from London to Heathrow is about $4.50, the trip by taxi about $50, and a train from Charles de Gaulle to Paris is about $6, a taxi $35 to $70. At least 2 hours are required: 40 minutes for the flight, 50 minutes for the London-Heathrow train and 30 minutes for the de Gaulle-Paris train; that does not count time for boarding, deplaning or making connections.
 
Crossing by Water
Here are approximate fares and travel times, exclusive of loading and unloading, for crossing the channel by water, the third alternative:
Ferry between Dover and Calais, $38 a person; with automobile and passengers, $90 to $195 (75 minutes). Hovercraft between Dover and Calais, $38 a person; with automobile and passengers, $84 to $285 (35 minutes). Train from London to Dover, $26 (110 minutes). Train from Calais to Paris, varying from $30 a person in second class on a regular train (3 hours) to $72 a person in first class on a TGV (90 minutes).
For comparison's sake, the approximate cost and total time, one way, between London and Paris, without a car: $200 (3 hours) on Eurostar, $81 to $320 (4 1/2 to 6 hours) by air, $94 to $136 (4 1/2 to 5 3/4 hours) by hovercraft or ferry. With a car, figure $98 to $233 (6 3/4 hours) on Le Shuttle, $84 to $285 (7 1/4 to 7 3/4) on hovercraft or ferry.
Through Rail Europe, the British and French railways offer a variety of packages combining rail passage with car rental. Two packages that may interest channel crossers are the BritFrance Pass and the BritFrance 'n' Drive Pass. For a fixed price, they provide varying days of train and car travel, but none include a ride through the Chunnel, only passage on a channel-crossing hovercraft.
The following phone numbers should prove helpful in planning a Chunnel trip, but bear in mind that precise information is not likely to be available until tunnel service actually starts: Avis, (800) 331-1084; Hertz, (800) 654-3001; Rail Europe, (800) 438-7245; Eurostar reservations through Rail Europe, (800) 942-4866, and through Britrail, (212) 575-2667 or, outside New York City and Long Island, (800) 677-8585; Le Shuttle, (800) 388-3876. A travel agent can help obtain plane, ferry or hovercraft reservations.

HEADLINE: More Buyers Turn to Mortgage Brokers

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
THE Greenbergs were in a hurry. They had just sold their house in Chappaqua, N.Y., and had found a new home in nearby North Tarrytown. With interest rates rising and movers virtually knocking at their door, they needed a mortgage quickly.
 Like most borrowers these days, Christine and Mark Greenberg checked newspaper ads and called banks in search of the best rates. The mortgage they chose, however, wasn't obtained through a bank, a savings and loan or even a mortgage banker. Instead, the Greenbergs found their loan through Homerica Inc., a mortgage broker with offices in Harrison, N.Y., and Westport, Conn. 
 "We had to get the ball rolling," Ms. Greenberg said. "Our lawyer told us to find the best rate as fast as possible."
 In recent years, more and more Americans have been using mortgage brokers -- intermediaries who find loans for borrowers and help them with the applications, rather than make the loans themselves. The percentage of home mortgage applications written by brokers has increased from about 20 percent in 1987 to about 50 percent last year, according to the National Association of Mortgage Brokers, a 15-year-old trade organization based in Phoenix.
 "Like in a lot of other areas, with mortgage brokers we have seen the development of a subservice that shops around on behalf of people and hopefully finds the best deal," said Lawrence J. White, a professor of economics at the Stern School of Business at New York University.
 "We have had this with travel agents for some time," he added.
 A major reason for the rising popularity of mortgage brokers in recent years has been the increased number of refinancings, which made up about 65 to 75 percent of all mortgage originations in 1993. Borrowers often sought mortgage brokers for refinancings because their original lenders, usually banks and savings and loans, were not offering the best terms.
 Home buyers, however, also look to mortgage brokers to help guide them quickly and efficiently through the maze of complex rates, products and qualifying standards offered by lenders today.
 The biggest benefit of mortgage brokers -- whose fee is almost always paid in large part by the financial institution providing the loan -- is that they can offer borrowers a wider choice in rates and terms than the client might be able to get from their original lender or by searching for a new lender on their own.
 "Good mortgage brokers are really financial advisers," said Margaret S. Scott, president of Mortgage Advisory Services, a Manhattan mortgage brokerage.
 Brokers can also be valuable when the borrowers are too busy to shop for a mortgage and fill out the paperwork. They also claim that they can often obtain a loan in two to three weeks, saving a borrower time that they might otherwise spend visiting and possibly being rejected by various lenders.
 "I thought that I should immediately go to a mortgage broker," said Mary S. Burns, a festival producer who recently took out a $100,000 mortgage to buy a one-bedroom co-op on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. "I am extremely busy, and didn't have the time to do anything more than look at the paper and see what the interest rates are."
 Traditional lenders have mixed feelings about the growth of mortgage brokers. "Bankers use mortgage brokers, and the majority are probably legitimate, but you need to be aware of some of the unscrupulous ones," said Patricia Boerger, spokeswoman for the American Bankers Association, a trade organization in Washington.
 To be sure, the mortgage brokerage business has cut into the market share of commercial banks and savings and loans, but it also helps attract new business while allowing them to reduce their sales and processing staffs.
 "We are lower-cost producers," said Bruce R. Lublin, president of Homerica, which has 21 employees in its two offices.
 Mortgage brokers should not be confused with mortgage bankers. Mortgage bankers essentially make loans with their own funds or lines of credit and resell them at a profit, like most traditional lenders.
 Sometimes, though, mortgage brokers are also mortgage bankers. Mr. Lublin, a mortgage broker in New York and Connecticut, is also a mortgage banker in Connecticut, but not in New York.
 "The licensing is more stringent," he said, referring to New York's licensing laws for mortgage bankers.
 Though the surge in refinancing has increased the mortgage brokerage business, home buyers are critical for the industry's survival, since the number of refinancings is projected to shrink over the next few years to as low as 25 percent of all mortgage originations. This would pull down the dollar value of mortgages written to about $750 billion to $800 billion this year, from $1.1 trillion last year.
 "A lot of people who were considering refinancing at lower rates won't do so now that rates have gone up, even though they are still at historically low levels," Mr. Lublin said. The decline in refinancings and overall loan volume may put many smaller mortgage brokers out of business. The number of mortgage brokers nationally has more than tripled since 1987, to about 22,000 last year.
"THE steady decline in interest rates helped spur the growth in the mortgage brokerage business as well as mortgage banking in general," Mr. Lublin said. "You will see a consolidation in the industry in the next year or two because of the decrease in loan originations. A lot of the small mom-and-pop businesses will go by the wayside."
Not long ago, the mortgage-brokerage industry had a reputation for deceitfulness. But stricter licensing and more rigorous self-policing have greatly improved the industry's reputation over the last decade.
"We are cleaning out the bad apples," said Clare E. Sykes, a spokeswoman with the New York Department of Banking.
She that about 25 percent of the 200 or so mortgage-related complaints her department received each month concerned mortgage brokers. In the past, she said, the chief complaints against brokers were not scams but failure to disclose how much and how they were being paid.
"The problems are equally with the mortgage brokers and the mortgage bankers," she said. "The problems with them would be things like stalling the closing so interest rates would go up, and fees at the closing that come out of left field, sometimes last-minute changes in the closing that have a tendency to cost the borrower money."
Ms. Scott, a former president of the New York City Mortgage Brokers Association, said that borrowers should still guard against brokers with questionable credentials or who ask for high up-front fees by making sure that they were licensed. Forty-one states including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut license brokers. Individual salespeople in brokerage offices do not have to be licensed.
Prospective borrowers should check the state licensing authority -- usually the Department of Banking -- to see if it has received any complaints about a broker. They should also investigate whether the broker is a member of the local chapter of the National Association of Mortgage Brokers.
Ms. Scott suggested that a borrower should also ask the broker how many lenders it represented. Some brokers are associated with only a few lenders, which can limit a borrower's selection. Others work with dozens.
"We are not married to one lender," she said. "And that is what has fueled the growth of the industry."
Ms. Scott added that borrowers should ask for details about fees in advance. Only a loan application fee (about $50), a credit check (about $60) and an appraisal fee (about $275 to $300, more for co-ops) should be required, she said.
Brokers receive a fee, generally 1 percent of the loan amount, customarily paid either when the loan is approved or at the closing date. The fee is generally paid by the lender.
Sometimes the borrower will pay the fee directly to the broker in exchange for a mortgage whose cost has been reduced -- whether by deducting a point or reducing the interest rate -- by an amount equivalent to the payment to the broker.
In either case, the combined cost of the loan and the use of the broker should almost never be more than if the borrower had gone directly to the lender.
"As a general rule, we are equal to or better than going directly to the lender," Mr. Lublin said. "We shop the market for the most competitive lenders and we are often able to find loans that are not readily available in the borrower's area."
The Greenbergs, for example, applied for a "five-one" $215,000 jumbo mortgage offered by a New York State savings and loan that doesn't advertise or have a major presence in the retail mortgage market.
The loan is called a "five-one" because it has a fixed rate -- in this case, 7 percent -- for five years and adjusts annually afterwards with a 2-percentage-point annual cap and a 5-percentage-point cap for the life of the loan.
The Greenbergs chose the "five-one" because they don't expect to be in the home more than five years, which is close to the seven-year average length of a mortgage.
If they had taken out a 30-year, fixed-rate loan, they would have paid 8.5 percent interest.
FOR the loan, the Greenbergs paid $55 for a credit check, $275 for an appraisal and $95 for an application fee. The loan also carried 1 point, in this case $2,150, which went to the broker.
If they had gone directly to the lender, they would still have paid the point.
The broker essentially earns a fee through locating business for the lender and aiding in paperwork, a chore that sometimes in the past has been handled, for a fee, by real estate brokers.
"The bottom line is that a mortgage broker has shopped the market for the most competitive rates and programs available, and the consumer ends up saving a lot of time by going to a mortgage broker," Ms. Scott said.
Mortgage brokers can also be helpful scouting out potential problems with a property being purchased or when a borrower has trouble documenting income or has damaged credit and needs special assistance in finding a loan.
The ability of brokers to contact a number of lending institutions whose policies may be more or less restrictive on various points can help them obtain loans, according to Mr. Lublin.
"We can pre-screen the deal with a number of lenders until someone says they will do the loan," Mr. Lublin said.
Such instances are not limited to borrowers who have been laid off or have fallen behind in credit-card payments. Even those with spotless employment and credit records sometimes need help dancing around strict mortgage lending standards.
MS. BURNS, for instance, owns a small company with an income that varies from year to year. "It is automatically a red flag in that I am not working for a big company," she said.
There can also be underwriting problems with a co-op or with condominium tax abatements that might soon expire and increase common charges.
Brokers are able to find a lender who will make a loan despite such problems.
A bank, on the other hand, often has its own strict lending standards, and if a borrower doesn't meet them the bank doesn't shop around for a loan for which the borrower would qualify.
Ms. Burns, for example, bought an apartment in a co-op building that was only 66 percent owner-occupied, perilously close to the 50 to 60 percent level where lenders often reject mortgages.
Even so, her loan -- a one-year adjustable-rate mortgage with a lifetime cap at 10.95 percent -- was approved. Her monthly payments will be $506.
"I worried that rates aren't going to get any better than they are now, and I don't know if it is a good idea to wait any longer," she said.
Ms. Scott said that brokers also ordered appraisals and title and certificate-of-occupancy reports.
Most important, perhaps, she said, a broker will help negotiate with the lender and, along with the borrower's attorney, attend the closing.
Discussing the intricacies of obtaining various types of mortgage loans, Ms. Scott summed up what she saw as an advantage offered by a broker.
"It's a time-consuming process," she said, "and the borrowers don't know the questions to ask."

HEADLINE: Ravens Team Up With a Renewed Yale Field

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
BABE RUTH played there, as did Lou Gehrig, Ted Williams, Ron Darling and a first baseman from Greenwich named George Bush. So, too, did the old Brooklyn Dodgers and Boston Braves, along with Albie Booth and Larry Kelley, Yale football immortals who also starred in baseball. Indeed, no other ball park in Connecticut is as steeped in history as Yale Field.
But the question now is whether people will flock back to the field to see minor league baseball on what for 67 years has been almost wholly a university preserve -- even at a refurbished baseball shrine that is home to the state's newest professional sports team, the New Haven Ravens of the Double-A Eastern League. 
 Ed Massey, a Ridgefield businessman and Yale alumnus who came up with the idea, thinks they will. So does Charlie Dowd, general manager of the Ravens.
An initial hint may come on Thursday when the team plays its opening home game at 4 o'clock at the field on Derby Avenue (Route 34) in West Haven, across from the Latham Field House, Yale Bowl and the Connecticut Tennis Center. (The Ravens' first game was last Thursday in Binghamton, N.Y., and they will have played three times in Albany before making their home debut.)
The Ravens' entry into the Eastern League will create an in-state rivalry with the New Britain Red Sox, a Boston Red Sox farm team. It was largely for that reason that Joe Buzas, owner of the New Britain franchise, waived his 35-mile territorial rights to enable New Haven to obtain a franchise. The two cities are about 25 miles apart.
It was poor attendance that cost West Haven its franchise in 1982 after 11 years in the Eastern League. So a lot rides on the Ravens, an affiliate of the fledging Colorado Rockies of the National League, as well as Yale Field's charm and strategic site, just across the border from New Haven.
One of the most beautiful ball parks in the country, the stadium, now capable of seating 6,200, finally has lights for night games. Previous West Haven teams, which at different times were affiliated with the New York Yankees, Seattle Mariners and the Oakland Athletics, played in the dilapidated 4,000-seat Quigley Stadium, about two miles, but another world, away. Season attendance at Quigley ranged from a high of 75,000 in 1979 to a low of 23,000 in 1976. But the Ravens already have sold more than 125,000 tickets, according to Mr. Dowd. "I'll be disappointed if our attendance for the year doesn't top 250,000," he added, as about 100 workmen put the finishing touches on the Yale Field renovation.
In recent years minor league baseball, seemingly on the verge of extinction in the 1970's and early 80's, has undergone a revival. Overall attendance surpassed 30 million last year for the first time since 1950; the Eastern League set an attendance record for the fifth year in a row.
Soaring ticket prices at big league games together with high concession prices and parking fees and heavy traffic have helped the minor leagues thrive.
In addition, the Ravens have a valuable asset in Yale Field. For one thing, it is easily accessible, within minutes of Interstates 91 and 95 and the Merritt and Wilbur Cross parkways. For another, it is in a picturesque and quiet area. Third, while the field has been made more functional and comfortable, nothing has been done to detract from its special charm.
"Our objective was to preserve the character and the overall ambience of the park," said Glenn Gregg of Gregg & Wies, the New Haven architectural firm that designed the renovation. "The stadium still has its wonderful sightlines and the roof has its original configuration. And the exterior concrete wall and columns will remain the same."
But there are significant changes to the park where George Bush played first base for Yale in 1947 and 1948, where Ruth, Gehrig and Williams played in exhibition games, and where Booth, Yale's legendary Little Boy Blue, hit a grand slam home run to beat Harvard in a Commencement Day game in the early 1930's.
The interior of the stadium, which was built in 1927, was essentially gutted. New seats have been installed on a new steel and aluminum platform beneath the signature roof, which covers most of the grandstand, an unusual feature for a minor league ball park, let alone a college baseball stadium. Beneath the grandstand, a clubhouse for the home team has been built and restrooms and concession stands added.
 
Picnicking at the Game
 A berm, or small hillside, now stands beyond the right field fence where spectators can picnic while watching games. Building it necessitated moving in the right field fence, to 315 feet from 340 feet from home plate. But Mr. Gregg does not expect that to produce many more home runs. "The prevailing wind is to left field, not to right, so I think it might just equalize things," he said. "Anyway, we'd rather not have cookie-cutter dimensions like a lot of today's modern big league stadiums."
Other changes include a pavilion in the right field corner, where for $10 a head, including admission, members of groups of at least 25 people can eat as many hot dogs or hamburgers as they wish. A new electric scoreboard has been erected in left-center field, but Mr. Gregg is quick to point out that the ball park's landmark 50-foot-high green manual scoreboard in center field will remain and be operated as always, much like the one at Fenway Park in Boston.
Mainly because of the severe winter, the renovation will not be entirely finished by opening day. All the seats, most of them of the aluminum bleacher type, will have been installed, doubtless disappointing longtime Yale fans accustomed to the 5,300 individual wooden seats that had been in place since the first game at Yale Field in 1928.
"One of the reasons we took them out was because they were too narrow," Mr. Dowd said. "Fans obviously were smaller, and, I guess, thinner, when the park was built." Partly as a concession to Yale sentimentalists and partly out of nostalgia, the last row throughout the grandstand consists entirely of the old narrow seats.
Still to be decided is where to display the ball park's most famous seat, actually a double seat built especially for former President William Howard Taft, a Yale alumnus who became a law professor at his alma mater (and, later, Supreme Court justice) after leaving the White House. Taft, a rabid baseball fan who as President began the tradition of throwing out the first ball on opening day, weighed more than 300 pounds.
The Ravens' home opener, against the Reading (Pa.) Phillies, is a sellout at $3 for general admission ($2 for seniors and children under 13), $5 for reserved seats, $7 for box seats and, when available, $12.50 for boxes. Parking fees are $1 to $3.
Mr. Dowd, who was the general manager of a Class A team in Salinas, Calif., before joining the Ravens, thinks the intimacy of a ball park like Yale Field and its prices ($1.50 for a hot dog, about half of what it costs at most big league stadiums) will lure fans from as far away as Westchester County.
"We're offering inexpensive family entertainment in a beautiful setting," said Mr. Dowd, 31, who is a native of Staten Island. "A family of four which goes to a big league game nowadays can spend $125 or more easily. By comparison, at Yale Field for a Ravens game, it will be about $30. And you're much closer to the action."
Mr. Dowd, a former high school and college catcher who played for the Guilford Giants of the Men's Senior Baseball League last summer ("I don't think I'll have the time this year," he said), does not think that an affiliation with a major league team more than 2,000 miles away will handicap the Ravens.
"Minor league baseball nowadays sells itself," he said. "And, besides, I've got the feeling that Connecticut is a state without a specific city sports identity. We might draw a few more if we were a Yankee affiliate, but I don't think it's going to be a big factor."
Still, Mr. Dowd, Mr. Massey and other club officials were not about to name the team the New Haven Rockies. They remembered all too well how the West Haven Eastern League team had to change its name three times because of different major league affiliations. "We felt that with our own distinctive name, we could keep it regardless who we were affiliated with," he said.
That minor league baseball will be played at Yale Field at all surprises many Yale alumni and others in New Haven. In 1981, David Goldstein, then the owner of the West Haven A's, tried to move his team from Quigley Stadium to Yale Field, but Frank Ryan, the Yale athletic director, opposed the plan. (After the next season, the West Haven franchise folded.)
But in recent years Yale officials, including the current athletic director, Harold E. Woodsum, have become receptive to having a professional team play at Yale Field, whose playing surface Ruth once described as the best he had ever seen.
Yale Field was the main selling point that Mr. Massey and his associates, several of whom are also Yale alumni, used in bidding for an Eastern League franchise (which cost them $3 million) along with 13 other cities in 1992. The $3.5 million or so the renovation project cost came in loan from the Baseball Foundation of Connecticut, set up as a liaison between Yale and the Ravens. The loan is guaranteed by the state, Yale and Mr. Massey.
"The loan will be paid by money from the tax on admissions, from private donations and from the rent that Yale gets from the Ravens," said Mitch Truwit, the foundation's executive director. Already, a $500,000 donation toward the renovation project has been made by John White, a former Yale baseball and football player (class of 1942) and a New Haven native.
By contrast, the $18 million Connecticut Tennis Center was built almost entirely with state funds and has been used only for the weeklong Volvo tennis tournament during each of the last three years.
But baseball "is Everyman's sport," said Mayor John DeStefano,who proceeded Mr. Truwit as executive director of the Tennis Foundation of Connecticut and the Baseball Foundation. "And I think it's great for New Haven."
Both Mr. DeStefano and Matthew Nemerson, executive director of the Greater New Haven Chamber of Commerce, said it was difficult to say whether the Ravens would benefit the city economically. "I really don't think that matters," Mr. Nemerson said. "What counts is that the Ravens are going to provide good family entertainment at reasonable prices and also promote New Haven as a safe city with a lot to offer. It's an investment in our future."
For a while, it appeared that the state would get a third Eastern League team when the ownership of the Albany Yankees announced last month that the club would move to Norwich next season. But that decision was put on hold after Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York protested the move and promised state funds to help renovate the team's stadium in Colonie, N.Y., outside Albany.
 
Many Stories, Some Tall
 Like most ball parks, that stadium, Heritage Park, does not compare with Yale Field, which, along with its charm, abounds with legends, some apparently apocryphal. Some old-timers claim that Ruth once hit a tremendous home run over the scoreboard in dead center field. Not true, said 84-year-old Mike Patricelli, who has rarely missed a Yale football or baseball game. In fact, he said, Ruth never hit a home run at Yale Field. "I was at the game when the Yankees played at Yale Field around 1930," Mr. Patricelli said, "and the Babe never hit one out. Neither did Lou Gehrig."
Then there is the legend of how Ted Williams, as a rookie, hit a titanic home run at Yale Field. But newspaper accounts of the day show that during a doubleheader between the Red Sox and Yale on April 16, 1939, Williams not only did not hit a home run, but went hitless in eight times at bat. However, the Red Sox beat the Eli in both games back in an era when there were only 16 major league teams, none further west than St. Louis.
As for Booth's grand slam homer, Mr. Patricelli said, "Albie definititely hit it, with the bases loaded, to beat Harvard."

HEADLINE: Helping Way Stations on New York's Greenway Trail

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

 BODY:
IT'S spring, and an appropriate time for thoughts to turn to the Greenway, the 300-mile system of trails that was supposed to stretch from Westchester to Albany, linking communities on both sides of the Hudson River. Whatever happened to it?
The idea was proposed about 10 years ago. Then in 1991, with the passage of the Greenway Act, the state started to designate a model Greenway community in each of the 10 counties along the proposed trail. 
 The state gives each community a grant of $50,000 to preserve open land along the water and to develop trails. It also helps them write waterfront master plans and provides other technical assistance.
One such community is the City of Troy in Rensselaer County, which parlayed an initial $25,000 grant into a plan that secured a $1.5 million grant from the Federal Government on March 17. The Federal grant will enable the city to build a pedestrian walkway from its downtown to a new viewing platform on the river, among other waterfront improvements.
"I'm not saying that Greenway can take the credit for Troy's plan," said David Sampson, executive director of the Greenway Council, a state agency in the Governor's office. "But they wouldn't have been able to do it without our help."
There are now nine model communities, among them the farming Town of Stuyvesant, population 2,200, in Columbia County. It became a model community last June in the hope that the program would help it gain access to the waterfront, which is separated from the town by the railroad tracks.
Four weeks ago, seven municipalities along the Albany County waterfront agreed to act as one model community to coordinate planning along the river to help bolster tourism and economic development.
In the midst of all this self-interest, how realistic is the ideal of the trail itself, which is what gives Greenway its name?
"All the model communities are making the establishment of a trail a part of their planning," said Mr. Sampson of the Greenway Council. Nevertheless, almost all of the 62 miles of trail already established is on state-owned land and none is in a model community.
The idea for the Greenway is credited to Representative Maurice D. Hinchey, Democrat of Kingston. A decade ago, when he was a State Assemblyman, Mr. Hinchey said that "there was no overall planning for the Hudson Valley as an ecological entity" and that he "saw that as a threat to one of the country's most beautiful natural resources."
Around that time, a Federal report came out encouraging the establishment of "greenline parks," Mr. Hinchey said.
These are "linear parks connecting communities with a common interest in preserving their waterfront," he said, and "the two ideas just seemed to fit together."
In 1988, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo established the Greenway Council to plan the trail system. After passage of the Greenway Act a target date of 2005 was set for its completion.
"I think the target date is optimistic," said Maggie Vinciquerra, executive director of the Greenway Heritage Conservancy, a state agency created to help communities develop their trail systems. "Since participation is completely voluntary," she said, "a lot of communities will sit back and see how the other guy fares before getting involved."
Selling the idea of a Greenway to Hudson River towns has proved a painstaking process. Several still seem to have no idea what it is, and some are openly hostile to it.
At a meeting last fall of the nonprofit Hudson River Environmental Society, William Capshaw, a trustee of the Village of Dobbs Ferry, in Westchester, chastised Greenway officials for not making their goals clear to communities on the river.
"WHEN the Greenway was first proposed, it seemed the state was going to tell local governments what they could do with their waterfronts," Mr. Capshaw said. "I don't hear a lot of people talking about what the Greenway is doing now. It's great to be spiritual and propose this idea, but how's it really going to work?"
Ultimately, it will involve 10 counties: Albany, Columbia, Dutchess, Greene, Orange, Putman, Rensselaer, Rockland, Ulster and Westchester. It will run from the mouth of the Mohawk River to the New Jersey border on the west side and from the Troy Dam to the New York City line on the east side. The trail will link urban, suburban and rural areas and weave in and out of historic, cultural and recreational resources.
The Greenway is currently financed by private donations and a 0.2 percent hotel tax levied in each Greenway county. New York City chose not to participate because of its already high hotel taxes.
Greenway officials are quick to point out that participation is completely voluntary. In fact, the Greenway Council doesn't even like to approach communities without first being invited.
"It's completely up to the individual community," said Mr. Sampson of the Greenway Council. "If it wants to protect its waterfront we're here to help them with that."
The Town of Stuyvesant was initially very resistant to Greenway. "We thought it was going to have eminent domain, purchase properties and control their use," said Tod Grenci, the Town Supervisor. "When the legislation passed, eminent domain was out and home rule was in. That's the only reason we got involved.
Stuyvesant has two at-grade railroad crossings, one on private land. The public crossing is not considered safe for hauling trailered boats to the water.
In a few months, even that may be closed off when the Department of Transportation begins a high-speed demonstration project between Stuyvesant and Schenectady. Trains will be passing through town at speeds between 110 and 125 miles an hour. They now travel at about 90. The state has indicated it might have to close several at-grade crossings along the route that were considered unsafe.
The town asked the Greenway Council to intervene with the Department of Transportation to keep an access road open so that it could usethe 234-acre waterfront parcel known as Nutten Hook, now owned by the state Department of Environmental Conservation. On it are a 19th-century ice house, an antique barn and other historic structures.
"We'd like to build a boat launch and develop a trail there that would take in some of the town's history," said Mr. Grenci. "Something that would be attractive to town residents and visitors."
THOUGH the bureaucracy has been moving at glacial speed, Mr. Grenci said, the Greenway Council did help arrange a meeting with Conrail and the Department of Transportation. "We finally got all parties together in a room to discuss options," Mr. Grenci said. Among the department's possible solutions were installing automatic gates on the public crossing and, ultimately, building an overpass.
The Villages of Ossining and Croton, in Westchester, which work in tandem as one model community, have asked the Department of Transportaion to repair a bridge linking the two communities and include a pedestrian and bike path. "That's exactly how the Greenway is supposed to work," said Mr. Sampson of the Greenway Council.
Ideally, the Greenway will also provide links between towns across the river from each other. Beacon, in Dutchess County, and Newburgh, in Orange, both model communites, have developed a 14-mile trail that crosses the Newburgh-Beacon Bridge. They are expected to submit the trail for Greenway designation soon.
"We think the river should be seen as a connector, not a divider," said Clara-Lou Gould, Mayor of Beacon.
"Once communities see the benefits to be derived from the Greenway, we believe they'll want to get involved," said Mr. Sampson. "They'll see there's nothing to be afraid of."
Since most of the land along the Hudson is in private hands, Greenway officials acknowledge they will also have to work out easements or other arrangements with individual owners if the Greenway is to succeed.
Of the 62 miles now established, only 5 are on private land. "We'll continue to demonstrate the benefits of the Greenway to land owners," Mr. Sampson said. "If they want to work with us, fine. If they don't, we'll just go around them."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
Amtrak's Reprieve for Downtown New Rochelle

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

 BODY:
NEW ROCHELLE has received a welcome boost from a decision by Amtrak to continue to use the city's downtown train station and invest $92 million in track, platform and station renovations.
The railroad had been considering building a station elsewhere in the city but eventually yielded to community opposition to its abandoning the downtown. 
 The city is still reeling from the rejection last year of its bid to become the new world headquarters of Unicef. It had planned to build four office buildings, 550 units of housing and a retail complex on mostly city-owned property downtown to accommodate the organization.
When the agency decided to remain in Manhattan, downtown revitalization hopes seemed all but dead. Amtrak's departure could have dealt a final blow.
"There was universal opposition to Amtrak's leaving the downtown," said Joseph G. Madonna, the city's Commissioner of Development.
"If Amtrak hadn't stayed it would have been much more difficult to attract other businesses and developers to our central business district. This gives us a lift."
The city-owned train station is the only stop in Westchester on Amtrak's New York-to-Boston run. The tracks there are used by both Amtrak and Metro-North trains, which frequently results in delays and congestion.
Starting in 1998, Amtrak will introduce high-speed service on the line. As a result, it expects the number of trains that stop at New Rochelle to increase to 18, from the present 4, and the passenger volume to double to 160,000 a year, from 80,000. For this reason, said David J. Carol, director of the New York-Boston project, Amtrak believes the present station is inadequate.
Although the station itself is in "pretty good shape," Mr. Carol said, "we need to put in another window for Amtrak customers, and a self-ticketing system."
Moreover, he said, the lobby now has almost no seating. "For inter-city passengers with lugguage," he said, "we need to provide that."
But the greatest problem and biggest expense will involve work on and over the tracks. When Amtrak trains now arrive at New Rochelle, they have to cross three Metro-North tracks to get to the platform. When they leave they have to cross back again.
"This causes all sorts of problems," Mr. Carol said.
To ease this situation, the company plans to construct center-island platforms. Amtrack's trains will stay on their own tracks and pick up passengers from a new platform.
BY far the most expensive part of the project will be building a flyover, or bridge, over the tracks, about a quarter mile south of the station, where Amtrak trains will cross above Metro-North's tracks. "The flyover alone will cost about $65 million," Mr. Carol said. "This will be a $100 million job before it's done."
Amtrak officials maintain that renovating the existing station will cost $20 million more than building a new one. But Representative Nita M. Lowey, who represents New Rochelle and is a member of the House Appropriations Committee, lobbied extensively in favor of Amtrak's remaining where it is.
The project will be financed by the $1.3 billion the Federal Government has earmarked for the Northeast Corridor Improvement Project, Mr. Carol said. While final details of the overall project are still being worked out and a construction start date has yet to be set, the project is expected to be completed by 1998.
For its part, Metro-North is also planning some improvements to the station, such as accommodating the disabled by installing an elevator, equipping platforms with tactile strips for the blind and lowering ticket windows for access from wheelchairs, according to a company spokesman, Daniel Brucker. In addition, he said, lighting will be upgraded and signs improved.
In addition, the city and both railroads will soon begin talking about building a parking garage at the station. Metro-North has said it needs 1,000 additional spaces at the station and Amtrak wants 300 for its customers. Exactly who's going to pay for what has yet to be established.
"We all have to sit down and hash this out," said Mr. Carol. "Since the city owns the land, I would hope that they will at least provide the property. It's very unusual to build a project like this with 100 percent Federal funding so we hope that the community and other parties will do their share on the parking facilities."
WHEN Amtrak announced its decision on Feb. 28 to stay at the station, Representative Lowey called it "a victory for New Rochelle." She said that the plan for renovating the station would "satisfy Amtrak's goal of expanded service and greater reliability while strengthening New Rochelle's downtown area."
The city is hoping that Amtrak's commitment to the downtown will be a giant step toward realizing its ultimate goal of becoming a transportation hub in Westchester.
In addition to the trains, there are buses that connect New Rochelle to Long Island as well as to upstate New York communities, such as Monticello and Binghamton. And there is limousine service to New York City's airports. The various transportation activities are now spread out all over the city.
New Rochelle's Department of Development is now seeking Federal funds toestablish an Intermodal Surface Transportation Center to be built around the train station.
"I wasn't aware that we had all this transportation in the city," said William C. Fahey, counsel to the city for the intermodal project. He recently completed a first draft of a grant proposal for Federal funds for construction of a center where all modes of transportation would be consolidated and connected to one another. As envisioned by Mr. Fahey, the center would include a bus station connected to the train station by a walkway. The document is now being circulated for comments.
Financing for such a project, Mr. Fahey said, could be available through the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act, the Clear Air Quailty Act and the Northeast Corridor Project.
Some of this Federal financing is meant to encourage private investment in such transportation facilites, Mr. Fahey said.
"We're ideally suited for that since the station is located right in the downtown," he said. "It could attract local office development and retail establishments. This is the kind of thing you see in Europe all the time. We're just catching on to it here."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The railroad station at New Rochelle is shared by Metro-North and Amtrak. Amtrak will build a center platforms for its riders. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: On Expanding Vernon Resort Area

 BODY:
Like many Sussex Countyans, I was shocked by an incredibly unbalanced front-page article, "Vernon Resort Expansion Plan Meets Criticism," on March 6. In addition to unjustly damaging the image and accomplishments of Gene Mulvihill, chairman of Great American Recreation, and his many Sussex County enterprises, the article has also slandered our area State Senator, several Vernon Township officials, local business people and, in effect, our county itself.
Granted, Mr. Mulvihill has been ambitious and aggressive and at times has cut corners. In my view, however, Mr. Mulvihill was and is primarily "guilty" of two things: first, the creation of nearly 2,000 full- and part-time jobs in a county where two-thirds of the work force must commute out of county to find work. Second, his projects (Great Gorge Spa, Golf Course, Action Park, Vernon Valley/Great Gorge and now the Hamburg Mountain wilderness complex) served to open for public recreation areas that heretofore were inaccessible because of lack of infrastructure or simply because they were off-limits state/private lands. 
 Instead of "plundering" the areas, as a critic quoted in the article suggests, Mr. Mulvihill (after others tried and failed) created a balanced recreational complex that should be a model for those seeking a equitable blend of environmental and economic concerns. But, reading the article, one might conclude that Mr. Mulvihill was akin to a scoundrel in the business of operating nuclear waste incinerators and landfills in the midst of pristine woodlands.
The article reports that critics say Mr. Mulvihill gets his way because he has Vernon Township government "in his pocket." This must come as a shock to Mr. Mulvihill, who constantly must do battle with town officials who, partly in response to overzealous environmentalists and elitists, hold him to a far stricter standard than other developers and entrepreneurs.
The implied conspiracy between Mr. Mulvihill and area officials simply doesn't exist, despite the overlap of names. Fact is, in a small county like Sussex, one of our historic problems is that because of our size, presumed conflicts do appear because the number of individuals willing to become positively involved, in anything, is very limited. Honest.
PETER MICHAEL BARDACH
Chairman and C.E.O.
WSUS Communications
Franklin

HEADLINE: Shouldn't Art Support Start at Home?

 BODY:
Your frequent articles on the Westchester Arts Council (the latest, "Art Advocates Troop to Albany to Seek a Piece of the Pie," March 20) and its attempts to seek public funds omit a crucial reality: that the council evidently sees itself as a quasi-public agency with more and more financing from the public rather than the private sector.
Meanwhile, political double-talk is still alive and well in the state of New York. Senator George E. Pataki, who with Change-NY laments the use of public funds for a myriad of agencies that should, in his view, be privatized, apparently sees nothing wrong in using tax money to help pay $100,000 a year to the council's executive director, Janet T. Langsam, who administers an annual budget of about $1.5 million. Consider that her salary is just $20,000 less than that of County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, who administers an annual budget in excess of $1 billion. 
 Not the least tragi-comic aspect of this Gothic situation is that neither Langsam, nor Pataki, nor Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky ("one of the strongest arts proponents in the Westchester delegation") are listed in the council's newsletter among annual contributors of $250 and over. It would appear that they do not part with their own money for the arts while they argue vigorously that we should part with ours, individually and collectively.
In any case, the belief that every dollar contributed to the arts affects the economy positively had its inspiration in the early 1970's when it was discovered that Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts might go bankrupt. The idea worked in New York City and environs. But since that time, symphony orchestras have gone out of business in other American cities, and the cities and their economies have survived.
Given the flaws of the economic argument and the nonrelevance to artistic quality of the council's current suggestions -- that the arts "keep elderly people stimulated and that they are essential in the schools" -- the arts in Westchester may be in serious trouble.
Put another way, if the council is demanding public funding for the arts, then the public should demand better thinking and more intelligent arguments (if it can get them) from the council.
MILTON GOLDIN
Tarrytown

HEADLINE: World Markets;
A New Theory of Continental Drift

BYLINE: By Richard W. Stevenson 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
HAVING slavishly followed the American stock and bond markets downward over the previous few weeks, it was only fitting that the European markets bounced back somewhat last week in synch with their counterparts across the Atlantic.
By the close on Friday in London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading shares stood at 3,120.8, up 34.38 for the week. In Paris, the CAC-40 closed at 2,114.77, up 32.83 for the week. The DAX index in Frankfurt rose 70.23 for the week to close at 2,203.34. 
 But as the immediate panic of the last few weeks subsided, it exposed what are perhaps the key questions for investors in European markets:
Can Europe, which is at a different point in the economic cycle from the United States and should still be enjoying the benefits of falling interest rates, uncouple itself from the bearish psychology that took hold on Wall Street when the Federal Reserve began raising rates? And in the meantime, what linkage should investors expect between tighter money in the United States and the performance of stock and bond markets in Europe?
Sushil Wadhwani and Mushtaq Shah, global strategists at Goldman, Sachs International in London, have taken a whack at those questions. In a report issued last week, they examined what has happened in Europe in past cases when the Federal Reserve sought to rein in unsustainable economic growth in the United States and choke off inflation by raising short-term interest rates, as it is doing now.
Between June 1983 and May 1984, they wrote, the Fed pushed short-term rates up by just under one percentage point, causing long-term rates, as measured by bond yields, to rise 2.55 points. But six months later, with the markets convinced that growth and inflation were under control, long-term rates had fallen back by 1.64 points.
Between February and September 1987, the Fed pushed up short-term rates by 0.83 points, causing long-term rates to increase 2.34 points. Six months later, long-term rates had fallen back by 1.09 points.
Drawing a parallel to today's investment psychology, the Goldman, Sachs strategists called those periods "growth scares" in the markets. In the 1983-84 scare, equities in the United States had a total return of -0.3 percent. In Britain in that period, total return on shares was 9.5 percent. In Germany, it was 9.1 percent, and in France, 50.5 percent.
In the 1987 scare, total return on equities in the United States was 15 percent. In Britain, it was 23 percent. In Germany, it was 14.2 percent, and in France, -2.3 percent.
In both cases, stocks generally outperformed bonds, suggesting that the equity markets were able to detach themselves from the psychology of rising interest rates.
The Goldman, Sachs team concluded that European equities were able to "decouple" from the American markets, though more clearly in 1983-84 than in 1987. But they offered some caveats.
"Decoupling from the U.S. bond yield can take time -- equities took time to break free from bonds after the Fed tightenings in 1983 and 1987," they wrote. "Moreover, there is a limit to how much interest rates can rise without equities suffering. In 1987, the rise in rates led to valuations becoming so extended that a stock market crash did follow."
Still, Goldman, Sachs took away from its study a basically bullish view on European equities for the rest of the year. Although long-term rates in the United States could continue rising for part of the year, causing more weakness in stock prices, rates should eventually start falling as economic growth is brought back down to sustainable levels.
In the meantime, Goldman, Sachs said, European stock markets are still relatively undervalued and should be helped by an earnings recovery.
"We believe that the likely persistence of a growth scare makes it somewhat more probable that European equities will experience some near-term weakness," the Goldman team said. "The most likely outcome remains, however, that the underlying fundamentals will eventually reassert themselves, so longer-term-oriented investors may, over the next few months, accumulate equities on weakness. We continue to expect 10 percent to 15 percent appreciation in European equities on a 12-month view."
Many other analysts agree, sometimes citing such other factors as the likelihood of continuing rate cuts in Germany and other big European nations.
But some strategists see continuing questions, if not problems, when it comes to the relationship between Europe and the American markets.
David C. Roche, the global strategist at Morgan Stanley in London, has for some time predicted that the huge flow of funds from American investors into European stocks and bonds was likely to dry up as rates rise in the United States, pulling a critical source of strength out from under the markets.
As a predictor of the behavior of investors in the United States, Mr. Roche said he is keeping a close eye on the flow of money into mutual funds, which has been continuing but at a lower rate than previously.
"U.S. investors have been conditioned to buy on dips," Mr. Roche said in a report last week. "The next few weeks will see if they continue to do so. If they don't, then I think the markets could fall another 15 percent. If they maintain inflows into mutual funds, then this sell-off will be only a correction, and we are closer to the end of it than the beginning."

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
When Brokerage Chiefs Bail Out

BYLINE: By Susan Antilla 

 BODY:
IF it's true that it pays to hang on to stocks for the long haul, then why have brokerage-firm big shots been bailing out?
Officers and directors of the nation's brokerage firms have been big sellers of their companies' stock this year. Their reasons are predictable: tax planning or portfolio diversification. Or for retirement, college bills, the new house, the old wife. 
 All sorts of financial demands surface that never seem to when the company is selling at half of book value.
Lee Fensterstock, executive vice president at the Paine Webber Group, unloaded 38,500 shares of Paine Webber at prices between $17.65 and $18.56 in January and February. He needed cash to buy a house, according to a Paine Webber spokesman. And Mr. Fensterstock made a second move in his account in which he moved 20,000 restricted shares into a deferred compensation plan -- first exchanging the shares for cash. Not the sort of move you make when you think a stock has farther to go.
Brokerage firm executives, in fact, have been big sellers since 1991, said Robert Gabele of CDA Invest/Net, a Fort Lauderdale, Fla., tracker of buying and selling by the corporate insiders who must, by law, inform the Securities and Exchange Commission about all their trades in their company shares.
While Mr. Gabele notes that the selling by securities executives accelerated in the fall -- in anticipation, perhaps, of the market's recent drop -- he and others say that a longer-term factor seems to be at work.
"These firms have had years of breaking earnings records, and the feeling is that it will be hard to replicate that as we go forward," said Michael Lewis, financial services analyst at Dean Witter. "Especially in a rising interest rate environment, I guess they must see the writing on the wall."
Not a single share owned by a Paine Webber insider was sold in 1990, according to Mr. Gabele's records, when the stock traded between $5.125 and $9.156. In 1991, though, as Paine Webber shares moved to $16.50, insiders began to cash in, selling 96,750 shares bought with options plus 87,000 shares with no ties to options privileges. In 1992, Paine Webber insiders sold 240,625 shares (161,458 related to options), and last year they sold 637,420 shares (31,600 were options-related).
At Merrill Lynch and other publicly traded brokerage houses, selling patterns were similar, Mr. Gabele said. Merrill insiders sold only 310 shares in 1990, but became more aggressive sellers in each year since, selling 480,000 shares through options and open-market purchases last year. (Merrill quibbles with Mr. Gabele's 1993 number, noting that the 80,000 shares sold by its former chairman shouldn't count.)
It's worth keeping a sharp eye on buying and selling by brokerage-industry executives in particular, Mr. Gabele said, because they can provide more information than the average insider at a publicly held company.
"When you look at the insider concept generally you figure all these guys have got to know something about their company," he explained. "But when you look at Wall Street insiders, you can take it farther, because these insiders are in the business of knowing something about the market. The Wall Street insider may be more of a market timer."
That theory is dismissed by many on Wall Street, who make a case that the public filings on insider selling miss part of the story. Senior staffers are increasingly compensated with stock, they argue, and the purchasing that goes on in employee stock plans needn't be reported to the S.E.C. William Montgoris, a lawyer at Bear, Stearns & Company, said that his firm has purchased 100 million of its own shares for employee compensation plans since July 1. In the first three months of this year, though, insiders unloaded more than 300,000 shares -- and that doesn't give a clue as to any activity by lower-ranking Bear, Stearns staffers who don't have to file with the S.E.C.
Mark Thompson, a spokesman at Charles Schwab & Company, said his company has been engaged in similar purchase programs, picking up 700,000 shares in the first quarter of this year because "our shares have been available at particularly attractive prices."
But you have to wonder why those bargain prices didn't catch the eye of the founder, Charles Schwab, who sold 300,000 shares at $27.05 apiece on Feb. 17. Or Lawrence J. Stupski, an officer and company director, who got rid of 40,000 shares in the first quarter. Selling at Schwab has risen from 175,000 shares sold by insiders in 1990 to 350,000 in 1991, 900,000 in 1992 and 889,000 in 1993. Mr. Schwab and his family still own 24.3 percent of the company, down only slightly from 25 percent a year ago, a spokesman noted.
Not every company is watching an executive bailout. At Alex. Brown & Sons, the investment bank in Baltimore, 28 insider purchases in the first quarter outweighed only 12 sales. But even there, enough of the sales were tied to expiring options to make the buying less bullish than it initially appears. For the most part, it looks as if the smart money is cashing in for now -- even at mutual fund purveyors like T. Rowe Price. Carter O. Hoffman, a T. Rowe director, sold 40,000 shares in mid-March. Thomas Broadus Jr. sold 10,000 at $28 apiece in January. And Alvin M. Younger, the company treasurer, got rid of 4,200 shares, too, when T. Rowe shares were trading at $34.50.
But never fear that this was some bad omen for the market. Mr. Hoffman got out as a diversification move related to his retirement planning, a spokesman said. And Mr. Broadus has been "average cost selling," also related to retirement planning. Mr. Younger needed to sell "to meet income tax bills this year due to the rise in the income tax rate that took effect."
They were lucky their personal needs struck when they did. By Friday's close, T. Rowe was 22 percent below where it was when Mr. Younger and Mr. Hoffman sold only a month ago.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 5; Financial Desk
