HEADLINE: California Being Enriched by Underground and Illegal Money

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 9

 BODY:
The state government may be short of money, but Southern California is awash in cash and experts say drug trafficking, instability in Asia and the state's underground economy that involves many illegal immigrants are the likely reasons.
Economists say the cash infusion may have insulated Los Angeles from the worst of the state's four-year recession. But it has also cost the state treasury at least $1.8 billion a year in unreported taxes at a time when the budget deficit has hit $3 billion. 
 Since 1990, the annual cash surplus reported by the Los Angeles branch of the San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank -- the excess cash the district bank collects from financial institutions compared with what it distributes -- has almost tripled, from $3.4 billion to $9.3 billion in 1993.
Since 1992, the Los Angeles surplus has soared past Miami's to lead the nation's 36 Federal Reserve bank districts.
Private financial institutions keep cash on hand to meet daily banking needs. When they have too much, they send it to the district bank for safekeeping.
"We don't know where all our excess cash is coming from down in Southern California," said Ron Supinski, a spokesman for the reserve bank.
But law enforcement officials say the cash switch from Miami to Los Angeles followed a similar trend in drug trafficking.
Tougher enforcement in Florida and the Caribbean created difficulties for Colombian cocaine transporters in the late 1980's, said Ralph Lockridge of the Los Angeles office of the Drug Enforcement Administration. The traffickers' response, he said, was to open routes through Central America and Mexico into the American Southwest.
"Now a large portion of the drugs -- some say 70 percent -- come through the Southwest," Mr. Lockridge said. "And they have also developed money-laundering systems along the West Coast."
Fed figures show that El Paso and San Antonio are also in the top five showing cash surpluses the past four years.
Nationally, estimates of laundered cash run as high as $100 billion.
In the late 1980's, Colombia's Medellin cocaine cartel used Los Angeles jewelry stores to hide drug cash. Now investigators say money exchange houses along the Mexican border are performing a similar task.
Last September, Customs agents near San Diego stopped three Colombian women and found $300,000 stuffed into special girdles.
Analysts agree on other legal and semilegal sources for the cash.
One of the most striking is California's "underground economy," a cash-driven system that does not use checks and credit cards. It includes everything from gambling and prostitution to off-the-books sales of legitimate goods.
A Wells Fargo Bank study estimates California's underground economy at $140 billion a year, or 18 percent of the gross state economy. That figure is probably low, and does not include Northern California's huge marijuana crop, said the study's author, Gary Schlossberg.
"You have to look at the underground economy, especially illegal immigrants and those whose transactions tend to be cash oriented," Mr. Schlossberg said.
California has more than half the nation's illegal immigrants, he said. They usually cannot open bank accounts or get credit, and are often paid off the books in cash.
The state's weak economy also gets some blame.
"When the economy goes south, a lot of legal transactions don't get reported, just to avoid taxes," Mr. Schlossberg said.
Another likely source is money flowing in from Pacific Rim countries.
The return of Hong Kong to China in 1997, the tension between North and South Korea and increased trade with the United States may be prompting Asians to move their dollars to Los Angeles for investment or safekeeping.

HEADLINE: Japan's Crisis Is Realigning Political Blocs

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 9

 BODY:
The maneuvering to choose a successor to Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa took shape today not just as a battle for individual power but also as a broad realignment of Japan's four-decade-old party structure.
"The Liberal Democratic Party is disintegrating, and to some extent the same thing is starting to happen to the Socialists," said Takeshi Sasaki, a professor of politics at Tokyo University and a Government adviser. Professor Sasaki added that the Prime Minister "had kept them together until yesterday," when he suddenly announced his decision to resign in the face of financial scandals in which he has been implicated. 
 After his announcement, Mr. Hosokawa said he wanted to reformulate his seven-party coalition Government under a single party-like structure called "kaikaku," or reform, and this led to the political battle.
 
A New Political Order
 The proposal is supported principally by the more conservative members of the coalition, who have been seeking to transform Japan's fractious political order into a two-party system. They are aiming for these parties to be located near the political center, rather than along the left-right axis that characterized Japanese politics during the cold war.
This group tends to favor a more active international role for Japan, strong relations with the United States and measured but real deregulation of some parts of the economy.
A leading contender to become Prime Minister, Tsutomu Hata, who is Foreign Minister, has backed the proposal and immediately sought to identify himself with Mr. Hosokawa's popular -- if only partly successful -- programs.
 
'Reforms in the Truest Sense'
 "I would like someone" to become prime minister, he said, "who, like the current Prime Minister, is determined to carry out reforms. We must implement reforms in the truest sense."
Mr. Hosokawa's announcement has thus acted as a catalyst, forcing the more leftward-leaning members of his own small party and of the largest party in the coalition, the Socialists, to threaten to leave the Government.
They could be replaced, however, with more defectors from what remains of the Liberal Democratic Party. Michio Watanabe, a former Foreign Minister and a conservative faction leader in the Liberal Democratic Party, dropped hints that he might join the new group, along with dozens of other Liberal Democrats. He is also regarded as a contender for the job of prime minister.
 
'Similar Policy Line'
 "The Liberal Democratic Party cannot realize a majority in the parliament," he said. "It's time to form a coalition with those who have a similar policy line."
The strongest opponents of economic deregulation are the parties that have traditionally relied for support on heavily regulated industries, such as agriculture and small retailers. That is where the Liberal Democrats and the Socialists have drawn many of their core supporters.
"Regulation is like air for many people in this country," said a Government official. "Even with all the talk about change, it is what they breath."
Last summer the Liberal Democratic Party lost power after 38 years of one-party rule when a group of mostly younger members demanding economic and electoral system reforms defected and formed the core of Mr. Hosokawa's coalition Government, an awkward combination of centrists and Socialists.
 
Policy on North Korea
 The subsequent party upheaval came to a halt when Mr. Hosokawa took office in August. But it has now resumed in earnest, with potentially important policy questions at stake, like the future of economic deregulation and policy toward North Korea.
Although Japanese politicians generally avoid spelling out policy differences too clearly, some important conflicts within the coalition have been emerging recently.
Since Japan's defeat in World War II there has been a powerful pacifist streak in the country, reaching across the political spectrum. Many people have been resisting the idea of Japan's joining an economic embargo against North Korea.

HEADLINE: Discontent Mounts in China, Shaking the Leaders

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, April 9

 BODY:
With China's economy still in overdrive, a new surge in inflation, labor unrest and corruption appears to be rattling the Communist Party leadership.
Chinese and Western officials say that concern in the Politburo about the stability of Communist Party rule may explain the vigorous crackdown this spring on political dissent, including the recent arrests of Wei Jingsheng and Xu Wenli, veterans of the "Democracy Wall" movement of the 1970's. Both had been freed from prison only last year. 
 A number of other dissidents have also been arrested in a clampdown that appears to be linked to the visit of France's Prime Minister, Edouard Balladur.
 
Parallels With 1989
 After two straight years of 13 percent growth in the economy, inflation is running at an annual rate of nearly 26 percent in China's biggest cities. Many analysts see parallels with turbulence five years ago, when rapid consumer price increases and evidence of rampant corruption fed worker and student unrest that mushroomed into huge street demonstrations. The protests virtually paralyzed the capital for six weeks and ended with the military crackdown and killings in Tiananmen Square on June 4, 1989.
Signs of deep dissatisfaction have returned, and the Chinese leadership is reacting -- some Western diplomats say it is seriously overreacting -- to the stirrings of protest.
The depth of discontent is hard to measure, but a secret Government report leaked to a Hong Kong newspaper this week tallied more than 6,000 illegal strikes in China in 1993 and more than 200 riots. Many were protests against layoffs and unpaid wages in cash-starved state industries.
"The Chinese Communist Party takes the issue of mass demonstrations and assemblies very seriously and is on the alert against the flames lest they should spread far and wide," the Chengming newspaper quoted the introduction to the report as saying.
The warning could have come from Mao himself, who, as a young revolutionary, understood that rebellion, whatever its cause, is a prairie fire waiting for a match.
Millions of ordinary people have grievances. In February, the price of vegetables was 54 percent higher than a year earlier; the price of staple grains was up 40 percent, and meat prices had increased by a third.
By any measure, incomes have not kept pace.
"Too high a growth rate will lead to inflation, this is a law," said Sun Shangqing, the research director of China's Cabinet, or State Council, in an interview. "It is true both in the United States and in China."
A Western economist said the year-to-year price increases recorded in the first two months of 1994 were greater than any in the previous four years. If the trend continues, overall inflation could accelerate to an annual rate of more than 50 percent by the end of the year.
"They've got to make controlling inflation the most important objective for the next six to nine months," the economist said. "People are already becoming intolerant of it."
Adding to the insecurity are rumors about the deteriorating health of China's 89-year-old paramount leader, Deng Xiaoping, whose feeble state in a televised appearance in February startled many Chinese.
"Stability" has become the watchword of Communist rule, even at the cost of slowing the pace of economic liberalization and reform.
 
Anger Over Corruption
 The Public Security Minister, Tao Siju, warned in a speech to security officials on March 31 that if the Government's seven-month-old drive against corruption did not succeed, "we will not be able to discharge the heavy responsibility of safeguarding stability, and we may even endanger stability."
Many citizens are angered by persistent reports of factory managers taking kickbacks from suppliers, bankers accepting bribes in exchange for easy credit terms and local party officials fixing legal cases.
The litany of public complaints seemed to be summed up last month in a speech by Hou Zhenting, a party official from Hunan Province. At an annual meeting of the National People's Congress, he told some of the more than 2,000 delegates that the Communist Party neglected to pay millions of teachers and issued I.O.U.'s to farmers for their grain in a cruel game of "peasant exploitation."
State industries "are in the red and workers' basic pay cannot be guaranteed while, on the other hand, factory directors and managers travel" abroad at Government expense and give lavish banquets for their cronies. "How can the masses be satisfied with this?" Mr. Hou asked.
The answer, evidently, is that they are not. And the leadership that was brimming with self-confidence just two months ago after a second year of heavy foreign investment and extraordinary growth is showing signs of anxiety.
China's Labor Minister, Li Boyong, warned this week that the country faced "unprecedented challenges in deploying all the jobless," who are flooding into cities from the countryside in search of work. The "floating" population of surplus labor now exceeds 100 million, by some estimates.
"A rise in unemployment rather than inflation would pose a greater threat to China," Li Yining, a senior Government economist, warned.
But labor unrest has other roots as well. Industrial accidents more than doubled in 1993, killing or maiming tens of thousands of Chinese workers, Labor Ministry figures show.
The spread of factories financed by foreigners has led to charges of sweatshop conditions and other forms of exploitation. In Guangdong Province, 500,000 child laborers are estimated to be among the eight million transients in the work force.
Few analysts are surprised that people have tried to organize an independent union movement, which would be perceived as an equal if not greater challenge to the Communist leadership than the campaign for democracy and human rights.
To combat inflation, the Government has reimposed price controls on 20 basic commodities, banned all new major construction projects and outlawed wasteful investment in golf courses and racetracks. But the State Statistical Bureau reported last month that new construction projects in 1994 are running 77 percent ahead of last year's record level.
The ban on golf courses was followed by an announcement from the Billy Caspar Golf Management Inc. of Vienna, Va., that it would break ground this spring on an 18-hole golf resort in the city of Qingdao.
There have been some partial successes in reining in the overheated economy. The central bank under Deputy Prime Minister Zhu Rongji is restraining the money supply after a spree of easy credit in 1992 and 1993.
Real-estate speculation touched off by the easy-money policy is now beginning to come under control. But the construction boom remains at full throttle, contributing to the 40 percent rise in prices for cement and steel.
Some economists fear that a shift to a go-slow attitude on the economy and reform will imperil a plan to break up China's 11,000 large state-owned industries. Last fall the Communist Party's Central Committee declared that 100 large state enterprises would be picked in 1994 for conversion to Western-style corporations. At the end of the first quarter, the enterprises selected have yet to be announced.

GRAPHIC: Photo: China's leaders are worried about labor protests and other signs of instability, like huge shifts of jobless people from the countryside to the cities. By some estimates, the floating population of surplus labor exceeds 100 million. Migrant workers waited last month at a train station in Guangzhou. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Atlantic City Seeks to Lure Non-Gamblers

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY, April 8

 BODY:
As campaigns for casino gambling gather momentum in neighboring states and elsewhere in New Jersey, Atlantic City is betting that it can reinvent itself as a convention center and seaside tourist attraction.
That is brave talk for a city that has 12 mammoth casino hotels and parking garages but not a single golf course, movie house or even a supermarket. Even the best natural attraction, the ocean beach, shuts down for most of the year for swimming. 
 The chief reason people are willing to travel long distances to get here -- there were 30.2 million visits last year -- is gambling and gambling alone, industry leaders acknowledge.
"Casino operators are running scared right now, there's no question about it," said Peter G. Boynton, president and chief operating officer of Caesars Atlantic City, one of the 12 casino hotels. "There is a tremendous sense of urgency to make Atlantic City work as a tourist destination instead of just a gambling destination."
 
Fewer Visitors
 The number of visitors to the city has been declining since 1988, from 33.1 million to 30.2 million last year. The recession is mainly to blame, but analysts also say that competition from other gambling centers is beginning to take its toll. Further, a breakdown of market research reveals that the 30 million figure actually represents 7 million people who visit Atlantic City an average of 4.5 times a year, spending seven hours here on each trip.
"Day-trippers represent most of Atlantic City's business, and the casinos made so much money from them for so long that they never readied themselves for competition in the region," said State Senator Richard J. Codey, Democrat of Essex County, who helped write the bill that allowed casino gambling in Atlantic City to begin in 1978.
He said the possible introduction in the next few years of forms of casino gambling in Pennsylvania, New York and Florida could deal a serious blow not only to the resort, but also to the $230 million or so the state collects every year from an 8 percent tax on gross gambling revenue to pay for programs for the elderly and the disabled. New York and Connecticut already have casino gambling on Indian reservations.
"Up to this year the threat of competition has not been a priority in Trenton," Senator Codey said. But the proposal last month by the financier Robert E. Brennan to buy the Meadowlands Sports Complex from the state for $1 billion on the condition that casino gambling be permitted there as well as at Garden State Park, the race track his company already owns outside Camden, has brought the issue "to the front burner," he added.
There is rising sentiment in some quarters that if casinos sprout like mushrooms in neighboring states, New Jersey would be forced to expand casino gambling to the densely populated northern New Jersey and Camden areas to compete. A bill recently introduced in New Jersey calls for a state referendum on riverboat gambling if Pennsylvania or New York approve riverboat gambling.
Riverboat casinos are given an increased chance for Philadelphia after the term of Pennsylvania's Governor, Robert P. Casey, a foe of casino gambling, expires this year.
 
Casino Bill in New York
 In New York, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo remains opposed to additional gambling in the state, but the Legislature is warming up to a bill that would allow a vote on a constitutional amendment on casino gambling by November 1995 at the earliest. Opposition was softened by the opening of a casino last year near Rome, N.Y., by the Oneida Indians under a Federal provision that allows gambling on reservations, and the St. Regis Mohawk tribe near the Canadian border is moving toward its own casino.
Mr. Cuomo appeared to concede last week that the political climate was shifting in favor of some form of casino gambling in New York, though he continued to oppose it.
Atlantic City's official response to this rising competition is to point to the building of a $234 million convention center, scheduled for completion in late 1996, and the tentative approval of plans for a $500 million central corridor redevelopment that would include an entertainment complex, shops, restaurants and other attractions to draw tourists.
Whether those projects will change the city's ragged image to draw another three million convention visitors and tourists a year, as architects of the plans claim, is uncertain.
 
Outside the Casinos
 Cathy Burke hopes the city is finally on the right course to expand its allure beyond the bright lights and whimsical architecture of the mammoth casino structures. She and her husband, Dick, own and operate the Irish Pub and Inn on St. James Place, just 100 yards from the boardwalk and, beyond that, the ocean.
The Burkes opened their establishment in 1973, five years before the first casino opened. After gambling was legalized, they discovered how formidable the casinos were in not letting patrons stray far from the excitement of the gambling tables. Free drinks, meals and hotel rooms kept a short leash on visitors lest they stray off a property and end up playing at a casino a block away. Day-trippers on a budget were induced to remain on a casino property with cut-rate "all-you-can-eat" buffets and discount coupons for shows in theaters adjoining the casino floors.
Even the perception that city streets were not safe to walk, a feeling bolstered by vacant lots, crumbling housing, high crime rates and drug abuse, worked to keep patrons and their wallets inside the high-security casinos. As a result restaurants, shops and nominal tourist-related activities more than one or two blocks from the casinos either died from lack of patronage or never got started in a city that is only six blocks wide for most of its 40-block length.
 
'Have to Sell Atlantic City'
 "I'm very pro-casino, but the reality is that they don't bring people to Atlantic City as much as they bring them into the casinos," said Mrs. Burke, whose popular restaurant and bar draws heavily from the 50,000-member casino-hotel work force, the great majority of whom live outside the city of 37,000. "They haven't had to face the reality before that they have to sell Atlantic City as a seaside resort."
Mack Latz, owner of the Knife and Fork, a restaurant that has been in his family since 1927, said the city long ago fumbled a chance to develop as a convention destination because the casinos preferred keeping many of their best hotel rooms free for high rollers to tying them up far in advance for conventioneers.
"After Atlantic City got gambling, Las Vegas recognized it had to change and it became a convention center and a family tourist destination," said Mr. Latz, 77. "If they could do that in the middle of the desert, imagine what could be done here with the boardwalk and the ocean."
 
Private Investors Are Needed
 Nicholas R. Amato, executive director of the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, says that Atlantic City is already well along the road to rebirth with the corridor project and 500,000 square feet of exhibit space in the new convention hall. So far, however, the project is dependent on financing by the casinos and the state and has not yet received commitments from private investors critical to its success, other than signing up Doubletree Hotels Corporation to operate a new 600-room hotel and a few additional private vendors.
The casinos must pay Mr. Amato's agency about $40 million a year in a special tax on gambling revenue, with the money going largely for cosmetic changes and landscaping along a three-block wide gateway. But beyond that obligation it is unclear how far casinos will be willing to invest in the rest of Atlantic City as their corporate boards dig deep into their pockets to get in on the ground floor of lucrative venues opening up around the nation.
"Gambling is the business they're in," said Thomas Ballezzi, acting director of the Casino Association of New Jersey, a lobbying and promotion arm of the industry. "From that standpoint they take every opportunity to expand, just like Wal-Mart or Kmart would."
But casino operators in Atlantic City will be competing with themselves by opening new ventures in the region, torn between the allure of profitable new markets and protecting their heavily mortgaged properties here.
"It's much cheaper to invest in a riverboat somewhere than rebuild Atlantic City," said Steven P. Perskie, the chairman of the Casino Control Commission, the state casino regulatory board, who recently announced he was stepping down. "But if they do substantially broaden tourist attractions here it is my opinion Atlantic City will flourish against any expansion of riverboat gambling in the region."


GRAPHIC: Dozens of states are considering allowing some form of casino gambling to raise revenues and in anticipation of similar actions by their neighbors. Connecticut and New York already have casinos on Indian reservations, which do not come under state jurisdiction. Legislatures in the following states are focusing on gambling proposals that could eat into Atlantic City's customer base.
Chart: "THE PUSH TOWARD CASINO GAMBLING: Legislatures Consider Gambling Bills

NEW YORK
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo opposes casino gambling, but the Legislature is considering allowing a referendum on the issue. Groups and lawmakers throughout the state have proposed casinos for their areas. The Oneida Indians have a casino in Verona, near Rome, and a second casino is planned by the Mohawk tribe on the St. Regis Indian Reservation. The Legislature recently rejected a proposal for a state-run keno game.
CONNECTICUT
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s opposition has been the biggest roadblock to casino gambling, but he is not running for re-election this year. A bill approved last week by a House committee would allow dog tracks in Plainfield and Bridgeport to build casinos offering table games, but its ultimate fate is uncertain. In addition to the Mashantucket Pequot casino in Ledyard, the Mohegan tribe in Montville also plans a casino.
NEW JERSEY
Expanding casino gambling beyond Atlantic City would require a voter referendum, which would have to be passed by a three-fifths majority in both houses of the Legislature. The powerful Speaker of the Assembly, Chuck Haytaian, opposes further expansion of gambling in the state, and last year the Legislature rejected a referendum on sports betting. The financier Robert E. Brennan has proposed casino gambling at the Meadowlands and at the Garden State race track outside Camden.
PENNSYLVANIA
The State Legislature is considering a measure to permit gambling on Pennsylvania's navigable rivers and lakes, subject to state and county referendums, within two years. But approval of riverboat casinos is far from certain, since Gov. Robert P. Casey, a Democrat, has vowed to veto any casino bill he receives before his term ends next January. The bill also faces strong opposition in the Senate. Philadelphia's Mayor, Edward G. Rendell, is a leading advocate of riverboat gambling. (pg. 44)

HEADLINE: Kohl's Challenger Is Coming on Visit to Try to Reassure U.S.

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BONN, April 9

 BODY:
Rudolf Scharping, the Social Democratic challenger to Chancellor Helmut Kohl in Germany's elections on Oct. 16, is taking his campaign to the United States in the coming week, hoping to persuade President Clinton and other leaders that he will be as reliable an ally as Mr. Kohl.
"There are some people in Germany who believe that NATO could be replaced by something else," he said before his departure, distancing himself from more radical members of his party who have suggested replacing the alliance with a 52-nation European security conference instead. 
 "There are others, like the Green party, who believe NATO can be disbanded," he said, referring to the environmentalist grouping many German commentators speculate he would have to rely on for support in Parliament if he won.
"I think both views are wrong," Mr. Scharping said. "We want NATO, and we understand it to be more than just a defense alliance. It's also accomplished a great deal politically."
One of its achievements, he believes from his experience as Governor of the state of Rhineland-Palatinate, where 150,000 American soldiers and their families were stationed at the height of the cold war, is a gradual reconciliation between Germans and Americans.
Mr. Scharping, 46, was elected leader of the Social Democratic Party in June, and has concentrated on restoring the centrist image it had when it last held power, under Chancellors Willy Brandt and Helmut Schmidt, more than a decade ago.
Mr. Kohl's Christian Democrats say Mr. Scharping will be unable to escape the influence of his left wing, which since Mr. Schmidt was deposed in 1982 advocated accommodation with the Communists in eastern Europe and distanced itself from United States military policies.
Though Mr. Scharping got into trouble last month for botching an explanation of a campaign pledge to impose a 10 percent tax surcharge on higher incomes (above $35,000, not $30,000 as he said), Mr. Kohl said this week that his party would impose a 7.5 percent surcharge on all taxpayers next year for as long as it took to get the formerly Communist eastern sections of the country into decent economic shape.
The Social Democrats lead the Christian Democrats by about five percentage points in public opinion polls, but Mr. Kohl dismissed that as irrelevant six months before the elections. Both contenders insist that they will win in October.
Mr. Scharping, who speaks English, is scheduled to see Mr. Clinton in the White House on Tuesday, and said he wanted to discuss such things as the economic policies both men want to stimulate growth, create jobs and reduce budget deficits.
 
Will Visit New York
 During his talks with other officials and business representatives in New York City, Mr. Scharping also expects to be questioned about his party's opposition to German military participation in United Nations "blue helmet" peacekeeping missions that could involve the risk of combat.
The Social Democrats challenged Mr. Kohl's decision to send 1,500 German soldiers to northern Somalia last year, also arguing that the 1949 German Constitution barred German participation in military enforcement of the naval and air blockades around Bosnia. The German constitutional court is expected to rule on the issue this summer.
He said "I am for German participation in blue-helmet activities" if they are constitutional and Parliament approves. He added: "These soldiers must have the right to defend themselves and to carry out their mission. I am also for Germany's taking part in blockade actions, and if need be in their military enforcement. That describes everything the United Nations has done in recent years and will realistically be able to do in the near future."

HEADLINE: Reassessing a Dream -- A special report.;
Years on Integration Road: New Views of an Old Goal

BYLINE: By CHARISSE JONES 

 BODY:
It has been 40 years since Brown v. the Board of Education, when the United States Supreme Court set the stage for all schools to be open to all children, no matter the color of their skin. It has been 30 years since Congress passed a Civil Rights Act that banished barriers to equal access, officially ushering in an era in which blacks and whites were to live and work together.
But for many black Americans, this year of anniversaries is more a time of reflection than celebration. From the young who never knew Jim Crow, to their elders who fought to destroy discrimination, many black Americans are raising questions about what integration has done, and what it can ultimately accomplish. 
 "I think there is a growing feeling in the black community that integration is a tarnished goal," said Dr. Lawrence D. Bobo, a sociology professor and director of the Center for Research on Race, Politics and Society at the University of California at Los Angeles. "It's viewed with greater skepticism by blacks then it was in the past. That doesn't mean it's been repudiated. There's not much evidence of that. But I think the benefits of it are more often questioned and the burdens that come with it are more prominent topics of discussion than they were in the past."
A March 1993 New York Times/CBS News poll found that a majority of both blacks and whites answered yes when asked if "generally speaking," they favored full integration. But recent interviews with blacks who acknowledged that they have benefited from victories of the civil rights movement, elicited a range of views more complex than the straightforward answers to that straightforward question.
Among blacks who have worked, learned and lived in predominantly white settings, one theme occurs over and over again: such interaction has not made many whites accept blacks as equals, and perhaps never will.
"We were integration warriors," said Karen A. Phillips, who helped integrate the white high school in her hometown of Ocilla, Ga. "I chose a college and a major because I didn't know any black people who'd done it before."
"The only problem is, things opened up, but attitudes stayed the same," said Ms. Phillips, 41, and running the Abyssinian Development Corporation, which is building housing for middle- and low-income residents to help redevelop Harlem. "We thought that if they saw we were intelligent and could compete with them, things would even out. It's taken us a long time to figure out giving up your community to go to theirs doesn't mean you're going to be accepted."
 
The Balance Sheet:
The Losses And the Gains
 The last three decades have definitely yielded progress. The percentage of all black families earning incomes of $50,000 or more (as adjusted to 1992 dollars) rose from 10.2 percent in 1970 to 16 percent in 1992, according to statistics from the United States Census Bureau. But meanwhile, whites -- already ahead -- were also making gains; the proportion of white families with comparable earnings rose from 24.5 percent to 35.7 percent in the same period.
The percentage of blacks in professional or managerial jobs rose from 10 percent to 16.8 percent in the same period. And the percentage of blacks 25 to 29 years old who had completed at least four years of college more than doubled, from 6 percent in 1970 to 12.7 percent in 1989.
But as much as some things changed, others have stayed the same. The median household income for blacks compared to whites has budged little in the last 20 years, with black households in 1992 earning 58 percent of the income earned by white households -- the same as in 1972.
A Harvard study last December found that in the 1991-92 school year, 66 percent of the 6.9 million black students in the nation's public schools attended predominantly minority schools -- the highest percentage documented since 1968. (There are no comparable figures for the years before the Brown v. Board of Education decision.) Even on integrated campuses, students often do not interact across racial lines, in the classroom or outside.
Some blacks lament what they believe was lost in the quest to integrate -- black neighborhoods, etched by the confines of segregation, that forged a bond between the poor and the middle-income who lived side by side; incubators for black commerce, and support systems for black families and institutions.
They emphasize they would never give up the hard-won right to choose where, and with whom to live. But they say there is a need for blacks to regain a self-reliance that flourished when it was painfully clear how important it was that blacks be able to count on one another.
 
Remembering Jim Crow
 "I think some of the things we enjoyed when we were living among ourselves need to be recaptured," said Pamela K. Johnson, 33, who believes that integration "dissipated our energies and our economic strength."
Ms. Johnson, an editor at Essence, a black woman's magazine, lives in Harlem, the community in which she was born. "It's a choice," she said. "I could have gone in a lot of different directions. I had the intelligence and education. But I came to Harlem."
The isolation she felt working more than three years at a predominantly white newspaper in Albuquerque, N.M., helped her make her decisions. "I didn't want to use my energies to reset the priorities of that organization," she said. "I felt I wanted my time, my energy to be invested into something that was building my community."
By the time Ms. Johnson was born in New York City, the official segregation known as the Jim Crow system was on its deathbed in the South.
Nellie Hester-Bailey, 47, grew up during its reign, and remembers it well.
She was raised in Tuscaloosa, home of the University of Alabama, where a defiant George C. Wallace once stood in the doorway to prevent black students from enrolling. Mrs. Hester-Bailey carried picket signs and marched in the streets to bring an end to segregation, and said she would never want to see it return.
"It's unreal to think you could create it again," Mrs. Hester-Bailey said. "The horror of segregation, and the deadly racism that it came from, is not something I'd want anyone to go through."
Today Mrs. Hester-Bailey, the widowed mother of two sons, lives on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, in a neighborhood that reflects the multi-colored diversity of New York City. Her 14-year-old son attends Trinity School, a private school on the Upper West Side; her older son is a freshman at Harvard. She has friends of various backgrounds, she said, and her husband was white.
Describing herself as a product of "a system of parallel lives, separate but unequal," she said: "I can say that it did not damage me. I am a bit nostalgic in the sense I survived."
She remembers with some fondness a nurturing all-black universe that helped hone her self-esteem.
"We had our own doctors, our own soda shops," Mrs. Hester-Bailey said. "We didn't have the psychic pressure of feeling uncomfortable, of feeling less than. We didn't have or need a Jesse Jackson on the national level saying 'I am somebody,' because it came from our teachers, our churches, the man who ran the movie theater."
 
Age-Old Debate
Renewed Urgency Amid Change
 The discussion about whether to concentrate on enhancing one's own community or integrating into the mainstream is not a new one. From Marcus Garvey to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the two philosophies have been coexistent constants, arguments for each gaining or losing strength depending on the political and economic climate of the time.
Recently the debate has taken on renewed urgency, driven in part by a changing economy that has eliminated jobs and highlighted the need for entrepreneurship, and in part by a series of decisions by government, courts and voters that many blacks read as signals of a growing national ambivalence, or even hostility, toward the civil rights agenda of the 1960's.
Others enter the debate because of more personal experiences at work, at school, in neighborhoods.
"I think the great optimism we all had after the civil rights movement was diluted, and finally just swallowed up by experience," said Derrick Bell, the author of "Faces at the Bottom of the Well: The Permanence of Racism."
 
'A Subtle Part of Racism'
 Many blacks talk of having grown weary, saying they have endured years of slights and doubts from some white colleagues and neighbors. Many contend that interaction on purportedly equal terms has not necessarily permeated the wall of race, or led to understanding and friendship.
Marcus L. Alexis 2d, 34, who works in investment management for Bankers Trust in Manhattan, said: "I think the trend is for people to retreat back into their comfort zone. Nobody wants to subject their children or their wives or themselves to an environment where they're not wanted."
Such withdrawal disappoints him, though he says he can understand why people make that decision.
There is, he said, "a subtle part of racism that's very different from what our parents and grandparents experienced."
"The subtle part is unspoken," he said. "It's inflection, it's body language, it's all the nuances people feel that suggest 'you're not welcome here.' And that's what a lot of my friends are feeling when they decide they don't want to participate in conversations and social gatherings with white folks."
But ultimately, Mr. Alexis said he has benefited from the doors opened during the civil rights movement.
"My world is a bigger place now," he said. "It doesn't always welcome me, but it's a bigger place. And I like that, even with all the baggage that comes along with it."
 
Pursuing Choices
As Individuals And in Groups
 Another perspective on integration comes from Dr. Judy A. Miller, 65, the New Jersey director of Cities in Schools, a national dropout prevention program. Thirty years ago she picketed schools in Montclair, N.J., and with her late husband, Don, fought to integrate the neighborhood where they lived and raised their two sons.
"It was what I had to do at that time," she said. "And when I came through it, I realized that integration in many ways really hadn't happened. It happened for me. I lived a very integrated life. But the kids I deal with every day don't. It didn't happen for them and their parents."
A professor emeritus of African-American studies at Seton Hall University, Dr. Miller said she also began to see a chasm between her students and less fortunate blacks. "I hear young people talk about 'them,' their own people," she said. "They don't feel a connection."
Dr. Miller remembers that as a poor child growing up in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, she lived next door to a schoolteacher who became her godmother. "Now, those of us who are middle-class are afraid of these young people," she said. "And I find that these are young people the same as I was, hungry for somebody to talk to them and help them."
 
Coming Full Circle
 She continues to live in an integrated neighborhood, but integration is no longer a priority in her life socially or professionally, she said. "I can't integrate the thousands of kids who are in the inner city of Newark," she said. "I just want to make sure they get a good education and know responsible adults who will help them grow up and live."
Ms. Phillips, the head of the Abyssinian Development Corporation, says her life illustrates how the benefits of integration have come full circle.
She graduated from the University of Georgia, where she studied landscape architecture because she knew no blacks who had done either, and she went on to work in what she calls "corporate America."
Because of these experiences, "I'm more fulfilled with what I do now," she said. "It's a fulfillment of what that whole cycle of integration meant. I was able to obtain skills that help me do what I do for my community."
With time has come a recognition that integration all too often meant blacks meeting whites on whites' terms, she said. "The whole pretense of integration was 'white was right,' that it can only be good if it's from that culture," she said. "And now we're getting to accept who we are, and saying 'No, I don't have to go somewhere else to get the better things in life.' "
Brumsic Brandon 3d, 37, helped integrate schools in Westbury, L.I., as a child. When it came time to find a neighborhood in which to raise their 2-year-old daughter and 5-year-old son, he and his wife knew what they wanted: safety, good schools and a middle-class neighborhood that was predominantly black.
"I didn't want them to become pioneers in a community where they would be odd people to their classmates, or their classmates would be ignorant of our people," Mr. Brandon said.
Saying that he wanted his children to have their cultural pride reinforced when they dealt with their neighbors, he added, "I'd like to limit the forces that work against that."
The family settled a year ago in Columbia, Md., a suburban community between Baltimore and Washington.
But even as some blacks are choosing to live and work in places that are not integrated, civil rights groups continue to fight for their right to make the opposite choice.
Michael Meyers, executive director of the New York Civil Rights Coalition, said: "To overcome institutional racism and sexism, you can't settle on a strategy of retreat and withdrawal and cynicism. If there's nobody pressing against the gates, it's only going to get worse."
For some civil rights organizations, as well as many black individuals, the answer is pursuing dual priorities: integration as well as other strategies aimed at improving the lives of the nation's nearly 32 million blacks, who make up more than 12 percent of the country's population.
Theodore M. Shaw, 39, associate director counsel for the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc., the nation's oldest civil rights law firm, said: "I'm not willing to say we're not committed to desegregating public schools where we can accomplish that. But we're not simply pursuing the mixing of bodies -- integration for integration's sake. There are other values that we also think are important."
Frank Lomax, acting president of the National Urban League, said, "We cannot give up on a goal of a pluralistic, integrated society, and the civil rights community has to continue to keep that goal in sight."
Despite tremendous advancement for blacks during the last few decades, Mr. Lomax said, there is still much to be done, and black Americans must continue to concentrate on helping themselves, especially their children. "I think we have to identify the resources we have and mobilize them to solve our problems," he said. "You can call it self-help if you want, but it's not new. And we have to accelerate it."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Plenty of Ammunition In Salary Cap Battle

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
After the first negotiating session between labor representatives of the owners and the players last month, Richard Ravitch made a comment that attracted virtually no notice but most likely signaled an important element of the owners' strategy as the talks for a new labor agreement proceed.
Noting that reporters always write about differences among the owners, Ravitch, the owners' chief labor executive, said: "I can't believe that with what is happening in the game that there aren't differences of opinion among players. Guys who were making millions of dollars last year aren't." 
 Translation: With a mushrooming number of veteran players being forced to accept relatively meager salaries if they want to continue playing, these longtime union members can't be pleased with economic developments and would fare significantly better under a salary cap.
Strategy: Emphasize the economic disparity with increasing frequency in an effort to divide and conquer. Drive a wedge between the stars making the big money and the growing segment of veterans facing vastly reduced wages or no jobs at all.
Ravitch has plenty of ammunition to use in his salary cap campaign if he pursues that strategy.
 
Drastic Cuts for Some
 Jack Morris, for example, is pitching for the Cleveland Indians for a base salary of $350,000 after having earned a career-high $5,425,000 last season. Bobby Thigpen has a $200,000 base salary with the Seattle Mariners, a mere pittance compared with his $3,416,667 income last year. Rick Sutcliffe, now with St. Louis, is earning one-tenth the $2.5 million he made last year.
In all, 29 players who earned $1 million or more last season have base salaries below $1 million this season, and other players have seen their salaries fall through the millions but not plummet lower than $1 million.
"It's disappointing, but there's nothing you can do about it," said Jeff Reardon, who only two years after a career-high $2,666,667 has a $250,000 base salary with the Yankees. "It's either take that salary or go home. I made that in 1982. Here it is 1994. On the other hand, you can't make that anywhere else. If you feel you can still play, you'll play for nothing."
Now there's an idea the owners would leap at.
Jay Howell, whose salary has reached $805,000 after peaking at $2,575,000 in 1992, said the clubs' practice of reducing veterans' pay has long existed. "You're just seeing it more now because the salaries are higher," the Texas Rangers' relief pitcher said. "There's a bigger decrease."
Anyway, he added, players who have earned millions in recent times aren't necessarily hanging around in the hopes of making more millions.
 
'Not in It for Money'
 Citing Reardon, Howell said: "He's not in it for money. He's made enough money. He's in it to win a championship."
When Howell's comment was related to Reardon, the veteran reliever said: "That's exactly why I'm here. The veterans want to get a ring. I made my money. Sure, I'd like to make more, but it's no big deal."
Howell noted that salary disparity exists in "all sorts of jobs." "You have to be realistic," he said. "If you're a starter, you're paid like a starter. If you're a second or third-tier player, you're not going to get the money."
As well as Howell and Reardon rationalize the development of the veterans' salary slash, players are not thrilled with it. Not that they can't live nicely on a few hundred thousand, but they feel they deserve more. The owners, on the other hand, probably shouldn't count on that feeling to influence the players' view of a salary cap or the possibility of their acting against the best interests of their union.
"I don't feel that will ever happen," said Chris James, an eight-year veteran who has a $500,000 salary with the Rangers. "We're strong as a unit. I can't see anybody turning against what we're trying to do. It's going to be important for us to stick together.
"That's part of the owners' ploy, to try to split the high-salaried players and the lower-paid players. They want to create a rift. But the players know the situation, what it would mean if a handful of players started griping. The players are unified regardless of what you make."
 
A Most Grateful Big Leaguer
 No one who won a major league job in spring training this year felt what Bill Taylor did when Tony La Russa, the Oakland manager, told him before the last exhibition game that he had made the team.
"He said keep it silent, don't tell anybody because he had to tell other guys they didn't make it," Taylor related. "I understood that. I've been there. But it was hard for me to keep from smiling and glowing. After 14 years, when someone comes up and tells you you made the big league club, how can you not show excitement? But I did a good job."
A relief pitcher who now is 32 years old, Taylor labored for the past 14 seasons in the minor leagues without ever getting a chance to pitch in the majors. He thought he had pitched well enough last spring to earn a seat in the Toronto bullpen, but when the Blue Jays went north he wasn't with them.
"You think you'll be on the team," Taylor said, "but just before the bus is leaving, he tells you you're not going to be on that bus."
This time, though, Taylor made the bus and the team. He also made it into each of the Athletics' first three games, facing nine batters and retiring all of them, including Dave Winfield and Matt Walbeck of Minnesota with the tying run at third base in the 10th inning Friday night. Four of the hitters batted left-handed, creating an early test for the right-handed reliever.
"We have only one left-hander in the bullpen," Taylor explained. "One of the things they're looking for me to do is go out and get left-handers out."
Taylor's new status means a new life style for his wife, Lisa, and their 5-year-old daughter, Logan. The women in the family traveled from their home in Thomasville, Ga., to Minneapolis Friday to join Taylor, and they plan to make other trips as well.
"My family stayed with me through all the frustration," he said. "Whatever we've been through, my wife never told me to quit playing ball. She said, you'll know when it's time; I'll support you as much as I can."
 
Mercker Remains a Realist
 Kent Mercker was talking about his role in the Atlanta Braves' pitching rotation. As the fifth starter in a renowned four-man rotation, he could face pressure to keep up with his four colleagues or he could be ignored because all of the attention is on them.
"It's not realistic for me to win 20 games," Mercker said one day in spring training. "At most, I could get 24 starts. I'm not saying if I had 36 starts, I'd win 20. The pressure is on them. They're expected to win games. I don't think there are great expectations about me."
Oh no? Why wouldn't the expectations be great when a pitcher makes 12 starts in the major leagues and two of them become no-hitters.
In the most recent of his 12 starts, which have been spread over six seasons, Mercker pitched a no-hitter Friday night against the Los Angeles Dodgers. In his third start, which occurred Sept. 11, 1991, he pitched the first six innings of a three-pitcher no-hitter against the San Diego Padres.
Despite his remarkable record, the 26-year-old right-hander knows his place.
"I know any time there are off days or rainouts, I'll be bypassed," Mercker said. "But I was going nine days between relief appearances so I'm used to the delay. If you're a long man, you don't have much of a job on this team. These guys will go six, seven, eight innings every time. I definitely want to start."
Mercker shouldn't have any problem holding onto that role. Whether or not he can maintain his no-hit pace is another matter.
 
Home-Run Firsts
 Joe Carter and Bill Mazeroski are linked in World Series history because they are the only two players who have ended a World Series with a home run. Mazeroski did it in 1960, Carter last year.
Now Carter and Ray Lankford are linked in an even rarer way. Last Sunday night, when Lankford began the St. Louis Cardinals' game against the Cincinnati Reds with a home run against Jose Rijo, it completed a first in baseball history. It marked the first time home runs have ended a World Series one season and started the opening game of the next season.
What happened in the first game of the 1961 season? Leading off for the Chicago White Sox against the Washington Senators 33 years ago today, Luis Aparicio walked.

HEADLINE: OUTDOORS;
The Blues Dwindle Down to a Precious Few Along Atlantic

BYLINE: By Nelson Bryant 

 BODY:
The powerful, rapacious bluefish -- the most important species in the marine recreational fishing industry from Cape Cod to Virginia -- is on the decline all along the Atlantic seaboard.
Those who began angling for bluefish 15 years ago chose a good time to do so. From then until about 1990, the fish were abundant, and many large specimens, 15 pounds and more, were present. In 1979, the total recreational catch along the Atlantic coast was more than 140 million pounds. It dropped to 86 million pounds in 1984, rose to nearly 130 million pounds in 1986 and has been declining ever since, falling to 37 million pounds in 1992. Landing figures for 1993 are not yet available, but there is every reason to believe that the downward trend is continuing. 
 The bluefish is a migratory species that spawns in the open ocean, with the young, or snappers, seeking the sanctuary of sounds, bays and estuaries, including salt ponds, to escape being eaten by other species as well as their own parents.
Over the last 200 years and more, bluefish have gone through cycles of scarcity and plenty, particularly in the northern portion of their range, from Long Island to Maine. Bruce Freeman, a research scientist with the New Jersey Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife, says that from about 1750 to 1770, bluefish were so scarce off Long Island that when they returned in good numbers, people didn't know what they were.
In their "Fishes of the Gulf of Maine," a 1953 publication of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, Henry Bigelow and William Schroeder noted that bluefish were plentiful off southern New England in colonial times, but had virtually disappeared about 1764, "not to reappear there until about 1810. From that time on they increased in abundance west and south of Cape Cod, but none was reported north of the Cape until 1837."
By the 1870's, bluefish were swarming throughout the northernmost portion of their range, but in the early 1900's they were once again in short supply, with their numbers increasing again in 1927. This petered out again, and in 1946, according to Bigelow and Schroeder, blues were so scarce that the total catch for the Gulf of Maine and the southern Massachusetts coast was only about 1,200 pounds.
There is no question that bluefish stocks have fluctuated widely over the centuries. Clearly, natural causes play a major role in this, if only because many such fluctuations took place before man's harvesting of the species became significant. Among the natural causes are changes in water temperature. Bluefish favor water between 66 and 72 degrees Fahrenheit. Depletion of forage species favored by bluefish -- such as menhaden, sea herring and sand eels -- and bad spawning years are also factors. Spawning success was poor in 1986 and 1987, and the lowest on record in 1988.
Before World War II, periodic declines in bluefish stocks had no major economic effect on the coastal states from Massachusetts to Virginia. Since the late 1940's, however, triggered by greater affluence and more leisure time, a saltwater sport fishing industry whose total economic impact is estimated at billions of dollars has evolved along the Atlantic coast. This includes surf fishermen, those who own their own boats and those who go out on charter or party boats.
In the Middle Atlantic Bight -- roughly from Montauk to Virginia -- the bluefish has been the backbone of this industry, even though in some areas at certain times, the summer flounder, or fluke, and the northern weakfish might get more attention. In the past several years, severe restrictions on the sport and commercial harvesting of striped bass has resulted in that species making an astonishing and welcome comeback from a record low, and last year along some areas of the coast, including southern Massachusetts, it was easier to catch a striper than a blue. There is every reason to believe that bluefish will be scarce in New England waters in 1994.
In 1990, the Mid-Atlantic Fishery Management Council and the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission devised a bluefish management plan for the entire Atlantic coast, from Maine to Florida. In essence, the plan called for a 10-fish-a-day limit for sport fishermen. It also, to simplify somewhat, limits the commercial catch to 20 per cent of the total (recreation plus commercial) landings. Should it appear that the commercial catch for a coming season is going to exceed that percentage, the participating states would impose quotas on their commercial fisheries. Most of the coastal states went along with the plan.

HEADLINE: In America;
Abandoning Democracy

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Under violent attack throughout Haiti, the struggling but unsubdued peasant organizations, representing 80 percent of the country's population, are making it clear that they are no longer fooled by the ruses and false promises of the Clinton Administration.
"President Clinton's position on Haiti is one that I would not even say is ambiguous," declared Chavannes Jean-Baptiste, leader of the Peasant Movement of Papay, Haiti's oldest and largest nongovernmental organization. "His position is very clear. It's consistent with a policy that does not want the restoration of democracy in Haiti. Nor does it want the restoration of Aristide as President." 
 The Haitian peasantry has been -- and continues to be -- ruthlessly exploited by the Haitian elite and by foreign governments and commercial interests, especially in the U.S. When democracy came to Haiti in the form of free and fair elections in December 1990, the peasants were overjoyed by their seemingly miraculous opportunity to go to the polls and vote for whomever they pleased.
United States officials had hoped that in the presidential balloting the Haitians would elect Marc Bazin, a smooth, well-educated technocrat who could be counted upon to restrain the surging aspirations of the poverty-stricken masses. After all, getting the right to vote is one thing, but making serious economic and social headway at the expense of the business elite -- both foreign and domestic -- is quite something else.
The peasants may be uneducated, but they are not stupid. They had no use for Mr. Bazin. They wanted real change. They wanted the man who had been with them all along and who spoke directly to their needs, who promised to end the violence and corruption of Duvalierism and to fight for land reform, and for an increase in the minimum wage to 50 cents an hour. They wanted the little priest they called, with great affection, "Titid."
When the balloting was through, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide had gotten a remarkable 67 percent of the vote in a field of 11 candidates. Having spoken, the poor people of Haiti exploded in celebration, dancing and singing in the streets, and exclaiming over and over: "Communique! Communique! Titid is President!"
The celebration has long since ended and a hideous wave of repression has once again rolled over Haiti. New paramilitary terror squads, successors to the dreaded Tontons Macoute, roam the cities and the countryside, thieving, raping and killing with impunity. The cruel system of section chiefs, local administrators with life-and-death power over peasants, has been reinstated. It had been abolished by Father Aristide.
Advances made over several years by the Peasant Movement of Papay and other organizations are being systematically destroyed. Citing just one example, Mr. Jean-Baptiste said that tens of thousands of trees planted by peasants to halt disastrous soil erosion were being destroyed by the military as part of its overall assault on the peasantry.
"They said that the trees were Communist," said Mr. Jean-Baptiste.
Grain and other commodities stored by peasants have been looted by the military. There has been widespread destruction of livestock. Working conditions, always poor, have deteriorated. The official minimum wage is 35 cents an hour, but it is common for Haitians to work for as little as 14 cents an hour.
Thousands of peasant leaders have gone into hiding to escape arrest and torture. Many others have been killed.
"It is worse," said Mr. Jean-Baptiste, "than it ever was under Duvalier."
The interests of the vast majority of Haitians, on the one hand, and the alliance of the United States Government and American businesses on the other, are different. And so the Clinton Administration -- in its actions, if not its words -- has abandoned Father Aristide and his followers and sided with the murderous enemies of democracy in Haiti. The Administration's goal is twofold: to maintain the gruesome exploitation of cheap Haitian labor by big American companies, and -- at all costs -- to keep Haitian refugees out of this country.
It is an infamous policy that will be damned in the cold light of history.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHELSEA;
Gay Businesses Follow Influx of Gay People

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE 

 BODY:
On May 1, A Different Light will move from the West Village to 151 West 19th Street between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue.
That the company, a focal point in gay literary circles, decided to move its flagship store to Chelsea seems to confirm what local residents have observed in recent months: that Chelsea has become a magnet for gay businesses, which were once centered in the West Village. 
 New businesses are moving in, and older ones are migrating. In the past year, citing space, safety and economic considerations, at least a dozen new businesses run by gays or lesbians, or that cater mostly to a gay market, have set up shop in the area from Avenue of the Americas to Ninth Avenue and between 13th and 23d Streets. The attraction has been growing for several years.
"Chelsea has become the gay neighborhood because gays and lesbians feel comfortable here," said Richard Laermer, author of "The Gay and Lesbian Handbook to New York City," due out in bookstores on April 25. "Stores and restaurants are coming in because they want to be among their own and they know their own have money to spend."
Tim Gay, co-chairman of Community Board 4's quality of life committee, said gay people had been moving into Chelsea in growing numbers since the 70's because it is "quiet, congenial, moderately priced and safe." Businesses, he said, are now coming for the same reasons.
Police statistics show that the West Village's gay-bias incidents outnumbering Chelsea's by far.
A Different Light's main reason for moving was space, said Walter Vatter, the marketing director. The old location had 800 square feet; the new one covers 5,000 square feet, with room for browsing, special events and a cafe to open in September. "That kind of affordable space cannot be found in the Village," he said.
It was Chelsea's affluent gay professionals and young couples that appealed to John Blair, co-owner of the new American Fitness on Eighth Avenue at 17th Street. And the gyms and body-conscious people drew Raymond Dragon, a unisex clothier, says Tim Cass, the manager.
Several major gay organizations, like Gay Men's Health Crisis and the Gay and Lesbian Anti-Violence Project, are based in Chelsea, providing "a strong sense of community," Mr. Gay said
As the gay population has grown, so has the number of local people with AIDS. Michael Kaminer, a spokesman for the APP Community Pharmacy, which opened last month, said it was "designed for people with AIDS and H.I.V."
Even the Gay Games IV has set up its New York headquarters in the Chelsea area. Marlin Collingwood, a spokesman, says the group also expects to open a shop with memorabilia next month -- "on Eighth Avenue, of course." MARVINE HOWE

HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK;
The Dog Ate It

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
THERE'S the dog that decided to chew up the electric bill. The family that couldn't return its library books because of the children's busy social schedules. And the man who had no choice but to double-park his car. (He had to go to the bathroom.)
In thousands of conversations around the city each day, a battle of wits is waged between those who owe and those who must collect, between those who pitch excuses and those who decide whether they are telling the truth. 
 The people who spend their day sizing up excuses are not a special breed of hard-boiled skeptics, as one might expect. In fact, some have fairly soft hearts, and most have even retained a sense of humor, although they are quick to point out that they weren't born yesterday.
"Sometimes you know they are not telling the truth," says Jackie Antoine, a customer service representative for Con Ed, who spends most of her eight-hour workday listening to excuses. "Some people come in every month and tell you their grandmother died. Or they didn't get the bill, or coffee spilled on the bill. Or their boss wouldn't give them the day off to pay the bill. One gentleman really told me that the dog ate the bill."
Ms. Antoine has spent 13 years listening to such offerings in person from people who can't seem to pay for their gas and electricity. From her desk in a customer-service center at 1555 Third Avenue in Manhattan, where soft rock music is piped in to soothe potentially savage consumers, she listens to constant tales of woe intended to stave off the utility at least for the moment.
She tells of a man who has presented a steady stream of excuses over the last year and a half. "This month he's taking care of his grandmother and has to pay her Con Ed bill," Ms. Antoine said. "The month before he had to send his daughter to California because he was having a custody fight with his wife. Before that he was going through the divorce. I've gotten his entire life story through his excuses for not paying the bill."
In general, Con Ed does not accept explanations, only money. But the company will bend before certain excuses. If a customer can show some dire personal circumstance -- like a death in the family or financial hardship -- the company will try to work out a payment plan or give advice about city agencies or charities that might be helpful, Ms. Antoine said. Con Ed employees have brought in old coats to help clients who were clearly needy, she added, and she frequently asks customers to sing along with her to the music wafting through her office.
"We are allowed to be human beings here," she said. "As a matter of fact, it's encouraged in these economic times."
Library-book borrowers lob all kinds of excuses, a patently unnecessary act in a realm where lateness is punished, regardless of the reason, at the rate of 15 cents a day. "There are people who, when you see them, you think, 'Oh, God, what is it going to be today,' " said Marsha Spyros, the New York Public Library's East Side regional librarian. "We have one reader who has an incredible string of sob stories that involve virtually every member of her family and divorce and drugs and serious illness, although we've never seen any evidence of it."
There are people who claim the weather interfered, trapping them in their apartments, or blame lateness on their children's schedules, or say traveling to Europe prevented them from returning their books. Then there are the people who fall into a separate category, Ms. Spyros said. "They are people who should be buying their books, not borrowing them," she said. "They are the ones who find it hard to be separated from books. They don't renew books, they just keep them."
Being the bad guy is stressful under such circumstances, she said. The worst punishment at her disposal is taking away someone's library privileges. "There is a woman who burst into tears one day because I insisted that she had to pay some of her fines. She said, 'I can either eat or pay my fines.' So there's a very heavy burden of guilt on us."
Judy Hensen also hears her share of excuses as manager of the Department of Transportation's Borough Help Center in Brooklyn. It's the place where people go to pay the city or (most of the time) to plead not guilty after receiving parking tickets, blaming unreasonable laws, enforced by meter maids and their male counterparts. The city's voluminous parking regulations entitle drivers to hearings, where excuses can actually be helpful if presented to judges who preside inside hearing rooms at the center.
The manager's office, however, is often the first stop. "A lot of times, they want us to tell them whether it's a good excuse," Ms. Hensen said, as an angry man with a sheaf of violations stood before her constructing a complicated tale about a wife with cancer, a case of mistaken identity and something about driving to Mexico. "We tell them, 'Tell the judge. Tell the judge.' " When the moon is full, she added, people tend to come in and scream their excuses.
Many of the excuses are predictable: "I didn't see the sign," or "I wasn't driving the car." And others seem to stem from the belief that New Yorkers have a divine right to park -- whether or not there is a legitimate space for the car. "There was no other place to park," a man named Roosevelt was telling one judge on a recent afternoon in one of the help center's 12 hearing rooms. He was trying to wriggle out of a $55 double-parking fine. He failed.
Another defendant, an elderly man in zippered galoshes and a tweed roadster cap, dragged a large black briefcase up to the bench. "I take a lot of medication, which I have with me," he told the judge, Edward Koppell, opening the case to release a cascade of pill bottles and other pharmaceutical products. "One of the pills I take is a diuretic. I had to go to the bathroom, so I parked the car. I left my wife in the car, and she was unable to move it."
The judge, a 15-year veteran, took some sympathy and reduced the fine. The man shuffled away, briefcase in hand and the tiniest smile on his lips.
All judges in the help center (there is one in every borough) are lawyers, and all must have practiced for at least five years before signing up for the parking bench. The experience helps them assess whether a person's excuse, however farfetched, is to be believed.
Many are not. "We had one woman the other day, who was absolutely crazy," Ms. Hensen said. "She said she was driving the car and her 13-year-old daughter was with her. She told the judge she thought her daughter had jumped out of the car, so she pulled over and the cop gave her a ticket for double parking. This was in Canarsie. She told the judge she wasn't double-parked, she was under the car, looking for her daughter." The woman was found guilty, Ms. Hensen said.
And yes, the old dog excuse gets unleashed here, too. "I had a lady whose license plate was mutilated," said Bert Berkow, another judge, "and she claimed her pit bull ate it."

GRAPHIC: Photos: "A lot of times, they want us to tell them whether it's a good excuse," said Judy Henson of the Transportation Department.; "Some people come in every month and tell you their grandmother died," said Jackie Antoine, a Con Ed representative. Chart: "DON'T EVEN TRY: A Guide to Bad Excuses"
 Here are excuses that don't work, excuse-takers say.
 
"THE DOG ATE THE . . . " (BILL, TICKET, LIBRARY BOOK, ETC.) Why it won't work: Too many people have exploited it, and even dogs draw the line sometimes.
 
"I DIDN'T SEE THE SIGN." Why it wont work: You're suposed to look for the sign. Although if you can prove that there was no sign, you may win your case.
 
" I DIDN'T KNOW THERE WAS A LAW AGAINST THAT." Why it won't work: Ignorance is no excuse, once you're an adult.
 
"I HAD NO CHOICE." (Frequently cited as a reason for illegally parking a car.) Why it won't work: You did have a choice.
 
"I FORGOT." Why it won't work: The lamest excuse of all.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Tax Free Doesn't Mean Risk Free

BYLINE: By Carole Gould 

 BODY:
MILLIONS of mutual fund investors are buying municipal bond funds for the tax-free income, which looks better and better as tax rates keep creeping higher.
But the tax break is not a measure of safety, and the risks in muni bond funds have come sharply into focus in 1994. While muni shares keep throwing off income, they lost 6.2 percent of their value in the first quarter, more than any other type of bond fund. 
 All bond funds suffered from rising interest rates, but munis were especially hard hit. Some think that may have been caused by muni fund managers dumping bonds to prepare for redemptions, which have so far been mild.
While $257 billion was stashed in muni funds in 1993, there were only small net outflows the last two months, according to AMG Data Services of Arcata, Calif.
The losses have brought home what has always been the question confronting muni investors: "Should you accept a smaller yield and leave your principal intact, or go for a higher yield and accept the risk to your principal?" said Anthony J. Ogorek, an investment adviser in Buffalo.
To illustrate, Mr. Ogorek gives the example of a client with $116,000 worth of muni bond fund shares, in addition to regular munis and equities, who needed the monthly income but was concerned about rising interest rates.
Last year, her muni funds were split between Vanguard Intermediate-Term Municipal Bond Fund ($69,000), which yielded 4.82 percent, and the Vanguard New York Insured Tax-Free Fund ($47,000), which yielded 5.07 percent. The mix produced an annual tax-free income of $5,709, or $476 a month.
That mix worked well in 1993. Because of falling interest rates that created capital appreciation for bondholders, the Intermediate-Term fund returned 11.49 percent, and the New York Insured fund gained 13.01 percent.
But that has changed in 1994, as the Federal Reserve has bumped up short-term interest rates. As a result, Mr. Ogorek's client saw the value of her investments fall. The share price of the Intermediate-Term fund dropped more than 4 percent in the first quarter, to $12.92. The share price of the New York Insured fund lost more than 7 percent, to $10.36.
One solution in this situation is to shorten the maturities of muni bond funds. The longer the time until a bond matures, the more sharply it reacts to interest-rate changes.
The most accurate way to measure this reaction is against a bond's "duration," which takes into account its term, its coupon and other factors that affect its response to rate shifts. The formula is simple: bonds lose the same percentage of value as their duration for every percentage-point rise in rates.
For instance, Vanguard's Long-Term New York Muni Bond Fund has a duration of 7.4 years plus a yield of 5.07 percent. If interest rates rose one percentage point, investors would see the share price fall 7.4 percent, more than offsetting the 5.07 percent yield.
By contrast, Vanguard's Short-Term New York Muni Bond Fund has a duration of only 1.2 years and yields 3.15 percent. Should interest rates rise one percentage point, investors would see the share price fall 1.2 percent, but would still make money because of the 3.15 percent yield.
Because his client was skittish about possibly losing even more money, Mr. Ogorek revised her portfolio on March 17. He kept the Intermediate-Term fund, yielding 4.82 percent with a duration of 5.1 years. But he sold the New York Insured fund, investing $27,000 of the proceeds in Vanguard's Short-Term New York Muni Fund, yielding 3.15 percent, and $20,000 in the Lindner Dividend Fund, an income fund. Lindner owns high-dividend stocks and yields 6.38 percent.
The result: annual income thrown off by the Intermediate-Term fund ($3,326), the Short-Term fund ($851) and the Lindner fund ($1,276) totals $5,453, or $454 a month. This reduces her monthly income by $22, or $46 if taxes on the national muni and Lindner funds are taken into account, assuming a Federal rate of 15 percent plus a New York rate of 5 percent. But restructuring makes the portfolio much less vulnerable to inflation.
The original portfolio would have lost 5.5 percent of its value so far this year as interest rates rose. Had the revised portfolio been in place since January, it would have dropped 3.1 percent in value. The switch so far may have thus cost $552 in lost income ($46 a month multiplied by 12), but it has saved 2.4 percent of the portfolio's principal, amounting to $2,784, Mr. Ogorek figured.
Another alternative, Mr. Ogorek said, would be an all-muni strategy, using Vanguard's Municipal Limited-Term Fund instead of Lindner. However, this option would provide $24 less income monthly than the Lindner option, or a total of $70 a month less than Mr. Ogorek's client would have had if the portifolio had not been revised at all. More important, more principal is lost, $3,712 versus $3,596.
Making such moves today would not put a permanent dent in your income stream if interest rates level off. Once that happens, you can bolster yields by moving money into the longer-term muni funds again and possibly pick up capital gains as interest rates decline, Mr. Ogorek said.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 24, 1994, Sunday
