HEADLINE: THE NATION;
How a Ruling on Abortion Took On a Life of Its Own

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
SUPREME Court Justices can usually time their own departures, as Justice Harry A. Blackmun did with grace and good humor last week. "I know what the numbers are, and it's time," the 85-year-old Justice said in announcing his decision to leave the Court this summer after 24 years.
But Justices have no such control over their legacy, and as Justice Blackmun has long acknowledged, he will always be known by one of the earliest Supreme Court opinions to bear his signature: Roe v. Wade, the 1973 decision that established the constitutional right to abortion. With passion and pride, he embraced and defended his handiwork as it came under sustained attack from all sides: from abortion opponents, obviously, but also from critics who, while supporting rights as a matter of policy, viewed the opinion as an example of judicial overreaching, weak in its constitutional theory and mired in detail about the stages of pregnancy and other matters best left to legislatures. 
 In the end, Roe v. Wade took on a life of its own, evolving into something so in tune with the ideals of the American mainstream that even conservative Republican Justices, who almost surely would not have joined the original Roe v. Wade majority, would not repudiate it.
Harry Blackmun alone could not have preserved Roe v. Wade. As the decision's margin of support dwindled -- from the original 7-to-2 to 6-to-3 and then to 5-to-4 -- on a Court reshaped by two Presidents who vowed to see the precedent wiped off the books, the likelihood that Roe v. Wade would outlast its author appeared remote. Of the seven members of the majority in 1973, only Justice Blackmun remained by 1991. All the others had been replaced by Republican Presidents. The momentum against the decision seemed unstoppable.
And yet Justice Blackmun is retiring and Roe v. Wade is still the law. More precisely, it is still the law as somewhat redefined at the margins by a trio of Republican Justices whose suprising opinion two years ago in Planned Parenthood v. Casey reaffirmed what they called the "central principle" and "essential holding" of Roe v. Wade: "the woman's right to terminate her pregnancy before viability."
While the 1992 decision left unresolved questions, that basic premise appears to be settled. Harry Blackmun will leave the Court with his legacy secure. How, against all the apparent odds, did Roe v. Wade survive?
One answer may be that there are two Roe v. Wades, the one he announced for the Court in 1973 and the one that it became, occupying a special place in the social fabric beyond the expectations of those who received it, with relief, anger or disdain, 21 years ago.
A comment from Justice Blackmun himself at the White House news conference announcing his retirement underscored, almost certainly inadvertently, the full dimension of the opinion's evolution. Asked to explain the decision's continuing importance, he said: "I think it's a step that had to be taken as we go down the road toward the full emancipation of women."
Yet in the 53 pages of the original opinion, there is scarcely a passage that could be distilled into a rallying cry for the emancipation of women. Unwanted motherhood "may force upon the woman a distressful life and future," the opinion stated. "Mental and physical health may be taxed by child care." The "continuing stigma of unwed motherhood may be involved."
The premise of the opinion was that unwanted pregnancy presents women with potential medical and social problems that "the woman and her responsible physician necessarily will consider in consultation" when deciding how to proceed. The point of view, reflecting Justice Blackmun's sympathy for the medical profession developed during a decade as general counsel to the Mayo Clinic, was that of a doctor seeking the ability to exercise informed medical judgment about a patient's problem without government intrusion.
 
The Justice From Mayo
 "Harry Blackmun was speaking as the Justice from Mayo," said David J. Garrow, the historian and author of a new book on the roots of Roe v. Wade, "Liberty & Sexuality" (Macmillan). "What Roe meant has changed over the years and we have to understand that Blackmun's understanding of Roe has changed as well. He began speaking for women and not for doctors."
This sentence -- "The ability of women to participate equally in the economic and social life of the Nation has been facilitated by their ability to control their reproductive lives" -- is not from Roe v. Wade. It is from the plurality opinion in Planned Parenthood v. Casey written jointly by Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Anthony M. Kennedy and David H. Souter. Given that the Casey opinion provides the current definition of Roe v. Wade, the sentence marks the place on the American landscape to which the original opinion has migrated. Roe v. Wade survived, perhaps, by transcending itself.
Those who oppose the right to abortion and who regard Roe v. Wade as an exercise in illegitimate judicial power tend to explain its survival in terms of politics.
"The single biggest reason that Roe v. Wade is the law of the land today is the November 1986 Senate election," said Clarke Forsythe, vice president and general counsel of Americans United for Life, a leading advocacy group. In that election, Democrats recaptured the Senate, which they had lost in the Reagan landslide of 1980, and made it possible to defeat the Supreme Court nomination of Robert H. Bork in 1987. Had Judge Bork been on the Court five years later instead of Anthony M. Kennedy, President Reagan's eventual choice for the vacancy, the 5-to-4 vote in the Casey decision would almost surely have been to overturn Roe v. Wade rather than preserve it.
But the defeat of Judge Bork could, at most, have bought only a few years for the pro-choice side had the public disliked Roe v. Wade enough to make its reversal a priority at the polls. Six months after the Casey decision, Bill Clinton was elected President, and barely six months after that, with his choice of Ruth Bader Ginsburg to succeed Justice Byron R. White, the margin of support for the right to abortion grew to 6-to-3.
"In the end, the power of courts is the power of persuasion," said Walter Dellinger, a Duke University law professor who is now an assistant attorney general. "Their opinions are only successful if they are consistent with the deepest movements in society."
Mr. Dellinger, a strong advocate of abortion rights, continued: "Roe v. Wade is like an old Dick Tracy cartoon -- it's shot full of holes but it's still standing. Blackmun had the instinct for the right result. It was picked apart by law professors, but it turns out that the reasoning of Roe appeared much more thin and brittle at the time than it does now. The more that women came to be seen as full moral agents, with rights against intrusion from the state, the more it has seemed to tap into a deep anti-totalitarian principle that's embedded in our notion of liberty.
"That's where we've come since 1973," he said.

LENGTH: 1933 words

HEADLINE: Efficiency, Not Ego, Gives Edge to a Design Firm

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
AT first, M. Arthur Gensler Jr. ran into a wall with his company's plans to transform a 600,000-square-foot Bank of America data center here into attractive office space four years ago.
The plans were rejected by Dan Costello, head of corporate real estate for the bank in San Francisco, who called them "grandiloquent," and said he wanted a no-frills, quality design. He set the cost at $35 million, or $60 a square foot, for the entire job, including furniture and telecommunications equipment, which he acknowledged was "an extremely tight budget." 
 The task facing Gensler & Associates Architects, the country's biggest interior design firm, was indeed daunting: The bank's 40-year-old, precast concrete building was dark and mundane. But Mr. Gensler's designers found a way. They punched a triangular hole in the center of the seven-story structure and added an atrium to bring in natural light. They saved money on electrical wiring and computer cables, while also breaking up the floor space, by running new lines through a network of four-foot-high walls. And they used recycled or existing furniture and materials wherever possible.
Mr. Gensler's designers "swallowed their egos and brought the project in on budget," Mr. Costello said. "And they gave me what I wanted." Mr. Costello has since given Gensler five more renovation jobs.
At a time when more companies are rethinking the amount of office space they need -- part of a corporate downsizing trend that has hammered the commercial building and real estate markets, along with many architectural and interior design companies -- Gensler has continued to grow.
One reason, industry experts say, is that in a profession dominated by a few superstars and many large egos, Gensler has made its clients' business needs the top priority. And toward that end, Gensler has become a leader in helping companies develop smaller, more efficient space outfitted with the latest office technology, either because the clients are still downsizing or are looking for new quarters as the economy improves.
Gensler's annual billings rose by 6 percent, to $80 million, in 1993, a year in which it opened six new offices in the United States and added 85 employees. The firm has 640 designers, architects and support staff members at 14 offices in the United States and abroad. By contrast, revenues as a whole for the 200 biggest interior design firms in the country have dropped by 10 percent since 1991, to $600 million, while employment has fallen by 19 percent, to about 5,500 people, according to Interior Design magazine.
In the 29 years since Gensler & Associates was founded here, its architects have designed more than 100 buildings, but the firm has gained its renown through interior design, which makes up 70 percent of its business. It has topped Interior Design's list of the biggest firms, measured by fees and volume of work, for 13 of the last 14 years. And in the magazine's annual readers' poll, Gensler has been ranked by its peers as the most respected design firm for all 14 years.
"Most design firms these days are struggling to hold their own," Stanley Abercrombie, chief editor of Interior Design, said. "Gensler's New York office is so busy they had to put drafting tables in what were once conference rooms. They just have a great ability to attract clients."
"A common failing in architecture firms is that they want to build the grand museum and get awards for themselves," he added. "Gensler wants to please the client and figure out what the client needs to run his business."
Still, Mr. Gensler, 58, acknowledged that his firm was feeling the pinch of the industry's changing environment. Profits, while still strong, have been flat for two years. There have been layoffs in some offices where work has slowed, though the number of employees has risen over all. And the firm's bread-and-butter business -- headquarters and new executive office design projects for big companies -- has dwindled.
Mr. Gensler has responded by leveraging his firm's size and talent to forge client relationships in Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan and other Pacific Rim countries where recessionary woes have not halted large construction projects. He is also building on prior assignments from Disney, Paramount, Columbia Pictures and others to prospect for work in the entertainment field. The firm is working with Sony and Loews Theatre Management on an entertainment complex near Lincoln Center in New York City.
But much of the firm's new business comes from preparing clients for a future in which working from home via computer hookups, known as telecommuting, shared office space and other evolving work arrangements will play much bigger roles.
So, Mr. Gensler has established new services like project management and strategic planning for Taco Bell, McKesson and Bank of America, among others. Gensler, for example, has spent the last year consulting with Taco Bell as the restaurant chain tries to decide whether to build a new headquarters building or renovate its existing one in Irvine, Calif.
"Technology is changing the way people work," Mr. Gensler said. "With electronic mail, the Internet, teleconferencing, people are starting to ask, 'What is a headquarters or office environment?' "
BOTH customers and colleagues say it is Mr. Gensler, the firm's affable, Brooklyn-born chairman, who etched the philosophy that continues to drive the company's success. In a field once characterized by one- or two-person shops that gathered what architects viewed as the scraps of a building project, Mr. Gensler adroitly changed the rules and tapped into what has become a profitable vein in interior design.
A graduate of Cornell University's architecture program, Mr. Gensler is recognized more for his management skills and salesmanship than for hands-on design talent.
"Art is garrulous and friendly, but a very sharp-eyed, clear-headed manager," said Martin Manley, a former consultant for McKinsey and client of Gensler who is an Assistant Secretary of Labor in the Clinton Administration. "He has single-handedly defined the business of interior design in the United States. He brought professionalism and the notion of client service to this business that simply wasn't there before."
Mr. Gensler, a voracious reader, has a penchant for seeing trends and getting ahead of them. "In the design world, he has the clearest sense of where the changes are coming from and what the challenges will be," William G. McMinn, dean of Cornell's College of Architecture, said. "He's kept a broader relationship with the business world than most architects do."
From the outset of his career, in a walkup office above a Greek restaurant here, Mr. Gensler saw the need for a geographically dispersed, client-driven firm that would forgo the ego-driven star system to create strong, functional work space for customers.
Gensler serves more than 7,200 clients, 85 percent of whom come back for repeat business, including 36 of the nation's 100 largest public companies, 8 of the top 10 commercial banks and 13 of the world's 25 largest investment securities firms. Gensler has received nearly 300 awards for its designs, including projects like the headquarters of Goldman, Sachs in London, the corporate interiors of Apple Computer in Cupertino, Calif., and the airport terminals in Las Vegas, Detroit and San Francisco.
Gensler's size and geographic diversity are usually anathema to designers, who tend to crave individualism and build their identities in small shops. "It's no easy thing to maintain common standards and identity across such a large organization, but Art has done that," Mr. Manley said.
YET a culture without stars can be a double-edged sword. Some people with the firm said they believed Gensler had pushed so far away from the star system that it had lost some of its edge in innovative design. Gensler has lost several prospective projects to more design-oriented competition. Mr. Gensler acknowledged that the firm had missed out on some work because customers wanted to be associated with someone with a recognized name.
Gensler's superstar designer, Orlando Diaz-Azcuy, left the firm six years ago to concentrate on residential and furniture design, and Mr. Gensler admitted that his departure had left a void.
"People said, 'I want Orlando,' " Mr. Gensler said. "But the thing that is hard for clients to understand is that projects are now so complicated, no one person can do it all."
One of the first design firms to utilize computer technology, Gensler relies on communications networks and computers to operate as a "one-firm firm," despite having 14 offices. "It was a radical concept to open so many offices, but technology lets us tie the whole firm together," Mr. Gensler said.
Early on, he tapped creative young people like Margo Grant Harris, a designer at a rival firm, Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, who signed a one-year contract with Gensler 21 years ago and has never left. She now runs Gensler's New York office, which has 160 employees and is the largest of the firm's offices. Mr. Gensler heard Ed Friedrichs give an impressive design presentation to the board of selectmen in Tiburon, Calif., in 1969 and recruited him at a local bar. Mr. Friedrichs, now a partner, runs the Los Angeles office, which has 126 employees.
Mr. Gensler said his secret to attracting talent is that he has enough self confidence to hire people smarter than him. "I get as much joy out of seeing one of the people I've picked do extremely well as I do seeing a building I've done," he said.
Ms. Grant Harris added, "He always sees the positive, not the negative. He gives you a lot of rope -- not to hang yourself, but so that you'll be more resilient."
 
 
 
TO BUILD, OR NOT TO BUILD? COMPUTING AN ANSWER
 THE lease on Taco Bell's corporate headquarters in Irvine, Calif., does not expire until November 1996. But at the urging of Taco Bell's architectural and interior design firm, Gensler & Associates, the $3 billion fast-food subsidiary of Pepsico Inc. began planning its headquarters of the future a year ago.
The critical question: Should Taco Bell construct a new building or extend its lease and renovate its existing space? The plans have yet to include a single blueprint or color swatch. Instead, Gensler, which designed Taco Bell's current headquarters in 1985, has turned the project into something akin to a business school case study, one that revolves around the changing nature of the workplace.
Gensler has looked into organizational design, outsourcing, which groups need to be in the same building and whether the headquarters should be a single structure or be split into regional sites.
Gensler is providing traditional cost analysis and regulatory-impact studies. But the firm has gone a step further, offering Taco Bell a variety of presentations on how office space will be affected by new approaches to work like "telecommuting" and the use of cross-functional teams, which get involved in different disciplines in a company.
One of the first design firms to embrace computers, Gensler has used sophisticated software to create three-dimensional computer images of what a new Taco Bell headquarters building might look like on a dozen potential sites.
"Most architects simply don't have the capability to talk to our business and planning people," Rudy Pollak, vice president of administration and employee services for Taco Bell, said. "A lot of architects try, but I don't believe anyone else out there is doing this."

HEADLINE: Teachers to the (Child) Stars

BYLINE: By By Mimi Avins 

DATELINE: Los Angeles

 BODY:
There are two teachers and three students inside a three-room house trailer parked in the shadow of Dopey Drive at the Disney Studios in Burbank, Calif. -- hardly an educational quorum, under normal circumstances. The situation, however, is decidedly out of the ordinary, because the pupils in the well-appointed mobile home classroom are the juvenile stars of the popular television comdey series "Home Improvement."
 "Do we have to do school now?" whines Zachery Ty Bryan, 12 years old, who portrays Brad, the eldest son. "I don't want to do these stupid lessons." Steve Elster ignores Zachery's lament and plunges into a lecture on how amino acids contribute to hereditary cell defects. As a studio teacher, Mr. Elster is one of a cadre of professional hybrids on whom children like Zachery depend. In order to do their jobs well, Mr. Elster and his co-teacher, Daphne Boelsma, must be by turns tutors, friends, therapists, protectors and surrogate parents for their young charges.
While California minors toil making commercials, acting in television shows or movies, those who haven't graduated from high school must go to school three hours a day, 15 hours a week. Although all states require a minimum number of hours of instruction for children working in the entertainment industry, only California law specified that even when a child's educational needs have been met, a state-certified studio teacher must be present on the set, serving as guardian of his or her health and safety, even during summer vacations.
 With children so prevalent in movies and television the last few years, studio teachers have not been faced with the intermittent unemployment that plagued them in the past. Hired by production companies from a roster maintained by the teachers' union, they earn more than public school employees when they do work -- though considerably less than their students do.
 Children who work have to be registered in accredited school, and the curriculum covered by their studio teacher is determined by their school of record. Students with continuing jobs, such as roles on television series, sometimes don't actually visit the schools at which they are nominally enrolled; they are often in independent study programs, which were developed for pregnant students trying to keep up with their lessons while out of school.
 
Rare Visits to 'Regular School'
 Zachery, a sixth grader, and his two television brothers call their home schools "regular school," an apt term since studio schooling is predictably irregular. Some children study with a studio teacher only a few days a year while appearing in commercials, while others spend several months making a movie or miniseries. And since many situation comedies schedule a break one week each month, the youngsters in their casts can return to their home schools periodically.
 Jonathan Taylor Thomas, 12, a sixth grader who plays Randy, the middle son in 'Home Improvement," says: "A lot of kids at my regular school don't understand. They go, 'Oh, you're so lucky. You don't have to go to school.' It's not like that. We do the same exact work that the public schools do, but sometimes it's more difficult because we have to do it in a shorter amount of time."
 Studio teachers maintain contact with their students' home-school teachers, getting copies of texts used and tests given. In many cases, they fax or mail work done on the set to the classroom teacher. For a junior high or high school student, they will keep track of work assigned by as many as six different teachers.
 The goal of most studio teachers is to keep students academically up to grade level and personally down to earth. Mr. Elster's dry sense of humor surfaces when his pubescent scholars sound inappropriately mature. "I like being on this show because I know I have a steady job," 12-year-old Jonathan tells a visitor. "Right," Mr. Elster adds. "He has the ex-wives, the alimony, the mortgage to worry about."
 How well studio schooling works depends on how important education is to the parents involved. Parents who value learning communicate that ethic to their children, who work hard in school even while they're busy acting. Conversely, the unmotivated student typically comes from a family more interested in a child's earning potential than in his acquisition of knowledge.
 Arlene Singer-Gross has been a studio teacher for 15 years, 8 of them on the long-running comedy "Who's the Boss?" "I've worked with parents whose priority was, 'How come my child didn't get a close-up and the other child did?' rather than 'Can she read?"' said Ms. Singer-Gross.
 She briefly taught a 16-year-old whose parents considered education a necessary evil. They were eager for the boy to take his high school proficiency exam so he could work longer hours as an actor. "He had gotten the message," Ms. Singer-Gross said. "It wasn't like he wanted to do homework; he wanted to do his publicity photos. I felt in that situation, my job was to teach him life skills. I taught him how to write a check, how to balance a checkbook."
 By law, California studio teachers may work with a maximum of 10 students, but the student-teacher ratio is usually one or two to one. As in Ms. Singer-Gross's experience, opportunities to tailor programs to a student's needs are abundant. "I can take a child in the seventh grade and have him reading Shakespeare, if he's that advanced," she says. "Or if a child is having a hard time with the multiplication tables, I can work on that for three days, design an approach just for him, or turn the math lesson into a game."
 Actors and actresses are the beneficiaries of the societal assumption that because a person is attractive and personable, he or she is bright. "I've taught some wonderful, sweet kids who were great when it was time for them to do their scenes, but they were struggling in school," says Laura Gary, a studio teacher who went on location when the movie "Free Willy" was filmed, and is currently working on "Full House," one of the television comedies that started the trend to family shows with young cast members. She enjoys being able to explain and drill until a subject is mastered, without worrying about boring the faster learners that inhabit a large, heterogeneous classroom.
 Zachery of "Home Improvement" says, "You get a lot more accomplished on the set because it's one on one with the teacher, not one on thirty. The teacher doesn't have to wonder about me not understanding something, because if I don't I'll just tell her. If I get it right away, we can just go on to the next thing."
 Studio teachers are as aware of a student's moods as his academic strengths and weaknesses. Although one of the professional child's survival skills is adaptability, the actor who goes directly from performing a very emotional scene to grappling with geometric proofs might not have an easy time making the switch. "When they come into the schoolroom from the set, I try to give them a cooling-off period," Ms. Singer-Gross says. "I might encourage them to talk about the experience they went through and how they internalized it, or instead of doing math, which takes more concentration, I give them an assignment to read for a while, so they can calm themselves down."
 When she isn't making a movie like "The Addams Family" or its sequel, 14-year-old Christina Ricci attends a suburban public school in New Jersey. For the four months she will work on the upcoming film "Casper" (about the friendly ghost), school is a one-room trailer that she has adorned with a Red Hot Chili Peppers poster, berthed on the Universal Studios lot. Although there are desks in the trailer, Christina can lie on the floor, pop a tape into her cassette player and drink a soda while she completes her assignments. "Here I call my teacher Rhona," she said. "In regular school, it would be Ms. Gordon." That reflects the rapport and trust that frequently, and rewardingly, develop between student and studio teacher.
 Like the private tutors once engaged for children of privileged class, studio teachers, by virtue of the intimacy and variety of situations they share with their students, inevitably impart more than the basics. When a teacher and student eat dinner together on location, a number of teachers say they can't help but notice a child's table manners and would be inclined to correct them if the need were obvious.
 Everyone expects that addition, subtraction and the causes of the Civil War will be covered in school. But questions of values that may not arise in regular classrooms are inescapable in an environment that is part school, part glamorous workplace.
 "There is no other business that tolerates the kind of behavior you see in this one -- spoiled, demanding behavior," Ms. Gordon says. "It happens with adults, teen-agers and young children. I've worked with children who were supporting their families and the balance of power was off. It got to be, like, who's running the store here? The kid was used to controlling everybody, and I felt it was up to me to teach him to treat adults with respect, because no one else had done it."
 But while it is inevitable for studio teachers to take on a variety of roles in their students' lives, including buddy and confidant, often what a young person really wants in a friend is someone the same age with the same interests, fears and curiosities.
 Lecy Goranson portrayed the eldest daughter on the top-rated television show "Roseanne" from age 13 to 18, and during that time, she said, she craved friends in her own age group. Ms. Goranson attended Vassar her freshman year, and at 19 is currently taking night classes at the University of California at Los Angeles. "When I went to college," she said, "I was better prepared in some ways than my peers, because I was always around adults on 'Roseanne,' and that was a very advanced learning experience."
 "But I think I missed out being isolated," she continued. "Even though my TV sister, Sara Gilbert, is really smart, there were still just the two of us in a little room. There was no recess, no walking from one class to the next where you would see other kids. You don't learn just from books or from your teacher. You learn from other students, too, from hearing what they have to say. When I think about having sat in the same room for hours and hours every day for five years -- the closest parallel I can draw is a prison."
 The 7-year-old stars of "Full House," Ashley and Mary-Kate Olsen, "do school" in a blue-carpeted second floor schoolroom inside a Burbank sound stage that is windowless, but hardly prison-like. The saucer-eyed twins (identical except for temporarily differing patters of baby tooth loss) sit on the flowered cushion of a white wicker loveseat taking turns ready a picture book, "Josefina Finds the Prince," aloud with their teacher, Ms. Gary. A rehearsal for "Full House" is going on directly below, on the permanent set for Uncle Jesse's attic apartment.
 
Growing Up on 'Full House'
 The twins have shared the pivotal role of Michelle since they were nine months old. They have thus virtually grown up on "Full House," and their parents, acting coach and teachers have made special efforts to infuse the twins' lives with elements of normalcy, including ballet classes for Ashley and riding lessons for her sister. The show films on a four-day workweek, so the girls attend separate second-grade classes at a private school on Mondays and every fourth week, when the show is on hiatus. To eace the transition between the two school settings, Ms. Gary has deliverately made herself less available in her classroom, prohibiting questions from her two students in the middle of a test, for example.
 The attempt to foster autonomy makes sense, but it seems to be an uphill battle. When Ms. Gary previews a nutrition test that will have to be completed and sent to their school ("Which picture shows a balanced meal?"), the girls, natural cuddlers, get up from their Lilliputian desks and each cling to one of her arms as they study the material.
 Independence, manners, spelling, a sense of persective about show business and single-cell reproduction -- if children in studio school learn all their lessons, they have the chance to avoid what every child dreads, being different. "I've met kids in this business who have never been around kids their own age and they don't know how to relate to them," Christina Ricci says. "It's weird."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 12; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1534 words

HEADLINE: 'I Speak Only From Love -- and Exasperation!'

BYLINE: By Wendy Smith; Wendy Smith is the author of "Real Life Drama: The Group Theater and America, 1931-1940."

 BODY:

THE COLLECTED WORKS OF HAROLD CLURMAN
Six Decades of Commentary on Theater, Dance, Music, Film, Arts and Letters.
Edited by Marjorie Loggia and Glenn Young.
Illustrated. 1,101 pp. New York:
Applause Books. $49.95. 
 Harold Clurman was no slouch as a director; his more notable achievements include the subtly stylized, emotionally profound 1935 Group Theater production of Clifford Odets's play "Paradise Lost" and the haunting 1950 premiere of "The Member of the Wedding" by Carson McCullers. But he really excelled as a cheerleader for the theater. Among students and friends, his dazzling conversation was legendary. "In a civilized country, Harold would have been employed simply to talk," Arthur Miller once told me, although he went on to admit that he often wondered how actors managed to extract useful information on how to actually play their parts from Clurman's enthralling torrent of words.
Happily, Clurman wrote as fluently as he spoke. As a drama critic for The New Republic from 1949 to 1952 and for The Nation from 1953 to 1980, and as a frequent contributor to The New York Times and many other periodicals, he assessed current productions and analyzed the state of the drama with an encyclopedic knowledge of theatrical history and technique and a warm sympathy for the artists' aims. "The Collected Works of Harold Clurman" reprints fully one-third of his journalism, capturing his sharp intelligence and salty humor. Only the ringing Bronx accent that made his speech so flavorful is missing, and Clurman's generous sprinkling of exclamation points and charmingly idiosyncratic use of quotation marks (usually to highlight words he feels are misunderstood or overused) give a nice intimation of his verbal style.
What is most striking in this collection is the coherent set of principles Clurman espoused, a philosophy about what theater is that did not essentially change from the time he founded the Group Theater with Lee Strasberg and Cheryl Crawford in 1931 until his death in 1980. In a previously unpublished 1931 essay that stands as a keynote for the entire book, he declared, "If the theater is an art, if it has any value beyond that of decorating the emptiness of our existence, it . . . must say something, it too must create from the chaos which is the common experience of its members an expression that will have, like that of the individual artist, an identity and a significance." If only all critics were so forthright about their basic beliefs.
Clurman was not a snob in his reviews -- he loved a good variety show and raved over the 1960 "Ice Ca pades" -- but theater as entertainment engaged him only marginally. He was primarily interested in a playwright's ideas and how well a production conveyed them. His brilliantly argued essays on the 1947 premiere of "A Streetcar Named Desire" and Peter Brook's 1964 version of "King Lear" voiced hearty appreciation for their superb direction and acting but strongly criticized the overall interpretations as false to the authors' intentions. You need not agree with Clurman's opinions to appreciate his valuable dissent from the "glowing enthusiasm disassociated from any specific meaning" that was his bete noire as a critic and theatergoer.
Despite a generally good-humored tone, Clurman could be devastating. Of Ingrid Bergman in "Joan of Lorraine" he remarked, "She is sincere, she is unspoiled, she is devoted and loyal -- and if we had a real theater she might soon learn to act." "Sleuth," he informed his readers, "is written with a certain literary coquetry which the innocent mistake for style." On the whole sympathetic to the 1960's avant-garde experiments, he deemed the Living Theater to be "more concerned with 'living' than with theater." He preferred a "travesty" like Joseph Papp's 1968 production of "Hamlet" to Richard Burton's "no 'Hamlet' at all" in 1964; in fact he was so aggravated by embalmed productions of Shakespeare exhibiting unthinking reverence rather than a point of view about the material that at one point he cried, "No more classics!" But he never seems nasty because, in his words, "I speak only from love -- and the exasperation that goes with it!"
A review can highlight only a few of the treasures in this wonderful but much too long collection. Readers must pick up the book themselves to savor the sensitive, supportive way Clurman followed dramatists throughout their careers, avoiding raves and pans in favor of sustained critical engagement with their work. (See everything he wrote about Eugene O'Neill and his thoughtful assessment of Edward Albee's "All Over," a play most reviewers scorned.) Readers will find his analyses of the economic factors that are killing serious drama as cogent now as when they were first published (some date back as far as the 1930's). They will soon spot his prejudices, about which he was candid: he thought musicals were fluff and had no appreciation for attempts to make them more challenging; he could admire but seldom really liked highly abstract work. Above all, they will feel his love for the theater, his conviction that it is the most exciting and deeply human of all art forms.
CLURMAN'S genius has not been properly supported here by his editors. At a minimum, Marjorie Loggia, a former television writer and producer, and Glenn Young, the publisher of Applause Books, should have provided a brief biography outlining Clurman's educational and personal background, his work with such organizations as the Group Theater and the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center, and a list of the plays he directed. (This could have profitably replaced their gushing foreword.) Instead, readers must glean virtually all biographical information from references in Clurman's own writings.
Slipshod organization and production also mar the book. Given the chronological approach -- the text is divided into sections titled "The Thirties," "The Forties" and so forth -- why place 1920's material, 1930's reviews from The Daily Worker and unpublished papers from all decades in appendixes? Surely it would not have required too much more type to append to each article the full name of the publication in which it appeared, rather than cryptic abbreviations the reader can identify only by flipping to a list at the very beginning of the book. The index is maddeningly incomplete and contains at least a few incorrect page numbers. Typographical errors include such howlers as the misspelling of a well-known evangelist's name as "Father Devine" rather than Divine.
An even more serious flaw is the editors' failure to be selective. The material on music, painting, film and dance here is enjoyable but peripheral. In addition, as the foreword notes, "there are many nearly verbatim reiterations of Clurman's fundamental tenets," reiterations he himself cut from collections that appeared during his lifetime. Clurman understood that books and journalism serve different purposes. Over years restatements of long-held opinions make perfect sense in a magazine or newspaper; they are unnecessary in a single volume that will probably be read in a few weeks.
By allowing repetitive material to swell the book's bulk to a point where it cannot easily be carried for long, the editors insure that their volume will reside primarily in libraries and other institutions. They do a disservice to the finest drama critic America has yet produced, an appealing and lovable man whose vision inspired generations of theater lovers and theater artists, and whose words deserve the widest possible readership.
 
 
 
THEATER FOR THE FUN OF IT
 We suffer nowadays [October 1948] from an inability to play. . . . A show is not a festivity to which we have been invited; it is a challenge. We doubt the host's honesty. Our wits are alerted; we are ready to administer due punishment if our demands are not met. This is our brand of the critical spirit. We are ready to forgo it if we are sure the host has no serious intentions -- if he merely proposes to knock us out with fireworks or narcotics. But let the party be of a quieter nature, where we may retain a modicum of our normal selves, and the relation between host and guest must be stated in terms of combat. . . .
If it is not to be just fun -- in the manner of a binge -- we demand that our entertainment be worthwhile, "pay off." . . . There is something sound in the instinct that prompts this attitude, but the results are nevertheless meager; they bring no joy. What we overlook is that life itself has no utilitarian value, that everything we hold dear has no end beyond itself. . . . In art what appears simplest and least demonstrably good is often the most enduring. . . . Does a flower, a bird, a river have to "prove" itself? There is in the ability to play something of that same sense of acceptance with which all men in a state of health face the world.
I say all this because during the past month I have noticed that my pleasures at the theater . . . have come from modest efforts which because of the topsy-turvydom of commerce are often represented to the public as special and abstruse.
 From "The Collected Works of Harold Clurman."

HEADLINE: Health Alliances Could Get Very Expensive

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Health care alliances (editorial, March 27) must be approached with care if they are not to degenerate into debacles like the New Jersey Joint Underwriting Association for automobile insurance. The Joint Underwriting Association ran up a deficit of billions by trying to insure high-risk drivers at low-risk rates. You state: 
 "Purchasing cooperatives are the best way to make sure that the chronically ill, employees of small firms and the unemployed are able to enroll in the same high-quality health plans, at the same prices, as employees of Fortune 500 companies."
The chronically ill are a high-risk group for health care. The unemployed may be high risk because they may be unable to get a job for health reasons. The employees of small companies may or may not be high risk as a group. All three groups, because of lack of cohesiveness, will have higher unit expenses. It is unlikely they can be covered under Fortune 500 plans at Fortune 500 prices.
How much more will they cost, and who will pay? As in the Joint Underwriting Association, costs are likely to be underestimated at first for many, maybe most, health alliances. As a result some alliances would soon be bankrupt or force health plans to accept risks at inadequate rates, thus driving some plans into bankruptcy. You suggest health alliances will be able to take money from plans not in trouble and transfer it to plans in financial difficulties. If not enough money comes into the system, such an approach merely changes the order in which plans become bankrupt.
Any legislation setting up health alliances must make sure that every alliance will be financially viable, not just in the short term, but forever. This means they must have the power and the will to raise rates when necessary. That may not be politically feasible.
 
HAROLD J. BROWNLEE
Chatham, N.J., April 1, 1994
 
The writer is a consulting actuary.

HEADLINE: CALIFORNIA SHOWS SIGNS OF RECOVERY AS JOBS INCREASE

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 8

 BODY:
After nearly four years of recession, and well behind the rest of the nation, the economic and political powerhouse that is California is finally showing signs of recovery.
Since January, California has added 29,000 jobs, a three-month spike in employment after a long, painful decline. That increase is dwarfed by the tens of thousands of aerospace jobs that disappeared in the 1990's, but it nevertheless has economists here trumpeting better things to come. 
 The national recovery is the main engine behind the California turnaround, which economists say is fragile and could be choked off by rising interest rates.
The recovery here came sooner than expected, by one fiscal quarter, because of the Jan. 17 earthquake, which brought a boom in construction jobs and an infusion of Federal aid to Los Angeles, where the sting of recession has been sharpest and where the most jobs have been lost.
Leading the way in optimistic predictions is the Business Forecasting Project at the University of California at Los Angeles, which offered the gloomiest, and most accurate, assessments early in the recession when others were reluctant to see the tarnish on the Golden State.
U.C.L.A.'s latest quarterly report last month was practically giddy. "By the time you read this California will be in recovery!" the report announced. "After almost four years in the Dumpster, the California economy is beginning to show signs of life, particularly in the job market."
Even the doubters are only quarreling around the margins. "There's some question whether the word 'recovery' is the appropriate word to use," said Joseph A. Wahed, the chief economist at Wells Fargo Bank in San Francisco. "I would rather use the word 'improvement.' "
California had a net gain of 7,300 payroll jobs in January, 15,900 in February and 5,800 in March, the first consecutive gains since hard times began here in 1990. That is a pittance compared with the 600,000 to 800,000 jobs lost during the long recession, and most of it comes in low-paying service and construction jobs.
Still, the new jobs have pushed the unemployment rate down to 8.6 percent in March, with U.C.L.A. predicting that it will dip an additional point by 1996, an improvement from recent years in which the rate occasionally moved above 10 percent.
Among the new workers are Francesco Canales, Luis Menjabar and Miguel Hernandez, who have helped swell the payroll at Ed Sylvis Construction in nearby Pasadena to 20 from 12. Rather than washing cars, delivering newspapers or searching for work, the three men are now paid $6 an hour to bolt house frames to their foundations for homeowners worried about the next earthquake.
Economists at U.C.L.A. and elsewhere also cite indicators beside job growth to prove their case:
*Sales of existing homes, which have risen for eight consecutive months, are up more than 30 percent. Last April, these homes were selling at an rate of 380,000 a year; in January they were selling at a rate of 520,000 a year. Most of the activity has been in the lower price range, but in recent weeks there have been reports from real estate brokers in the Los Angeles basin that buyers are again at least poking around in the million-dollar market.
*The home building industry, which hit bottom in June when the rate of housing starts was 80,000 a year, brightened as the rate edged up to 90,000 in January. Again, this is a far cry from the boom years of the late 1980's, when a quarter of a million homes went up in California each year. But the major builders are optimistic, reporting that their unsold inventory is finally selling without discounts or other concessions. And financial planners are urging bold clients to invest in home building companies.
*Business failures as tracked by Dun & Bradstreet have fallen more than 20 percent, compared with a year ago. And help-wanted advertising is on the rise, according to the prognosticators at Salomon Brothers, who urged clients in a January report to buy stocks of companies in the state because "California is turning."
That Salomon Brothers report was prepared before the earthquake and things have further improved since then, with $9.5 billion in Federal aid and at least $4 billion in insurance reimbursement flowing to this hard- hit region. "It's like a Marshall Plan for Southern California," said Don L. Gevirtz, chairman of the Foothill Group, a financial services company here.
 
Political Beneficiaries
 The turnaround is widely regarded as a boon to both Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican in the midst of an uphill re-election campaign, and President Clinton, a Democrat who has courted California and its trove of electoral votes with frequent trips to the state and a speedy infusion of Federal earthquake relief.
"Their fortunes are ironically linked," said Merv Field, director of the Field Poll, a California polling concern. "Both of them are dependent on an improved California economy -- Wilson totally dependent and Clinton largely dependent."
The President scores points with some economists here for the size of the Federal aid package and the speed with which the money reached the state. Adrian Sanchez, at First Interstate Bank here, said he had wrongly predicted a few "down months" after the quake. Instead, in contrast to the situation after the 1992 hurricane in Florida, the money flowed immediately from Washington, stimulating construction and retail sales.
Another difference is that there were plenty of unemployed workers ready to step in when the earthquake struck. Virtually all the demolition, repair and reconstruction work has been handled by local concerns, Mr. Sanchez said, and the relief money is recirculating in the region rather than flowing out of the state, as it did from Florida.
The most palpable benefit from the earthquake is the boom in construction employment. Of the 29,000 net gain in jobs since January, 6,000 are in construction, including the relatively low-paying, nonunion jobs at small concerns like Ed Sylvis Construction and the higher-paid, union positions at the huge highway rebuilding projects, like the Santa Monica Freeway, which is scheduled to reopen next Tuesday, months ahead of schedule.
At Ed Sylvis, the payroll has grown substantially, but others in addition to the new workers have gained. Existing employees who had seen their hours cut back in the slow months of 1993 are again working full time.
The early completion of the Santa Monica Freeway is largely a result round-the-clock repairs that have yielded an overtime bonanza for workers. Larry J. Kimball, the director of the U.C.L.A. Business Forecasting Project, noted that this extra income will stimulate retail spending here, which has yet to show a significant rise.
But even overtime does not turn these jobs into the equivalent of those lost in the aerospace industry. While the rate of job loss there has slowed somewhat, according to economists at U.C.L.A. and at Salomon Brothers, the nose dive is expected to continue. Northrop, for instance, which recently announced layoffs of 2,000, is expected to eliminate more jobs after its merger with Grumman. And in addition to aerospace cuts, the full impact of military base closings in the state is not expected to be felt until next year.
"You still have drags out there on the economy," said Jack Kyser, the chief economist at the Economic Development Corporation of Los Angeles County.
The biggest concern at this tentative stage in recovery is the recent rise in interest rates. Other regions have enjoyed a significant increase in construction because their recovery began while mortgage rates were at record lows. But with a later recovery, California may not have that advantage.
"We're not going to get any help from aerospace, so housing is the key," said Ted Gibson, the chief economist at the state Department of Finance. "I'd hate to see home building cut off at the knees by a rise in interest rates. That's the big worry."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Growth in construction and repair jobs after the Los Angeles earthquake has jump-started a recovery in California, the last state to show signs of pulling out of the recession. Employees of Ed Sylvis Construction of Pasadena worked underneath a house last week, bolting the frame to its foundation. (Scott Robinson for The New York Times)(pg. D9)

LENGTH: 1298 words

HEADLINE: Tokyo Vacuum: U.S. Fears Bureaucrats Will Rule

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 10

 BODY:
To understand the enormous frustration of the Clinton Administration as it waits for a Japanese leader with the clout to deal head on with Tokyo's worsening relations with America, just ask the country's fallen Prime Minister, Morihiro Hosokawa, about his dining room table and his television set.
Not long after Mr. Hosokawa took office, he and his wife, Kayoko, were shocked to discover how the Japanese Government expected the leader of the world's second largest industrial economy to live. In the dingy official residence, the dining room came equipped with a dirty carpet, a single, bare fluorescent lamp, and what Mrs. Hosokawa described the other day as "a folding table, the kind you would find in a school cafeteria." The TV set was a flickering, 20-year old dinosaur from the pre-remote control era; whenever Mr. Hosokawa wanted to turn on the talk shows and watch someone attack him, he had to get up and fiddle with the dials. 
 The Prime Minister sought a small budget to fix the place up. "The staff said 'No, no, nothing else is possible,' " Mrs. Hosokowa recalled. "They said that in a few years, we'll be building a new prime minister's residence anyway. Maybe then." The Hosokawas surrendered. They borrowed a table from the Prime Minister's small political party, and bought their own new television.
 
Power Vacuums Likely
 Just as the redecoration was just the first of many projects sabotaged by the bureaucracy and his own allies in the bickering coalition Government, so is his premature resignation a portent of the difficulties to come. The Clinton Administration is facing the prospect of several months if not years of power vacuums and setbacks in Tokyo, in which the people who say no to the prime minister also say no to the President.
Ultimately, the country's leading politicians argue, the momentous transition Japan is going through should change all that. When the political parties are reorganized, when a new election system -- Mr. Hosokawa's one great accomplishment -- empowers urban voters, when the drive toward deregulation gains speed, Washington should finally find some leaders in Tokyo with the mandate to get things done. But getting from here to there, everyone agrees, is going to be a messy, chaotic process.
"There cannot be a strong Government here until there is a new election under the new system, and maybe two or three," Gerald L. Curtis, a Columbia University professor who has studied Japan's Byzantine political system for decades, said today. "Until then, no one will really be in charge. But in the long run, the forces for change seem inexorable."
In the meantime, the Clinton Administration seems reduced to only one real strategy: Sit back and watch. Its early bet, that heightened American pressure on Mr. Hosokawa and his new Government would speed the course of change, has gotten nowhere. Now, there is growing agreement that the strategy needs considerable rethinking: Whatever its frustrations with Mr. Hosokawa, Washington is likely to find that his successor is neither as articulate nor as impassioned in voicing the need for change.
"The reality is that no matter what we say, this is all going to be in the air for a while," one of Mr. Clinton's closest advisers on Japan issues said over the weekend. "We are going to be left talking to the bureaucrats, because no one else is going to have time for us. And you have a pretty good idea how far that is going to get us."
Until his financial scandals exploded in the Parliament, Mr. Hosokawa had a very methodical, extraordinarily ambitious agenda for change laid out for the first half of this year. He talked of changes in building and zoning regulations to make it possible to build bigger houses -- with imported lumber. He had commissions under way to cut through the country's morass of regulations. He talked about short-circuiting a distribution system that manages to double the price of every import.
But the fact of the matter was that he had no political capital left to get any of it done. To pass political reform legislation earlier in the year, he spent every bit of influence he had. Mr. Hosokawa's hope had been that passage of the bill, even in the watered-down fashion that finally became law, would give him momentum. Instead, it sapped his coalition of what little sense of unity it had left.
 
Tax Reform Bungled
 In the ensuing three months, Mr. Hosokawa tried, and failed, to get a tax reform plan through. He bungled the presentation of the plan, and it was quickly torpedoed by the powerful Ministry of Finance -- which refuses to use deficit spending as a tool for spurring the economy -- and by the Socialists, the biggest party in the coalition. An effort to reorganize his Cabinet also died, but not before it transformed some of his one-time allies, including the chief cabinet secretary, Masayoshi Takemura, into sworn enemies.
Mr. Hosokawa's get-tough response to President Clinton in February in Washington, where he said "no" to a demand that Tokyo agree to "numerical indicators" and other targets for American imports, played well back home. But he failed to follow it up with a strategy for solving the trade surplus problem or repairing relations with Japan's chief ally.
Close advisers to the fallen Prime Minister say his helplessness was partly a function of the institution: a Japanese prime minister has almost no political staff to make independent judgments or set a long-term course for the country.
 
Top Politician's Strategy
 "In Japan currently, no system exists that would help the prime minister be the top politician," Shusei Tanaka, who was Mr. Hosokawa's closest aide until earlier this year, said in a recent interview. "In the future, the question is what can we do to create a support system around the prime minister. If you have to make decisions in such an isolated environment, you cannot be a top politician or a reformer."
Among those advocating a far stronger role for the prime minister is Ichiro Ozawa, perhaps the country's most powerful behind-the-scenes politician and the moving force of one of the leading reform parties in the coalition, Shinseito. He is also the figure at the center of the current maneuvering to pick Mr. Hosokawa's successor.
His strategy is clear: The current rag-tag coalition must go, and should be replaced with an ideologically cohesive party, or a smaller collection of parties, that can begin to exercise real power. To accomplish that, he must dump many of the Socialists, whose vision of a minor world role for Japan -- scant military involvement with the United Nations in peacekeeping, continued protectionism in many markets -- has virtually frozen any major policy changes.
But he cannot get rid of them until he has sufficient replacement votes to keep the coalition in power -- and to keep the Liberal Democrats, who governed the country for 38 years, from returning. He will try to do that this week, trying to lure more Liberal Democrats to defect from their party. But if he fails, and that seems likely, there will be little change until an election is held. Most people think that will be nine months away, because the process of redistricting the country under the new election laws has just begun.
In the end, Mr. Tanaka says, "the direction we are seeing is one in which decisions will finally be made by the politicians." Then the American strategy -- to place political pressure on Japan, making it clear to Japanese voters that its demands for more open markets will also bring down prices and increase their choices -- has a chance of working. Until then, though, Washington is pushing on a string, trying to get 1990's-era decisions out of politicians still watching 1970's-vintage television sets.

The Clinton Administration now faces a period of frustration while it waits for Japan to choose a new leader to deal with the worsening relations with the United States. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Plan Is Announced For Russian Ships

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, April 10

 BODY:
A Congressional delegation and top Russian military officials agreed today to bring old Soviet ships to the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard to be dismantled.
The shipyard is scheduled to close next year, taking with it about 45,000 jobs in the Philadelphia area. Its unprecedented new use could "provide hundreds if not thousands of jobs here," said Representative Thomas M. Foglietta, a Democrat whose district includes the base. 
 Local lawmakers, announcing the pact after returning from Moscow, said the arrangement would help the 193-year-old navy yard make the transition to the private sector.
The first contract is to be signed 90 days after economic and environmental studies are completed and a private American company is selected to buy the vessels, the lawmakers said. They said toxic materials like asbestos and lead paint would be removed before the ships sail for Philadelphia.
American officials have said the success of any such arrangement would hinge on developing procedures that are environmentally sound and consistent with environmental regulations, and on developing a profitable business plan.
Mr. Foglietta, who made the trip with four House colleagues, could not say exactly how many jobs would be created. At least 155 Russian ships could sail into the port, he said.
Though the plan would be a private-sector venture, lawmakers said it could be partly financed by some of the $1.6 billion in defense conversion funds the United States plans to given the former Soviet Union.

HEADLINE: Clinton and Technology: Some Policies Clash

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 10

 BODY:
It would be hard to find a President more enthusiastic about promoting technology than Bill Clinton. Yet in a striking number of cases, the Administration seems to be picking fights with the very companies that want to build its cherished information superhighway.
Even as some Federal agencies funnel billions of dollars in tax breaks and new spending for research on projects from high-resolution video to high-performance computing, others are taking actions that even some Democrats say could weaken the nation's commercial technology prowess. 
 Signs of the internal conflict are almost everywhere. The President and Vice President Al Gore have made several high-profile trips to Silicon Valley and have courted its executives as advisers. At the same time, however, the Justice Department is pursuing an intense antitrust investigation of the Microsoft Corporation, the biggest software company.
 Even as Vice President Gore has promoted his broad vision of high-speed computer networks, the Federal Communications Commission has forced the cable television industry to swallow $2 billion in rate reductions. That decision helped scuttle two big mergers between telephone and cable television companies that were intended to foster construction of advanced networks.
And while the National Security Agency and the F.B.I. have been promoting technologies that would insure law enforcement officials' right to wiretap telephone and computer networks, the Commerce and State Departments have been relaxing export restrictions on computer and satellite technology that some security experts worry could fall into the hands of foreign enemies.
Lester C. Thurow, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, criticized what he saw as the Administration's push-and-pull on advanced information technology. "Here you've got the hottest industry in the world at the moment," he said, "but it's an industry that has historically been regulated and the role of Government has been to slap it down."
Yet, for all the seeming contradiction, there is a discernible pattern to the Administration's information technology policy. When forced to make a choice between promoting commercial technology companies and traditional national security interests, the Administration will usually side with commercial companies. But when crime or consumer issues are at stake, Clinton officials are less likely to toe the industry line.
White House officials concede there is a tension between goals but deny any policy confusion. "Even within a company you have huge fights about the right way to maximize profit," said W. Bowman Cutter, deputy assistant to the President for economic policy. "A government has a whole set of societal objectives and it has to try to keep the herd headed west in a reasonably coherent way."
 
Pleased, in General
 Executives in the computer and telecommunications field are on balance pleased with the attention the Administration has given to their fields. And even as they express frustration with particular actions, they acknowledge that all of them can be supported by reasonable arguments.
But economists and even some Democratic supporters of the Administration, say that the Government often appears to be working at cross-purposes as different agencies pursue agendas that collide with each other.
White House officials say that even seemingly contradictory actions may in fact be serving the same goal. Efforts to enforce antitrust laws will benefit all companies by promoting competition, they say, and new rules on cable prices merely prevent the extortion of monopoly profits.
Indeed, the Administration has demonstrated a certain consistency in its political priorities.
The White House announced two weeks ago, for example, that it would lift most of the export restrictions on advanced computer and communications equipment that had been previously considered to have military value. The decision was a big victory for companies that make high-speed computers and fiber optic communications equipment, and it came after years of resistance from the Pentagon.
Similarly, the White House recently overruled reservations by the Central Intelligence Agency and decided to let American companies develop commercial satellite imaging services based on spy-satellite technology.
 
Siding With Consumers
 On the other hand, if the Administration must choose between promoting advanced cable television networks and responding to consumer complaints about high prices, it will side with consumers. Likewise, the Administration seems wedded to the more traditional Democratic idea that bigness in business is suspect and that antitrust laws need to be enforced aggressively. And the Administration's support for computer companies is outweighed by its desire to be tough on crime.
The White House has brushed aside vehement objections from computer and software companies and is pressing the industry to adopt a new encryption technology called the Clipper Chip that would allow Federal investigators to intercept coded transmissions over computer networks. Computer companies object that many customers, particularly foreign ones, will never trust a coding technology developed by the United States Government and that American companies will be hurt on the global market as a result.
Some of the potentially biggest conflicts with technology companies are at the Justice Department's antitrust division, headed by Anne K. Bingaman. In sharp contrast to its predecessors in the Bush and Reagan Administrations, Ms. Bingaman's antitrust division is seeking out cases even before it receives formal complaints. Agency officials say they have begun 50 new "preliminary investigations" on their own initiative in the last year -- up from 4 in 1992.
"There is absolutely no conflict between what we're doing and what the Administration is doing," Ms. Bingaman said in a recent interview. "We're investigating situations in whatever industry that are in violation of the antitrust laws. Our obligation is to create a level playing field, where no company is squelched by a monopoly player."
 
Microsoft Inquiry
 The Justice Department began its investigation of Microsoft after the Federal Trade Commission ended its own three-year investigation without taking action. Microsoft, which sells about 80 percent of the operating systems that run I.B.M.-compatible personal computers, has come under fierce attack from rivals who say the company has used its dominance to thwart rivals who make word-processing and other applications software.
The Justice Department has also begun investigating the cable television industry. The focus of that investigation is on the General Instrument Corporation -- a key supplier of advanced set-top boxes and scrambling technology -- but Government officials say they are looking rather broadly at "relationships and practices" throughout the industry.
But the new activism has caused concern even among Democratic economists. One prominent critic is Robert J. Shapiro, vice president of the Progressive Policy Institute, a policy research group in Washington, who was an economic adviser to Mr. Clinton during the election campaign.
Mr. Shapiro contends that the Microsoft investigation may damage the overall strength of the software industry because it may be based on premises that are outdated in the information industry. In software and other technology markets, he contends, the need for common technical standards tends to leave a few companies with a dominant share of the market.
At the same time, he said, dominant companies in the information industry remain vulnerable to displacement from new rivals that offer innovative alternatives. Microsoft, like I.B.M., is only as strong as its next generation of products.
 
Issue of Bigness
 The question is not how big a particular company has grown but whether the market is "contestable" for new players, Mr. Shapiro said. Attacking the industry leader, he argued, risks subsidizing lagging players and weakening the industry as a whole.
"What I'm trying to argue is that the antitrust division needs to understand how modern markets operate," Mr. Shapiro said. "Having a big market share in certain markets is not the real issue. Rather than a sign of dysfunction, it's a sign that the market is working well."
Justice officials respond that they are not simply presuming that big is bad. "Size alone is not the determinant," said Stephen Sunshine, a Deputy Assistant Attorney General. "It's the practices. We're interested in exclusionary power and market power."
Some critics say the Administration shows even more internal conflicts in its effort to promote what it calls a National Information Infrastructure -- a ubiquitous array of advanced networks that offer two-way video communications and high-speed data to homes, schools and local government agencies.
Mr. Gore and other top Administration officials have made it clear they expect private industry to build these networks, but they have also called on the industry to meet broad public goals like extending the networks to both haves and have-nots. Likewise, Mr. Gore warmly supported the Federal Communications Commission's decision in February to cut cable television rates by a total of 17 percent.
 
Companies Cite Regulation
 The cable regulations were justified on the basis that most cable television systems enjoy exclusive franchises and have been able to raise prices for years at a pace well above the rate of inflation. A day after the rate cuts were announced, Bell Atlantic and Tele-Communications Inc. abandoned their effort to merge and form a joint effort to build hybrid telephone-video networks across the country. On Tuesday, Cox Enterprises and Southwestern Bell called off plans for a $4.9 billion joint venture and blamed the F.C.C. as well.

HEADLINE: Workers Behind Federal Red Tape Find Its Strands Impeding Retirement

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 7

 BODY:
When the clock strikes midnight on Sept. 30 ending the fiscal year, nearly 50,000 Federal workers will retire or take early leave as part of the Clinton Administration's plan to remake the Federal Government. But leaving is not easy.
In a Kafkaesque turnabout, the makers of so much red tape will themselves now face a maze of forms and briefings before they can leave their jobs. 
 There are compulsory departure seminars to attend, identification cards to return, E-mail codes to be divested, interviews to be given, signatures to be checked and an inch-thick stack of forms to fill out. The higher the position held, the more material required.
Each month hundreds of Federal workers across the nation leave Government employment for a variety of reasons including retirement or taking private sector jobs.
But the departure rate is expected to step up considerably in the coming months because of the Federal Workforce Restructuring Act of 1994. Better known as the Buyout Bill, it authorizes Federal agencies to offer up to $25,000 to employees who resign or retire early.
As many as 50,000 Federal workers will leave their jobs as part of the Administration's push to downsize the Government.
 
Lists of Rules
 Vice President Al Gore, who is overseeing the departures as part of his mission to "reinvent Government," said the reduction "would help rid the Federal Government of unnecessary and duplicative layers of management control that result in inefficiency and red tape."
But unless the current system changes, those wishing to take advantage of the offer will have to make their way through layers of management control. The process is much more exhaustive than the relatively simple procedure most people go through in leaving jobs in the private sector.
"You're actually given a checklist," said Richard E. Bissell, a former assistant administrator at the United States Agency for International Development who left the Government a year ago. "There are literally dozens of items to be checked off, each of which requires a separate form and a visit to a different office."
 
'Ripe for Reinvention'
 Richard Seifman, another A.I.D. official who retired earlier this month, said, "The retirement process itself is ripe for reinvention."
Jim King, the director of the Office of Personnel Management, leavens his observations about the departure process with humor but does not hold out much hope for change.
He ticked off a series of forms and checklists for what is known as "disengagement," but warned, "I'm touching on the high points now, not everything."
"Take Form 4754-A," Mr. King explained. "That assumes that you have led a notorious life and that you have in point of fact been every place in the Government and have something that you should return and apologize for: library card, equipment, bank or credit union loans, forwarding address, Government identification, cars, car keys.
"Over the years," he continued, "every agency has identified that somehow someone slipped out in 1947 without doing something, and so they keep adding to the list."
Federal employees face a bewildering set of options on a long list of things like health insurance and where and to whom their retirement benefits should go. As part of the process, most agencies have seminars that orient the departing worker to the departure process.
 
Manuals and Confusion
 "You're required to attend it so you can fill out all the forms correctly," said Mr. Bissell, now a research associate at the Overseas Development Corporation here. "Otherwise, it's impossible to make sense out of them."
Before the seminar, the worker is bombarded with manuals and pamphlets offering information about choices. Some departing employees compare these to the instructions for programming a VCR. The required seminars, they say, comes as a relief.
"At that point, you're just so happy to have a human being speaking in plain English, you don't mind," Mr. Bissell said.
The process is especially difficult if an employee had top-level Government security, allowing access to classified documents, said Jerry Shaw, director of the Senior Executive Association, which represents 7,500 career senior executives in the Government, 40 percent of whom are eligible for retirement.
 
Red Tape Doesn't End
 Mr. Shaw pointed out that for top-level officials, the red tape does not disappear once they are out the door. "There are substantial post-employment restrictions," he said, noting that top officials are barred from writing about or talking about their field of expertise or from doing business with their former departments for several years.
Once back in the private sector, Mr. Shaw said, lawyers and contracting officers must check with the ethics office or the general counsels of their old agency before taking on certain work so they will not face criminal prosecution.
But Madeleine Jacobs, now managing editor of Chemical and Engineering News Magazine, worked for the Federal Government for 21 years had a different experience. She left her job at as director of communications for the Smithsonian Institution.
"I had a very good experience," Ms. Jacobs said. "My organization, the Smithsonian was very helpful and I only gave three weeks notice."
She acknowledged, though, that her departure may have been eased because at 47 she did not have to fill out pension forms. "I still have a whole package of forms saved to fill out for when I'm 65," she said.
Mr. King concedes that the paper hurdles to departure "on the surface, look foolish." But he said that the costs of changing locks on desks if employees failed to turn in desk keys added up and that the difficulty of relaying information when an employee had not left a forwarding address was considerable.
Despite the Restructuring Act, Mr. King said there would be "no big queue" of departees lining up come fall.
"For the most part the system works very well because most folks know how to work the system," he said. "The more senior officials should think of it as an ego trip. The longer it takes, the more they should be flattered."
Ron Sanders, principal director for civilian personnel policy at the Department of Defense, said the Pentagon had had the authority to buy out employees since the 1990 fiscal year.
"We've reduced by about 200,000 since that time," said Mr. Sanders, who is a hot commodity on the lecture circuit. "Most people are amazed that the Federal Government can do something so well, and we've still got 120,000 more to go by the end of the century."
