HEADLINE: Jobs Program May Become The Casualty Of Its Success

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BERKELEY, Calif.

 BODY:
A federally financed program to provide housing and job training to the homeless has worked so well that the Clinton Administration wants to copy its methods on a larger scale and put it out of business.
Though this could mean more help for the estimated one million homeless Americans, the directors of the smaller, largely autonomous project say that its shoots of hope will be trampled by the big foot of the Federal bureaucracy. 
 The Administration acknowledges that the program, run by 20 nonprofit community agencies, has proved effective, but said it wanted to revamp and consolidate the 154 employment and job training programs. And Labor Department officials said the programs were demonstration projects not intended to continue indefinitely.
But several lawmakers, including Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, have complained. "It makes no sense to dismantle successful programs in order to create new programs elsewhere," he said in a recent letter to Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich.
Such an action, Mr. Glenn wrote, the department "is throwing all the knowledge that was learned through the demonstration program" away "and put us back at square one."
 
8,000 Homeless Each Year
 Part of a program established under a 1987 law on the homeless, the community agencies have been steering 8,000 homeless people a year into jobs in 12 states, including New York, and the District of Columbia. The Labor Department provides most of the money for the agencies: about $40 million in six years. Businesses and state and local governments contribute the rest.
The biggest reason the agencies have worked so well, proponents say, is that they are not constrained by a raft of government regulations and can tailor their aid to suit individual needs. The agencies are judged by their results, not by how they do their job. The majority of Government job training programs have stringent regulations aimed at limiting abuses and keeping costs in line.
The agencies' officials and their advocacy groups had hoped that they were laying the foundation for a larger network to help the homeless.
Instead, they said, they were stunned in late February when the Labor Department announced that their grants would not be renewed when they run out on April 30. The department has since extended the agencies' financing to run through August, but at sharply reduced levels.
The services are now turning away applicants and cutting staff. Michael Daniels, director of the largest agency, Jobs Consortium for the Homeless in Berkeley, said he is looking for local funds but has limited his clients to those already on his rolls and plans to cut back on staff on May 1.
Eliminating the small demonstration projects is part of a plan, announced last month by Mr. Reich, to consolidate and revamp Federal unemployment insurance and job training services. Douglas Ross, assistant secretary for employment and training, said the demonstration projects were experiments to see if the homeless could be helped.
"We invested a little capital to see if this hypothesis about job training and the homeless had any merit," he said. "We found out that it does. The next step is to find out what was learned so we can introduce it into our local labor market organization."
The Jobs Consortium here, eight blocks down Telegraph Avenue from the campus of the University of California at Berkeley, works from cramped cubicles with hand-me-down furniture on a budget this year of $850,000, of which the Labor Department provided $710,000.
"We see people nobody else will see," Mr. Daniels said. "If a person walks in the door with a disability or an addiction, we don't freak out."
In the last 11 months, Mr. Daniels said, 879 people have come in for help. So far, the agency has found homes for 550 and jobs for 228, many of them the same people. The jobs included carpenters, security guards, electricians, truck drivers, secretaries, cooks, janitors, home health care aides and graffiti removers. Their average hourly wage was $8.05, far higher than the $4.25 minimum wage. Half of those who found jobs were still working three months later.
 
'How Can I Help You?'
 The consortium's clients shower praise on the agency. David Osbourne, 30 years old, said he has been off cocaine for a year. The agency gave him meal vouchers, counseling, training to be a security guard, leads to job interviews and carfare.
"This place, you say, 'Help me,' " Mr. Osbourne said. "They say, 'How can I help you?' "
He said other Government agencies he visited were brusque and cold to and presumed he was unsalvageable.
Early this month, a security agency hired Mr. Osbourne for $8 an hour, and he is now moving from a shelter to a room in one of eight transitional houses in Berkeley, subsidized and operated by churches and nonprofit organizations, mostly for the homeless who have found jobs.
 
Jobs for 34 Percent
 A job training consultant, James Bell Associates of Arlington, Va., examined the Berkeley consortium and the other agencies -- known collectively as the Job Training for the Homeless Demonstration Project -- in a report last month to Congress for the Labor Department.
Over five years, the study said, 34 percent of the people who sought help found jobs through the 20 community agencies and 26 others that took part in the program earlier. The proportion still on the job after 13 weeks rose to 53 percent from 40 percent over the five years.
The average cost of job training for a homeless person was $1,342. The authors said the agencies provided "evidence that a substantial minority of the homeless population can immediately benefit from employment and training programs."
Larry Robbins, an independent consultant who has evaluated the Berkeley homeless consortium for the Labor Department, contrasted the billion-dollar partnership program with the community projects.
He said the larger program's regulations frighten people off. "They're not user-friendly," he said.
Franklin Newman, 33, needed user-friendly services once. In early 1990 he and his wife broke up, and he moved out of their apartment. Then he was dismissed from his job as a shipping and receiving manager for an electronics company after a feud with his boss.
Mr. Newman said he went to a check-cashing service with his last paycheck from that job, for $286.50, and planned to take a bus home to see his parents in San Bernardino in Southern California.
"Two guys pulled a gun," he said. "They took my suitcase, all my money." He went to a shelter. "I was on the verge of commmiting suicide," he said.
Then Mr. Newman went to the Berkeley agency. "They called the suicide prevention," he said. "They took me to the hospital. I was released in 48 hours, and they found me counseling. They got me clothing."
Earlier this month, Mr. Newman, in a white shirt and necktie, stopped by the Telegraph Avenue office to complete paperwork after landing an $18,000-a-year job with full benefits as a manager of a retirees' organization.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Clinton Administration is so impressed with the success of programs like the Jobs Consortium in Berkeley, Calif., that it wants to consolidate them despite misgivings by their operators. David Osbourne, 30, who had been addicted to cocaine, was recently hired as a security guard. (Darcy Padilla for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
 The Clinton Administration often seems to have a contradictory policy on information technology, fighting with the companies that would build its cherished data superhighway. Yet there is a pattern to the Government's strategy. When forced to make a choice between promoting commercial technology companies and national security interests, the Administration will usually side with commercial companies. But when crime or consumer issues are at stake, Clinton officials are less likely to toe the industry line. [Page D1.] 
 The teamsters strike is expected to have only a minor impact on the economy, even if the strike against 22 trucking companies lasts more than a week. Companies have an unprecedented flexibility in choosing how to ship goods because of new computer technology and the expansion in nonunionized trucking. [D1.]
California is showing signs of recovery after four years of recession. The Jan. 17 earthquake in Los Angeles, which has brought building jobs and U.S. aid, helped the state economy. [A1.]
 
Companies
Weapons manufacturers are pressing for legislation to limit the ability of whistle-blowers in Government fraud cases to collect multimillion-dollar awards. An increasing number of people have filed cases seeking awards for revealing fraud by Government contractors, especially weapons manufacturers, since Congress revised the whistle-blower law eight years ago. The contractors say the large awards encourage unfounded suits and discourage employees from alerting management about wrongdoing. [D1.]
A prominent lawyer involved in the Macy bankruptcy case has an avocation that takes him far from the courtroom and the corporate suite: he is a composer and plays bass guitar for his own jazz quartet that performs at Manhattan nightclubs. [D1.]
Wordperfect, going up against Microsoft in the home computer market, will introduce 25 new software products today. [D2.]
 
International
 Just when it appeared that Japan's long-awaited recovery was on the horizon, Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa's startling resignation on Friday dashed many economists' hopes. Political turbulence in the coming weeks could abort what even optimists expected to be only a fragile recovery. [D1.]
 
The Media Business
Ted Turner's new project, Turner Classic Movies, begins this week on an undisclosed number of cable systems. Cable operators,still trying to make sense of the voluminous regulations issued recently by the F.C.C., are reluctant to add new channels. [D5.]
The annual survey by the Committee to Protect Journalists details the increased dangers of imprisonment and death that journalists around the world face. [D5.]
The Associated Press plans to start a 24-hour all-news radio network in June, seeking to capitalize on the rising popularity of news and talk-radio programming as station owners seek inexpensive but profitable formats. [ D5.]
The Western pulp magazine, which rode off into the sunset about three decades ago, has returned. Dell Magazines started publishing its Louis L'Amour Western Magazine in January. [D5.]
A new telecommunications company introduces itself with a campaign that gently mocks the technical talk and pretensions of its rivals' spots. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D6.]
 
Today's Columns
 A New York company has patented a technology that uses sensors, microchips and air pillows to make shoes, chairs and beds more comfortable. Sabra Chartrand: Patents. [D2.]
 Higher interest rates shouldn't scare away car buyers, as long as they don't hit double digits, some auto industry analysts argue. They say the recovery in auto makers' sales and earnings -- and their stocks -- will continue. Market Place. [D4.]

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
A Turner Channel Seeks Carriers

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT 

 BODY:
When Ted Turner does something, he likes to do it big. And so when he starts his new cable channel, Turner Classic Movies, on Thursday, he will do so from that most public of spaces: Times Square. The channel's first few minutes of programming will be carried on the giant Jumbotron screen above Broadway.
The question is: Besides those gathered in the street, will anyone else be able to see it? 
 The Turner Broadcasting System is starting Turner Classic Movies, or TCM, at a time of enormous turmoil in the cable industry. Cable operators are still trying to make sense of the voluminous regulations issued recently by the Federal Communications Commission mandating yet another cut in cable rates.
Before cable systems add new channels, they will be looking for ways to pass costs on to consumers, or at least not lose any money. And that is making it hard for Turner to sign up carriers.
 
'In a Straitjacket'
 "We're sort of in a straitjacket until we sort through these new rules," John Rigsby, the president of Paragon Manhattan Cable, said.
At this point, he said, Paragon has no plans to add Turner Classic Movies to its lineup. Even though Paragon's parent, Time Warner Cable, has a partial stake in Turner Broadcasting, the cable operator has made no commitment to try to introduce the channel on its systems. The same is true for Tele-Communications Inc., which also owns part of Turner Broadcasting. Tele-Communications and Time Warner are the nation's largest cable operators.
Further, many cable systems around the country have run out of channel space, at least until new technology lets them expand capacity. Indeed, many systems were already forced to drop some channels last year when new Federal cable regulations took effect. The act required many systems to carry more broadcast stations.
Turner Classic Movies is Mr. Turner's sixth cable channel, after TBS, CNN, Headline News, TNT and the Cartoon Network. The channel will be built largely around the MGM film library, which Mr. Turner bought for $1.4 billion in 1986. (The steep price was what forced Mr. Turner to take on Time Warner and Tele-Communications as partners.)
 
Movies and More Movies
 Like its closest rival, American Movie Classics, or AMC, Turner Classic Movies will run movies 24 hours a day, seven days a week, without commercial interruptions. First on the schedule is "Gone With the Wind."
Brad Siegel, the general manager of TCM, refused to say how many viewers would be able to watch the channel after Mr. Turner pulls the switch in Times Square. "We are literally adding subscribers and systems on a daily basis," he said.
Cable industry analysts say the cost of starting TCM is so low that the channel can be profitable without a large audience. Turner Broadcasting, they note, already owns many of the films to be shown, and can promote them on its other channels.
"This is all about channel real estate," said Larry Gerbrandt, senior vice president of Paul Kagan Associates, a media research firm. "If you've got the programming and you've got the economies of scale, it makes sense to clear as many channels as possible."
He said TCM might take some viewers away from Mr. Turner's other channels, but over all, it should add viewers to the Turner empire. "The net effect is you want to end up with more viewers than you had before," Mr. Gerbrandt said.
 
Aiming for a Bigger Audience
 AMC focuses almost exclusively on movies of the 1930's, 40's and 50's. But TCM plans to show films from the 60's, 70's and 80's as well. Mr. Siegel said this should let the channel appeal to a "much wider demographic, not just to older people."
Executives at AMC, which is owned by Rainbow Programming Holdings Inc., say they are not worried that TCM may cut into their franchise. AMC is available in 43 million households. "We really feel our niche is alive and well," Jayne Wallace, AMC's director of public relations, said. "We've been building a brand that is really steeped in the golden age of Hollywood. People tune in to AMC because they want to be back in that time.
"What you often hear from Turner is that they have the MGM library and we don't, which is true," she said. "They might have more titles, but the question is: Are they any good?"
To encourage cable systems to carry the channel, Turner is allowing them to package it in ways that maximize their profit. Thus, while some systems may carry the channel as part of their basic service, many are likely to offer it as part of a higher-priced tier, or on an "a la carte" basis for a special monthly fee. "We're giving the operators flexibility," Mr. Siegel said.
He said he was not worried about the channel's initial reach. "We're patient," he said. "We're in this for the long haul."

HEADLINE: Salt Mine Cave-In Brings Pollution and Jobs Debate

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RETSOF, N.Y., April 8

 BODY:
Just two months ago trucks lined up in record numbers at the Akzo salt mine here, hauling away road salt to melt heavy winter snow throughout the Northeast.
But a banner winter for Akzo, the largest salt mine in North America, has been followed by a nightmarish spring. Since the March 12 collapse of part of the mine roof, millions of gallons of water have been flooding the mine, which covers an area roughly the size of Manhattan some 1,200 feet underground. No one was injured in the collapse. 
 If nothing is done, the whole mine could collapse because water is eroding the salt pillars that hold up its roof, said Thomas Pearson, an environmental engineer who is leader of the team assigned to the mine by the New York State Environmental Conservation Department.
The collapse is evolving into a struggle between those worried about the more than 300 jobs at the mine and residents of the Rochester area who are concerned about what will happen if plans are approved to pump millions of gallons of salty mine water into the Genesee River. The salt mine is in Livingston County about 25 miles south of Rochester.
 
Contamination Concerns
 "We spent a billion dollars to clean up the Genesee River," said Edward P. Curtis Jr. who runs a cruise boat service in Rochester and used to direct Monroe County's tourism and convention efforts. "I'd hate to see that contaminated again for any reason."
Initially the collapse was believed to have been caused by an earthquake that measured 3.6 on the Richter scale. Now geologists and seismologists have all but ruled that out, suspecting instead that the readings were caused by the collapse itself.
Some environmental groups have charged that the collapse was caused by overmining to meet the heavy winter demand for salt. But an Akzo spokeswoman, Catherine Bolton, said that the vast majority of the salt mined this winter came from elsewhere in the mine.
Company officials believe that whatever caused the collapse disrupted an aquifer that is the source of the water flooding the mine. So far, the flooding has taken place in a relatively small section amounting to less than 10 percent of the total mine, Ms. Bolton said.
 
Trying to Level Volume
 "The vast majority of the mine is in fine shape," Ms. Bolton said.
The long-term answer is plugging the hole in the aquifer, company officials say, but meanwhile, they are seeking permission from the Environmental Conservation Department to discharge some of the salt water so the flooding does not get any worse.
"It would buy us some time," Ms. Bolton said.
Mr. Pearson maintains there are not many options besides pumping water into the river. The volume of water is too great to haul away by train or truck. A pipeline would take too long to build, as would an evaporation plant.
The conservation department has not formally issued the company a permit for pumping the water into the Genesee River, but has drafted guidelines for one.
 
Keeping the Mine Open
 The department has proposed allowing the mine to pump water with 1,000 parts per million of chloride after complete mixing into the Genesee for 30 days and then 500 parts per million after that. Pumping would be significantly reduced in the summer when river levels are low. Water already in the mine that is heavily saturated with salt would remain there. The pumping would be aimed at keeping the volume of water in the mine from growing.
Keeping the mine open is considered vital to Livingston County, where Akzo is the third-largest private employer. When transportation jobs connected with the mine are included, Akzo is the largest private employer, accounting for some $50 million annually going into the local economy.
The environmental conservation department has held two public meetings to explain the water-pumping plan. At the first in Livingston County, the audience seemed receptive. But a second meeting in a Rochester suburb was contentious. At one point the department's regional director threatened to end the meeting if the audience did not improve its behavior.
Gary Neuderfer, an aquatic toxicologist with the conservation department who drafted the standards Akzo will have to meet for pumping water, said the river can safely handle the amount of salt water prescribed by his agency. He said salt water in the ocean contains about 18,180 parts per million of chloride.
"I fish the Genesee," he said. "I live here. I have a vested interest in protecting this river."

HEADLINE: Probability Experts May Decide Pennsylvania Vote

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Fraud, virtually everyone agrees, should not be allowed to decide the election of a public official. But how is a court to determine whether the fraud was decisive? How certain must it be to take the extreme step of seating the nominal loser?
That problem faces Judge Clarence Newcomer of Federal District Court in Philadelphia, who will soon decide whether to order a new election in Pennsylvania's Second State Senatorial District in Philadelphia or declare the losing candidate, Bruce Marks, a Republican, to be the winner last November. To help, Judge Newcomer has hired a consultant from Princeton University who is an expert in the mathematics of probability. 
 The analysis of the expert, Orley Ashenfelter, an econometrician, along with that of statisticians hired by the Republicans and Democrats, may or may not sway the judge.
At the very least, though, the work of the statisticians will give the judge a rigorous basis for arguing about the probabilities that the election was stolen, and the case offers a fascinating glimpse at the no-man's-land where the law's wish for certainty meets a reality that many events can be explained only in terms of chance.
 
Absentee Ballot Problem
 In the special election to fill a Senate vacancy, Mr. Marks received 19,691 votes on the voting machines to the 19,127 for William Stinson, his Democratic opponent. But in absentee ballots, Mr. Stinson outpolled Mr. Marks by 1,391 to 366, giving him a victory by 461 votes. And in spite of charges of fraud by the Republicans, Mr. Stinson, a former assistant Deputy Mayor of Philadelphia, was sworn into office, temporarily giving the Democrats exactly half the seats in the State Senate.
In February, Judge Newcomer ruled that many of the absentee ballots had been improperly obtained and processed by the Democratic-controlled Philadelphia County Board of Elections as part of a "massive scheme" to control the outcome of the election. In some cases, for example, registered Democrats were given absentee ballots and told that they need not go to the polls to vote. In other cases they were specifically guided to vote Democratic. Judge Newcomer declared Mr. Marks, a former aide to Senator Arlen Specter, to be the winner.
Then, on March 12, a Federal appellate court ruled on the case, letting the decision to void the results of the election stand, but ordering Judge Newcomer to reconsider his decision to seat Mr. Marks rather than to call a new election. Shortly thereafter, Mr. Stinson and two Democratic campaign workers were charged with election fraud by the Pennsylvania Attorney General, a Republican.
How might statistical theory be used to determine the probability of the Democrats' stealing the election?
Professor Ashenfelter's approach is to analyze the relationship between machine-counted votes and absentee ballots in state senatorial contests in Philadelphia over the last decade.
There have been 22 such contests since 1982, including the disputed 1993 election. And using the standard statistical technique of regression analysis, Professor Ashenfelter found that the difference between the Democratic and Republican tallies in the machine-based vote has been a good indicator of the difference between the two parties' absentee vote.
Assuming this relationship in the 21 previous elections had held in the most recent, Professor Ashenfelter estimates that the Republican's 564-vote edge on the machines should have led to a 133-vote advantage in absentee ballots. In fact, the Democrat ended up with a majority of 1,025 absentee votes.
 
Chance and Statistics
 But as Professor Ashenfelter readily acknowledges, the predicted relationship between machine and absentee balloting is statistical in nature and dependent on the stability of the historical relationship. There is some chance that random variations alone could explain a 1,158-vote swing in the 1993 contest -- the difference between the predicted 133-vote Republican advantage and the 1,025-Democratic edge that was reported.
More to the point, there is some larger probability that chance alone would lead to a sufficiently large Democratic edge on the absentee ballots to overcome the Republican margin on the machine balloting. And the probability of such a swing of 697 votes from the expected result, Professor Ashenfelter calculates, was about 6 percent.
Putting it another way, if past elections are a reliable guide to current voting behavior, there is a 94 percent chance that irregularities in the absentee ballots, not chance alone, swung the election to the Democrat, Professor Ashenfelter concludes.
Paul Shaman, a professor of statistics at the Wharton School at University of Pennsylvania who is the statistical consultant retained by the Democrats, exploits the limits in Professor Ashenfelter's reasoning. Relationships between machine and absentee voting that held in the past, he argues, need not hold in the present. Could not the difference, he asks, be explained by Mr. Stinson's "engaging in aggressive efforts to obtain absentee votes?"
Elizabeth Holtzman, New York City's former Controller who has had a practical education in the vagaries of election statistics, agrees. With the exceptionally low turnout in the State Senate contest -- no surprise in a special election -- she believes it is unfair to project voter sentiment from historical relationships.
Brian Sullivan, the statistical consultant working for the Republicans who is an economist with the Center for Forensic Economic Studies in Philadelphia, responds to some of Professor Shaman's and Ms. Holtzman's objections. He analyzed the findings of a post-election poll of registered voters who had applied for absentee ballots. From the survey responses that he judged most reliable, he estimated that 84 percent of the absentee ballots had been illegally solicited or cast. By this reckoning, even if every legitimate absentee vote had gone to the Democrat, the Republican would still have won a majority in the overall vote.
Professor Shaman questions the quality of the survey, which was conducted by Republican campaign workers without supervision by neutral professionals. He notes, among other things, that the survey implies a total of 1,395 absentee ballots were illegitimate -- more than the total absentee ballot vote for Mr. Stinson.
 
Polluted by Irregularities
 Where does this leave an impartial observer? There is certainly a widespread impression that the election was badly polluted by irregularities. Were Mr. Stinson convicted of election fraud he would not be eligible to serve in the Senate, even if an analysis later found that the fraud was insufficient to change the election result. But those observations are of little help in deciding whether to seat Mr. Marks or call another election -- an election that would be won by the Democratic candidate if registered voters cast their ballots along party lines.
Lowell Finley, a partner in the San Francisco firm of Altshuler, Berzun who specializes in election law, thinks the burden of choice should rest on those who would declare a winner in the absence of certainty. "In a democracy voters ought to have the last word," he argues, "not judges."

HEADLINE: Connecticut Set to Change The Guard

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., April 7

 BODY:
When Connecticut voters go to the polls in November to choose their next governor, the top line on the ballot will belong to A Connecticut Party, the party of the victor in 1990, Lowell P. Weicker Jr.
But now that Mr. Weicker is leaving office, whether voters are interested in continuing their experiment with an independent governor remains to be seen. 
 Mr. Weicker, most politicians grant, has proved that a governor can govern without a major party behind him. He has accustomed the state to hearing its chief executive say what many people think: partisan politics does not make good government.
And the party he founded will have a well-financed candidate, Lieut. Gov. Eunice S. Groark, to carry the anti-politics, good-government banner forward to November.
 
Coattails Not Apparent
 But Democratic and Republican leaders say A Connecticut Party has never been anything more than a personal vehicle for Mr. Weicker, and a recent poll by the University of Connecticut found that image widespread. Four out of five people surveyed said they expected the party to disappear after Mr. Weicker's term.
"Lowell Weicker continues to be seen to a great extent as Lowell Weicker," said G. Donald Ferree, the director of The Connecticut Poll, done by UConn's Institute for Social Inquiry. "It's not at all clear that he's been able to transfer that to anybody."
Mr. Weicker's legacy to state politics may prove to be his removal of the great unmentionable, the personal income tax, as a block to the candid debate of issues. Or it could be the younger generation of political leaders who are entering a field cleared for them by his tenure.
But this year, at least, his third party will have an influence by holding over Democrats and Republicans the continuing suspicions of the state's voters as the candidates debate how to turn around Connecticut's bleeding economy and create jobs. The candidates are acknowledging that influence by pledging to talk straight and with specifics on the issues. Good government and heeding the people's will are all the rage.
 
Leaving Politics of Blame
 "This period has provided us with an opportunity to get away from the politics of blame," said Senator John B. Larson of East Hartford, who is supported by much of the old Democratic leadership even as he talks of the potential for a "paradigm shift" in the way government operates.
"Weicker's not going to be the focal point," Mr. Larson said. "It's going to be the candidate who can be candid with the people and put forth solutions. People want to take back their government."
The State Comptroller, William E. Curry Jr., who will challenge Mr. Larson at the Democratic convention and is expected to wage a primary fight if he falls short there, said the state government itself is an issue.
"One thing this campaign is about is a generational change in the political leadership of the party and of the state government," he said. "It's about looking at some of the old orthodoxies with fresh eyes and making a transition that is long overdue."
"The anger over the performance of government is as deep-seated as it has ever been. People don't really believe that it is capable of change."
How well Mrs. Groark does in November may be most critical to the Democrats, who finished third in 1990 with only 21 percent of the vote, after holding the governorship for 32 of the previous 36 years.
Mr. Marcus, the Democrats' state chairman, says the election "is kind of like Armageddon" for the party, as he lobbies for unity among Mr. Larson, Mr. Curry, and two other candidates, State Senator Richard J. Balducci of Newington and Joseph P. Ganim, the Mayor of Bridgeport.
The Republicans, a smaller party with a more loyal core of voters, could again gain from a three-way race. John G. Rowland, the former Congressman from Waterbury who nearly beat Mr. Weicker in 1990, is hoping to block a primary challenge by the Secretary of the State, Pauline R. Kezer, and then turn Mr. Weicker's record against both Mrs. Groark and the Democrats.
 
'They Worked With Weicker'
 "Whoever is running for the Democratic Party has to run on the record of the Democrat-controlled Legislature," said Mr. Rowland's press secretary, Richard Slawsky. "They can't run away from that record, and it is a real handicap. Start with the fact they worked with Weicker to give us the income tax."
Mrs. Groark says she will run on the Weicker administration's record of restoring the state's financial stability and of fighting the recession by cutting business taxes and making loans and grants to employers.
"We've invested too much time and energy to allow the state to be turned back to partisan politics, where it's the strength of the party or someone's candidacy that is more important than the welfare of the people," she said.
"The Democrats and Republicans would like to think that if they turn around and look the other way, this candidate and A Connecticut Party will disappear. But I'm running on our record, and there is very little else to talk about in this campaign."
 
Anything More Than Weicker
 The ultimate question is whether A Connecticut Party has come to mean anything to voters apart from Mr. Weicker, a former three-term Republican Senator who was perhaps the state's best-known politician when he formed his own party in 1990.
Peter Gold, a former Weicker hand who now is Mrs. Groark's campaign chairman, said the party, with only 1,770 members, is mainly a legal mechanism for putting a third candidate on the ballot.
It succeeded, he said, by appealing to the broad interests of voters across party lines, just as Mr. Weicker has governed in Hartford by forming coalitions of Democrats and Republicans and mediating what Mr. Gold called "the partisan interests that tend to overwhelm the system."
But while the poll by the Institute for Social Inquiry found that residents were persuaded that an independent governor could govern, it found little evidence that they thought the nature of governing had changed. And only one in 10 thought A Connecticut Party would become an established party.
The independent streak among Connecticut voters is more a lack of commitment to the major parties than an identification with a new one, said Mr. Ferree, the poll's director.
"Lowell Weicker is seen as being something unto himself, and should she be elected, Eunice Groark would most likely be seen as something unto herself," Mr. Ferree said. "It is fair to say that the present administration, and its possible successor, may well be an interlude."

HEADLINE: Truck Strike Impact Seen As Limited

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 10

 BODY:
The American economy is likely to wiggle through even a lengthy trucking strike by the teamsters' union with minimal disruptions, transportation experts and business executives say.
Since the 75,000 teamsters walked out at 22 trucking companies at midnight Tuesday, there have already been anecdotal reports of shipments canceled, production schedules altered and other dislocations, and experts expect many more, including scattered manufacturing layoffs, if the strike lasts more than a week. But no one expects a repeat of 1979, when a much broader 10-day teamster strike against 500 companies provided a severe if short-lived economic jolt that forced the Chrysler Corporation, for one, to shut down 9 of its 10 North American auto assembly lines. 
 The greatest concern about the impact of this strike has been that many companies -- including auto makers, which are the primary pace setters for the industrial sector -- are operating more leanly than ever before to reduce the amount they have invested in inventories. But their dependence on more frequent delivery of raw materials and components from suppliers has not led to greater reliance on the teamsters union.
Instead, the huge expansion in the last decade of the nonunionized trucking sector has given them unprecedented flexibility in choosing how to ship goods and materials while new computer systems have helped them use that flexibility more wisely.
"I doubt there will be anyone screaming to Congress to intervene," said Hugh Randall, head of the transportation group at Mercer Management Consulting, a firm in New York that often studies logistics issues.
The most obvious change since 1979 has been the creation of an estimated 30,000 trucking companies after the deregulation of the industry in 1980, resulting in a total of 45,000 companies today. Members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, who once accounted for nearly 90 percent of intercity truck traffic by tonnage, now handle about 15 percent in total and less than half in the "less than truckload," or L.T.L., business, the segment that is the target of the current strike.
L.T.L. carriers generally pick up loads from 50 pounds to 10,000 pounds and often handle several different orders in a run that goes to a variety of destinations. They face competition at the high end of their $18 billion market from full-truckload carriers, who prefer to take an entire truckload of materials from a single pickup point to a single delivery site, and at the low end from companies like the United Parcel Service and Roadway Package Systems.
 
Gains by Alternative Shippers
 Some L.T.L. customers are also being wooed by alternative shippers like airlines and railroads. Some of these shippers have been able to consolidate small loads into full truckloads, which can then be handled by truckers not affected by the strike, or better yet stacked onto trains.
Wall Street analysts say such "intermodal" truck-train traffic can cut fuel costs by as much as two-thirds per ton shipped. Railroads can ship the same tonnage as trucks over a long distance with one-seventh the number of workers.
While less obvious, the economy's vulnerability to a teamsters' strike has been tempered by new technology as well as by the increase in nonunion truckers and other transport options. The process of becoming leaner has forced many companies to develop a clearer picture of where they should focus their efforts when faced with transportation disruptions. Billions of dollars have been invested in computerized inventory and production management systems that allow them to keep better track of their operations.
"Companies have a much better idea of what they need," Mr. Randall of Mercer Management Consulting said. Beyond that, the entire transportation system has become so laced with computer-based management systems that adjustments to disruptions can be made far more efficiently.
Initially, these management systems have been used primarily to help customers of the struck carriers figure out which goods now stuck in transit can be quickly retrieved and shipped on to their destination using alternate carriers.
 
Technology's Impact Unclear
 "In the past, there wasn't much information that accompanied shipments," said Gary Malek, contract and planning manager for the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company of St. Paul, which expects to have recovered 90 percent of its shipments trapped by the strike by Wednesday. "Now we know exactly where our freight is."
How much the new technology helps will not be apparent for a while. A significant number of companies and their carriers took precautionary steps in advance of the strike. Yellow Freight Systems, the largest of the struck L.T.L. carriers, delivered so much freight on the Monday and Tuesday before the strike began that it had about half its normal load in transit when the teamsters walked about, said Kathy Finlen, a spokeswoman for Yellow Freight, based in Overland Park, Kan.
 
Problem Areas Remain
 Companies like Minnesota Mining, which has a routine plan for anticipating all sorts of labor conflicts, had used its electronic mail system to tell customer service teams to anticipate a strike in talking with customers about promotions or other projects that might create special shipping demands. There are still problem areas -- Mr. Malek cited hiccups in getting parts on schedule for production machinery scheduled for refurbishment -- but the company reports no significant interruptions to date.
"If you forecast your needs several days in advance, there's no problem," Mr. Malek said. "If you need a truck in a few hours, you could be in trouble."
The trouble results from the general strength of the economy, which already had many trucking companies scrambling to hire new employees and buy new equipment. Home Depot Inc., the rapidly growing home improvement chain based in Atlanta, stocked up in advance of the strike but now has low inventories of some products and is running into trouble with products delivered weekly by L.T.L. carriers, like power tools and plumbing accessories, said Peter Cleaveland, vice president of traffic and distribution.
Home Depot's distribution system is not set up to help manufacturers who rely on L.T.L. carriers to reach the chain, but others do have such flexibility. Cotter & Company, a cooperative in Chicago that represents more than 6,000 Tru-Value hardware stores, already picks up about 40 percent of the goods that are shipped to its distribution centers on return trips from delivery routes to its stores.
 
Making Adjustments
 "We have the capacity to grab more on the backhaul if manufacturers are having trouble getting things to us," Dean Challed, Cotter's national transportation manager, said.
The easiest adjustment for many suppliers is simply to ship products less often, which allows them to accumulate a big enough load to fill a truck on their own. That is what Corning Inc. is doing with some of its consumer glassware and scientific glass products, said Scott Proudfoot, the company's director of transportation. But strong demand from regular customers is limiting the ability of full-truckload companies to pick up all of the business being offered by L.T.L. customers. That adds to the demand for L.T.L. truckers not on strike.
"We are at or near capacity in every location," said Jeff Jordan, spokesman for Overnite of Richmond, Va., a subsidiary of the Union Pacific Corporation, which is the largest L.T.L. carrier not being struck. "Some locations are handling double their normal volume."
Some of the adjustments are temporary measures likely to be undone as soon as the strike ends. But others will not. Mr. Malek of Minnesota Mining said that once a company begins reconfiguring its shipping patterns, it often discovers that some of the changes result in faster and cheaper service than it had been living with in the past.
Minnesota Mining has begun shipping tape products from its plant in Hutchinson, Minn., to its distribution center in Forest City, Iowa, where full truckloads are made up for shipment around the country, instead of shipping via the distribution networks set up by national L.T.L. carriers.
"In many cases, we won't go back to the old arrangements," he said.

HEADLINE: Lawyer Says Rifkin Will Plead Insanity In L.I. Murder Case

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., April 10

 BODY:
Lawyers for Joel Rifkin, a 34-year-old Long Island man who has confessed to killing 17 women, say they will try to convince a jury that he was insane and unable to tell right from wrong when he strangled his victims and disposed of their bodies.
"It won't be the easiest task, but in this case I think the facts support such a defense," said John Lawrence, Mr. Rifkin's lawyer. "It will no doubt come down to a debate between experts." 
 The trial is to begin Monday in Nassau County Court with jury selection, which both the defense and prosecution expect to take several days.
"Because of all the pretrial publicity, it's probably going to take some time before a fair and impartial jury can be selected," said Mr. Lawrence.
He said that Mr. Rifkin was "well aware of what is going on" in planning his defense. "He is in his cell in solitary confinement for 22 hours a day, and the trial is what he dwells on primarily."
Fred Klein, the prosecutor, has been anticipating an insanity defense, which many law-enforcement officials view as a last-ditch effort. Mr. Rifkin, an unemployed landscaper, has been imprisoned in Nassau County Jail since he was arrested on June 28, 1993, in the killing of Tiffany Bresciani, 22. Her body was found in Mr. Rifkin's van after he crashed into a telephone pole, ending a 20-minute chase that began when the police tried to pull him over for a missing license plate.
After his arrest, Mr. Rifkin admitted killing 16 other women, recalling the details in a 12-page confession. Although he is to be tried in Nassau for a single count of murder, he is expected to face trial in the other killings in Suffolk County, Queens and Brooklyn.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
The auto industry isn't afraid of higher interest rates, yet.

BYLINE: By James Bennet 

 BODY:
ARE rising interest rates a threat to automobile sales and auto makers' earnings?
Not yet, in the view of Wall Street analysts, dealers and auto executives. The increases brought on by the Federal Reserve so far have not deterred buyers, Alexander J. Trotman, the chairman and chief executive of the Ford Motor Company, said at a news conference before the recent New York Auto Show. 
 "Interest rates are perceived as low in general by our buyers out there -- potential buyers -- and we've seen no damage from the recent turns of the screw," Mr. Trotman said.
But, Mr. Trotman added, he is not encouraging anyone to raise rates further. "We're hopeful that if there are any further increases this year, they would be extremely modest," he said.
One worry in the industry has been that far from scaring away buyers, the prospect of higher rates could start a stampede toward the showrooms, as consumers tried to lock in low rates. Such a response could shorten the auto recovery, causing it to peak earlier than 1996 or 1997, as most analysts have projected. Sales ran far stronger than expected in February and March.
Some sales people have incorporated the possibility of a rate increase into their pitches. Jas Marilley, a salesman for the Norm Reeves Honda Superstore in Cerritos, Calif., has warned wavering buyers that rates could reach 11 percent in six months. "I definitely preach doom if I want to increase the urgency," Mr. Marilley said.
But for the most part, executives, dealers and analysts say car buyers do not base their decisions on fears of future interest rates. "I don't think anyone who needs a car will go out and buy one just to head off an interest rate," said Abe Wiaz, sales manager for Englewood Dodge in Englewood, N.J. "He may do that with houses, but not cars."
Dealers said interest rates would not have much impact on car buying unless they hit double digits. Five years ago, buyers could pay 12 percent interest; today they can easily find financing for much less. At Star Hickey Ford in Detroit, for example, a customer buying a $19,000 Taurus could expect to pay about 8 percent interest, with $1,000 down -- yielding payments of about $385 a month for four years. An increase of half a percentage point, dealers argue, would translate into only a few extra dollars a month.
Still, analysts contend that interest rates do not scare off consumers by increasing the monthly payment, but by dampening their confidence in the economy. "I do see interest rates as a threat to consumer psychology that causes people to pull back from discretionary spending across the board," said Philip K. Fricke, auto analyst with Prudential Securities in New York.
The basic ingredients of the auto recovery are still in place, auto market bulls say. Consumer confidence remains high, employment is rising and cars on average are older -- about 7.5 years -- than they have been since 1946.
Rates would have to climb about two full percentage points before they began to scare off buyers, said Gurudutte Baliga, assistant portfolio manager for IDS Financial Services in Minneapolis. As a result, he said, he still favors the Big Three auto stocks because "these companies are going to definitely deliver the earnings."
Mr. Baliga predicted that if the growth of the economy was stable at about 3.5 percent, the auto market would not peak until 1996, at more than 17 million cars and light trucks -- well above its high of 16.2 million in 1986.

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Whitewater Pulse

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Every scandal has its pulse. Whitewater has entered a quiescent stage. As investigators silently dig deeper, previous revelations sink in:
Let's say I want to make an untraceable investment in a political figure. How could I launder the donation and even get a tax deduction for it? 
 I might find a broker willing to "allocate" trades in the futures market -- that is, to put in orders to buy and sell at the same time. He could then allocate the winning trade to my political friend and the losing trade to some poor sucker, or even to me; I would then take my losses on the down side of the "straddle," using them to reduce taxable gains from other trades.
In that way, a pol or his wife could make a bundle with no risk and little or nominal capital. The pol gets rich on reportable profits, while I have laundered -- effectively hidden -- my contribution to him.
This beats slipping cash under the table. Not only is my political friend's newly "made" money usable for other investments, the transaction is too complicated to outrage most voters.
Some mean-spirited partisans are advancing that hypothesis -- with no evidence offered in this case -- as a possible explanation of Hillary Rodham Clinton's ability to turn a thousand dollars (at most) into a hundred thousand in a single year.
That's a 10,000 percent return on her investment, more than just about any other investor in America in 1979. (Fair-minded observers will adjust for inflation; that makes hers a 9,987 percent return.)
The Clintons reject the sinister inference being drawn by slavering hounds of the press (especially the Wall Street Journal editorial page, which knows too much about straddles and futures). At first, the White House line was that the Clinton 100 G's -- some of which was later murkily invested in tax-sheltering Whitewater -- was the result of phenomenal investment acumen by a lawyer then still in her 20's.
Yesterday, backpedaling Clinton aides admitted to The Washington Post that James Blair, lawyer to Tyson poultry interests, did the cattle-futures ordering in her behalf. (That's probably because the broker, "Red" Bone, told other reporters that Mrs. Clinton was a stranger to him.) Soon after the 9,987 percent profit, Mr. Bone was suspended for three years for the preferential way he handled trades and margin requirements.
Maybe Blair and Bone operated entirely within the law, and the Clintons received only good advice -- and not what some of us leap to opine was in effect a $100,000 gift.
The special counsel may not be following leads into these new areas. How can the public discover the truth? The answer: from sworn testimony in Congressional hearings.
Speaker Tom Foley and Banking Chairman Henry Gonzalez are succeeding in their stonewalling in the Democratic House. They expect counsel Robert Fiske to make a finding of suicide in Vincent Foster's death, rebuking only mildly the obfuscation of White House counsel Bernard Nussbaum, who chose Fiske. The Speaker will then declare hearings unnecessary.
In the Senate, however, Republican leader Bob Dole will deliver a letter at noon today to majority leader George Mitchell specifying a proposed makeup and timing of the investigating committee; the experienced fraud squad on Senator Sam Nunn's government operations staff should be Mr. Bone's interlocutor. Hearings on confirmation of a Supreme Court justice could be held up until Whitewater hearings are under way.
Why pursue this "old story" to its source? Because when Whitewater was first exposed by The New York Times in early 1992, candidate Clinton effectively squelched it with a legal-accounting "report" that was at least misleading, and may turn out to be a tissue of lies. If so, President Clinton should be held accountable.
The pulse beats on: the mortification of civil penalties, not impeachment, may be in store.
Would it weaken this Presidency? Sadly, yes. But for one-party government to condone a campaign cover-up would damage the American system far worse -- which is why the truth about Whitewater must be flushed out.

HEADLINE: PULSE;
Car Pooling

 BODY:
New York City's first car pool lanes will open next Monday morning on the Queensboro Bridge. "High-occupancy vehicle lanes," or H.O.V.'s, which are rare in the region, are meant to help governments and businesses comply with the Clean Air Act by rewarding commuters who share their cars with others. The H.O.V. that opened last month on Interstate 80 in New Jersey was expected to be used by about 600 vehicles an hour but so far it is getting more use than that, state transportation officials say. Vehicle counts for car pool lanes on Interstate 84 in Connecticut were declining -- partly because of the area's weak economy, officials say -- until last year when the rules were relaxed to allow cars with as few as two occupants to take the lane. The car pool lanes shown are open to vehicles with two or more people, busses and all motorcycles.

HEADLINE: In Musical Odessa, Playing On for the Love of It

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ODESSA, Ukraine

 BODY:
Somehow, they just keep playing. Despite the poverty and the loss, the bleak future and the burdensome past, the musicians of Odessa refuse to lay down their instruments.
With little state support and even less from private business, orchestras throughout the former Soviet Union are wasting away. Music schools can no longer afford to pay for electricity, let alone salaries or instruments. 
 The great orchestras of Moscow and St. Petersburg have gone begging for rent money.
And here, in the musical center of Ukraine, where Jascha Heifetz was born and where generations of the world's most gifted virtuosos have been produced -- the violinists David Oistrakh, Nathan Milstein, Isaac Stern, for example, and the pianists Benno Moiseiwitsch and Emil Gilels -- the economic situation is as bad as it can be. The entire annual payroll of the 103-member Odessa Philharmonic Orchestra, less than $34,000, would not be enough to hire a good second violinist for the New York Philharmonic.
"Every one of us has considered leaving," said Viktor I. Kuzikov, the Odessa's 50-year-old concertmaster, who recently received Ukraine's highest artistic award. "And of course many, many have. But there is something about this city, I don't know what it is, that won't let go of me. It isn't easy to explain, but there is a quality about Odessa, sadness maybe, or desire, that makes music more beautiful."
 
Prodigy Factory
 It has always been this way. This cosmopolitan city has long supplied the concert halls of the world with its musical prodigies, drawn, as Isaac Babel recalled in one of his memorable tales of Jewish life here, from the slums of the Moldvanka. Children when they were 4 or 5 would be plucked "from the evil-smelling courtyards of the Old Market," he wrote, and shipped off to a "factory of infant prodigies, a factory of Jewish dwarfs in lace collars and patent leather pumps," where they would learn to play the violin.
Mr. Stern once joked that cultural exchanges between the United States and the Soviet Union were simple affairs: "They send us their Jews from Odessa," he said long after he moved to America. "And we send them our Jews from Odessa."
Little has changed. The smells still linger in the Moldvanka. And so does the talent. Here there are no basketballs in the broad courtyards, no Michael Jordan T-shirts. The streets are filled with 10-year-old boys clutching violin cases. The Philharmonic, housed in the acoustically dead former stock exchange building and conducted by a charismatic young American, sells out every concert. And at the school of Pyotr Stoliarsky, one of the world's renowned training grounds for young musicians, the thick stone walls ring with the rich sound of children's dreams.
 
Different in Odessa
 "We are just fanatics about our music," said Pavel P. Butovsky, the deputy director of the Stoliarsky School. "It's in the water or the air. There is this belief now in Moscow and abroad that technical skills above all are the path to achievement. That without them you can be nothing.
"We have always disagreed. Here you play with the heart. First comes the freedom. Then comes the technique."
Of course, the Stoliarsky approach to musical education could hardly be described as lax. The 400 students who enroll in the 11-year program are expected to practice daily, from dawn to dark. And they are expected to practice what they are told to practice. But since its creation in the early years of the century, students here have always been taught to use their technique to communicate something more profound than physical dexterity.
The results are beyond dispute. The school no longer keeps a list of international prizes awarded to its pupils on the wall of the director's office. It got too long. Just last month, three 10-year-old Stoliarsky students took the first three prizes in a competition in Kharkov in central Russia, bringing home $200 each, more than the average annual salary for many adults here.
There is an unlikely guiding spirit behind Odessa's current musical vitality. Hobart Earle, the 34-year-old Princeton graduate who conducts the Philharmonic, is the first American to be the conductor of an orchestra in the former Soviet Union. And in March, after the Odessa Philharmonic sold out three straight performances in Kiev, he became the first foreigner to be honored by the Ukrainian President, Leonid M. Kravchuk. Last year, Mr. Kravchuk granted the orchestra federal status, making it eligible, members joke dryly, to receive no salary like the rest of the country.
 
Harder Every Day
 Mr. Earle, who first came here in 1990 when he was living in Vienna, took the orchestra abroad for the first time last year to the United States, where it performed in Carnegie Hall in front of many former Odessites. In the fall the musicians plan to tour Austria, Germany and Switzerland. And their concerts in the Ukrainian cities of Chernivtisi, Lvov, and Ivano-Frankovsk all sold out, bringing live performances to people who had never attended a concert.
Despite the abundance of talent, success gets harder every day. Touring at home seems impossible. Touring abroad has become the orchestra's only hope of earning enough money to stay alive. The average wage of $27 a month (twice what any other Ukrainian orchestra earns) still barely covers food bills. An attempt by Mr. Earle to replace fragile old handwritten orchestral parts with printed sheet music has been stymied by costs. Most of the orchestra's instruments are so bad that the average American high school would toss them out. When it travels abroad, the orchestra borrows drums.
"It's really very frustrating," said Mr. Earle, who came here without knowing a word of Russian but now speaks it and Ukrainian fluently. "They are capable of so much. And they have achieved so much. But to go to the next level without decent instruments or housing or a hall that even has a changing room seems very difficult to imagine." He isn't giving up though. He has a dream of building cooperative apartments for orchestra members in Odessa. For the many musicians who share a room with seven or eight other people, often without heat or plumbing, it would be a miracle.
Mr. Earle also wants to move the orchestra from the ornate, old stock exchange building, a beautiful place to watch music but a horrible place to hear it, to a new hall. "But that," he said, "would take a Carnegie, or a Mellon or a Rockefeller. Somebody with roots here who wants to come to the rescue."
So far no such person has appeared. Donations have been on a smaller scale: the Chicago Symphony Orchestra sent bow hair and strings last year for example, and some desperately needed sheet music has come from Europe.
 
No Compromises
 There are even artists here who fear success, who seem to find comfort in the eternal struggle to survive that occupies so much of their energy.
"I am totally free," said Sergei Terentiev, who many people feel is the city's most gifted pianist. "I never compromise. It is easy for me, of course, there has never been anything to compromise for." Mr. Terentiev has performed in St. Petersburg and Moscow, but under Communism his free interpretations of classics by composers from Liszt and Chopin to Bill Evans and Keith Jarrett were not widely appreciated.
"I was not asked back," he said, without a trace of unhappiness. "They would have preferred that I disappear."
Things are changing for Mr. Terentiev, a wildly bearded man of 50 who recently returned from the Festival of Music in Perth, Australia, where he received unanimous acclaim both for his classical performances and for jazz improvisations.
"Now I am asked again to perform and to travel," he said, warily. "But it is such a risk to go abroad. To change language and tempo. It is so dangerous. It could be interesting to work abroad for a while. After all Tchaikovsky did it, Glinka did it. But I love this place. And I am afraid what will happen if I leave it."

HEADLINE: Money Growing on Trees? No, but Study Finds Next Best Thing

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
PLANTING trees in cities and suburbs can reap millions of dollars in long-term savings by making it less costly to heat and cool buildings, by absorbing air pollution and by conferring a range of other environmental benefits, according to a study by the United States Forest Service.
The three-year study focused on metropolitan Chicago, and the researchers estimated that planting 95,000 trees in Cook and DuPage counties would result in a net benefit of $38 million over 30 years. 
 Scientists have long known that trees exert a cooling effect, absorb pollutants, improve water quality, lessen flooding and abate noise, among other benefits. But the new study is believed to be the first to put dollar amounts on the benefits and measure them against the cost of planting and maintaining trees in a specific area. In the course of their investigation, the researchers also produced an unusually detailed examination of the role of vegetation in an urban-suburban ecosystem.
 
Questions of Worth
 Metropolitan Chicago is particularly well endowed with trees -- more than 50 million of them in the two-county study area, according to the study report by Dr. E. Gregory McPherson, Dr. David J. Nowak and Dr. Rowan A. Rowntree, all research foresters with the Forest Service.
Trees "have long been recognized as valuable community assets" by Chicagoans, Dr. McPherson wrote. But, he went on, officials faced with dwindling budgets are questioning whether trees are worth the cost of planting and maintenance, and homeowners are beginning to wonder whether coping with fallen leaves, invasive roots, grass-killing shade and broken branches is worth the trouble. "Urban forestry programs," he wrote, "must now prove their cost-effectiveness."
The report estimated that in 1991 alone, the value of the removal of pollutants like carbon monoxide, sulfur dioxide, ozone and particulate matter from the air by trees amounted to $9.2 million in the study area.
By providing shade and blocking winter winds, the study found, a single 25-foot tree can reduce annual heating and cooling costs by 2 to 4 percent, and three adroitly placed trees could save Chicago homeowners $50 to $90 a year. The economic analysis found that energy savings could exceed costs by 35 percent for trees planted near typical two-story buildings and by 90 percent for trees near energy-efficient wood-frame buildings.
"You can manage your trees to improve energy efficiency by planting the right species in the right spot and doing the right pruning," Dr. Nowak said.
For example, trees planted on the western side of a house generally provide maximum shade. Trees planted on the southern side would also increase the cooling; but in northern climes, they would also block valuable southern sunlight in the winter, thereby raising heating costs. Even the branches of leafless deciduous trees can block 30 to 40 percent of incoming solar radiation, Dr. Nowak said.
Selecting "solar friendly" trees with open crowns that drop their leaves early in the fall and sprout them again late in spring can mitigate this problem, according to the report. Among solar-friendly trees listed in the study are, for instance, ash, Norway maple and poplar. And trees planted on the northern or northwestern side of homes in many northern areas can turn away chilling winter winds, reducing heating costs.
Street trees, which account for 10 percent of Chicago's trees and 24 percent of total leaf-surface area, were found to be a major source of building shade. The researchers calculated that the shade of a large street tree situated to the west of a typical brick residence can reduce the use of air-conditioning energy by 2 to 7 percent.
While the study found that large trees remove 60 to 70 times more pollution than do small ones, it also discovered that most of the Chicago area's trees are small. Many of these are invasive species that sprout readily in disturbed areas, grow quickly and live a relatively short time.
The most common trees are buckthorn, green ash, white ash, various species of the cherry family, box elder and the American elm. The invasive buckthorn, a European native originally imported as a decorative shrub that has widely proliferated and crowded out many native species,accounts for 12.7 percent of the total tree population but only 2.9 percent of total leaf surface, according to the study.
Buckthorn is being eradicated in some parts of the Chicago area as part of a program aimed at restoring some of the region's original oak savannas. For pollution reduction, it would be an advantage to replace buckthorn with bigger trees, Dr. Nowak said.
 
Doing the Calculations
 The overall cost-benefit calculations were based on the planting of 95,000 green ash trees, which were described as a typical tree species in the Chicago area. The calculations found that planting the trees and maintaining them for 30 years would cost $21 million, while the benefits conferred by the trees would be $59 million, for a net benefit of $38 million, or $402 per tree planted.
Environmentalists engaged in urban reforestation were quick to praise the study, contending that it bolstered their case for planting more trees in a time of budgetary limits.
"It's the first thorough study of a city that could be reasonably compared to a city like New York or other older, densely populated cities," said Nancy A. Wolf of the Environmental Action Coalition, a nonprofit research and educational group in New York.

 Pollution "storage"
 The amount of carbon stored annually by one tree with a 3-inch trunk diameter is estimated to equal the amount of carbon emitted by one car driven 10 miles.
 Best-placed trees

In the late 1980's, according to fresh census findings, the flow of welfare applicants into New York City all but dried up. HEADLINE: Electricity Stalls Power of Wind As a Statewide Source of Energy

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., April 11

 BODY:
With the cost of the technology dropping, windmills could help the Northeast meet its energy needs more cleanly, experts said today at a conference on renewable energy sources.
The catch is that, right now, the region is awash in cheap electricity, so there is little economic incentive to invest in windmills. 
 California is by far the largest user of wind, with windmills producing 1.2 percent of its electricity, and up to 7 percent in peak-demand periods. If every site were used, the state could generate one-third of its electricity with wind, said Donald Aiken, senior energy analyst at the Union of Concerned Scientists.
But New York State has even more wind power available than California, and could use wind to meet half its electricity needs if all potential sites were used, Mr. Aiken said.
 
Low Winds Forecast
 Wind projects are scattered around the Northeast, including one in New York State. But Bernard Fox, the president and chief executive of Northeast Utilities, which serves most of Connecticut and large parts of Massachusetts and New Hampshire, said, "We're not going to be ordering much of anything for the next few years."
The combination of the recession and conservation efforts means that the company will not need any new generating stations until well into the next decade, he said.
In addition, the company will not pay more for renewable energy than it has to, Mr. Fox said. Northeast is now paying $215 million a year for electricity from plants that burn wood or garbage that it could generate itself for $50 million. The reason is that it priced the power in the early 1980's by comparing it to the cost of oil, which was then high, and the estimated future cost, which was even higher. But the price of oil fell.
Utilities' use of renewable energy is important because electric companies consume more than 40 percent of all fuels used in the nation, and the proportion is rising; if the economy moves to non-depletable resources, the utilities will play a huge role.
The conference, organized by the Northeast Sustainable Energy Association, of Greenfield, Mass., drew hundreds of utility executives, scientists, environmentalists and others to the Sheraton Hotel here for three days of workshops and lectures. Wind, rain and sun each got their own conference room this afternoon.
Photovoltaic cells, which make electricity from sunlight, are also dropping in cost. Jane M. Weissman, coordinator of an inter-utility testing group, said that in Boston, despite three feet of snow in February, there were still 16 days of strong sun.
Solar-cell manufacturers have high hopes for the Northeast, particularly New York City and Long Island, which have the highest electric rates of almost anywhere in the country. Their product cannot make electricity nearly as cheaply as a conventional power plant, but the cells can produce electricity for less than the retail cost.
The technology that is closest to making its way in the competitive market on an unsubsidized basis -- and is beginning to do so -- is wind.
Hydro-Quebec, the Canadian provincial utility that exports hydro-electric power to the states in the Northeast, plans to install about 300 wind machines, with a capacity of 100 megawatts, on the south shore of the St. Laurence River in the next two years, a $110 million project. The wind will produce as much energy as 30 megawatts of hydroelectric capacity -- enough to power 15,000 houses, the utility says, and up to 40 megawatts on windy days in the winter, when demand is highest.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 1; Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1388 words

HEADLINE: Looking at the Markets;
With Future Bright, Stocks and Bonds Fall; Economists Grapple With Contradictions

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
For more than three years stock and bond prices marched optimistically upward in spite of economic forecasts that varied from murky to guarded. But once the clouds lifted to reveal a sunny future for the American economy, the securities markets took their worst dive since the recession of 1990.
Economists have a plausible explanation -- fear of inflation -- for this seeming paradox, but they have had a lot more trouble explaining the timing or depth of the mini-crash that jolted public confidence and left traders scrambling for portents of the aftershocks. 
 Indeed, economists are once again grappling uneasily with the contradiction between their textbook image of securities markets as well-oiled machines for grinding new information into prices -- sometimes referred to as "efficient markets" -- and the reality of securities traders who seem to stampede as mindlessly as groupies at a rock concert.
"We just don't understand the social psychology of financial markets," said Richard Thaler, an economist at Cornell.
The part that is well understood is that in a rational world, good news for the economy can be bad news for traded securities.
The price of a bond is inherently sensitive to changes -- or expectations of changes -- in the interest rates charged on freshly minted i.o.u.'s. So when the economy showed signs of heating up and the Federal Reserve tweaked interest rates in what was advertised as a pre-emptive strike against inflation, it is at least plausible that bond prices fell in anticipation of more interest rate increases down the pike.
Why stocks get jarred is trickier (but still possible) to rationalize. For one thing, said Burton Malkiel, an economist at Princeton, inflation raises the effective tax rate on corporate earnings because the tax laws do not take into account the fact that corporations incur the heavy burden of replacing worn-out capital equipment at higher cost. For another, periods of inflation often presage recession, and thus lower profits. So shifts in inflationary expectations could certainly lead to a sharp drop in stock prices.
This is hardly the whole story, however. While fear of inflation could explain why stock and bond prices tanked in tandem this winter, it doesn't say much about the timing or magnitude of the drop. Indeed, with hindsight, it is clear that the probability of an economic boom had been building for many months, as had talk that both stocks and bonds were due for a fall.
But if securities markets are really precision instruments for setting securities prices, why didn't they incorporate shifting opinions a little at a time, drifting down to a new level that fully incorporated the new expectations?
Mr. Thaler, for one, sees a possible answer in "herding" -- the notion that securities traders tend to act in concert, creating sharp breaks in securities prices rather than smooth adjustments. But, as he is happy to acknowledge, herding is more a description of what happens than an explanation for it.
One possibility is what Mr. Thaler calls "safety in numbers." Most decisions to trade securities these days are made by managers of mutual funds, pension plans and the like, who have a strong interest in not looking stupid when their competitors are looking smart. If, for example, a money manager buys when others are selling and the markets go down, he is likely to be out of a job.
On the other hand, it's almost O.K. to look stupid when everyone has also made a fool of himself. Hardly anyone blames a money manager who loses by doing just what the rest of the pack does.
 
How Keynes Saw It
 Another way of rationalizing herd behavior, offered by Jeremy Stein of the Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, draws on John Maynard Keynes's image of the stock market. Keynes likened the stock market to an unusual beauty contest that had been sponsored by his local newspaper. The pictures of a dozen women were displayed. But readers were asked to pick the one who they thought others would think prettiest, not the one they themselves thought prettiest. By analogy, Mr. Stein said, it is wrong to be right ahead of the pack -- to sell while others are still driving up prices, or to refrain from selling when everyone else is dumping stocks.
Yet another explanation for herding, one held dear by economists still wed to the idea that securities markets are efficient, is that actions speak louder than words -- that a lot of information is actually broadcast by the act of buying or selling.
Consider the last plunge in securities prices on the heels of the nudge by the Federal Reserve to interest rates and warning from its chairman, Alan Greenspan, that he had spotted inflation in his tea leaves. One might have expected an "efficient" market to anticipate the news and act accordingly. On the other hand, if the the major players in the market look to each other for confirmation of their suspicions, what looked like panic selling could have been a rational rush for the exits. And the rush could have been exacerbated by the need to unwind debts backed by falling stock values.
 
The Sheep's Perspective
 The trouble with herding hypotheses is that they do not begin to explain what investors and policy makers really want to know. It may be comforting to believe that herd behavior makes sense from the perspective of the sheep. But it doesn't provide a hint as to when the sheep will change direction, or how far they will stampede. Nor does history offer many clues, said William Schwert of the Simon Graduate School of Business at the University of Rochester.
According to Mr. Schwert, who has plotted the volatility of stocks over the last century, there are no discernible trends to be ferreted out. In spite of all the institutional changes over time -- the advent of securities regulation and standardized accounting procedures, the growth of professional money management, computerized trading, electronic distribution of business news -- the data on volatility show a monotonous squiggle of modest ups and downs, randomly punctuated by catastrophic breaks.
The last few months' market activity suggest no exception to the rule: Indeed, they are almost lost in the noise of history. "A lot of things that people think are important in explaining volatility probably aren't," Mr. Schwert concluded.
It is conceivable that market behavior is inherently "chaotic" in the sense that the timing and magnitude of market changes may be exquisitely sensitive to what natural scientists call "initial conditions."
 
Seemingly Random Dance
 Next month's weather will be no surprise in the sense that it will more or less follow from known rules of physics. But whether it rains or shines in Chicago next month, we now believe, may depend on effectively unknowable details of cloud and wind patterns this week halfway across the world. By the same token, it is conceivable that securities markets bounce from unstable equilibrium to unstable equilibrium within broad bands, in a seemingly random dance to the tune of simple responses of traders to each others' actions.
This would suggest that economists may someday understand what makes the stock market tick (the way meteorologists understand what makes weather), yet be forever precluded from accurately predicting the big bumps in stock indexes. Economists who study the securities markets, however, are not quite ready to stop worrying and learn to love chaos. Indeed, some believe that models of market behavior with predictive power may be within reach.
Robert Shiller of Yale is amassing data on how securities traders respond to other traders by asking them hypothetical questions. And some of the answers are provocative, if hard to interpret. For example, Mr. Shiller found that the percentage of professional money managers who believed that the stock market would go up the day after a 3 percent tumble fell from 34 percent in early 1990 to just 18 percent in mid-1990.
As yet, Mr. Shiller has no testable theory that would use surveys to predict trading behavior, but he is frustrated that social scientists are not more aggressively pursuing this approach. "Economists depend too much on what they observe" rather than what they could find out by asking, he laments.
