HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Bear, Stearns Hires Former Fed Governor

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
Bear, Stearns & Company, the Wall Street investment bank, said yesterday that it was appointing Wayne D. Angell, a former Federal Reserve governor and inflation hawk, as its chief economist.
Mr. Angell, 63, resigned from the Fed in early February after completing an eight-year term that included the stock market crash of 1987 as well as the beginning of the bond market meltdown of 1994. A fourth-generation Kansas wheat farmer, former banker and longtime economics professor at Ottawa University, a Baptist college in Ottawa, Kan., Mr. Angell is well known on Wall Street and in financial circles around the world. 
 He had been something of a gadfly at the Fed -- actively promoting his monetarist and supply-side views -- and has become a favorite of journalists, a popular speaker and a frequent contributor to opinion pages.
Mr. Angell is replacing another high-profile economist, Lawrence A. Kudlow, who resigned abruptly a little over a month ago and recently told journalists that he had been battling drug and alcohol addiction. Mr. Angell, a grandfather eight times over and a teetotaler, could scarcely be more different from Mr. Kudlow, a sophisticated baby boomer who grew up in the New York suburbs and attended Princeton University.
Senior managers at Bear, Stearns made it clear that they regarded Mr. Angell as a real catch. "He's got an incredible persona, he's highly respected, he's a hard money guy; there's no 'I'll tell you later' about him," said James Cayne, the firm's president. "It's not just a terrific hire, I'd call it a major step in building the franchise."
While Mr. Angell and Mr. Kudlow have markedly different backgrounds, they share a knack for getting attention, hold strong free-market views and exude brash self-confidence. Indeed, Mr. Kudlow had regarded Mr. Angell, the leading supply-sider in setting Fed policy, as something of a mentor.
"Wayne Angell follows perfectly in the Kudlow tradition," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence, the securities firm. "He's well connected, he's in the same philosophical tradition and he states his opinions very clearly."
To the firm, Mr. Angell is someone with whom Bear, Stearns clients, traders and salespeople will feel comfortable. His name recognition in financial circles abroad is a plus, given the firm's strong push into emerging markets from Argentina to China. And the fact that he is a close friend -- not to mention frequent tennis partner -- of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, doesn't hurt either, especially at a time Wall Street is fixated on the Fed's next interest rate moves.
 
An Indelible Mark at the Fed
 The fact that Mr. Angell does not have a track record as a forecaster is less important, several analysts asserted, than the fact that he took a strong stand in a variety of disagreements with other members of the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee. In the last year, as the Fed has kept interest rates low, Mr. Angell dissented four times, always urging the central bank to adopt a tighter policy of higher short-term interest rates than most of the rest of the committee wanted.
"He made an indelible mark on all of us," Lawrence B. Lindsey, a Fed governor and fellow anti-inflation hard-liner, said.
"I am much more attentive to commodity prices and price-level targeting than when I first became a governor," Mr. Lindsey added, referring to Mr. Angell's influence.
Bear, Stearns got in touch with virtually every big-name economist on Wall Street in an effort to fill Mr. Kudlow's shoes quickly. But once Mr. Angell -- whose name was put forward by an economist at the firm -- came on the scene, he had no serious rivals.
 
Not a Mouthpiece
 Mr. Angell, a former Kansas state legislator who once aspired to be a Republican senator, hit it off immediately with senior managers in his first meeting with them. "He was in New York to give a speech," Mr. Cayne said. "I asked him, 'How would you like to speak full time?' "
Mr. Angell had been planning to become a money manager, investing the resources of pension funds and other large institutional investors.
Asked what at Bear, Stearns appealed to him so much that he did not bother to look at other firms, he said, without missing a beat: "Right off the bat, I thought, 'Gee, these people are really very intelligent because they wanted me.' Wayne Angell isn't exactly the kind of person you go after if you want a mouthpiece."
Mr. Angell would not say how rich his compensation at Bear, Stearns would be, but senior managing directors, one of Mr. Angell's new titles, are thought to earn a base salary of $200,000. Bonuses generally run several times the base pay, and it is safe to say that Mr. Angell will be earning at least $1 million, if not more.
His new schedule will be grueling, requiring constant travel and frequent meetings with clients. But Mr. Angell, who rode 42 miles on his bicycle last weekend and often flies his own plane, says he has energy to spare.
Mr. Angell is not the first Fed official to try his hand on Wall Street. A former vice chairman, David W. Mullins Jr., recently joined a group of ex-Salomon traders at Long-Term Capital Management, and Paul A. Volcker, the former Fed chairman, is an investment banker at James D. Wolfensohn.

LENGTH: 803 words

HEADLINE: U.S. Puts Sanctions On Taiwan

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration said today that it was imposing trade sanctions on Taiwan for refusing to halt the sale of tiger bones and rhinoceros horns, the first time that Washington has deployed trade sanctions to protect the environment.
While trade sanctions have often been used by the United States as a lever to promote human rights or to lower trade barriers imposed by other countries, they have never been used to protect endangered wildlife. 
 "I am delighted that the U.S. has taken the lead in this worldwide battle to save the rhinoceros and tiger before it is too late," Diana E. McMeekin, head of the African Wildlife Foundation, said. "It is as if the governor has issued a last-minute stay of execution for those magnificent creatures on the edge of extinction."
The sanctions on Taiwan will involve a ban on all Taiwan wildlife-product exports to the United States, which amount to about $25 million a year in coral and mollusk-shell jewelry and in snake, lizard and crocodile skin shoes and other leather products, the White House said.
This is a fraction of Taiwan's trade with the United States, which last year involved $25.1 billion in exports to the United States and $16.25 billion in American exports to Taiwan.
 
 
Underground Trade
 Tiger and rhinoceros parts are used by people in Taiwan and many other Asian nations for medicinal purposes, and because many people consider them sexual stimulants. Their use has become so widespread that an underground trade has developed and populations of both animals have been decimated.
"This is the first time any country has acted on the international call for trade sanctions to protect endangered species, but if the illegal trade in rhinos and tigers is not eliminated, these species could be extinct in five years," President Clinton said in a statement. "The world must know that the United States will take strong actions to protect the earth's natural heritage."
[In a statement released Tuesday in Taipei, Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs expressed "deep regret and dissatisfaction over the U.S. Government's obviously unfair and unjust sanction." Asked if Taiwan planned reprisals, a Government spokesman, Eric Chiang, said, "We haven't discussed any counteractions."]
The American move underscores the fact that as trade grows more global and as barriers between countries come down, the environmental consequences can be enormous. When advances in hunting techniques are combined with lower trade barriers and rapidly growing populations that demand medicines made from exotic wildlife, a species can be wiped out in one generation.
Tigers, commonplace in circuses and zoos around the world, will shortly be extinct in the wild if this trade is not stopped. At the turn of the century, the world tiger population was estimated at about 100,000; today, there are fewer than 6,000.
In 1970, there were more than 65,000 African black rhinos and today there are fewer than 1,800, according to the African Wildlife Foundation. There are only about 10,000 rhinos of all species left in the world.
It is a common practice in Asia to grind the bones of both animals for medicines and aphrodisiacs. Tiger and rhino parts are prescribed by doctors in Taiwan, China and Korea for fevers, arthritis and impotence.
The Administration's Interagency Rhino/Tiger Task Force, which recommended sanctions to the President last week, had been considering imposing sanctions on China as well. At the last minute it decided to act only against Taiwan, saying China had taken some limited steps to curb the sale of exotic-animal parts.
At a time when Chinese-American tensions are running high over human rights issues and Washington is considering revoking Beijing's preferential trade status, the Administration probably did not want to open a new front with the Chinese on wildlife -- even though the Chinese are considered by experts to be among the worst offenders.
Still, the move against Taiwan, argued the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, constitutes "a major step forward."
"Other administrations have threatened these kinds of measures to protect the environment before, but none has ever acted," he said.
The United States had warned Taiwan and China in November that it might impose trade sanctions if they did not demonstrate by March 30 "measurable, verifiable and substantial progress" in curbing illicit trade in tiger and rhino parts.
China took some steps, the most notable a public burning of tiger and rhino medicines, and made an effort to register stocks of those medicines and to educate people against their use. But Taiwan did little to satisfy American demands to safeguard rhinos and tigers, which are protected under the Convention on International Trade and Endangered Species.

HEADLINE: Bank Mutual Fund Saless Face Check

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
In a partial concession to Congressional critics, the Treasury Department announced today that its officials would begin making anonymous visits to banks to determine if bank officials were advising clients about the risks of putting their money into mutual funds.
At the same time, the Treasury, which is trying to maintain bureaucratic authority over the issue despite challenges in Congress, announced a plan that would effectively expand its oversight of bank's sales of such funds. The alternative would have been to hand this responsibility over to the Securities and Exchange Commission, a step opposed by banks but urged by some members of Congress who consider the S.E.C. better staffed and more independent. 
 The House Subcommittee on Telecommunications and Finance is scheduled to hold a hearing on Thursday on whether to bring in the S.E.C. to oversee bank-managed mutual funds.
 
Warning on Insurance
 The goal of the Treasury Department's planned anonymous visits is to force banks that sell mutual funds to warn customers that these investments are not insured by the Federal Government, unlike certificates of deposit and other bank accounts.
If the checks find banks to be behaving improperly, the Treasury has the power to fine banks or even order them to stop selling mutual funds.
Banks won the legal right to sell mutual funds only a decade ago, but have only plunged heavily into the business in the last several years. With interest rates low in the early 1990's and the stock market growing strongly, many bank account holders switched into mutual funds and banks began selling the funds themselves to avoid losing these customers entirely.
An S.E.C. survey late last year of 1,000 households found that 66 percent believed erroneously that money market mutual funds sold through banks were Federally insured. The survey, released on Nov. 10, also found that 28 percent of the households believed that all mutual funds sold through banks were Federally insured. The S.E.C. also found that 36 percent of households thought that mutual funds purchased from a stockbroker were federally insured.
 
Checks Began in 1993
 Until now, the Treasury has contended that it could adequately oversee bank mutual fund sales through spot-checks by bank examiners. A Treasury agency, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, began making these checks late last year.
That stance has dissatisfied several influential members of Congress, who have introduced legislation to put the Securities and Exchange Commission in charge of overseeing bank-managed mutual funds.
John D. Dingell, the chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, has led these criticisms, with support from prominent Republicans on the committee and from Representative Edward J. Markey, the Massachusetts Democrat who heads the committee's panel on telecommunications and finance.
Eugene A. Ludwig, the Comptroller of the Currency, made two new proposals in a letter today to the Federal Reserve, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the Office of Thrift Supervision and the S.E.C.
 
Calls for Test on Sales
 He called for all five agencies to test bank sales practices. Leonora Cross, a spokeswoman for the Comptroller's office, said today that testing banks meant using anonymous visits.
The F.D.I.C. recently indicated that it would begin using anonymous visits. Ms. Cross said that the Comptroller's office planned to proceed with such visits regardless if any agencies other than the F.D.I.C. joined in.
Until now, the Comptroller's office has relied on reviewing bank sales pamphlets for mutual funds and checking banks' records of these saless, with some phone calls to mutual fund customers to ask whether they understood what they were buying.
"It is becoming increasingly clear to me, however, that we regulators also need to conduct testing in this area," Mr. Ludwig said.
 
Fear of Legal Issues
 The Federal Reserve Board has opposed the use of anonymous visits to test if banks engage in racial discrimination but has not taken a position regarding anonymous visits and mutual funds. Officials at the Office of Thrift Supervision declined to comment. The S.E.C. believes that anonymous visits raise legal issues that need further legal review, said Barry P. Barbash, the director of the division of investment management.
Mr. Ludwig also proposed an interagency task force that would involve each agency performing separate reviews of mutual funds operated by banks or savings and loans.
Mr. Markey, who wants the S.E.C. to play a greater role, warned that this approach might create a "hydra-headed regulatory monster.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops Against Yen On Fears of Trade Tension

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar finished sharply lower against the yen yesterday on the prospect of no early resolution to American and Japanese trade tensions.
The concerns were fueled largely by Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa's abrupt resignation in Tokyo on Friday. Despite assurances to the contrary from American officials, dealers said there was a growing perception that Mr. Hosokowa's departure would slow the pace of trade negotiations. 
 "The feeling is that with the political disarray in Japan, the Japanese are not going to take any actions in the near term to permit their current account surplus to decline," William Arnold, chief dealer at Chemical Bank, said.
American officials have argued strenuously for Japan to address its rising trade surplus with the United States by providing foreign products more access to the market.
Much of the dollar's decline against the yen occurred in overseas activity, with trading in New York relatively quiet by comparison.
The dollar was quoted at 103.48 Japanese yen late in New York, down from 105.26 yen on Friday. In Tokyo, it slipped to 104.48 yen, from 104.95 yen on Friday.
Dealers said they expected the dollar's weakness against the yen to continue, and some reckoned that the Bank of Japan might eventually be forced to intervene in the currency markets to halt the dollar's fall.
"The market is really going to test" the Bank of Japan, Stefan Carlsson, chief dealer at Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken N.Y., said, "to see how committed they are to defend dollar-yen levels."
In late trading against other leading currencies, the dollar was little changed. Against the German mark, the dollar was quoted at 1.7130 marks in late New York trading, up fractionally from 1.7125 marks on Friday. Earlier in Europe, the dollar stood at 1.7075 marks, down slightly from 1.7125 on Friday.
While officials from the German Bundesbank are scheduled to discuss prospective monetary policy on Thursday, traders said the widespread expectation was for no change in official interest rates.
The British pound slipped to $1.4690 in late New York trading, from $1.4760 on Friday. In London, it closed at $1.4715, from $1.4760 on Friday.
Other late dollar rates, compared with Friday's quotes, included: 1.4430 Swiss francs, down from 1.4455; 5.8675 French francs, barely changed from 5.8633; 1.3870 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3834, and 1,628 Italian lire, down from 1,633.

HEADLINE: Treasury Prices Mixed Ahead of Inflation Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday in moderate trading, as investors awaited new inflation data today and tomorrow.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond was up 8/32 , to 884/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from prices, was 7.23 percent, down from 7.25 percent on Friday. Ahead of reports on producer and consumer prices investors and dealers sharply reduce their trading. 
 The Labor Department releases the Producer Price Index for March today. Economists surveyed by the Reuters news service expect the closely watched gauge of wholesale prices to show an increase of one-tenth of 1 percent over all and an increase of two-tenths of 1 percent in the core, which excludes the more volatile food and energy components.
In February, producer prices rose half a percentage point and one-tenth of a percent when food and energy were excluded. That was slightly higher than analysts had expected, and the market rallied.
 
Consumer Report Is Due
 Tomorrow the Government will release the Consumer Price Index for March, which is a monitor of price pressures at the consumer level. The index is expected to be up two-tenths of 1 percent over all and three-tenths of 1 percent in the core.
Matthew F. Alexy, a government trading strategist at CS First Boston, said that the market was also likely to pay attention this week to the monthly retail sales report tomorrow and capacity utilization on Friday.
"The retail will give us a good idea of consumer spending and a better line on the gross domestic product for the first quarter," Mr. Alexy said. "Both the retail and capacity numbers probably offer the most potential to surprise the market, so everyone is being careful not to get caught too far out of position."
Mr. Alexy said that the market might have become a little oversold on the long maturities, which might have accounted for their rebound in the afternoon, supported by lower commodity prices and gold.
 
Attention to Fed
 And the market continues to pay attention to comments by Federal Reserve officials. The president of the Federal Reserve bank in Dallas, Robert McTeer, told the Association of Private Enterprise yesterday that he saw the first-quarter gross domestic product growing at an annual rate of more than 3 percent and saw inflation "behaving well."
In the municipal market yesterday, many investors were reluctant to make purchases as long as there was still the possibility of higher interest rates. That is one reason municipal bond prices have been hammered over the last couple of months.
As a result, few issuers were in the market. The biggest deal yesterday was a $199 million sale by Harris County, Tex., through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company.
The general obligation revenue bonds were initially priced to yield a maximum of 6.40 percent for an issue due in 2020. For shorter-maturity bonds serials were priced to yield from 6 percent in 2008 to 6.30 percent in 2013. An issue due in 2016 was priced to yield 6.35 percent.
Underwriters said the financing included zero-coupon bonds, which make no quarterly interest payment, but if held to maturity yield from 5.70 percent in 2001 to 6.25 percent in 2007.
The issue is rated Aa by Moody's Investors Service and AA+ by Standard & Poor's, expect for the zero coupons, which are insured by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corporation and are rated triple-A.
With the municipal market somewhat stablized, New York City priced a $250 million tax-exempt general obligation variable rate issue through J. P. Morgan Securities.
The debt issue has a 0.95 percent coupon and is offered with various maturity dates and at various prices, with a 10-year noncall provision. Underwriters report the issue is triple-A rated by Moody's and S.& P. because it is insured by Ambac, M.B.I.A. and the Financial Security Assurance.
At the Treasury's weekly bill auction of new three- and six-month securities, the average discount rates were mixed. The discount rate for a three-month bill was 3.63 percent, down from 3.71 percent last week.
The rate for a six-month bill increased to 4.03 percent, from 4.02 percent last week and is the highest rate at auction since March 30, 1992, when it was 4.19 percent.
The following are the results of yesterday's weekly Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: New York City Drawing Fewer In Need of Aid

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS 

 BODY:
In the late 1980's, according to fresh census findings, the flow of welfare applicants into New York City all but dried up. In stark contrast to the experience of a decade earlier, New York City appears to have become a net exporter of welfare families.
Between 1985 and 1990, an analysis of newly released census results shows, more families left New York and signed up for public assistance elsewhere than arrived in the city and joined the welfare rolls. 
 It appears that New York City's severe recession of recent years prompted many poor families to seek better opportunities elsewhere. The exodus may have been pushed by an erosion in the city's welfare benefits as well.
In the latter half of the 1980's, about 815,000 people moved to New York City. But only a minute fraction -- 30,000 adults -- told census takers that they were on welfare in 1989.
By contrast, in the like five years a decade earlier, nine times as many newcomers turned to welfare. In the late 1970's, 625,000 people moved to New York City, nearly 200,000 fewer than in the late 1980's. But a far larger proportion of them -- more than 270,000 adults -- told 1980 census takers they were relying on welfare.
If, as some scholars have argued, New York City's relatively generous welfare benefits were once an attraction, luring waves of poor people from the South, from Puerto Rico and from elsewhere in the United States, they are no longer.
"A major reversal has occurred in a historic trend," said Dr. Andrew A. Beveridge, a Queens College sociologist who conducted a computer analysis of fresh data from the 1990 census for The New York Times. "New York is no longer a welfare magnet." He said the migration trends found by the census probably continued into the 1990's.
The census results suggest that people who end up on welfare often are responding to the same allures as other people.
In the late 1980's, when New York City was in a severe recession, hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers moved away, mostly in search of better jobs. Their place was taken by hundreds of thousands of immigrants. Both of those flows -- the out-migration of New Yorkers and the great influx from abroad -- were mirrored in the welfare population.
For instance, during the late 1980's, half the newcomers who settled in New York and then collected public assistance came from outside the United States. Nearly as many new claimants to welfare emigrated from the former Soviet Union -- almost 5,000 -- as from all 49 states outside New York combined.
 
Shift Is Contrary To City's Image
 Charles R. Morris, who wrote "The Cost of Good Intentions -- New York City and the Liberal Experiment" (Norton, 1980), agreed that the shift is "completely contrary to the image." He suggested that New York City lost some allure because welfare grants did not keep pace with inflation and it became harder to survive.
"People were acting rationally and going elsewhere on the basis of an economic judgment," he said.
Not everyone agrees that New York was ever a "welfare magnet." Mitchell I. Ginsberg, who served as welfare commissioner in John V. Lindsay's administration, which saw a huge expansion of the rolls in the late 1960's and early 1970's, contends that many people were drawn here by job prospects, not higher benefits.
"In our experience, overwhelmingly, two things stood out," said Professor Ginsberg, dean emeritus of the Columbia University School of Social Work. "One is that people came for jobs and then couldn't make it. And secondly, they came because other family members here preceded them. They found their relatives, but they didn't find work."
Dr. James R. Dumpson, the city's Human Resources Administrator during the administration of Abraham D. Beame in the mid-1970's, recalled that by the 1980's, people were going to other "places of choice" because eligibility rules had generally become less stringent. Federal courts had ruled by 1970 that states could not deny public assistance to new residents, perhaps prompting an influx into New York, where benefits were still relatively high.
Among those who left the city in the 1980's and had to turn to welfare, about one in three were still living in the New York region. Two in three went elsewhere in the United States.
The computer analysis of the 1990 census results also found that the new New Yorkers who claimed public assistance defied durable stereotypes of poor blacks from rural states like South Carolina or semiliterate cane-cutters from Puerto Rico.
According to the 1990 census, more newcomers who landed on welfare came from New Hampshire, where applications for public assistance and food stamps soared in the late 1980's, than from South Carolina. Fewer than 200 natives of New Hampshire migrated to New York City, but nearly half of them were receiving welfare benefits.
A decade earlier, more than two-thirds of the 272,000 people who came to New York City and ended up on welfare were black or Hispanic, and the vast majority of the new New Yorkers came from elsewhere in the United States.
By contrast, in the late 1980's twice as many Puerto Rican families left New York and collected welfare elsewhere as came into the city. More black families moved out and then received public assistance elsewhere than came to the city and collected welfare.
One in four recent immigrants born in the former Soviet Union were on welfare when the census was taken. They accounted for nearly one in five of the adults, often accompanied by children, who moved to New York between 1985 and 1990 and were collecting public assistance in their adopted city.
Beyond the golden door pried open by glasnost, many Soviet emigres discovered that the streets were paved only with glasphalt. A surprise detour on the road to riches often led to the city's cavernous Fort Greene Income Support Center in Brooklyn.
"I don't think they come here with the intention of being on public assistance for life, but they know exactly what's coming to them," said Robin Berg, the assistant office manager at the Fort Greene center.
 
A Modest Factor In Picking New York
 Wherever people came from, though, welfare was at most a modest factor in prompting them to move to New York during the late 1980's. Altogether, roughly 4 percent of the new arrivals turned to city government for public assistance. That proportion mirrored the national figures for welfare. The 1990 census found that across the nation 3.3 percent of the native-born population and 4.4 percent of the foreign-born were receiving welfare. That consistency indicates that people did not flock to New York City to collect more generous benefits.
The recent newcomers were also a modest factor in the city's welfare equation. They made up only about 3 percent of the million or more New Yorkers who depend on welfare. That finding corroborates a study late last year that suggested that the city's dependent population is largely home-grown or has been in New York long enough to put down roots.
Who goes on public assistance and where they migrate are questions with broad national implications. The answers affect national debates about tightening welfare eligibility, restricting the access of immigrants to welfare or requiring the Federal Government to help pay the cost of welfare benefits for immigrants.
"In Washington there is hot and heavy debate going on about taking money from immigrants to fund the Administration's version of welfare reform," said Dr. Richard P. Nathan, provost of the Rockefeller School of Government at the State University of New York in Albany.
In his successful 1992 campaign, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, a Republican, maintained that New York had been transformed into a "welfare Cadillac" and proposed that benefits be reduced for recent migrants.
A survey by the American Public Welfare Association found that the maximum monthly welfare grant -- $573 for a family of three in New York last year -- was higher in only six states.
 
Short-Term Bridge To a New Culture
 For many, in particular for the immigrants from the former Soviet Union, welfare has become a short-term bridge to a culture where getting established is not easy. Typically, they are supported by relatives or by American philanthropic agencies for a few months or more. Because they lack proficiency in English and do not have American degrees or licenses to practice their professions, they eagerly enroll in college, where they can often continue to receive welfare benefits, or they leave welfare to accept jobs for which they are overqualified.
Some people worry about welfare undercutting the immigrants' characteristic eagerness to become self-reliant, and they fear that many remain on public assistance largely to get Medicaid.
"Russians as a group may not be as vulnerable," Dr. Nathan acknowledged, "but it still makes me nervous when people get too close to the welfare culture, and their transition may not happen or may be deferred. It would be better to have a health care system where you don't have to get caught up in a welfare trap."
Oleg Sokolov, a 50-year-old immigrant from Ukraine, personifies the flow of Soviet immigrants who may remain on welfare several years while they go to school, look for work and try to match their professional skills to American licensing standards.
Mr. Sokolov, who received a master's degree in engineering and a doctorate in radiology in the Soviet Union, was on welfare for 11 months until he landed a job as an X-ray engineer in Connecticut two years ago. His wife and daughter remained in Rego Park, Queens.
"I had two, three, four hours of English every day, but language was maybe 5 percent of the problem," Mr. Sokolov recalled. "You have to first observe the life and absorb it, from how to sit on the chair to how to make coffee."
As refugees, immigrants coming from the former Soviet Union, among others, are immediately eligible for public assistance. Legal immigrants may receive welfare benefits; illegal immigrants do not qualify.
The migration patterns emerged from an analysis of recently released details from the 1990 census, conducted by Dr. Beveridge, who directs the Program of Applied Social Research at Queens College of the City University of New York.
These census findings were extrapolated from a questionnaire administered to about 1 household in 20. Among other things, it asked whether the household had moved during those five years and whether it was on welfare in 1989.
 
A Net Outflow Of Welfare Families
 The census results leave some questions unanswered. They do not establish whether people were on welfare before they moved -- only that they were dependent on public assistance thereafter. But experts say it is highly likely that many were. So the upshot appears to be a net outflow of welfare households.
The net outflow of Puerto Rican families on welfare was remarkable, the city's Planning Department pronounced in a migration study last year, "given that it entailed a loss of New York City's public assistance benefits, which rank among the highest in the nation."
"There were fears that high public assistance benefits could induce migration to high-benefit states like New York and inhibit the migration of those already on public assistance," the Planning Department said. "Neither scenario was borne out during the 1980's."
From 1985 to 1990, the census data showed, welfare recipients represented one in five of all the adults who arrived from Puerto Rico. All told, 5,500 Puerto Rican-born adults who arrived from there in that period were on welfare in 1989. Still, for every household that arrived in New York from Puerto Rico and wound up on welfare, twice as many Puerto Rican households left the city and ended up on welfare somewhere else. Half of them went back to Puerto Rico.
"It kind of goes against some of the stereotypes," said Dr. Joseph Salvo, director of the City Planning Department's Population Division. "But when people speak about public assistance benefits being higher in New York, they forget that the cost of living here is also higher."
About 12,700 Hispanic adults, including the 5,500 Puerto Ricans, moved into the city and began receiving benefits. About 10,600 left and were collecting public assistance where they had relocated.
Among non-Hispanic whites, 9,300 who moved in claimed welfare benefits, and 6,400 who moved out collected them elsewhere. Among Asians, too, more newcomers were on welfare, 3,300, than the number who had moved away, 1,400. Among blacks, though, 7,300 newcomers said they received public assistance, compared with 10,600 who had left the city.
Since 1990, Dr. Salvo said, the greatest annual source of immigrants for New York, regardless of whether they went on welfare, has been the Dominican Republic, as it was in the 1980's. The Soviet Union moved to 2d place from 12th during the 1980's.

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: NEWS ANALYSIS;
NATO's Balkan Gamble: Using Force Is the Best Way of Achieving Peace

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Crotia, April 11

 BODY:
In twice bombing Serbian positions around the Muslim enclave of Gorazde, the United States and its Western allies have wagered that force will bring the Serbs back to the negotiating table because force is the one thing Serbian soldiers in Bosnia understand.
It is a big gamble. Ever since the President of Serbia, Slobodan Milosevic, began whipping up Serbian nationalist sentiment in 1987 as a means to consolidate his power, Serbs have been fed an unrelenting diet of myth and history in which their warrior attributes, heroic struggles against the Ottoman Turks and the Nazis, and their capacity for martyrdom have been a constant theme. 
 The basic nationalist message is that Serbs never bow to pressure, and there is no more fervent believer than the commander of the Bosnian Serbs' army, Gen. Ratko Mladic, who ordered the recent onslaught on Gorazde. General Mladic, whose father was killed in 1945 fighting Nazi and Croatian fascist forces in Bosnia, is apparently driven by the conviction that only military might will save Bosnia's Serbian minority.
One American official said: "When we bomb, we are telling Mladic and the Serbs that their aggression will no longer be tolerated and we want them back at the negotiating table. But we have not even been able to see Mladic yet, and his aims remain hard to gauge."
 
Highly Centralized Army
 The nature of those aims are crucial. From a bunch of often undisciplined militias, the Serbian force in Bosnia has evolved in two years into a highly centralized army under General Mladic's command, Western diplomats say.
Thus, if General Mladic wants to prosecute the war, he has the means to do so.
"Milosevic surely wants peace because he wants to free Serbia from economic sanctions, but it's questionable that Milosevic can stop Mladic at this stage," said John R. Lampe, the director of East European studies at the Woodrow Wilson Center in Washington. "General Mladic appears to be worried that the recently formed Muslim-Croat federation will eventually have the effect of freeing the Muslims to attack the Serbs."
Western diplomats say they believe that the Serbian military commander may also be worried by the prospect of a large United States troop deployment in Bosnia in the event of the peace settlement, the possibility of war crimes trials and the effect on his army's morale of any territorial concessions made to secure peace with Bosnia's Muslims and Croats. So he acted by blasting Gorazde.
 
Gorazde Settlement Is Key
 A United States special envoy, Charles Redman, has been talking to Mr. Milosevic and the Bosnian Serbs' political leader, Radovan Karadzic. On the basis of these discussions, he reportedly felt until this weekend that an overall peace settlement bringing the Serbs into some loose association with the Muslim-Croatian federation was attainable.
But in a television interview today, Mr. Redman conceded that no progress would be possible until the situation in Gorazde is resolved through a cease-fire, the deployment there of United Nations troops and the withdrawal of Serbian forces -- a solution similar to the one now sustaining a tenuous peace in Sarajevo.
"We now have a difficult issue to deal with in Gorazde," Mr. Redman said. "That has to be settled first."
A spokesman for Yasushi Akashi, the top United Nations official in the region, said Mr. Akashi would travel to the Bosnian Serb stronghold of Pale on Tuesday for talks with Dr. Karadzic aimed at securing a cease-fire in Gorazde. Only after that would broad peace talks resume.
This new caution clearly reflects the fact that Mr. Redman has been confronted in the Gorazde attack with the reality that undermined and frustrated previous intermediaries in the quest for a Balkan peace: The Serbs are quite capable of saying one thing and then doing another.
The question now is who is serious: Mr. Milosevic and Dr. Karadzic when they talk of their earnest desire for a just peace, or General Mladic when he speaks at Gorazde with howitzers and mortar shells?
The Muslim-led Bosnian Government says the Serbs remain fundamentally united in their commitment to the logic of war. Mr. Redman, who spoke today of his hopes of resuming negotiations soon, apparently thinks otherwise.
NATO has now backed Mr. Redman's efforts with a show of force. That, however, may not be enough to make a lasting impression on General Mladic, who likes to repeat a favorite phrase to reporters, "The Serbs will not roll over."

HEADLINE: Quake-Damaged Freeway Reopening Ahead of Time

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 11

 BODY:
Less than three months after an earthquake shut it down and more than two months ahead of schedule, the Santa Monica Freeway, aorta of this city's circulatory system, reopens on Tuesday. And if every public official claiming credit for the rapid repair stood on them at once, the two newly restored bridges over La Cienega Boulevard and Fairfax Avenue might just collapse again.
On Tuesday morning, Vice President Gore will join Gov. Pete Wilson; Mayor Richard J. Riordan; the Federal Secretary of Transportation, Federico Pena; Rodney Slater, the Administrator of the Federal Highway Administration, and other officials for the reopening. "Every politician west of the Pecos and a few east of it will be in attendance," said Sean Walsh, a spokesman for Mr. Wilson. 
 The orange cones and other barriers that have tortured commuters since the Jan. 17 earthquake will disappear, and the rubber from the first of the 300,000 cars that use the freeway daily under normal seismological circumstances will hit the restored pavement. Today, as workmen swept and restriped the roadway, Mayor Riordan and Mr. Pena fought bumper-to-bumper traffic on parts of the road that never went down as they headed for a test drive on what just went up.
The reconstruction -- it cost $29.4 million, all from the Federal Government -- has been hailed as a rare example of what government can do when it really works. Spurring everyone on was the realization that in Los Angeles, where one radio station gives traffic updates every six minutes, political careers can ride on commuting time. To reopen the nation's busiest highway, money was no object -- particularly since it all came from Washington -- and bureaucratic niceties were secondary.
"Anyone who did even the slightest thing to become an obstacle would have paid for it dearly," said Joel Kotkin, a political analyst who has written extensively on California politics and the economy.
In the last few days, government officials have also been working against one another, trying either to bask in the project's success or to belittle it. The question here is how they ever finished the Santa Monica Freeway so quickly, and at what cost.
The contractor for the job, Clinton C. Myers of Rancho Cordova, Calif., nearly doubled his earnings by finishing the work 74 days ahead of schedule. His company, which was supposed to receive $14.9 million for finishing on time, got $200,000 for every day it beat the June 24 deadline.
To Mr. Wilson, the deal represented a sensible use of market incentives and a bargain to boot: his research office said Los Angeles and neighboring communities paid $1 million in extra commuting and delivery time for each day the highway was down. Mr. Wilson's critics, mostly Democrats -- he is a Republican -- say that the target date was pushed back deliberately to make the repair seem even more swift and that taxpayers in California and elsewhere were paying for electoral gamesmanship.
 
'Generous Time Line'
 "Either the Governor's transportation department is all incompetent and ought to be fired, or someone purposely set a very, very generous time line in order to come in early," State Assemblyman Richard Katz of Sylmar said over his car phone while driving on another freeway. "This was a manipulation of the process for maximum political benefit."
Mr. Pena said he had no reason to believe that the incentive system, which is being used in 20 states, had been abused in this case. Nevertheless, he said Federal officials would review the contract with the California Department of Transportation.
Four more bridges damaged in the earthquake, on two interchanges at Interstate 5 north of Los Angeles, are still to be repaired.
Politically speaking, Governor Wilson headed everyone off at the overpass. In a move that angered officials in Washington and Los Angeles alike, the Governor, embroiled in a re-election campaign with implications for 1996 Presidential politics, announced last Tuesday from the unfinished roadway that the freeway would open in six days. Less than 24 hours earlier, state transportation officials had told Mayor Riordan and Senator Dianne Feinstein that the project would not be completed for another three to five weeks.
"The Mayor was surprised; I was surprised," Mr. Pena said.
 
Cutting Through Red Tape
 Standing at a wooden lectern amid piles of pallets and mounds of dirt, and competing with the noise of heavy equipment, the Governor called the pace of the repair job "truly phenomenal." He said it had taken a 10h of the time it would normally have taken had he not cut through mounds of red tape by executive order. "I must say, I did that with great glee in this case," he said.
While Mr. Riordan later saluted "the Clinton team from Washington," the only Clinton Mr. Wilson mentioned either in his speech or in an accompanying press release was Clinton C. Myers, the burly, plain-spoken contractor whose 400 employees worked round the clock to complete the project.
Mr. Myers, the low bidder on the job, said that with higher overhead than expected, he would clear about $8 million from the project. He said he had pocketed enough of a premium to put a down payment on a larger airplane -- a Citation 3, he said -- if not to buy it outright.
Mr. Myers said taxpayers had got their money's worth from the new bridges. The concrete pillars on the new ones are larger, have bigger bases and have more and stronger steel than those that failed, exceeding the standards of existing bridges being retrofitted. They are also sunk twice as far into the ground as those that were damaged.
 
Contractor's Seismology
 "If they have another earthquake, and all of Los Angeles flattens out, these things will still be standing," he said. An earthquake like the one on Jan. 17, measuring 6.7 on the Richter Scale, he said, "wouldn't even rock" the new bridges, and that one measuring 9.0 "might not bother them either." He even offered a money-back guarantee.
Bruce Bolt, a retired seismologist at the University of California at Berkeley, was skeptical about the contractor's seismology. "It's a great challenge to build something to withstand Armageddon," he said.
Some critics say government officials failed to use the earthquake-induced hiatus to explore ways of weaning Angelenos off their freeways. Others lamented that the social leveling brought about by the earthquake -- when residents of the affluent West Side were forced to drive through poorer neighborhoods rather than fly past them at 70 miles an hour -- would surely prove ephemeral.
But others, including Robin Kramer, Mayor Riordan's deputy for communications and community affairs, seemed to equate the last few months to a coronary bypass operation, and the repair of the freeway as the replacement of vital valves.
"If you're on that freeway and you're lucky to have a convertible and the sun is shining and you're heading west, the freeway has a wonderful curve that goes just to the north," she said. "And as you round it, you see this incredible ocean and beach spread out before your eyes -- and you remember the reason that you're here."

HEADLINE: Benefit Funds May Run Out Of Cash Soon, Reports Warn

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
If Congress takes no action, the Clinton Administration said today, the Medicare trust fund that pays hospital bills for the elderly will run out of money in seven years and a separate trust fund that pays benefits to disabled workers will be exhausted next year.
The estimates were part of reports on Social Security and Medicare finances that have to be submitted to Congress each year. Such reports are often gloomy, but the figures this year are, in some ways, slightly worse than those of recent years. 
 The Administration said there was a "high probability that the hospital insurance trust fund will be exhausted around the turn of the century." Looking to the future, the report added, "the Medicare program is not sustainable in its present form."
Medicare finances health care for 36 million people, at a cost of $143 billion in the last fiscal year.
The Administration said the Social Security trust fund that paid cash to disabled workers would be exhausted next year if Congress did not change the existing law. The Government is receiving record numbers of applications for disability benefits and approving them at a higher rate than in the past.
 
Proposal to Cut Retirement Fund
 The Administration said that problem could be solved, at least temporarily, by taking money earmarked for the Social Security retirement program and shifting it to the disability program. The trustees made a similar recommendation last year, but Congress did not act on it. The trustees said today that the need was "more urgent now."
Even without the change, the reports said, the trust fund for the retirement program will be exhausted in 2036, eight years sooner than predicted last year. People born in 1971 turn 65 in 2036.
Social Security paid $302 billion in benefits to 42 million people last year. As baby boomers age, the ratio of active workers to retirees will decrease, worsening the problems of Social Security and Medicare alike, the trustees said. But, they added, the hospital-insurance fund "is projected to become exhausted even before the major demographic shift begins to occur."
The outlooks for Medicare and Social Security were described in detailed reports from the trustees of the trust funds, including Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich and Dr. Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The reports, widely regarded as authoritative, were prepared by Government actuaries.
 
Specter of Political Trouble
 The bankruptcy of Medicare or Social Security is politically unthinkable. As in the past, Congress is likely to pass legislation to keep money flowing to elderly people, their doctors and hospitals.
But the trustees' reports show that the financing of Medicare, the biggest Federal health program, is shaky as Congress considers large programs to finance care for 39 million people who lack health insurance.
The Medicare hospital trust fund had a balance of $127.8 billion at the end of last year. Under current law, the trustees said, it is expected to decline to $100.9 billion at the end of 1998 and $40.4 billion in the year 2000 before it runs out of money in 2001.
"Medicare's financial condition," Dr. Shalala said, "would improve significantly as a result of general cost containment under the President's health-care-reform proposal." But some members of Congress, as well as the Congressional Budget Office, say the Administration has underestimated the cost of the Clinton proposal.
In a separate statement the two independent public trustees of the Medicare trust fund, who are not part of the Administration, said, "Current national health-reform proposals do not adequately address the serious long-range financial imbalance in the Medicare program."
In an interview, one trustee, Stanford G. Ross, a tax lawyer who was Social Security Commissioner in 1978 and 1979, said:
"The long-term deterioration in the Social Security retirement trust fund is a serious concern. When combined with the long-term financial imbalance in Medicare it suggests that we need to take a serious look at the long-term financing of these programs."
Medicare is growing much faster than Social Security. The trustees highlighted the difference by measuring the programs in relation to the economy as a whole. Social Security outlays equal 4.8 percent of the gross domestic product, the total output of goods and services. That share will rise to 6.9 percent in 75 years, the trustees said.
By contrast, they said, Medicare outlays, now 2.5 percent of the gross domestic product, will rise to 10.4 percent of G.D.P. after 75 years.
Mr. Ross and the other public trustee, David M. Walker, an expert on employee benefits at Arthur Andersen & Company, the accounting firm, said people should worry about these problems now, when the solution is relatively painless.
"The changes that will be required can be relatively small and gradual if they are begun in the near future," they said in a joint statement. "However, the magnitude of those changes grows each year that action is delayed."
In a statement attached to the report, the chief actuary of the Medicare program, Roland E. King, expressed some concern about the trustees' estimates of growth in workers' earnings. He suggested that the estimates might be too optimistic. Medicare's hospital-insurance program is financed with a payroll tax on earnings.

HEADLINE: Struck Trucking Company Closes Business

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
One of the 22 trucking companies that the teamsters union struck last week went out of business today, leaving more than 2,000 employees, most of them teamsters, unemployed.
"The economic impact of the strike and the economic impact of increased costs once the strike is settled led us to the decision that we could not operate," said Kenneth F. Churchill, president of Churchill Truck Lines Inc. of Chillicothe, Mo. 
 Philip Young, president of Local 41 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in Kansas City, Mo., which represents 200 of the workers, said he doubted that the strike was at the root of the company's decision. "They've been indicating they were considering closing down for some time," Mr. Young said.
A teamsters' spokesman here, Bernie Mulligan, said the workers accepted a 10 percent pay cut last year to help Churchill reduce its costs. "We estimate that they had given back $3 million in wages," he said. "But that wasn't enough to overcome poor management decisions."
The company, which was established in 1926, operated 95 terminals in 26 states. It owns 2,300 trailers and 1,007 tractors that pull them. It employed 1,561 unionized workers and 560 nonunion workers, all of whom are losing their jobs and will not receive severance pay.
News of Churchill's closing came on the fifth day of a nationwide strike by 75,000 teamster drivers and loading-dock workers. The union and Trucking Management Inc., the bargaining consortium representing the struck companies, disagree over the companies' insistence on using part-time dock workers to reduce costs.
The workers handle most of the nation's freight that weighs 150 to 10,000 pounds per order. The trucks go door to door picking up shipments from customers and deliver them to terminals, where they are sorted for nationwide delivery.
Competition in the business has grown with Federal deregulation of trucking 14 years ago. Nonunion companies, which pay well below the teamsters' typical $17 hourly wage, have driven out many unionized companies, and the number of union jobs has plunged to about 110,000 from 300,000 in 1980.
Last Tuesday, on the eve of the strike, the fifth largest company in the consortium, Carolina Freight Carriers in Cherryville, N.C., broke with the bargaining group and agreed to go along with any settlement reached by negotiators. Consequently, the union permitted drivers to keep working.
Today, the union reported that another company, Preston Trucking in Preston, Md., broke with the consortium to negotiate its own contract.

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Ron Brown Re-emerges in Halls of Power, and Thrives

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
During a breakfast meeting at which the Secretary of Commerce was communing with his senior staff last week, the topic drifted from Russia to Japan to China and then hovered, briefly, over his recent visit to the great state of Iowa.
The Secretary, Ronald Harmon Brown, a study of nervous energy even in repose, took a long, slow sip of coffee, brushed a wayward bit of doughnut from his elegant blue suit and then fixed his gaze on the woman who had arranged the trip. 
 "Iowa," he said with a deep sigh. "Uh, yeah, I-o-w-a."
It was a subtle reprimand for what Mr. Brown obviously saw as a 17-hour low point. He quickly moved on. But later, when he rose to get another cup of coffee, he stopped to make amends, sharing a laugh and a warm moment.
 
A Definite Style
 The sum of Ron Brown's style could be printed on an index card: Maximize your time. Focus on your goals. Know who runs what. See them. Make your point. Don't linger. Never look back.
Mr. Brown, 52, has never looked back. Nor has he had to. A quintessential operator with a perfect pitch for power plays, he remade the Democratic Party as its chairman and then stepped easily into the Clinton Administration, accepting a department that had long been a low-watt bulb within the Cabinet.
He seemed perfectly situated to remake a lumbering bureaucracy with 36,000 employees and a $3.5 billion budget into an aggressive element of an Administration sworn to deliver on its most famous campaign line: "It's the economy, stupid." Mr. Brown floated through his Senate confirmation and several early missteps with hardly a scratch.
But then he took a difficult detour that seemed to threaten both his reputation and his future.
Shortly after Mr. Brown's confirmation, field agents from a Miami office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation opened a criminal investigation into accusations that he had accepted a $700,000 bribe from a representative of the Vietnamese Government in exchange for arm twisting to liberalize American trade policy toward Vietnam.
Centered on accusations by Ly Thanh Binh, a Vietnamese businessman living in Florida, the investigation dragged on for months, moving in and out of the headlines. It gained new force with conflicting reports from the Commerce Department over whether the Secretary had met with the man who was supposed to have arranged the bribe, Nguyen Van Hao, another Vietnamese expatriate in Florida. Mr. Brown finally admitted that he had met with Mr. Hao three times, but he denied any wrongdoing.
In February, the Justice Department agreed. Concluding that Mr. Brown had not misused his position, it closed the investigation.
 
Back in Play
 Now Mr. Brown is back. While other Administration officials duck over the Whitewater matter, the Commerce Secretary has been winning extravagant praise. In short order he has produced the apparent oxymoron of a Democratic Administration that is good at doing business with big business.
After playing an important role pushing through the North American Trade Agreement, he won kudos for his deft maneuvering to win a $6 billion passenger jet deal for the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation in Saudi Arabia; for persuading Russian officials to drop a threatened 50 percent tariff on imported aircraft, and for pushing those same officials to reduce a $5-a-barrel oil tax that would have hampered or killed pending deals with American oil giants like Texaco.
Fresh from those successes, and now huddling with President Clinton on classified negotiations over issues like international patent law and China's trade status, Mr. Brown is secure enough to let a reporter trail him in even some of the more private meetings of his day.
And he is, again, where he is most comfortable: dead center in the power circle, sipping cocktails with world leaders. In Russia last month, he met with President Boris N. Yeltsin. In South Africa, on an earlier trip, he met with President F. W. DeKlerk, Nelson Mandela and Chief Mangosuthu G. Buthelezi.
It is precisely that ability to play in the symphonies of power that has been both Mr. Brown's strength and his Achilles heel. In a career marked both by astonishing success and persistent suspicions, his style and substance always raise the same questions.
Detractors say Mr. Brown exemplifies the slippery slope of Washington politics that the Democrats once railed against. His strength, by his own admission, is in his contacts and his familiarity with the strange ether of this capital. Critics, though few will speak on record, say he is a master of insider dealing and quiet profit taking.
 
Praise and Criticism
 A former partner in the powerful Washington law firm of Patton, Boggs & Blow, Mr. Brown retired last year with a $1 million golden handshake but retains a web of ties that have left lingering questions about mixing business with government. He is sure-footed, wealthy, subtle and elusive.
Many longtime Washingtonians see nothing wrong with that. "You can't fault people for being savvy, smart and well-connected," said Anne Wexler, a Deputy Secretary of Commerce under President Jimmy Carter. "Ron Brown does very well with everything he is given."
Others are much less charitable. "The long and short of it is that he is an operator," said Charles Lewis, the executive director of the Center for Public Integrity and one of the few Washington insiders willing to question the Secretary on the record. "He knows everybody. And they need him."
In 1992 Mr. Lewis raised conflict-of-interest questions about Mr. Brown, who was then chairman of the Democratic National Committee, in a report titled "Private Parties: Political party leadership in Washington's mercenary culture." It did not include a smoking gun, just smoke.
Mr. Lewis praises Mr. Brown for competence but says the landscape that the Secretary knows best is a quicksand of interconnections. "He knows the game," Mr. Lewis said. "And he knows where the edges are. And he is willing to walk right up to the edge. To the absolute edge."
That, of course, is not illegal. Yet some who have questioned the connections have learned first hand one way in which Mr. Brown may use his power.
Before the publication of his report, Mr. Lewis said, he got a call from a union leader on the center's board. After praising Mr. Lewis's work, the leader said he had received a call from Mr. Brown and asked Mr. Lewis to hold the report until after the Presidential election because of its criticism of Mr. Brown.
Mr. Lewis, a former producer of the CBS News program "60 Minutes," refused. The labor leader withdrew from the center's board and canceled his financial commitment to the fledgling research organization. Within a month, Mr. Lewis said, "half the labor money dried up."
Other critics cite a general uneasiness with Mr. Brown's style, but give no examples. On the other hand, to a person, friends and longtime colleagues speak with respect that borders on reverence. Many friends say Mr. Brown has been subjected to a double standard because he is a black man in what has always been a white man's job. They say he is always underestimated, and then when he does what everyone said he could not do, which is to take an inside track, he is condemned.
 
Seeking a Party Post
 That was particularly true, they say, in his passage through the Democratic National Committee. When Mr. Brown, who had made his mark steering Jesse Jackson's 1988 Presidential campaign and rising through the ranks of the National Urban League, announced in the fall of 1988 that he intended to run for Democratic chairman he created a storm inside a party that seemed to be energetically crafting its own obituary. He had to fight hard, enlisting the support of old friends like Gov. Mario M. Cuomo (one of his law professors at St. Johns University), Senator Edward M. Kennedy and Senator Bill Bradley.
Alexis M. Herman, a friend from the Jackson campaign and now an assistant to the President, remembers the rawness of that fight. Critics complained, she said, that Mr. Brown could not get Jewish money and support because of his links to Mr. Jackson. They also argued, she said, that he could not attract big business to the party and would alienate conservative whites.
None of that proved true. Instead, Mr. Brown so deftly worked the sidelines that every other candidate for the chairmanship pulled out.
 
'A Tough Town'
 Seated in his elegant office one afternoon last week, Mr. Brown looked back at the trials of his last year and said they had made him grow.
"There are a lot of people out there who maybe feel I haven't needed them," he said. "Maybe I should have spent more time being loved. This is a tough town that way."
Yet Mr. Brown is loved in the way that only Washington can love. James Hackney, a friend of 20 years and Mr. Brown's counselor at Commerce, said Mr. Brown has "from 15,000 to 16,000 friends" if that can be measured by the people who call Mr. Hackney and identify themselves as such.
That smoothness started early, as Mr. Brown was growing up in Harlem and coming into contact with intellectuals, artists, politicians and other members of the black elite. "There was always something different about him," said his wife of 31 years, Alma Arrington Brown. "He was more mature than the other boys, and sure of himself."
And even then, he didn't waste much time. After his first date with Alma Arrington, Mr. Brown fell sound asleep in the car ride from Greenwich Village back to her home to Brooklyn.
It hardly seemed like a good sign. But as soon as he woke up, she said, he started planning their next date.
 
Trying the 'Political Hat'
 He still plans, though he denies it. At an afternoon meeting with several hundred staff members at the Commerce Department on Wednesday, between a meeting with Vice President Al Gore, private talks with Egyptian officials, a reception at the Willard Hotel and a trip to Los Angeles, a clearly relaxed Ron Brown took questions.
Easily fielding queries from salaries to foreign policy, he smiled when asked about the toll the Whitewater matter was taking next door at the White House.
"Now," he said. "You are asking me to put on my political hat. And it almost doesn't fit me any more."
For a moment, the room fell silent. Then, like a storm gathering just beyond the horizon, the sound of laughter started until it crashed about like thunder. For a moment, Mr. Brown looked taken aback. Then, he leaned way back and started laughing, too.

HEADLINE: For a Hot Mutual Fund, Hard Issues

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DENVER

 BODY:
Thomas H. Bailey, the iconoclastic founder and chairman of the Janus Capital Corporation, a hot stock-picking mutual fund boutique, leads an enviable life. Three days a week, he works out of his Aspen office, right near the ski slopes. As the stock market began its nail-biting slide just before Easter, Mr. Bailey, a trim 56-year-old, was out-of-pocket on a sailboat in the Caribbean. Oh yes, and last year, he took home more than $9 million in salary and dividends.
But behind this seemingly effortless approach to money-making, lies a mutual fund company that after years of living a charmed life now faces some hard issues. The eye-popping returns of its flagship funds, particularly the $9.5 billion Janus Fund, have turned dismal of late. The rush of money that came into Janus chasing these returns has slowed. And where Janus and its top executives were once touted on the cover of investment publications, the $22 billion fund group is coming under criticism for growing too far too fast. 
 "Growth snuck up on Janus," said Don Phillips, publisher of Morningstar, a mutual-funds research company. "They were picking stocks in relative obscurity in Denver and then they had an explosion in assets and interest. Incredible money poured in. But their performance hasn't been as good since. The tail wind that was helping them has now turned into a head wind."
Now some of the strategic decisions Janus made during the mid-1980's are raising troubling questions about how well Janus is prepared to face the future, particularly if the equity markets that gave it such impetus continue to be rough. Clearly Janus has walked a different path than most mutual fund companies. "We're a different kind of organization," said Mr. Bailey, who came to an interview dressed more for mountain climbing than for business.
Janus is a creation of Mr. Bailey and reflects his conservative, iconoclastic bent. Where funds of similar size have more than 2,000 employees, Janus makes do with just 700 people. Where many fund companies have a depth of investment managers on the bench, Janus has just two stars. And where other fund companies live and die by their own bottom line, Janus is fortunate to have the deep pockets of Kansas City Southern Industries, a railroad conglomerate that owns 81 percent of Janus.
But now this conservative bent means Janus has little else but equity funds to offer at a time when stocks are falling. Janus has been slow in getting into fixed income funds, and its array is skimpy by fund industry standards. Especially when markets are unsettled, having a broad array of investment options helps keeps investors from fleeing.
"Janus is several years behind in broadening its product line," said W. Gordon Synder, an executive vice president at the rival Twentieth Century Mutual Funds in Kansas City, Mo. At Fidelity Investments, Roger Servison, a managing director, agreed: "Janus's core issue is they don't have enough depth. There are not enough money managers. Can they become more than a hot equity house? Investment styles are not hot forever."
 
Beaten By Rival
 Where the company's flagship Janus Fund, a growth stock fund, once racked up annual returns of 46 percent (in 1989) and 43 percent (in 1991), it has lately underperformed its rivals and barely matched the Standard & Poor's 500 index, the benchmark of average. Since 1991, the Janus Fund has been consistently beaten by the rival Fidelity Magellan fund. This year, the Janus Fund has closed the quarter with a 2.6 percent loss, a full percentage worse than Magellan's quarterly showing.
As a result, the money flowing into Janus has slowed -- disconcerting in a business where the amount of assets under management determine how much a mutual fund company earns. Since January, for instance, net fund sales have slowed to less than a 1 percent quarterly increase. This compares with 200 percent net annual increases in the early 1990's when net sales came to $3 billion, $4 billion and $5 billion a year. What is more, two of Janus's larger funds, Janus Twenty and Janus Venture, have seen up to 10 percent of their money flee this year alone.
If these trends aren't troubling enough to Janus, they are also of concern to Kansas City Southern Industries, which bought its 81 percent stake for $16 million in 1984 to diversify into financial services. (Mr. Bailey remains a 17.5 percent owner of Janus with the rest owned by a few minor shareholders). The original sale netted Mr. Bailey $5 million, along with a stream of dividends from Janus since.
Last year, the Janus stake accounted for more than 40 percent of Kansas City Southern's earnings -- some $39 million. Since 1990, Janus has contributed a total of $28 million to the railroad's earnings. As a result, Kansas City Southern's stock doesn't trade like a transportation company, it trades like a financial services company -- in line with such mutual funds as T. Rowe Price and Dreyfus.
With so much of Kansas City Southern's income coming from Janus, the railroad is vulnerable to what happens when -- and if -- investors cool to Janus. "The question is how will they keep people from running out of Janus when the markets take a dive," said Elizabeth Fusco, an analyst at Salomon Brothers.
 
Taking Money Out
 Graeme Anne Lidgerwood, an analyst at First Boston, said, "A market correction will slow funds into Janus and that's a concern when Janus has been so profitable for the railroad." Since the recent break in stock prices, investors have been slowly taking money out of Janus equity funds. But, so far, it's "not a flurry," said Chrissy Snyder, a Janus spokeswoman.
The railroad's exposure to Janus's fluctuating performance has led to speculation that Kansas City Southern might consider spinning off Janus to a new owner. At current prices, Janus could fetch more than $700 million. But Landon H. Rowland, the railroad's chairman, doesn't seem so inclined. "It would be with great difficulty," he said.
Mr. Rowland sees Janus as part of a foray into financial services that began in the mid-1960's when it bought, and later sold, Kemper Financial Services, which is now being sought by General Electric. The railroad already owns DST Systems, a transfer agent for mutual fund companies, and it has an 18 percent stake in Berger Associates, another mutual fund company.
 
Long Term Is 'Favorable'
 "Financial services represent real growth and, while there are momentary highs and lows, the long-term secular trends are favorable," Mr. Rowland said. For now, Mr. Rowland says Janus "needs more diverse product offerings" and Mr. Bailey "has been alerted to that concern."
There had also been speculation that the railroad may buy a fixed-income operation and merge it with Janus. But Mr. Rowland said that was not on the table now -- although "something like that might pop out of the blue." Besides, anything the railroad does to change control at Janus must be approved by Janus investors -- and if Mr. Bailey and his crew leave, the fund investors may not approve. "They can sell only if they make me happy and make my boys happy," Mr. Bailey said.
 
Adding Bond Funds
 Back in Denver, however, Janus is taking steps to improve its showing. It is planning to add about one to three new bond funds a year, it has hired some new fund managers and reduced the workload on those managing the Janus Fund so it can be their top priority. It has also taken a defensive position to protect investors from a possible bear market by keeping high cash levels in the fund.
"My own sense is that these guys were just in the wrong stocks," said Michael Stolper, a San Diego mutual-fund-industry consultant who owns a small percentage of Janus. "It's not a problem that the funds have gotten too big. They just made some bad stock picks." For instance, one of its biggest holdings is Wal-Mart shares, which have fallen by 30 percent in the last 18 months.
Even James Craig, manager of the Janus Fund, says that times may favor Janus's style. "It's harder to discover companies with undiscovered earnings," Mr. Craig said. "The opportunities now are fewer. And if you look at last year, when stocks had 17 and 18 percent returns, you are not going to see that."
Janus's investment strategy reflects Mr. Bailey's belief in growth stocks -- by picking companies with growing earnings, a rising stock price will follow. (This contrasts with managers who pick stocks based on economic cycles, or hidden asset values or other strategies.)
Mr. Bailey's dislike also of spending money accounts for Janus's thin resources. While some might argue that by selling out in 1984 for a few million dollars, Mr. Bailey gave up hundreds of millions in future gains, he's happy. Psychologically, Mr. Bailey admits, he lacks the fortitude to have brought Janus to this level without the security of a corporate parent.
"Tom has a bear market mentality," Mr. Stolper said. "The firm wouldn't have grown to this size, or any fraction of it, without the railroad. Tom would not have bought a zillion dollars worth of computers or put 40 people on an 800 number. It's not his nature."
 
'Something Different'
 "The railroad allowed me to do something different," said Mr. Bailey, who would be interviewed only if his two top portfolio managers remained in the room with him. "I would have never been able to do it on my own. If I had just continued running money, I'd probably have one or two funds with, maybe, $500 million and that would be it. The railroad allowed me to take this and see what I could make of it."
Right now, Mr. Bailey is focused on protecting investors from a choppy market: "Everyday we come to work, trying to find stocks we think will go up. Performance can be streaky, but over the long term, we've done pretty well. The market could drop significantly and we at Janus will still be open for business."
