HEADLINE: A Primer on Hedge Funds: Hush-Hush and for the Rich

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
If investment bankers and junk bond dealers were the popular Wall Street villains of the 1980's -- living lavishly on hundreds of millions of dollars of earnings -- managers of hedge funds are being cast as the suspicious characters of the 1990's.
There is almost no way that hedge funds would not arouse suspicion. They are, by law, secretive investment partnerships of rich people seeking to make a lot of money selling stocks short, using complex financial techniques and borrowing huge amounts of money for their investments -- things not usually available to ordinary investors. They tend to be managed by strong-willed, often-reclusive trading impresarios. 
 If that's not enough to create the presumption of some sort of conspiracy in the minds of people who do not have $1 million required for the minimum investment, hedge funds have been blamed for many of the recent traumatic events in world financial markets, including the collapse of Europe's plan for stable currency rates and the recent slide in the stock and bond markets.
Today the House Banking Committee, led by Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas, will question the biggest hedge fund manager of them all, George Soros, whose Quantum Fund group controls more than $11 billion, as well as Ezra Zask, who runs a much smaller portfolio, and several financial market regulators.
"One hundred years ago, central bankers would have been concerned about a Morgan or a Rothschild, but you don't hear about those sort of people any more," said Greg Kipness, a former hedge fund manager who now heads proprietary trading at Jefferies & Company. "Today, it is George Soros, who has no particular power base other than the ability to move quickly with a lot of money."
While Mr. Soros is one of the most visible of the managers of this breed of fund, both because he is one of the biggest and most experienced managers and because of his extensive charitable activities in Eastern Europe, the industry has mushroomed in recent years as investors have sought higher profits in an era of low interest rates.
There are about 700 different hedge fund groups, each plying its own strategy for beating the markets. Most of these are relatively small, with assets of less than $200 million, and focus on buying and selling short American stocks. Short-selling is a way of betting that a stock price will fall. Some investors try to exploit technical discrepancies in the bond market, often by using mathematical models.
But the largest funds have moved beyond stocks to roam the world looking for opportunities, moving from stocks to bonds, currencies to commodities. Typically they borrow heavily, both from banks and brokerage firms, which increases their investing power but also their risks.
And their profits have verged on the spectacular, with many of the largest funds earning their investors more than a 50 percent return last year. Of course, some of their losses have been just as stunning, with many of the same funds losing half last year's gain in the last three months alone.
 
A Bad Bet on Yen
 Mr. Soros, for example, in March, acknowledged that he had taken a $600 million loss from a bad bet on the yen -- but since that only represents about 5 percent of his investments, he was able to shrug his shoulders and focus on his next moves.
But not all hedge funds are so well heeled. Askin Capital Management, a small hedge fund company that lost nearly all the $600 million it had under management in just two months in the mortgage markets recently, was forced out of business.
Despite the ever-present risks, the potential for big payoffs has helped hedge funds attract ever more investors, both among the affluent individuals who are their traditional customers and institutions like pension funds and charitable organizations. The Rockefeller Foundation, for example, last year allocated $130 million -- 5 percent of its assets -- among 10 hedge funds, in search of returns that are 6 to 10 percentage points higher than short-term Government bonds, said David White, Rockefeller's chief financial officer.
Investors like Rockefeller have helped hedge funds more than double their assets in the last year, to some $75 billion, from $35 billion a year earlier, according to E. Lee Hennessee, who advises clients on hedge fund investments for the Republic New York Securities Corporation. But while the number of funds has increased from only 100 in 1987, half the capital is controlled by the largest dozen or so fund groups.
The rapid growth has been driven in large part by the low short-term interest rates, which have led investors of all kinds to seek higher returns from more risky activities. Moreover, the low cost of borrowed money has made it much easier for hedge funds to borrow cheaply, using the leverage to increase their positions -- and their potential earnings.
 
Rush of New Funds
 The hedge fund boom has also been prompted by the rush of new fund managers, as mutual fund operators, Wall Street analysts and even academics have been lured by the money they can make by running a hedge fund. Typically, hedge managers receive a fee of 1 percent of a hedge fund's assets annually, plus 20 percent of the trading profits.
"It's a business which attracts a lot of entrepreneurs because it's easy to get into, and people can do very well very quickly if they have good performance," said Antoine Bernheim, who publishes the annual U.S. Offshore Funds Directory.
Of course, the reverse is also true. Even last year, which was the best of times for most hedge funds, 5 percent of the funds Mr. Bernheim tracks closed. But the hedge fund managers who succeed are among the most successful investors in the world.
"Hedge funds get you the brightest minds, the people who have the guts and believe that they are better than the pack," said the manager of one of the enterprises that funnel money into several different hedge funds.
They also have enormous self-confidence and tolerance for risk -- and do not shy away from portraying themselves as hungry animals. In a particularly telling interview, in Jack D. Schwager's 1992 book, "The New Market Wizards," Stanley Druckenmiller, the chief trader for George Soros, described the financier's philosophy: "Soros has taught me that when you have tremendous conviction to a trade, you have to go for the jugular. It takes courage to be a pig. It takes courage to ride a profit with huge leverage. As far as Soros is concerned, when you're right on something, you can't own enough."
 
Focusing on Three Issues
 This week, when Congress tries to look beyond the secrecy and greed, it will focus on three main issues.
Are consumers placed at undue risk by the existence of these funds and their operations? While customers can, indeed, lose large sums in hedge funds, the current limits on hedge funds probably keep all but the most sophisticated investors away.
Are the funds bad credit risks whose possible failure could create problems for the banks and brokerage firms that lend money to them? While lenders may indeed lose some money, many lenders say the risks for them are no larger than for other lending they do. And the worst casualty to date -- the failure of Askin Capital -- seems to have resulted in no more than about $25 million in losses for any one lender.
Do the funds, with their sheer size and leverage and ability to flit from one market to another, add to the instability in global financial markets, sharply increasing the instability?
This is the question that most disturbs central bankers and investors. Yet many other institutions including banks, insurance companies and pension funds trade in large size often with leverage. Moreover, it is unclear whether it is possible to restrict such disruptive trading and whether those restrictions would cause more problems than they solved.
When hedge funds got their start in the 1960's, the field consisted of a small coterie of managers whose main strategy was to buy some stocks and sell others short. These funds were considered hedged because their portfolios were split between stocks that would benefit if the market went up and the short positions, which would gain if stocks fell.
 
Shift to World Markets
 But during the last few years, the largest hedge funds, like those managed by Mr. Soros, Michael Steinhardt and Julian H. Robertson Jr., have departed from their traditional strategies and moved beyond American stocks to bet on broad global shifts in stock markets, currencies and interest rates. Increasingly, these funds bet on the overall direction of markets rather than simply picking stocks.
"One question hedge fund owners ask now is where is the hedging in the hedge funds," said William McBride of Lipper Analytical Services. Indeed, some old-timers complain that "hedge fund" is no longer an accurate term for the range of strategies in what they term "private investment partnerships."
The trading strategies of the large funds have evolved in part because of the opportunities recently in bond and currency markets and also because their funds have grown so big that it is difficult to make the returns they want simply from stocks.
The large global hedge funds have also been active users of derivatives, the rapidly growing category of financial techniques whose value is based on -- or derived from -- an underlying financial market. Derivatives like interest rate and currency swaps allow investors to bet on market moves with virtually no upfront cash.
Moreover, some hedge funds use derivatives as part of complex investment programs. For example, one very large hedge fund manager was said to be betting positions that the Japanese stock market was going down, but he worried that the one thing that would prompt that market to rise would be a drop in interest rates. So as protection, according to a big derivatives dealer, the manager bought options on the bond market that would pay off in cash if interest rates fell, compensating the fund for the expected losses on its short equity position.

GRAPHIC: Photo: George Soros, whose Quantum fund group controls more than $11 billion, is to testify before the House Banking Committee. (Bill Cunningham)

HEADLINE: To Justify Flogging, Singapore Cites 'Chaos' on U.S. Streets

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, April 12

 BODY:
Defending the decision to flog an American teen-ager for vandalism, the Senior Minister of Singapore suggested in a television interview broadcast today that tough criminal laws had saved this wealthy, authoritarian city-state from the "chaos" found in the streets of the United States.
"The American society is the richest and most prosperous in the world, but it is hardly safe and peaceful," the official, Lee Kuan Yew, told an interviewer for the Government-controlled Singapore Broadcasting Corporation. "If you like it that way, that is your problem. But that is not the path we choose. They always talk about human rights. I think it is just a convenient slogan." 
 Mr. Lee's uncompromising remarks about the need for strict criminal laws in Singapore were more unwelcome news for Michael Fay, an 18-year-old Ohioan who was sentenced by the authorities here to six lashes with a cane after he confessed to spray-painting several cars and other acts of mischief.
 
Appeals for Clemency
 Mr. Fay has appealed for clemency. President Clinton has called the caning sentence "excessive" and has protested the punishment, which lacerates the skin, leaving permanent scars, and is so painful that prisoners typically go into shock. Yet public opinion polls in the United States suggest that Singapore's methods have broad support among Americans fed up with crime in their own neighborhoods.
Mr. Lee stepped down as Prime Minister in 1990 after 31 years in power, but his views are known to carry great weight among Government officials, presumably including President Ong Teng Cheong, who will review Mr. Fay's clemency appeal.
"Which is more important, the interests of the whole society or those of an individual?" Mr. Lee asked in the Chinese-language broadcast. "The majority of our people support the Government's efforts in protecting the interests of the society. This is the right thing to do."
Arguing that the Western concept of individual rights had been taken to extremes and had left the United States in a crisis, he catalogued a list of social ills that plague the United States but scarcely exist in Singapore -- street violence, homelessness, unemployment.
 
'Out of Control'
 "Just look at the problem of drug abuse," he said. "It has gone out of control. In Singapore, if your behavior is questionable and the police or officials suspect you are taking drugs, they can have your urine tested. If you are tested positive, you'll be dealt with. For three or four months, you will be kept away from drugs until you are rehabilitated."
"In the States, you will not be able to do anything like that" because of laws that limit government drug testing as an infringement of civil rights. "That's why the whole country is in chaos."
In Singapore, conviction for drug trafficking carries a mandatory death sentence.

HEADLINE: P.& G. Bet On Rates Turns Sour

BYLINE: By SUSAN ANTILLA 

 BODY:
The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that it would take a $102 million after-tax charge against its third-quarter earnings as a result of having been "badly burned" in two derivatives contracts.
The contracts, which soured as interest rates rose, were entered in hopes of "managing" its interest rate exposures, said Erik G. Nelson, senior vice president and chief financial officer at P.& G. 
 The loss was one of the largest reported by an American corporation on derivatives contracts, which are investments that are linked to, or derived from, an underlying financial market, like the market for currencies. Companies use them for various reasons, including the reduction of risk when they translate the earnings from their foreign subsidiaries to dollars.
While analysts who follow P.& G. did not find a $102 million charge to be catastrophic for a $30 billion company, they expressed concerns that the news could be a harbinger of problems among other companies that have taken positions in complex financial instruments.
 
A 'Bigger Story'
 "I think it's the tip of the iceberg," said Joseph H. Kozloff, a consumer products analyst at Smith Barney Shearson. "It's obviously an embarrassment for P.& G., and that's unfortunate. But the bigger story is, 'What the hell else is out there on corporations' balance sheets?' "
The chairman and chief executive of P.& G., Edwin L. Artzt, said in a statement last night that the company was considering legal action against the Bankers Trust New York Corporation, which designed the derivatives.
Meanwhile, however, P.& G.'s own treasurer has been put on "special assignment," the company said yesterday. Raymond D. Mains, who, until yesterday, was vice president and treasurer, has been replaced by Clayton C. Daley, who had been vice president and comptroller. A spokeswoman for the company would not comment on whether the news on Mr. Mains constituted a demotion; she would also not say whether any P.& G. executives had been dismissed.
Bankers Trust, in its own statement last night, said that it had entered into "a number of leveraged derivative transactions" with P.& G., several of which brought profits to its client. Further, the bank said, the two interest-rate swaps that led P.& G. to take the one-time charge against earnings had been entered into "after extensive discussion of the risks" with P.& G. executives, who "expressed a bullish view of U.S. and German interest rates" at the time the contracts were entered.
But those interest-rate bets turned out to be wrong, and, by Bankers Trust's account, the bank "strongly and formally recommended" that P.& G. begin getting out of the contracts when interest rates began to rise sharply in March. "Senior officials rejected these recommendations," Bankers Trust said in its statement.
Derivative instruments known as swaps amount to contracts in which two parties agree to exchange money based on the movement of an underlying market -- typically interest rates or currencies.
"For P.& G., a $100 million noncash write-off is basically irrelevant," Mr. Kozloff of Smith Barney said. "We're in a very volatile interest-rate environment and they got nailed. Whether it's Bankers Trust's fault or P.& G.'s fault, let them fight it out. You just wonder what else is out there."
He noted that other companies had increasingly attempted to hedge their interest rate, currency, and other exposures in the derivatives market, though he said it was anyone's guess how many other companies could be at risk.
In a telephone conference call with analysts and reporters, Mr. Nelson said P.& G. had entered into the contracts upon the suggestion of Bankers Trust. When it became clear that P.& G. was at increasing risk as a result of the swaps, "we had to close these down and take a one-time charge and put it behind us," Mr. Nelson said.
After taking the accounting charge against earnings this year, "the cash effect begins in the next year and continues on for five years," he added.
Both companies declined to say whether they had now severed their business ties. But the spokeswoman for P.& G. said the company still had relationships with other packagers of derivatives.

HEADLINE: Easier Arms-Maker Mergers Asked

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 12

 BODY:
A Federal panel of defense and antitrust experts recommended today that the Government reduce procedural obstacles to mergers of defense contractors, but did not propose the partial exemption from antitrust rules that some companies had sought.
The outcome represented a compromise between the Justice Department, which has opposed giving special consideration to armament builders, and the Defense Department, which has become increasingly interested in helping weapons makers cope with a steep drop in orders. The panel included a lawyer from each agency, as well as military-industry executives and academics. 
 Industry executives welcomed the report as making it easier to create mergers, but Justice and Defense Department officials were much more cautious, saying they were only trying to improve the process.
Bernard L. Schwartz, a panel member and the chairman and chief executive of the Loral Corporation, a defense electronics producer, said that while he had wanted a change in antitrust rules, he was satisfied with the outcome. "It defines the antitrust issues that both the industry and Government need to focus on," he said.
But Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum of Ohio, chairman of the Judiciary antitrust subcommittee, an antitrust advocate, was also satisfied. "This report assures American consumers that defense industry mergers will continue to get rigorous scrutiny and will be challenged if they are costly and anticompetitive," he said.
The panel's main recommendation was that the Defense Department designate one or two of its lawyers to provide advice to the Justice Department on mergers among military contractors, said Stephen Preston, the Pentagon's acting general counsel and a member of the panel. This would make it easier to advise both the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission on such mergers, he said.
Paul G. Kaminski, chairman of the Defense Science Board, a Pentagon agency that advises on commercial and technology issues and that organized the panel that produced the report, said the study "concludes that competition among firms in the defense industry is significantly different from competition among firms in other sectors of the economy, but that the antitrust merger guidelines are flexible enough to take into consideration the special circumstances of downsizing in the defense industry."
In previous mergers, officials from different Pentagon agencies have sometimes taken conflicting positions on mergers. Anne Bingaman, the Justice Department's top antitrust official, remarked that "this gives us a number to call over at the Pentagon."
Officials differed on how much difference the report would make. Mary Lou Steptoe, director of the Federal Trade Commission's bureau of competition, said it would not have changed the outcome of 300 mergers that antitrust-enforcement authorities have looked at over the last 15 years, 297 of which were approved.
But Mr. Schwartz of Loral said it was more significant, producing closer relations between the Defense Department and the antitrust agencies.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
The Canadian Triangle Where High Tech Reigns

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WATERLOO, Ontario

 BODY:
Thirteen years after starting a company here in Canada's high-tech hub, a Waterloo University professor, J. Wesley Graham, and his 50 backers are some $100 million richer.
As head of the university's Computer Systems Group, Professor Graham founded the Watcom International Corporation to produce software he developed that makes it easier to learn computer programming. The software has been used by more than one million students worldwide. 
 Watcom, which offers a variety of specialized programming tools, was bought by the Powersoft Corporation of Burlington, Mass., early this year. The deal gives the professor and each of his backers, many of them former students who now work for Watcom, bundles of Powersoft shares worth about $2 million (United States).
 
Haven for Entrepreneurs
 Watcom is one of hundreds of fledgling companies that have emerged from Canada's main industrial incubation area, a pocket of college towns in Ontario that has become known as the Canadian Technology Triangle.
Three highways connecting Waterloo-Kitchener, Guelph and Cambridge form the rough triangle, which is an hour's drive west of Toronto.
In Waterloo, there is Waterloo University, which has 21,000 students and is strong in engineering and mathematics; Wilfred Laurier University, which has 6,000 students and a graduate business administration program ranked fifth in Canada by one Canadian business magazine survey, and Conestoga College, whose 9,500 students learn a variety of technical and management skills. Only 20 minutes away is the University of Guelph, which is regarded as a heavyweight in biological and agricultural sciences, with 12,000 students.
Immigrants from Germany and Central Europe settled the area in the 19th century. About half a million people live there today.
Canada is still largely a natural resource producer, and the long global recession curbed demand for its lumber, metals, and other commodities, contributing heavily to today's double-digit nationwide unemployment rate. But within the 100 square miles of the triangle, where knowledge is the only natural resource, unemployment is 7 percent, lowest in the nation.
The triangle did not go unscathed during the long recession. Shutdowns of the Labatt brewery, the Uniroyal Goodrich tire factory, the Seagram's distillery, metal-stamping plants and other heavy-duty manufacturing operations added up to a loss of 6,000 manufacturing jobs.
Yet the region generated 11,000 new jobs, said D. G. McKenzie, director of economic development for the city of Waterloo. Mr. McKenzie was one of those hit by economic change. He had been president of the local subsidiary of the Buffalo Forge Company, a position that he said, smiling at the euphemism, was "restructured."
Now at least 350 high-tech companies give the region its economic lift. Many are start-ups like Watcom, hatched from talk over beers at the pub or around the soft-drink and juice machines in university research labs.
 
Optimistic Outlook
 J. Alex Murray, dean of the school of business and economics at Wilfred Laurier, has been smiling over the region's prospects. His annual survey of regional business conditions found that 52 percent of companies that responded said they were financially better off than a year ago, and 66 percent expected their financial picture to improve in 1994.
As with Route 128 in Boston or the Research Triangle area of North Carolina, here the lines between industry and academia are often blurred.
Professor Graham of Watcom never gave up his teaching job. Now that his company has been sold, he is resigning as chairman to teach full time. "Nobody told me to," the 62-year-old academic said, "but I've arrived at a stage where I just felt it's better to let the younger people carry on."
Other entrepreneurs have retained their academic ties. Prof. Savvas G. Chamberlain started Dalsa Inc. 10 years ago to make high-performance image sensors for document scanning and other uses. He still runs the company today while teaching microelectronics at Waterloo's electrical and computer engineering department.
"Before 1984," said the 53-year-old professor, who was born in Cyprus, "I didn't know the difference between a balance sheet and an income statement, but I learned quickly."
Professor Chamberlain originally offered his technology to I.B.M. and then to Northern Telecom. Both companies turned it down because they did not regard the potential market as big enough. Now Dalsa, an acronym of his and a friend's names, employs 70 people and has revenue of more than $10 million a year.
The smudging of boundaries between office and classroom is enhanced by co-op programs, in which students spend alternate semesters working for local companies, usually in positions closely related to their field of study.
The programs extend the academic year to 12 months but are popular because the students earn wages, gain work experience and have job prospects upon graduation. The companies gain low-cost consultants and a skilled work force.
The American software giant the Microsoft Corporation has a close relationship with Waterloo University. Dr. Arthur J. Carty, dean of research at the university, said Microsoft snapped up more graduates from his institution than from any other university.
A team from Waterloo won the 18th International Collegiate Programming Contest in Phoenix in March, sponsored by the Association for Computer Machinery. Harvard was first last year.
Waterloo collects $2 million a year in royalties from technology born in its labs, Dean Carty said. The 106 companies it has spun off employ more than 2,130 people.
 
Nurturing Enterprises
 Each of the four institutions in the triangle has spawned entrepreneurs.
Dan Einwechter worked his way through Wilfred Laurier in the 1970's driving trucks. Now 39, he operates one of the biggest trucking companies in Canada, Challenger Motor Freight Inc. in Cambridge, which employs 700 people in North America.
Challenger is high-tech trucking. Football-sized satellite dishes are mounted on the top of the truck cabs. The system lets the head office know exactly where the trucks are and how long it takes them to reach their destinations. The drivers send and receive messages on laptop computer keyboards.
Another company, Langford Laboratories in Guelph, was born in the veterinary school of the University of Guelph. It developed a vaccine for bovine respiratory disease and is now the animal research arm of Cynamid Canada Inc.
Zepf Technologies Inc., another private company in Waterloo, is prospering as a designer, manufacturer and installer of automation equipment for packaging lines. It is run by a machinist, Larry Zepf, who is a graduate and benefactor of Conestoga College.
 
Fostering Innovation
 Innovation is the key to all the enterprises, said Gordon F. Cummer, who manages the Canadian Industrial Innovation Center. His center, formed in 1976 by Waterloo University, is now independent and assesses hundreds of inventions a year for their commercial potential.
"We're a very innovative people," Mr. Cummer said, alluding to Alexander Graham Bell's telephone, Gideon Soundback's zipper and other inventions by Canadians, like basketball, five-pin bowling, table hockey, the Laser sailboat and Trivial Pursuit.
"When you have a relatively small country with a large geography," Mr. Cummer said, "it means you're constantly solving problems, whether you're a farmer trying to get grain harvested or a shipper trying to get something to market."

HEADLINE: Definitions of Financial Terms Involved

 BODY:
Hedge Fund: A flexible investment fund for rich people and institutions. The minimum investment is typically $1 million and the manager usually receives 20 percent of the profits. Hedge funds can use virtually any investment technique including short-selling -- borrowing shares and selling them in hopes of benefiting from a decline in prices -- and heavy borrowing, or leverage, neither of which is allowed for mutual funds.
Short-Selling: A way to bet that the price of a stock, or other security, will go down. A hedge fund would borrow the stock from a brokerage firm and sell it in the market, hoping to buy it back for a lower price and return it to its owner. Stocks bought the normal way are said to be owned "long." 
 Leverage: A way to amplify the potential gain or loss of an investment, usually by investing with borrowed money. For example, a fund with $100 of its own cash might borrow $900 -- making it "highly leveraged," allowing it to buy $1,000 in bonds. If the bonds rise by 10 percent, or $100, the fund would effectively earn a 100 percent return on its initial investment, far greater than the $10 it could have earned if it had used only its own cash to buy just $100 in bonds. Of course, if bond prices fall by 10 percent, the fund's entire investment would be wiped out after paying back its $900 loan.
Hedging: A strategy for protecting against financial risk by taking two positions that offset each other if prices change. Hedge funds originally tried to protect themselves by purchasing some stocks long and selling others short. If the stock market fell, the short positions would be worth more, but the long positions would lose money. If the market gained, the reverse would be true. The fund would make money, not because of the overall market movement, but because the stocks it bought long would do better relative to the ones it sold short. Today, not all hedge funds hedge.
Arbitrage: A form of hedged investment meant to capture slight differences in the prices between two securities that should be related. The classic example of arbitrage would be buying gold in London and selling it at a higher price in New York. Many hedge funds specialize in various forms of arbitrage, for example, in the relationship between the common stock and the preferred stock of the same company. Usually the price discrepancies are small, but the investment returns are amplified using leverage.
Derivatives: A broad class of transactions whose value is based on, or derived from, a financial market like stocks, interest rates or currencies. Hedge funds have become big user of derivatives to take large positions, either as outright investments or as hedges, quickly and secretly. Derivatives can also be a way of investing with leverage because many derivative transactions require little or no upfront cash payments.
Margin Calls: A demand for more collateral by a brokerage firm that has lent money to an investor. Investors are said to be taking a margin loan when they borrow money, but put up stocks or bonds as collateral. But when the value of those securities falls, the lender calls for more collateral to cover it if the borrower defaults. If the margin call is not met, the broker may sell the collateral he does hold to pay off the loans.

HEADLINE: Inquiry Challenges Doctors On Ordering Diagnostic Tests

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 12

 BODY:
Doctors order many more diagnostic tests when they have a financial interest in the equipment and clinics that perform the tests, Congressional investigators said today.
The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, said that doctors were three to five times as likely to order CAT scans, magnetic resonance imaging, ultrasound procedures and other diagnostic imaging services when the equipment was owned by the doctors themselves or by groups with which they were affiliated. 
 The accounting office produced the report at the request of Representative Pete Stark of California, a California Democrat who is chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health, the first Congressional panel to take up proposals for restructuring the health care system.
On the other side of the Capitol, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who is chairman of the Finance Committee, suggested today that work on health care legislation might not go as quickly as the Administration had hoped. Mr. Moynihan said his committee would continue holding hearings on health issues through mid-May and would probably not start writing a bill until some time in June, about a month later than planned.
 
Timetable Troubles Mitchell
 Senator George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine, the majority leader, expressed disappointment at the delay. "It had been my hope we could begin a little sooner than that," he said.
As part of any comprehensive legislation, Congress is considering proposals to tighten the limits on doctors' ability to profit from the referral of patients, an issue that has been debated for some time.
Congress has already prohibited doctors from sending Medicare patients to laboratories with which the doctors have financial relationships. On Jan. 1, 1995, the ban will be extended to cover these services under Medicare and Medicaid: physical therapy, radiology, home health services and hospital services.
But the law permits one doctor to refer patients to another one in the same group practice. In the last few years, some doctors have formed loose affiliations among themselves so they can call it a group practice. These "clinics without walls" have proliferated in Florida, California and other states as doctors try to avoid the ban on certain referrals.
 
Stark Cites Abuse
 The accounting office reviewed 2.4 million claims for imaging services. It did not try to determine whether the tests were medically necessary. But Mr. Stark said the data suggested that some doctors were "ripping off taxpayers" by ordering too many tests.
"The magnitude of over-ordering of tests by doctors who own an interest in an X-ray or M.R.I. practice is staggering," he said. "We are talking about billions of dollars of waste and abuse."
The American Medical Association declared in 1991 that it was unethical for a doctor to refer patients to clinics and other health-care businesses in which the doctor had a financial interest. But the application of this policy to specific cases is hotly debated.
 
Doing What Comes Naturally
 Kirk B. Johnson, senior vice president and general counsel of the association, said today that the data collected by the General Accounting Office were not surprising.
"If you have the equipment at your fingertips and you operate it yourself, you have complete confidence in the results, and you're more likely to use it," he said. "I'd rather go to a doctor who has his own machine and will feel free in a close case to use it. The economics of medicine are such that blatant overutilization is going to make a physician's practice uncompetitive."
With the spread of managed care and other techniques to control costs, Mr. Johnson said, "the real issue for patients is whether they will get the tests they need, not whether they are getting too many."
 
Hospitals Official Sees Harm
 At the Finance Committee hearing today, lobbyists for hospitals, doctors and the elderly said it would be disastrous to cut the growth of Medicare as much as President Clinton and authors of competing health plans have proposed.
Richard J. Davidson, president of the American Hospital Association, said: "Hospitals are firm supporters of fundamental health care reform. But hospitals strongly disagree with the idea that Medicare reductions are a reasonable way to finance reform."
The cutbacks proposed by the Administration would harm the quality of care, forcing hospitals to lay off workers and postpone the purchase of new equipment, he said.
White House officials, by contrast, assert that hospitals could be much more productive and could save money by sharing costly new technology.
The Congressional Budget Office says the Clinton plan would cut the growth of Medicare by $103 billion, or 9 percent, from 1996 to the year 2000. Under these proposals, Mr. Davidson said, the Government would pay hospitals 71 cents on the dollar for Medicare patients, as against 88 cents today.

HEADLINE: Alvin Ward Vogtle Jr., 75, Dies; Led Big Power Supplier in South

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Alvin Ward Vogtle Jr., a former president and chairman of the Atlanta-based Southern Company, parent of one of the country's largest electric grids, died on Sunday at Rockdale Hospital in Conyers, Ga. He was 75 and had lived in Reddick, Fla., since his retirement in 1983.
The cause was apparently heart failure, the company said. 
 Mr. Vogtle led the holding company through a period of growth and challenges as its president and chief executive from 1969 to 1983 and as chairman and chief executive for the months remaining until he stepped down that fall. Among those challenges were the Arab oil embargo of the 1970's, a worldwide recession and inflation rates that drove up the cost of electric power.
Southern's operating divisions include Alabama Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power in Florida, Mississippi Power and Savannah Electric.
A native of Birmingham, Ala., Mr. Vogtle graduated from Auburn University and the University of Alabama Law School. As a member of a Birmingham law firm, he became legal counsel and then president of the Southern Electric Generating Company, a Southern Company subsidiary.
 
Pilot in World War II
 He was elected a vice president of Alabama Power in 1962 and three years later took the same position at the parent company and Southern Company Services, another subsidiary.
Immediately after graduating from law school, Mr. Vogtle entered the Army. As an Army Air Force pilot in World War II, he flew more than 30 missions before crash-landing in North Africa.
Captured and sent to a prisoner of war camp in Germany, he made four unsuccessful escape attempts. On his fifth try, in 1943, he reached safety by scaling a 14-foot barbed-wire border fence and crossing the Rhine to Switzerland.
Mr. Vogtle is survived by his wife, Rachel Giles Vogtle; three daughters, Kathryn V. Humphrey of Durham, N.C., Anne M. Baldwin of Birmingham, and Rachel G. Vogtle of Gainesville, Fla; four sons, Alvin W. 3d, of Charlottesville, Va., Bryant W., of Charlotte, N.C., William P., of Ocala, Fla., and Robert J., of Gainesville, and four grandchildren.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alvin Ward Vogtle Jr. (Fabian Bachrach, 1973)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
 Hedge funds have been vilified as the junk bonds of the 90's: they are being blamed for many of the recent traumatic events in world financial markets and their managers, like George Soros, have come under fire. But hedge funds -- funds for rich people and institutions that typically borrow huge amounts of money for their investments -- continue to attract investors. [Page A1.] 
 Producer prices rose a modest two-tenths of 1 percent in March as energy costs steadied. Although the report on inflation was reassuring, analysts predicted it would do little to dissuade the Federal Reserve from raising interest rates further. [D1.]
The Government should reduce some obstacles to mergers of defense contractors, a Federal panel recommended. [D2.]
 
Companies
 Procter & Gamble, as a result of losses on risky interest rate investments, plans to take a $102 million charge against earnings. The company said it was considering legal action against Bankers Trust, which was involved in a number of the transactions. [D1.]
What does Michael Ovitz want? That is the question being asked in Hollywood after the chairman of the Creative Artists Agency appeared to stir turmoil at two entertainment giants. [D1.]
Macy's senior creditors submitted their plan for reorganizing the retailer. Creditors, who were generally unhappy with Macy's plan for emerging from bankruptcy, are meeting with Cyrus R. Vance, the mediator appointed by the bankruptcy court. [D4.]

 Canada has its own Silicon Valley, a pocket of college towns in Ontario that has become known as the Canadian Technology Triangle. The area has spawned hundreds of fledgling companies in software, medicine and other technologies. [D1.]

International Germany's biggest real estate developer has disappeared, leaving his company and its creditors in the dark and possibly liable for hundreds of millions of dollars worth of debts. [D1.]
 
Markets

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bonds Rise As Fed Buys Securities

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury bonds gained yesterday after the Federal Reserve Bank bought Government securities to increase banking system reserves.
The Labor Department's report on producer prices, showing low wholesale inflation for March, also helped prices. The price of the bellwether 30-year bond rose 11/32 point. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from prices, fell to 7.20 percent, from 7.23 percent on Monday. Prices of intermediate- and short-term maturities also gained. 
 The advance in prices, the fifth in six trading days, helped restore stability to a fragile market that until only recently had been buffeted by waves of selling by panicky investors.
"Trading is returning to more normal kinds of dynamics, said Dana Johnson, head of market analysis at First Chicago Capital Markets in Chicago. "We're likely to find we're in a trading range consolidation period."
But he added, "it's unlikely that all of a sudden the markets are going to say all is forgiven and rally back."
 
No Interest-Rate Rise Seen
 The central bank's purchase of Treasury securities, known as a coupon pass, had been expected and did not signal a further interest-rate increase by the Fed.
But the Fed's estimated $3 billion to $4 billion purchase gave a lift to the overall secondary market for government securities, Mr. Johnson said. The purchases raised bond prices, convincing others who anticipated further rises to buy as well.
Bond prices initially edged higher in early trading after the Labor Department reported that the Producer Price Index rose two-tenths of 1 percent in March, continuing the trend of low inflation of the last year.
The slight increase was generally in line with expectations. But since inflation can erode the value of fixed-income securities, the data reassured investors that the Labor Department's report on consumer prices, due out today, would also show inflation remained subdued in March.
Another major economic release today is the Government's report on March retail sales. A strong increase in sales could indicate an acceleration in economic growth, which could aggravate inflation pressures.
Also supporting the market yesterday was the Johnson Redbook's weekly report, which showed retail sales dropped 9.5 percent in the first week of April from the March average.
"We're starting to get a little bit of a positive tone," said Nick Kinas, a government bond trader at the Bank Leumi Trust Company of New York. "The jury's still out, but in the interim, the market is trying to regain its footing."
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, rose 1.97, to 1,235.74.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 3.63 percent as the discount dropped 0.07 percentage point, to 3.56 percent, from the level at Monday's auction. Six-month yields fell to 4.10 percent as the discount fell 0.06 point, to 3.97 percent, from the auction. One-year yields fell to 4.64 percent as the discount lost 0.02 point, to 4.43 percent.
Yields are the interest bonds pay by maturity, while the discount is the interest at which they are sold.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 923/32 , up 11/16 from late Monday. The average yield to maturity was 6.31 percent, down from 6.40 percent.

HEADLINE: 4 Former Brookhaven Officials Indicted in Bribe Scheme

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 12

 BODY:
Four former officials of the Town of Brookhaven have been charged in a Federal indictment with accepting bribes of as much as $250,000 to support a prominent developer's real-estate projects.
The indictment, unsealed today, grew out of statements made in September 1992 in Federal court by John McNamara, a car dealer and Long Island developer who pleaded guilty at that time to bilking General Motors out of $436 million in loans by faking the export of tens of thousands of vans. 
 As part of his plea agreement, Mr. McNamara admitted bribing officials in the Brookhaven town government, and for months, residents of this town of 420,000 people and 326 square miles, the largest on Long Island, have waited to learn their identities.
In the 1980's, Brookhaven, with its vast expanses of open space, became something of a last frontier for developers, and the town's favorable attitude toward some of them led many residents to nickname the town "Crookhaven." Some civic leaders questioned why town officials approved the plans of developers like Mr. McNamara over the objections of homeowners who sought to preserve some of the last enclaves of pine barrens and meadows on Long Island.
Some residents hailed the indictment today as an important step toward ending the backroom deals they say characterized the town's government, though they questioned whether it had gone far enough. Law-enforcement officials said the investigation was continuing, with more indictments possible.
In a statement released this morning, Zachary Carter, the United States Attorney for the Eastern District, announced that Buovodantona (Anthony) Aliperti and Peter A. Sapienza, former members of the Town Planning Board, and Anthony Losquadro and Donald W. Zimmer, former members of the Town Board, had received kickbacks in cash, discounted cars, real estate commissions and jobs in return for supporting Mr. McNamara's development projects.
 
Shell Game Alleged
 Alan Vinegrad, the Assistant United States Attorney who supervised the investigation, said, "The payments by McNamara were motivated to insure that the defendants would act favorably on his real-estate projects." The defendants, who held office in the 1980's and left in the early 1990's, voted on Mr. McNamara's many projects during their terms.
In a separate indictment, the Government also charged Mr. Sapienza with assisting Mr. McNamara in his scheme to bilk General Motors.
According to court papers, Mr. Sapienza operated Kay Industries, a shell corporation owned by Mr. McNamara in Indianapolis, that apparently provided Mr. McNamara with false paperwork involving the purchase of tens of thousands of nonexistent vans and cars. This paperwork enabled Mr. McNamara to borrow more than $4 billion from the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the financing branch of the corporation, from 1989 to 1991.
Mr. McNamara then used that money to build a $400 million real-estate empire that included luxury town-house complexes and apartment buildings in Brookhaven, a golf course in Florida and a gold mine in Nevada.
Lawyers for Mr. Sapienza, Mr. Zimmer and Mr. Losquadro insisted that their clients were innocent and that Mr. McNamara was lying about their activities to save himself. Paul Gianelli, Mr. Aliperti's lawyer, did not return phone calls asking for comment.
In the court papers, Mr. Sapienza appears to be the biggest beneficiary of Mr. McNamara's payments, though all four men are accused of entering into a conspiracy to extort money from Mr. McNamara and his real estate and automobile companies.
 
Payments Listed
 Prosecutors said that Mr. Sapienza received $250,000 in cash payments from Mr. McNamara, and that he and another town official also were paid a $95,000 commission from Mr. McNamara's sale of land in Brookhaven shortly after the town had approved Mr. McNamara's request to rezone the property to allow more building.
The indictment also charges that Mr. Sapienza received $37,600 in kickbacks and more than $20,000 in home improvement work from the Crystal Brook Construction Corporation, a company not connected with Mr. McNamara.
The Brookhaven Town Supervisor, John LaMura, said today that he was disturbed by the indictments and that he had made reforms in the town government since taking over in 1992.
Some residents remain convinced that corruption persists. They point to Mr. Zimmer's being rehired by the town a few years ago as an executive assistant in the town's Economic Development Department and Mr. Losquadro's being given a job with the Suffolk County Off-Track Betting Corporation, as examples of how things have not changed.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Up a Modest 0.2% in March

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 12

 BODY:
Prices paid to American producers increased a modest two-tenths of 1 percent in March as energy costs steadied after steep advances earlier in the year, the Labor Department reported today.
But while the eagerly awaited figures were seen by economists as fairly reassuring -- and did not unhinge the bond or stock markets -- analysts predicted that they would do little to dissuade the Federal Reserve Board from raising interest rates further to keep inflation in check. 
 "The Fed wants to see inflation trending down and this number's not pointing to that," said Carl J. Palash of MCM Moneywatch, a New York advisory firm.
When the volatile food and energy components are excluded, leaving the core rate of inflation, prices of finished goods rose at an annual rate of 3.3 percent in the first quarter of 1994, compared with nine-tenths of 1 percent in the final 1993 quarter, today's report showed. This acceleration was paced by industrial equipment and consumer durable goods like cars.
Core inflation was calculated at two-tenths of 1 percent for March and a scant four-tenths of 1 percent for the latest 12 months.
The performance at earlier stages of production was mixed, with a jump in energy prices driving raw materials up 2.8 percent, the biggest increase since October 1990, soon after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.
But analysts did not fret particularly about higher prices for raw materials -- excluding food and energy, they were up nine-tenths of 1 percent for the month and 10.9 percent for the year -- on the ground that commodities are a relatively small part of the cost of most products.
The biggest cost for most companies is labor, and this was subdued as companies offset moderately higher pay costs, 3.5 percent in each of the last two years, with aggressive increases in efficiency.
"Unit labor costs in manufacturing almost certainly declined again in the first quarter and will probably decline for the year," Donald H. Straszheim, chief economist for Merrill Lynch & Company, told clients today. "That means companies can enjoy fatter profit margins even without raising prices."
Indeed, higher prices for raw materials like cotton have generally not filtered through even to the intermediate stage of production, which in this case would be a bolt of cloth.
Intermediate goods moved up just two-tenths of 1 percent last month, the same as for finished goods, and are a mere seven-tenths of 1 percent higher over the last year.
 
More for Finished Goods
 "It's a long way from what these crude materials cost at one end of the pipeline to what the consumer pays at the end of the distribution chain," said Joseph R. Liro, chief economist at S. G. Warburg.
What he and other analysts did find a bit unnerving, however, was the predominance of increases in the finished-goods index, which is made up of items ready for sale to the individual or business user. Mr. Liro said that among the 74 product categories, goods rising two-tenths of 1 percent or more outnumbered goods that fell two-tenths or 1 percent or more by 40 to 14. The rest moved only slightly or were unchanged.
"I don't think we're on the cusp of a sharp acceleration," he said, but this imbalance could be reflecting faster industrial operating rates "spreading to more sectors."
On Wednesday, the Government is to publish its report on consumer prices for March, with forecasters expecting the index to rise two-tenths of 1 percent.
 
How Shrewd Was the Fed?
 Economists say it will probably be weeks, perhaps months, before data will show whether the Federal Reserve moved too soon, too late or just at the right time in beginning to raise interest rates on Feb. 4.
The Fed, seeking this time to head off inflation before it appears, has observed that waiting for the inflation gauges to register has meant waiting too long to act.
A major factor in the rise in finished goods last month was a five-tenths of 1 percent rise in food prices, reversing a February decline. The upturn mainly reflected a 9.8 percent surge for vegetables.
Energy prices were unchanged as gasoline and home heating oil fell while natural gas jumped more than in February. Capital equipment, up three-tenths of 1 percent last month, rose at a 4 percent annual rate in the first quarter, compared with a rate of less than 1 percent in the final quarter of 1993.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises on Speculation About a German Rate Cut

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most leading currencies yesterday amid speculation that the Bundesbank may cut interest rates at a meeting tomorrow on German monetary policy.
Many traders expect the German central bank will continue to lower rates to revive the country's slumping economy. The Bundesbank last cut its discount rate, the lowest rate it charges banks to borrow money, to 5.25 percent from 5.75 percent in February. Lower rates make investments denominated in marks less attractive. 
 "People sold Deutsche marks against everything today," said Dave Glowacki, senior trader for NBD Bank in Detroit. "They're expecting rate cuts in Germany, perhaps as soon as Thursday."
The dollar was quoted at 1.7161 marks in late New York trading yesterday, up from 1.7126 marks on Monday.
At the least, traders said, the Bundesbank is expected to lower its securities repurchase rate, a money-market rate, this week. The rate, which banks pay to borrow from the Bundesbank, has fallen to 5.73 percent from 6 percent in six weeks.
The dollar strengthened against the yen, rising slightly in New York to 103.70 yen, from 103.41 yen on Monday. The dollar was helped when Roger C. Altman, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, said he did not see the trade dispute between the United States and Japan widening. Formal trade talks between the nations collapsed in February.
"There's not going to be a trade war," Mr. Altman said. "No one in the United States is in favor of a trade war."
The dollar plunged against the yen on Monday amid concerns that trade relations will suffer as Japan scrambles to find a successor to Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa, who resigned Friday.
"Hosokawa's resignation made people think the U.S. would start talking tough on the yen again," said David Durst, a trader at Bear, Stearns & Company. Mr. Altman's comments eased some of those concerns, he said.
Also yesterday, the British pound rose to $1.4765 from $1.4708. The dollar rose to 5.8686 French francs from 5.8656 francs and strengthened to 1.4455 Swiss francs from 1.441 francs. The dollar rose to 1,634 Italian lire from 1,628 lire. The Canadian dollar rose to 72.52 United States cents from 72.12 cents yesterday.

LENGTH: 2146 words

HEADLINE: Washington Dining: A Deficit No More

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
Michel Richard, the chef and owner of Citrus in Los Angeles, is ensconced in Georgetown.
Patrick Clark, who made his mark at Metro in New York, is cooking at the Hay-Adams Hotel, across from the White House.
Dean & Deluca and Les Halles, both offshoots of New York operations, are drawing crowds. 
 Opening on Friday is Coco Loco. It is owned by Yannick Cam, best known as the chef of Le Pavillon in Washington, and by Savino Recine of Primi Piatti here. B. Smith's, a New York restaurant, and Legal Seafood of Boston are expected to be in residence soon.
The nation's capital is the country's hot new dining spot, and it's about time. Unlike other capital cities -- Paris, London, Rome -- Washington has never been a culinary mecca. But in the last year, the number of restaurants here that can hold their own with respected places in New York or Los Angeles has increased at a dizzying rate.
While out-of-towners have been moving in on the local chefs, the locals have not been standing still. Roberto Donna, who owned two restaurants two years ago, is now involved in five. Jean-Louis Palladin, whose restaurant Jean-Louis in the Watergate Hotel holds the distinction of being the most expensive in town, has opened a less expensive place, also at the Watergate. With Mr. Donna, he also owns Pesce, a moderately priced fish restaurant.
And in keeping with the supposed preferences of the Arkansans who have moved to town, several restaurant owners have opened places with a Southern feel.
In the 1960's and 1970's, when the best restaurants in other cities were serving French haute cuisine, the best meals in Washington were found in embassies and in private homes. The people who had money to spend in restaurants were lobbyists, and they weren't on a quest for culinary excellence.
By the 1980's, diplomacy had changed and the embassies had lost their power and their cachet. The grandes dames who entertained so splendidly at their mansions had dwindled to a precious few. Washingtonians, like everyone else, began to eat out more, and became much more sophisticated about food.
A result, said William D. Lecos, executive vice president of the Restaurant Association of Metropolitan Washington, is that the city has become a destination for aspiring chefs. And it's a city with money to spend.
"Washington is still growing: the recession wasn't as bad here as elsewhere, and there is a new Administration," Mr. Lecos said. "The Clintons dine out a lot, which is consistent with the baby-boomer age group, and that sets a style."
Among the new restaurants, here are some of the better-known ones:
 
Citronelle
 One of the most consistently excellent newcomers is Citronelle, the less expensive version of Mr. Richard's Citrus. Located in the Latham, a small hotel in Georgetown, it is full of cheerful light and many of the city's movers and shakers.
Unlike many other restaurants, this one combines good people-watching with stunning food that reflects Mr. Richard's French background and his years in California. He is particularly adept at weaving the homey and the elegant.
A diner who ordered the foie gras with mashed potatoes, paper-thin oven-dried beet chips and a vibrant red beet sauce wondered whether he could lick the plate. Equally fine were rabbit and lentils, quail, crab cakes, and sweetbreads and rice. The desserts were sublime, and the wine list very good, although expensive.
 
Hay-Adams Hotel
 Patrick Clark cooked at Odeon and at Metro in New York, then went on to Los Angeles, where he was at Bice. He is now making splendid food at the Hay-Adams Hotel, a small and charming place whose windows look across Lafayette Park at the White House. This luxurious Old World setting, with handsome furnishings -- crystal chandeliers and upholstered armchairs -- is just right for Mr. Clark's sophisticated food.
Two out of three meals at the Hay Adams were splendid. The mouthwatering names attached to some of the dishes are justified: smoked salmon and potato layer cake, shrimp with Thai seasonings, roasted salmon with Moroccan barbecue sauce, and pan-roasted Maine cod with leeks, potatoes and mussels.
If there is still room for dessert, the intensely flavored sorbets, the gingery creme brulee or the mint chocolate marquise would make almost anyone happy. At a restaurant where entrees are from $18 to $28, it is not surprising that the wine list, though extensive, is expensive.
Jaleo
 There is lots of stucco, wrought iron, flamenco music and flavor at Jaleo (pronounced ha-LAY-oh), a wildy successful tapas bar and restaurant in the old section of downtown, which is undergoing a rebirth. The owner of Cafe Atlantico and the owner and chef of the two Austin Grills, three of the city's hipper places, have added a fourth hot spot.
America's increasing interest in spicy food is well satisfied here. And it isn't only the tapas: many other dishes were successful, including the paella. Outstanding tapas include lentils and greens, marinated mussels and green beans, grilled portobello mushroom, spinach with pine nuts and raisins, warm goat cheese with garlic toast and grilled chorizo with mashed potatoes and turnips. This is a good place to go with a lot of friends, so you won't miss any of the tapas.
Vidalia
 Now that Jeffrey Buben, formerly of the Occidental in Washington, cooks in a restaurant he owns with his wife, Sallie, he has come into his own. They have turned a basement space into Vidalia, a charming country dining room.
When he is hot, which is most of the time, you will not find better onion rings, mashed potatoes, grits, corn bread and other Southern delicacies. When he isn't, the food is still O.K. He has a blue-plate special of vegetables that could make converts out of meat eaters. Also superb are shrimp with caramelized onions and creamy grits and seared salmon with an onion-coriander sauce.
The quality of the desserts is in keeping with the rest of the food.
Sesto Senso
 From linguine in a sauce brimming with freshly cooked seafood to the more unusual buckwheat noodles with spinach, potatoes and fontina cheese, there are not too many missteps at this restaurant opened by former employees of Bice in Washington.
The lentil soup at lunch is enough for a meal, especially when you include the bruschetta that arrives when you sit down. The pizzas are crisp and thin, the lightly fried calamari tender, the seafood risotto creamy and moist. Even the tiramisu is noteworthy.
But beware the canned music. Those with sensitive ears need to go early before the scene and sound become unbearably cacophonous.
Georgia Brown's
 Those looking for noisy fun will find some soul-satsifying food at Georgia Brown's, one of the Southern restaurants that opened when the Arkansans arrived in Washington. These people know how to fry -- oysters, fish, crab cakes.
But this is a 1990's Southern restaurant. As one patron, a Tennessean by birth, said, "The grease is gone."
Tasty pork and collards and spicy chicken sausages redeemed an uninspired vegetable plate. Dress is casual and the crowd is young.
Mimmetta
 Anyone with even the slightest curiosity about Sicilian dishes should make a reservation at Mimmetta, where Mimmetta Lo Monte is pleasing the guests in her homey dining room with simple food.
Scallops seasoned with mint and ginger; grilled tuna with lemon, garlic and oregano, and beef rolls with bread crumbs, pine nuts and currants are distinctively Sicilian and suffused with flavor. The more familiar Italian dishes, like baked eggplant with lemon, garlic and tomato, and fusilli with tomatoes, eggplant and zucchini, are also appealing.
Kinkead's
 Bob Kinkead started off in Washington with the well-regarded and very expensive 21 Federal, which went out of business when the economy started to slide and deductions for business meals were reduced. Now, he has opened a less expensive, much less formal restaurant, Kinkead's, and it is packed. You can go there in a black sequined spaghetti-strap dress or a plaid flannel shirt.
Can success spoil it? Sometimes.
This wonderfully cozy restaurant with lots of little nooks and crannies and a reasonably priced wine list was having a very bad night on my last visit. It took 45 minutes to get the first course, the swordfish was overcooked, the waiter was mainly invisible and the pear crisp had a doughy underbrowned crust.
Blame it on the rave review in The Washington Post a week earlier. At three meals eaten before the review, the food had been quite good, particularly the tuna with white beans, salmon with a crunchy crust of pumpkin seeds, a comforting roast chicken and some well-dressed salads.
Ristorante Luigino
 Ristorante Luigino is located in a former bus station in a part of downtown Washington that has very little in the way of good places to eat. But even on a freezing day in February, the tomatoes were so well marinated they tasted like summer.
The antipasti were the standouts: firm asparagus in a creamy sauce of fontina, earthy wild mushrooms sauteed with garlic and parsley, soft polenta with Gorgonzola. The entrees were forgettable.
Il Radicchio
 Il Radicchio, the latest in Roberto Donna's growing stable, is a spaghetti-pizza parlor with pretensions. A bread basket of exemplary focaccia and Tuscan bread with olive oil for dipping helps to while away the very few minutes you wait for your dinner, once you are seated; there are no reservations.
The pastas, with 23 different sauces, all priced under $10, are the best choice. There's a simple pomodoro, a zesty but sweet radicchio, sausage and red wine and a powerful puttanesca with black olives and capers. Crusts on pizza are thin and crisp. But a chicken was still pink and we had to argue with the waiter about taking back a potato pizza with undercooked potatoes and pancetta and burned garlic. Maybe that's how they get the food to the table so fast -- they don't finish cooking it.
Palladin
 Some of the well-known chefs aren't living up to their previous reputations.
Jean-Louis Palladin, whose restaurant in the Watergate is probably the most expensive in Washington, has opened another in the same hotel, using his last name instead of his first and reducing the tab significantly.
Palladin is lively; the people are all dressed up, and the tableware is a reminder of the days when nouvelle cuisine was in flower and entrees came on 18-inch plates. Unfortunately, the contents were not worthy of their impressive containers. One night the food was mediocre; on another it was often delicious and mostly salty.
The clam consomme was salty and filled with flavors of the sea; the onion tart in a wonderfully crisp and buttery crust was salty, too. There was an excellent but salty galantine and a dish of salty shrimp and beans. Several dishes that were not salty had no taste.
Pesce
 Whoever is overseeing the kitchen in Palladin must also be overseeing the kitchen at Pesce, the fish market-cum-restaurant owned by Mr. Palladin and Mr. Donna. Salt was the primary seasoning.
There are blackboard menus, huge portions, great focaccia and uneven cooking. It's a neighborhood restaurant with reasonable prices.
Gerard's Place
 In McPherson Square, Gerard Pangaud has a attractive bistro where he has not achieved the quality of cooking for which he was known when he was a two-star chef in France.
The Hot Spots of the Capital's New Restaurant Scene
 At expensive restaurants, a three-course dinner with tax and tip costs $40 or more; at moderate restaurants, $25 to $40; and at inexpensive restaurants, less than $25.

SECTION: Section C; Page 4; Column 1; Living Desk 

LENGTH: 1051 words

HEADLINE: Eating Well

BYLINE: By Marian Burros 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
AS soon as the early-morning bullet train from Tokyo to Kyoto pulled out of the station, Japanese children pulled out their breakfasts: deep-fried chicken nuggets, pork cutlet sandwiches, hot dogs and soft drinks.
There may be poetic justice here. 
 If, as some believe, the Japanese are undermining the American economy by their trade practices, Americans may be quietly undermining the health of the Japanese public -- with its eager cooperation -- by selling it billions of dollars' worth of hamburgers and french fries, ice cream and Danish pastries. There are at least a thousand McDonald's in Japan today.
The Japanese seem to have an ever-growing appetite for Western-style food high in fat and calories and low in fiber and complex carbohydrates. "Diet is related to the change in economic growth," Dr. Shuhei Kobayashi, the director of the National Institute of Health and Nutrition, said earlier this month in Tokyo. "The richer people are, the more food they eat." Especially food that is high in fat.
The Japanese fascination with Western food is not based on taste alone. Western food is easier to prepare than the traditional labor-intensive Japanese meals, with their emphasis on rice and vegetables. And fast food is much cheaper than even the simplest bowl of soup in a noodle restaurant.
On a recent trip to Japan, it was obvious that the trendiest Japanese adolescents, in their neatened-up version of grunge, eat fast food often, and on some of them it is already showing, as they grow horizontally as well as vertically.
"I eat hamburgers and french fries and a Coke two or three times a week, and cakes and pastries, but not every day," said Saori Yamaguchi, standing in front of a McDonald's.
Hayashi Masazumi, with the top of his hair dyed red, several earrings and a John F. Kennedy medallion around his neck, said he ate cheeseburgers, fries, milk and ice cream every day. "It tastes good and it's cheap," he added.
A report by the Japanese Government released last month shows the impact of Western food. It warns that if the Japanese continue to increase their consumption of fat, which rose from 8.7 percent of calories in 1955 to 25.5 percent in 1992, they risk a much higher rate of chronic diseases.
Between 1960 and 1991, consumption of grains in the Japanese diet dropped from about 14 ounces to less than 10 ounces a day per person. Rice, the staple of the Japanese diet, dropped from a little over 10 ounces a day to less than 7 ounces, while milk and dairy-product consumption rose from about 2 ounces a day to about 8 ounces. Low-fat dairy products are unheard of.
Meat consumption per person, according to the report, rose from less than an ounce a day to more than 3 ounces; consumption of fats and oils tripled, from less than half an ounce to an ounce and a half.
But the consumption of sodium, which once amounted to 20 grams a day, has dropped strikingly, to a little less than 13 grams a day.
These dietary changes have resulted in a mixed bag for the Japanese. The height and weight of younger Japanese have increased strikingly, reflected in the need to buy larger school desks. The decrease in salt consumption has strikingly reduced the number of deaths from stroke and from stomach cancer. And the incidence of infectious diseases like pneumonia and tuberculosis, caused by malnutrition, has dropped.
While the Japanese continue to have the longest life expectancy of any nationality, there has been a significant increase in the mortality rate from colon, lung, rectal and liver cancer among men, while breast cancer among women is also on the rise.
Dr. Takashi Sugimura, president emeritus of the National Cancer Center in Tokyo, said that the striking rise in the cancer rate among men may be due to their eating so much more Western food than women do. "In Japan housewives still stay home," Dr. Sugimura said, "but men have many outside dinners and meetings, and food is Western style because it is easier and more convenient for the hotel or restaurant to prepare."
And perhaps, as others have suggested, Western food, especially French and Italian, is seen as more sophisticated.
The relation between colon cancer and a high-fat diet is pretty clear, Dr. Sugimura said. The relationship between breast cancer and fat is less so.
A recent study of the cholesterol levels of Japanese children from ages 8 to 14 does not bode well for their future health. Children in urban areas have higher cholesterol levels than their American counterparts.
"The Government is concerned; pediatric cardiologists are concerned," said Dr. Teruo Omae, president of the National Cardiovascular Center in Osaka. "They are warning that the situation is very risky and that children will have a greatly increased risk factor for heart disease."
Over all, the mortality rate from heart disease has decreased somewhat, but the incidence of heart disease is rising. Dr. Omae said the impact of the Westernization of the Japanese diet on heart disease will probably not be clear for 20 years.
The Japanese have embraced the worst aspects of the American diet and don't seem to know how to counteract their effects. Dr. Kobayashi said that there are 800 health centers throughout Japan with professional dietitians who meet with people in the workplace and in schools. But the information in the Government's pamphlet on health may be too vague to be helpful.
A few samples:
* Have a nutritionally balanced diet.
* Eat a variety of types of food.
* Avoid excess calories, especially as fat.
* Don't smoke; otherwise, smoke as little as possible.
After 10 years of publication only 200,000 copies of the booklet have been handed out.
Dr. Sugimura said some of the suggestions in the book were softened because of food industry criticism.
"This kind of compromise is always necessary," he said. "We have to have everyone feel happy. We need mutual coexistence.
Dr. Sugimura is not in favor of more specific advice. "I think recommendations on food should be very soft," he said. "I think scientists need to be modest. They sometimes think they know everything, like God. Government does not have the responsibility to do this education. Government is too busy fighting each other. It's people's responsibility to decide what they eat."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The proliferation of cheap but high-fat fast food is changing Japanese eating habits. This McDonald's is in Tokyo. (Hashimoto/Sygma)

HEADLINE: Cutting Too Deeply

 BODY:
The House is poised to vote on a motion that would cut the Federal budget to damagingly low levels. The motion would reduce discretionary spending over the next five years by $26 billion below the stringent levels set by last year's deficit-reduction package. The Senate has already approved the cut; the House motion will instruct House conferees to accept that decision.
The vote will appear bloodless because the motion backs the idea of cuts without naming victims. But if the cuts become law, they would force Congress to gut President Clinton's investment program, diminish its own crime initiative or reduce defense spending. 
 Promising to cut Federal spending always sounds prudent. But in this case the promise is unnecessary and unwise. The 1993 budget law will drive the deficit below $175 billion by 1995, low enough to keep the nation's debt from growing faster than the economy. Domestic discretionary spending will be held constant for five years; that would bring such spending to its lowest level, compared with the size of the economy, in 30 years.
Congress will be hard pressed to meet these spending targets. The President's plan, for example, includes $15 billion in budget savings over five years that few outside the Administration believe will materialize. Nor is Congress expected to grant many of Mr. Clinton's proposed cuts -- forcing them to come up with more of their own.
At risk is the President's planned investment program. According to the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, it started out at $120 billion over four years but has already been pared back, because of last year's budget law, to less than $75 billion. Congress plans to raise Mr. Clinton's proposed spending by $9 billion for crime prevention and by $11 billion for defense programs this page has opposed. If Congress now requires an additional $26 billion cut, these plans will be scuttled.
Neither the White House nor Congress has yet found some $10 billion to pay for the GATT treaty, which the world's trading partners took seven years to negotiate and which they will sign next week. It makes no sense for Congress now to move the fiscal goal posts $26 billion further away.
