HEADLINE: Women Campaign for New Plan To Curb the World's Population

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 8

 BODY:
For decades, when population planners talked about the world's poorest women, they concentrated on how to keep them from having more babies. Vast programs in Asia, Africa and Latin America were geared to sterilizing women, implanting them with IUD's, handing out contraceptives and imposing quotas on family size.
Despite the success achieved by family planning programs in India, Thailand, Kenya and other countries in curbing population growth, women's groups argue that these traditional methods are demeaning and coercive, and that a dramatic shift is needed. 
 The women's groups have won broad support among many population experts for a new emphasis on expanding health services to include prenatal care, educating girls and promoting women's equality.
The proponents of change argue that birth rates in poor countries will decline in the future only after the status, health, education and economic opportunities for women rise.
But some longtime population experts criticize the new approach, fearing that money spent for these broader goals, however worthy in principle, will divert resources from programs that have worked to curb population growth in the past.
"As women gain more control over their lives, they will have fewer children," said Dr. Nafis Sadik, executive director of the United Nations Population Fund and an advocate of the new policy. "This has been the experience of successful programs that have pursued a broader approach."
A debate over how to proceed on population control is taking place this month at a United Nations conference, attended by 170 countries, that will shape how billions of dollars are spent by rich countries, the World Bank and poor countries themselves in the next decade.
The delegates are arguing over the wording of a document to be adopted at the International Conference on Population and Development in Cairo this fall. The document is to serve as a kind of blueprint for international agencies and countries on how to devise population programs and channel money in the future.
The real fights, experts say, will come later: whether to spend scarce money for, say, implanting intrauterine devices, or for prenatal care and other services that would lead women to curb the size of their families on their own.
The new approach set forth in the draft plan at the conference has been devised partly by women themselves, and has the support of the Clinton Administration. Delegates say they expect it to be adopted in general form.
The draft plan would offer women and teen-agers a broad range of health services, including prenatal care, counseling about AIDS or other sexually transmitted diseases, child immunization and a free choice of contraceptives.
But there are powerful detractors lobbying for changes in the draft.
The Vatican, for example, is attacking the plan because it does not rule out abortion and because counseling and birth control services would be offered to married and unmarried women alike. There is strong opposition in many countries, including the United States, to offering sexual counseling or contraceptives to adolescents.
Many developing nations also resent any pressure to change traditional customs or interfere with their own programs. Specifically, countries with conservative social traditions resent talk of providing "sexual counseling" to young women, especially if they are unmarried.
Perhaps the most surprising opposition to the new plan comes from advocates of traditional family planning programs that have helped to reduce birth rates in developing countries by about a third since the 1960's. Many of these experts say that these gains may be imperiled if resources for such programs are cut back.
"They never face the issue of what to do when resources are scarce, and they are," Dr. J. Joseph Speidel, president of Population Action International, said about advocates of the new plan. He argued that widening the services without increasing the money for them would mean that fewer women would benefit.
 
Feminism vs. Birth Control
 In some quarters, the debate has become acrimonious, pitting longtime population control advocates against feminist groups.
"The women don't like to talk about rapid population growth," said Charles F. Westoff, professor of sociology at Princeton University. "See if you can find any unambiguous statement in that document that fertility rates are too high and women should be discouraged from having children. You're hard put to get some recognition by these women that birth control is one of the best ways to improve women's status."
Providing the services called for in the new plan would cost an estimated $13.2 billion in the year 2000, an amount that several groups said was not enough.
Breaking with previous policies, the new plan also asks men to take responsibility for using birth control and preventing sexually-transmitted diseases.
Despite the criticism from traditionalists, population experts say the plan reflects an emerging consensus that family planning alone will not work fast enough.
 
World Population May Double
 United Nations demographers project that the world's population, now 5.7 billion, will reach more than 10 billion by 2050, but the conference has set a goal of stabilizing population at 7.8 billion by that year.
Dispensing contraceptives alone does not necessarily lead families to want fewer children or give women a voice in that decision. The demographers cite studies showing that birth rates drop when women are better-educated and when immunization and other health services help children survive into adulthood.
Many experts also say that slower population growth may well depend on offering counseling or birth control to adolescents so they postpone childbearing.
 
Women Find a Voice
 Delegates say that never before have so many women, in rich countries and poor ones, participated in the planning and policies likely to be produced.
"When we say population policy, people think family planning, and we're saying it's far more than that," said Joan Dunlop, president of the International Women's Health Coalition, a nonprofit group. "To talk about gender equity and women's rights in population policy -- it's unbelievable. It's such a dramatic change."
Women are a minority among the official delegates, but women from around the world are crowding the corridors here this week, and the conference's Secretary General, Dr. Sadik, is a woman.
"Women's groups really drove this," said Timothy E. Wirth, the State Department Counselor, who said he heeded their advice in drawing up a broader United States population policy.
But opponents to this new approach are working to alter the draft plan during the next few weeks.
 
Sharp Exchanges
 There have already been some sharp exchanges at the conference. Shortly after the Vatican representative, Msgr. Diarmuid Martin, said the plan lacked a "coherent moral vision," the conference's chairman, Dr. Fred Sai of Ghana, rose to disagree, and women from several countries held a news conference to denounce the Vatican position.
The Vatican is particularly troubled by the radical shift on abortion since the last population conference in Mexico City in 1984, when the United States backed a decision not to give aid to family planning programs that offered abortion.
Vatican representatives, who have observer status at the conference, say they will try to persuade member countries to oppose including abortion in family planning services, and to narrow the definition of family to married couples only.
 
Catholic and Muslim Allies
 Allied with the Vatican on these issues are Latin American governments that side with Roman Catholic teaching against abortion and Muslim fundamentalists who oppose the emphasis on equal rights for women.
The draft plan still allocates the most money to family planning services -- $10.2 billion of the $13.2 billion, with the rest for expanded health services and AIDS prevention. But Ms. Dunlop argues that some family planning programs, like sterilization, are more expensive than efforts to help women.
Defenders of traditional family planning programs argue that the accomplishments of past programs are being overlooked. They cite estimates that these programs have already reduced the world population by about 400 million people.
But women's groups say that many family planning programs do not help poor women understand their rights or contraceptive choices.
 
Bangladeshi Model
 Ms. Dunlop, of the International Women's Health Coalition, pointed to a program in Bangladesh as a model for the broader services the United Nations plan envisions.
The Bangladesh Women's Health Coalition began in 1980 by offering abortions. But at the urging of the women it served, it soon expanded to include family planning, basic health care services, child immunizations, legal aid, and training in literacy and employment skills.
According to its director, Sandra Kabir, the coalition now serves 110,000 women a year at 10 clinics.
Ms. Kabir told the story of one 18-year-old woman who approached them for prenatal services. She returned after the birth for contraception, had her daughter immunized, joined an adult literacy program, underwent job training and now runs a successful village business. She was also decribed as determined to educate her young daughter.

HEADLINE: Ferry Service Makes Ready To Broaden In the Region

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
After seven years of gradual expansion, ferry service in the New York region is about to branch out in a big way with several new routes to serve commuters -- and two designed especially for baseball fans.
Arthur E. Imperatore, who already operates ferries across the Hudson River, will announce plans today for a new service, beginning in May, between a dock just south of Newport Center in Jersey City and Battery Park City in lower Manhattan. In June, he said, service will begin between a barge just south of 35th Street in the East River and another in Hunters Point, Queens. 
 By opening day of baseball season in 1995 -- and perhaps before this season ends -- he said another new ferry route will connect the East River barge with a dock 1,500 feet west of Yankee Stadium in the Bronx.
While Mr. Imperatore so far dominates the ferry service industry in the region, others want part of the business -- encouraged in some cases by interest from the state. But even if all the new routes become reality, they will fall far short of resurrecting the heyday of ferry travel at the end of the 19th century, when ferries plied the waters on 125 separate routes from Manhattan to docks elsewhere in the region.
 
Only One Survived
 Those ferries died a slow death, as commuters found other options in new river bridges, tunnels for cars and trains, and highway systems; only the stalwart Staten Island Ferry survived through the last 90 years.
Environmentalists and urban planners say the demise of ferries came at great cost, eliminating alternatives for motorists who now drive to the city and belch harmful emissions in their wake, and leaving old piers and docks abandoned and rotting along the region's vast expanses of waterfront.
Now, according to Mr. Imperatore and others, a revival has found its underpinnings in simple economics: people are willing to pay more to ride a ferry to Manhattan than to ride trains, buses and other forms of public transportation, most of them heavily subsidized by the government.
"We find that people chose ferries for reasons other than price," said Donald Liloia, director of ferry services for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which has conducted several surveys of people using the region's embryonic ferry services since the late 1980's.
What attracts them to the ferries, he said, is their reliability and safety, as well as the opportunity they provide for an esthetic break in commuters' workaday lives.
 
Started in '87
 "People ride the ferry to punctuate the day," said Mr. Imperatore, a New Jersey trucking executive and real estate developer who formed the Port Imperial Ferry Bus in 1987, with ferry service connecting Weehawken and Hoboken to docks at Battery Park City and West 38th Street in Manhattan.
Mr. Imperatore, who has renamed his company NY Waterway, said the decision to expand was based largely on the success of his ferries running from Hoboken and Weehawken. The ferries carry 20,000 riders a day, compared with less than 1,000 a day in 1987, he said.
Even as his business was showing what ferries could do, a High Speed Ferry Task Force, formed in 1992 by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, has been negotiating with several New York State towns to set aside piers and docks, and reviewing proposals from ferry operators.
A group of American and Norwegian executives, the New York Fast Ferry Consortium, is planning to build ferries in a shipyard in Mammaroneck and provide service, beginning by the end of 1995, between the St. George Terminal on Staten Island and Pier 79, at West 39th Street in Manhattan. The group also plans service by 1996 between a dock at the foot of Wall Street and another in the Brooklyn Navy Yard.
Not all of the new routes envisioned by state officials have attracted operators. When the task force asked ferry companies last year for proposals to provide service between Manhattan and Tappen Beach Marine in Oyster Bay, no one bid for the job.
 
Heading Upstream
 But other routes being encouraged by the state have attracted operators, mainly Mr. Imperatore, who is planning additional service by the end of 1995 between West 38th Street and Nyack, Yonkers and Tarrytown, and the Sandy Hook recreational area of New Jersey.
Although New York City and other municipalities in the region have readily offered to turn over derelict piers and docks for the use of the ferry operators, disputes in some places may delay new routes.
Along the Hudson River waterfront in Manhattan, plans for new ferry service have come into conflict with other plans by the city and state to remake the shoreline from 57th Street to Battery Park into a park and esplanade. At issue is whether ferry operators will be allowed to use Pier 79, just north of the pier that is already used as a ferry dock by Mr. Imperatore's company.
In Rockland County, Nyack, the Town of Haverstraw and the Village of Haverstraw are all vying to be the destination of ferries connecting them with Manhattan. Mr. Imperatore, who has already been selected by New York State to provide the service, says a dock at the foot of Main Street in Nyack would be best, but the New York State Thruway Authority, which has been designated to mediate between the competing towns, said no decision on the selection had been been.
But despite the disputes, experts said ferry service seems certain to expand.
One reason is the speed of the ferries already in use on the Hudson River and being planned for other routes. They cruise at 35 miles per hour, nearly double the speed of the Staten Island Ferry.
And if the popularity of Mr. Imperatore's boats now plying the Hudson is a reliable gauge, customers are willing to pay for the luxury of ferry service. His company charges $4.50, one way, for service from New Jersey to midtown Manhattan, a price that also entitles customers to the use of shuttle buses that the company operates in Manhattan. By contrast, PATH trains to Manhattan from New Jersey charge $1 per rider.

HEADLINE: Health Debate Splinters After Initial Consensus

SERIES: The Basics of Care: A periodic report on national health issues.

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 12

 BODY:
"Too high premiums and not enough health care." That was how a clerk in Fargo, N.D., answered last month when asked what was the nation's biggest health care problem.
Her reply was a singular moment of clarity in the current debate. 
 In contrast, the arguments on Capitol Hill have concentrated on detail, process and politics, frequently cast in incomprehensible jargon as legislators and lobbyists compare hard-to-explain parts of President Clinton's plan with elements of competing proposals that no one, except perhaps their sponsors, understands.
The clangor has left the public confused and, recent polls show, perhaps even less knowledgeable than it was a few months ago.
The problems Congress is trying to solve are often drowned out in the din. But the main points are as the Fargo clerk identified them: cost and coverage.
Except among some very conservative Republicans, there is a consensus that major gaps exist in the present system and that costs have produced a crisis. And as Congress returned today from its Easter recess, there is widespread agreement with the message that Hillary Rodham Clinton carries everywhere these days: "Maintaining the status quo cannot be an acceptable alternative."
 
Identifying the Problem
 Agreeing on problems is a first step toward fixing them. But what comes next is a giant step, because a solution to one problem can make the next one worse.
The politicians' reluctance to tell constituents that there is no free lunch is reciprocated; the public has not descended on Capitol Hill to say what it wants to sacrifice.
For the Fargo clerk, who would give only her first name, and hundreds of others interviewed in a recent New York Times Poll, the connection between cost and coverage is clear: cost means the higher and higher insurance premiums they have to pay.
But it is a different side to the cost problem that is forcing Congress to grapple with this vast, complicated issue: health care has become the monster that eats Federal budgets, forcing up deficits and starving other initiatives.
Coverage is largely a function of insurance. About 38 million Americans have no health insurance. After years of steadily increasing private insurance coverage, in the late 80's more Americans started losing insurance than were signing up. Rising costs were the main reason. Millions of other Americans found themselves with only bare-bones coverage. People without insurance do get medical care, but it is worse than the insured receive, although many uninsured are young and healthy.
 
Other Constituencies' Desires
 Beyond these two biggest problems are a swarm of other issues, each crucial to someone. There have to be more medical personnel in rural areas if the promise of health insurance is to mean more than possession of a plastic card. But there also may be a need to produce fewer specialists.
Doctors think that if change is coming this must be the moment to change the malpractice lawsuit system. The elderly argue say now is the time to provide prescription drug coverage under Medicare, and at least a start on benefits for long term care.
The difficulty is that all these issues, especially in combination, lead some lawmakers to despair and ask if it would not be enough to deal with just a few of the issues, the ones people agree on, like restraining the most grating practices of the insurance industry.
But the dominant view is the one offered recently by John Rother, legislative director of the American Association of Retired Persons: "You can't solve only one or two without making the others worse."
 
Costs
Rising Rates Across the Board
 About 14 percent of the United States' gross domestic product is spent on health care. That is a greater share than any other country spends, and it could reach 19 percent or 20 percent by the end of the century.
To most people, the issue of cost is more personal: soaring bills. Many employers never tell workers how much the company pays on their behalf, but benefits have been cut back and employees' payments have been steadily increasing. The Health Insurance Association of America says the cost of family coverage under an average group insurance plan went to $436 a month in 1992 from $235 in 1988, an average annual increase of 17 percent.
For people who have to buy individual insurance, the increase has been even steeper, "20 percent or a little bit more than that" a year, says Cecil Bykerk, chief actuary for the nation's major individual insurer, Mutual of Omaha. Their premiums are vastly higher, too, because high administrative costs and a lack of bargaining power mean that only about $55 out of every $100 in premiums goes to pay claims. In large group plans, as much as $90 may go to claims, meaning the insurance company charges less for the same benefits.
Those difficulties might not have seized the attention of Congress and the Administration if the Government did not face sharply rising bills, too.
Federal health spending for care for the elderly under Medicare and for the very poor under Medicaid went to $200 billion in 1992 from $128 billion in 1988. That is a smaller rate of increase than in group policy costs and was accomplished partly by medical providers' shifting costs onto patients for whom the Government does not pay. Nonetheless, it is still much more than the Government can manage in an era when it is beginning to take the Federal deficit seriously.
 
States Spending More
 States are no better off. The National Association of State Budget Officers contends that states' spending for their share of Medicaid went up 22 percent in 1991 and 33 percent in 1992. Steven D. Gold, director of the Center for the Study of the States at the State University of New York at Albany, argues that those figures are exaggerated and that the real increase is around 17 percent in each year, but that even so, Medicaid is the fastest-growing component of state budgets.
In 1994, Mr. Gold said, the 50 states together "are spending more for Medicaid than for higher education."
Why are costs going up?
Dick Davidson, president of the American Hospital Association, argues that the answer is this: "We pay for medical care on a piecework basis. There's an incentive for more medical encounters."
Dr. Philip R. Lee, Assistant Secretary for Health in the Department of Health and Human Services, says a surplus of specialists causes more spending than necessary.
In medicine, an excess supply of services does not drive prices down; instead, it seems to drive demand up. "When a physician goes into practice," Dr. Lee said, "you generate more costs, ordering lab tests, doing X-rays, in some cases doing procedures."
 
Access to Care
How to Help The Uninsured
 Health insurance is not the same as appropriate care, but it is the first step. The 38-million figure used by President Clinton for the number of uninsured is just a momentary snapshot, because people go on and off insurance rolls, especially as they get jobs or lose them. Diane Rowland, senior vice president of the Kaiser Family Foundation and a leading student of health statistics, says she believes that about 50 million Americans lack insurance at one time or another in the course of a year.
Conservative Republicans often argue that too much is made of the number of uninsured people, because Medicaid is available to the poor, or at least the very poor. And that belief exists, says Mr. Davidson, the hospital association president, because hospitals have boasted they treat anyone who comes in, regardless of whether they can pay for it. While the boast is accurate for life-threatening circumstances like emergency appendectomies, Mr. Davidson says, it is not for postponable treatments like hip replacements.
Indeed, a book on the problem, "Falling Through the Safety Net," to be published next month by the Johns Hopkins University Press, concludes that being uninsured "has a substantial effect on the amount, location and even quality of care received."
The authors, Joel S. Weissman, who teaches health policy at the Harvard Medical School, and Dr. Arnold M. Epstein, a domestic policy adviser at the White House, say the insured have less primary care and less preventive care. "People who lack insurance delay care," they write, "and there is evidence to suggest that they come into the hospital more severely ill. They may also be hospitalized more frequently for conditions that could have been treated on an ambulatory basis."
In addition, the authors say, "there is also emerging evidence that the quality of their care may be compromised."
 
Other Issues
Cutting Specialists, And Lawsuits, Too
 Though there is wide agreement that controlling costs and broadening access are the goals of overhauling health care, the list of serious problems does not stop there.
One problem is the question of whether the United States has the right number, in the right mix, of primary care doctors, specialists, nurses and physician assistants. There is a consensus that the nation produces too many specialists, though there is also fierce disagreement on how to slow the increase.
Linda Aiken, a professor of nursing and sociology at the University of Pennsylvania, argues that the nation ought to be using twice its current total of 35,000 nurse practitioners and ought to ease the restrictions many states place on what those practitioners can do, such as prescribing drugs. The nurse practitioners do provide basic care both in places where there are no doctors and in place of more expensive physicians in health maintenance organizations and other forms of collaborative medical practice.
But there is also a widespread sense that more personnel alone will not solve the problem of access, either in rural areas or urban slums. Dr. Lee, the assistant secretary, says that in the slums in particular it is far-fetched to expect many doctors to open up practices because "the environment is just too difficult." But he says the problems are least severe in areas served by networks like the one established by Montefiore Hospital in the South Bronx. Similarly, a rural network of clinics, nurses, hospitals and doctors has minimized the personnel shortages in the open spaces of the Dakotas.
Few health care problems evoke such widespread complaint as insurance practices. Insurance companies have an endless variety of rates and policies.
Mr. Bykerk, the Mutual of Omaha actuary, says that only 1 percent to 2 percent of the public is "uninsurable," meaning that they have "such a bad health condition that under today's conditions a typical insurance company would not insure them under any circumstances."
But many millions more have health conditions that either mean much higher rates or exclude that a particular problem from insurance coverage. People usually have to be insured anew when they change jobs, and many fear that they will not be approved. If a person loses his job, his insurance is usually lost, too. Small companies that provide insurance can find that one worker's sick child can cause their rates to soar or for them to be told that unless that worker is excluded, the insurance will not be renewed.
 
Malpractice Litigation
 The result is a worried nation. Thirty percent of the public, in the Times poll last month, said they were "very concerned" that in the next five years they would lose their insurance.
Insurance companies today, unlike the Blue Cross agencies that really began hospitalization insurance in the 1930's, look for good risks and charge people differently. Even the Health Insurance Association of America does not defend these practices and would be willing to see them barred, so long as the rates of good risks could be raised to pay for coverage of poor risks.
A less clearly defined issue is malpractice litigation. Doctors and most Republicans regard it as a very serious burden, not only because some plaintiffs win immense verdicts but also because the threat of being sued forces wasteful habits on doctors who overtreat in self-defense. In some fields, particularly obstetrics, soaring insurance rates have driven doctors out of business.
Counterpressures, from lawyers' organizations and genuine skeptics about the medical industry's commitment to policing its own quality, have stalled past efforts to change the laws on malpractice. That skepticism persists. "I'd like to see the A.M.A. reduce their fees in return for malpractice reform, " said Mr. Rother, who has often battled the American Medical Association on behalf of retired people.
Doctors and hospitals alike contend that antitrust laws scare them out of getting together and agreeing on ways to eliminate expensive duplications. (Mr. Davidson says that as far as hospitals are concerned, the Clinton Administration is easing the antitrust fear by spelling out the rules in advance.)
 
Covering Prescription Drugs
 Only organizations representing the elderly have made an issue out of prescription drug coverage. Still, there seems to be widespread agreement that a change in medicine since Medicare was enacted in 1965 away from hospitalization and towards greater use of prescription drugs supports the demand for adding a prescription drug benefit to Medicare now, though the expense is scary.
While the elderly annually spend about three times as much on prescription drugs as do other Americans, nearly two-fifths of them have no insurance to cover it. So Mr. Rother and his group's members, who vote heavily, see coverage as the bottom line.
"If you don't have coverage for prescription drugs for my people," Mr. Rother said, "it's like not having health care."
Then there are other, widely acknowledged problems in the health care system, ones that affect its spirit and that none of the overhaul proposals seem to combat. One is paperwork. Eighty-two percent of the adults in that Times poll said there was too much paperwork in health care today.
A related problem is the tone of modern medicine for its practitioners. The steadily growing private efforts to cut costs require continual checking with insurance companies, and doctors do not like it, saying it denies them the dignity they expected when they picked their profession.
As Dr. James S. Todd, executive vice president of the A.M.A., said, "They have to call 1-800-CONTROLL before they can do anything."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 20, 1994, Wednesday

An article on April 13 about health care, under the label "The Basics of Care: A Periodic Report on National Health Issues," referred incorrectly to people who have less primary and preventive care than those who are insured. They are the uninsured.

HEADLINE: Real Estate

BYLINE: By Kathleen Sharp 

DATELINE: OXNARD, Calif.

 BODY:
A COASTAL area of Southern California that embraces Oxnard has gained a substantial number of office tenants as a result of the Jan. 17 earthquake in Northridge, 30 miles to the east.
In the first quarter of this year, about 100 companies left their earthquake-damaged buildings in Los Angeles County and have leased space here in southern Ventura County, William Kiefer, an associate with Grubb & Ellis, a real estate company, said. 
 Most of these leases appear to be short term, brokers said.
The area, about 60 miles northwest of Los Angeles, also includes the towns of Camarillo, Thousand Oaks and Newbury Park. Quake-related relocations have accelerated the region's economic growth.
The area has a total inventory of 23.5 million square feet in office and industrial space. Leasing for the first quarter totaled 750,000 square feet, said Rick Heath, industry property specialist for Grubb & Ellis in Oxnard.
"Normally, it would take us a year to do that kind of business," Mr. Heath said. "The market has changed dramatically in the last 60 days."
Camarillo has an inventory of 8.8 million square feet of industrial and office space, accounting for most of the commercial real estate in the area. Oxnard has 8 million square feet, Newbury Park has 4.5 million square feet and Thousand Oaks has about 2 million square feet.
At the end of the year, the occupancy rate for Oxnard was 21 percent and Camarillo's rate was about 9 percent. At the end of the first quarter this year, Oxnard's rate dropped to 17 percent, while Camarillo's fell to about 7 percent, according to Grubb & Ellis's figures.
To assist the many small and midsized companies that had to move quickly after the earthquake, a group of 20 business people here formed an organization called Partners in Action. Spearheaded by the Ventura County Economic Association, it found temporary sites for about a dozen companies until their former buildings could be repaired.
Within a few weeks, the group helped lease 600,000 square feet of space in southern Ventura County.
Packard Bell, for example, moved its operations to Camarillo from Chatsworth in Los Angeles County.
In one two-year deal, the computer giant leased 160,000 square feet of space in Westlake Village, Mr. Heath said. In another, it leased 125,000 square feet in Camarillo from Daytron Transco.
"At first, we thought many of these deals would be short term," said Michael Slater, a Grubb & Ellis broker. "But in many cases, we ended up doing five-year deals." He forecasts that many of the new commercial residents will remain in the region.
With a population of 150,000, Oxnard is known primarily as an agricultural town. Named in 1898 after a sugar-beet farming family, Oxnard borders the only deepwater port between Los Angeles and San Francisco -- Port Hueneme (pronounced WHY-nee-me) -- and has a Naval Construction Battalion Center, a small airport, a major thoroughfare in Highway 101 and housing less expensive than Los Angeles County's.
In the late 1980's, the city rezoned about 1,600 acres from agricultural to industrial use, Mr. Heath said. Speculators developed a few business parks, like the Northfield Industrial Center, owned by Vista Properties of Texas, and many commercial buildings. A large volume of commercial space became available as Southern California's recession arrived, and much of the new space had sat vacant.
About a third of the current leases are unrelated to the quake relocations. In one lease, for example, GTE California, a telephone carrier based in Thousand Oaks about 20 miles away, announced that it would consolidate its customer operations spread throughout Southern California, moving into a 115,000-square-foot building in Oxnard by September. The company leased a building from the Chevron Oil Company, which built it in 1990 for $15 million but never moved in. GTE will employ 650 people.
De Weese Inc. is also moving to Oxnard, said John Weingarten, its president. Five years ago, the swimsuit manufacturing company sold its 78,000 square-foot building in downtown Los Angeles, and leased back the space. Two years ago, it decided to look for a permanent home outside of Los Angeles.
"We weren't enjoying living downtown," Mr. Weingarten said.
The company now leases 7,000 square feet in the older industrial part of Oxnard from Deardorff Jackson. By August 1995, the company intends to occupy a total of 65,000 square feet.

HEADLINE: States' Eagerness to Experiment On Welfare Jars Administration

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
California is fingerprinting people on welfare. Massachusetts wants to enroll them in a work program within two months. New Hampshire wants to straighten their teeth, on the theory that better looks will lead to better jobs.
With a record 15 million Americans on welfare, more than 30 states have asked the Federal Government for waivers allowing them to run welfare experiments. The requests have prompted an unusual debate: do the programs represent responsible social science or a backdoor war on the poor? 
 The states say the experiments allow them to act, in Justice Louis D. Brandeis's famous phrase, as "laboratories of democracy." They say the programs, which are being evaluated by social scientists, may yield important information about ways to reduce welfare dependency.
But opponents have sued to stop the experiments in California and New Jersey, and they are threatening to do the same in Wisconsin and several other states. They say that some of the programs violate laws governing experiments on humans and, by reducing aid, subvert the fundamental purpose of the welfare system: to provide a safety net for poor children.
The proposals put the Clinton Administration in a politically awkward position. Several of the requests have alarmed officials at the Department of Health and Human Services, who have privately voiced fear that some of the experiments could leave poor families with no support.
But as a former governor who long argued for flexibility in Federal programs, President Clinton has vowed to approve experiments, even when he disagrees with them. And with the public clamoring for changes in the welfare system, the Administration does not want to be accused of standing in the way.
"We try to focus completely on the policy, but we are not unaware of the political consequences," said Mary Jo Bane, an Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services, who presides over the waiver proposals. "It's a balancing act, but I'm quite confident that we've achieved a good balance."
Mark Greenberg, a lawyer for the Center for Law and Social Policy, a Washington advocacy group, estimates that the experiments already in place affect about a third of the nation's welfare recipients. They vary widely, and many have generated no objections. New York and at least 13 other states, for instance, are allowing welfare recipients to earn more money without losing benefits, to encourage them to work.
But other states are trying strategies that reduce, or even end, cash assistance in some circumstances. Maryland, for instance, is reducing the payments to mothers who fail to have their children immunized. Ohio and Wisconsin are reducing payments to families whose children skip school.
 
Limits on Payments
 Arkansas, Georgia and New Jersey won approval to eliminate increased payments to mothers who have additional children. Florida and Wisconsin are experimenting with different versions of a two-year limit on cash payments. And California has reduced benefits for all recipients, calling the move an experiment that will prompt more people to work.
Critics argue that behind the talk of experiments, states are dismantling a system set up to protect poor children. "It has become a backdoor way of a state to enact any policy it wants, regardless of the potential harm to families," Mr. Greenberg said.
Lawsuits in California and New Jersey contend that the programs violate Federal regulations that bar human experiments without informed consent. Jay Katz, a Yale psychiatrist who is a specialist in human experimentation, filed a supporting affidavit in California that called "informed consent a basic tenet of research ethics." The suit was rejected in Federal court and is being appealed.
Michael Wiseman, a professor of public affairs at the University of Wisconsin, raises a different set of objections, arguing that the flurry of activity is producing flawed research.
Contending that the experiments sometimes test too much at once, he notes a Colorado program that not only establishes time limits, but also substitutes cash for food stamps, penalizes parents who do not get their children immunized and allows families to own more expensive cars. Whatever the result, Mr. Wiseman said, it will be hard to know which policy was responsible.
A previous generation of welfare experiments, begun in the early 1980's, produced valuable research about job training and led to adoption of a nationwide program. But the current proposals are far more radical.
They began with President George Bush, who, facing a re-election campaign with virtually no welfare policy, found one through waivers. He pledged in his 1992 State of the Union speech to make the waiver process "easier and quicker," and approved a flurry of experiments, including one that a Federal court later found unlawful.
That waiver gave California permission to offer reduced benefits to welfare recipients who move in from other states. A Federal court blocked the move, citing precedents that barred such residency requirements.
 
Negotiating With States
 In defending the Clinton policy to give the states great leeway, Ms. Bane emphasized that she would not grant waivers for experiments she considered unconstitutional. She barred, for instance, an Illinois proposal that would have lowered benefits to new state residents.
She also negotiated with Florida and Wisconsin to modify their experiments placing a two-year limit on cash assistance.
Florida, for instance, initially proposed a two-county experiment that would have simply ended cash assistance after two years, with no guarantee that recipients could find work. "There might not have been anything for people, even if they worked hard and followed the rules," Ms. Bane said.
Instead, she persuaded state officials to guarantee a job for all the welfare recipients affected by the two-year limit. Jim Towey, the state's Secretary of Health and Rehabilitative Services, credits Ms. Bane for devising a program with better safeguards.
"We are very happy campers," Mr. Towey said. "They took our raw material and polished it, and they did it with amazing speed."
Ms. Bane reached a different accommodation with Wisconsin. Participants in the two-county experiment there will not be guaranteed a job when their two years end, even if they cannot find one on their own. But Ms. Bane did insist on a clause that gives the Federal Government permission to suspend the experiment if the local economy is too weak.
Advocates have called that scant protection, saying many welfare recipients cannot find jobs even when the labor market is good. But while she clearly does not relish the Wisconsin idea, Ms. Bane defends her solution. "I'm actually pretty proud of our record over the last six months," she said.
 
Welfare and Fertility
 Among the most criticized waivers are those that deny increased payments to mothers who have additional children while on welfare. The Bush Administration approved a New Jersey program that applies the provisions statewide. Ms. Bane then approved a statewide experiment in Georgia and a program in Arkansas that operates in all but 10 counties.
Critics say there is no evidence the policy will deter childbirth and among the scholars they cite is Ms. Bane herself, a former Harvard professor. In a study published 10 years ago, she concluded there was "no real evidence supporting the proposition that welfare and fertility among young women are linked."
Mr. Greenberg argues that duplicating the experiment around the country needlessly exposes additional families to potential harm. A New Jersey mother who has a second child must now get by on $322 a month, for instance, rather than the $424 she would have received in earlier years. The $102 cut could force families to go hungry or lose their homes, he said.
Ms. Bane acknowledged that she probably would not have suggested such experiments, since she doubts their effectiveness. But when much of the public believe a policy should be tested, she said, "it is appropriate for us to be responsive." She also said it mades sense to test the idea in several states at once, to see if results can be replicated.
The Bush Administration approved the fingerprint plan in California. The Clinton Administration has still not ruled on the two-month limit in Massachusetts, or the dental plan in New Hampshire. It has, however, continued a Bush waiver that gave California permission to cut benefits to $607 a month for a family of three, from $633.
In calling the benefit reduction an experiment, California officials argued the policy would encourage more adults to work. But Amy Albright, a spokeswoman for the California Department of Social Services, acknowledged that the state had a fiscal agenda in addition to its research interests.
Noting the cuts save $140 million a year, she said, "California is in a position where it needs to achieve substantial budget savings."

HEADLINE: '81 Tobacco Study Discussed Raising Levels of Nicotine

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
A 1981 study by two tobacco company researchers discussed techniques for raising or lowering the amount of nicotine in cigarettes, a Congressman who is a strong opponent of the tobacco industry disclosed today.
The Congressman, Representative Henry A. Waxman, a California Democrat who is chairman of a House subcommittee on health and the environment, said at a news conference that the study was evidence that the tobacco companies had lied about whether they manipulated the amount of nicotine in cigarettes. 
 The Food and Drug Administration has been investigating whether the tobacco companies manipulated nicotine to make sure that smokers stay addicted. The agency has said it has the authority to regulate cigarettes as drugs and will consider doing so if its suspicion can be demonstrated. A senior official at the agency said the article showed "the industry in its own words talking about setting the levels of nicotine."
The tobacco industry has denied the contention, and one company, Philip Morris, has filed a suit against ABC accusing the network of libel for making a similar accusation.
Today, the leading tobacco companies broke decades of silence about the additives put in cigarettes made in America. They released a list of 599 such ingredients and additives, from acetic acid to yeast. Not all the chemicals are used in all brands, and most are added in tiny amounts for flavoring.
The companies said they had not released the list before out of concern that their secret formulas might be compromised.
But a report last week on National Public Radio said that 13 of the ingredients in the list might be hazardous because they are not in the Federal Government's list of approved additives. The six largest tobacco companies jointly released the list, not saying which company uses which ingredients.
Company spokesmen said almost all the additives were commonly used in foods and beverages, including cocoa, vanilla and licorice. Others were agents like glycerin, which is used to keep the tobacco moist.
In releasing the 1981 study, Representative Waxman accused the chief operating officer of Lorillard Inc., Alexander W. Spears, of deceiving Congress in testimony last week. Mr. Spears was the co-author of the 1981 paper. Asked if he was accusing Mr. Spears of perjury, Mr Waxman said he was not "because that is a legal determination, but it is a criminal offense to try to mislead Congress."
 
Dispute About Study
 Dr. Spears said in a written statement today that Mr. Waxman "made a serious error in reasoning" in reading the 1981 article. The article, written by Mr. Spears and S. T. Jones, who also worked for Lorillard, was presented to the 35th Tobacco Chemists' Research Conference in 1981. The paper points out that low-tar cigarettes using special blends of tobacco could keep the level of nicotine up while tar was reduced.
"Higher nicotine levels can be achieved by decreasing Oriental, and the stem and tobacco sheet, and increasing the Burley and upper stalk positions of both the Flue-cured and the Burley tobacco," the article said. As a result, the paper said, "current research is directed toward increasing the nicotine levels while maintaining or marginally reducing the tar deliveries."
Appearing before Mr. Waxman's committee on March 25, Mr. Spears said: "We do not set nicotine levels for particular brands of cigarettes. Nicotine levels follow the tar level."
In his statement today, Dr. Spears said the amount of nicotine in ultra-low-tar cigarettes was lower than the nicotine in regular cigarettes. But his statement did not dispute that tobacco companies used tobacco blends with higher levels of nicotine when they make low-tar cigarettes. As a result, the low-tar brands are nearer the regular brands than they would be if high-nicotine blends were not used.
Several scientists who once worked for leading cigarette companies supported Mr. Waxman's reading of the report, saying that cigarette makers routinely adjust the levels of nicotine and other substances during the maufacturing process.
Vedpal S. Malik, a biochemist who worked in the Philip Morris research laboratory in Richmond for more than 11 years, said he and other Philip Morris scientists had developed methods to remove nicotine and other chemicals believed to be harmful. But he said the company did not encourage additional research.
"A safer cigarette can still be made. But they don't want that," Dr. Malik said in an interview. "They don't want the projects to succeed."
Lawyers for Philip Morris contended that Dr. Malik's experiments were inconclusive and that his accusations were motivated by anger over his low performance ratings and his dismissal in 1992, which they said came as part of a companywide staff reduction. They also said the research he initiated, including an attempt to produce a nicotine-free tobacco plant, was continuing.
 
Approved in Foods
 On the matter of the 599 ingredients, David Fishel, an executive of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, said the ingredients were virtually all approved by the F.D.A. for use in food.
Mr. Fishel said the companies submitted the list of ingredients to food scientists at a number of universities last month and received a report back saying the ingredients were not hazardous in cigarettes.
Scott Ballin, chairman of the Coalition on Smoking or Health, which is an alliance of the American Lung Association, the American Heart Association and the American Cancer Society, said today that whether the ingredients were approved for use in foods was not relevant because the ingredients in cigarettes are inhaled, not eaten.
Victor Zonana, a spokesman for the Department of Health and Human Services, said that releasing the list of ingredients was a smoke screen. "We know that the two main ingredients in cigarettes are tobacco, which kills, and nicotine, which addicts," he said. Every year, 419,000 people die from cigarettes and the cost to the economy is $68 billion dollars a year, he added. "Those are the relevant facts."

HEADLINE: Tokyo Stocks Soar as Hata Moves Ahead

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, April 14

 BODY:
The Tokyo stock market soared Wednesday amid rising expectations that Foreign Minister Tsutomu Hata will be selected as Japan's next Prime Minister. The market's performance reflected investors' hopes that Mr. Hata, a moderate conservative, can stabilize the country's fractured political order and help pull the economy out of recession.
Share prices bobbed nervously throughout the day today because of the political uncertainty but generally held their gains. 
 Parliament is not expected to vote until early next week, but opposition to Mr. Hata has begun to die down, along with the squabbling that has wracked the governing coalition since Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa announced on Friday that he intended to resign.
Mr. Hata, 58, does not have Mr. Hosokawa's oratorical skills or sense of mission, and he has not yet won the support of all the political leaders and factions that he needs to wrap up the election.
 
Pragmatism Welcomed
 Nevertheless, Mr. Hata's knack for getting things done and his experience in the back rooms of Parliament, where legislative battles here are settled, were welcomed by a country seemingly eager for pragmatism over flair. In addition, he appears likely to hold the ruling coalition together, forestalling at least for now a more sweeping and tumultuous reorganization of the political order.
The 225-stock Nikkei index rocketed up Wednesday by 412.08 points, or 2.1 percent, and closed the day at 20,060.41. At the close today, the market was down 73.21 points, or 0.36 percent, to 19,987.20. The market is now back to its level of three weeks ago, when nasty political infighting and a personal financial scandal began to push Mr. Hosokawa out of office.
"The market breathed a sigh of relief," said Kathy Matsui, stock market strategist for Goldman, Sachs & Company. "The political question mark has been set aside. And as far as the market is concerned, any step toward the right politically is a good thing."
Hirohiko Okumura, chief economist at the Nomura Research Institute, reflected what appears to be a certainty among many analysts that Mr. Hata will be installed.
"The choice of Hata means there won't be an election for a new parliament right away, which is what many people were afraid of," he said. "We'll probably have a little better direction for the economy."
If chosen for the job, Mr. Hata's first order of business is expected to be enactment of a long-delayed budget for the fiscal year that began April 1. That budget includes big increases in public works spending and a tax reduction to stimulate the economy.
He is also seen as likely to develop an economic deregulation program in an effort to mend Japan's tattered trade relations with the United States. These goals hearten most Japanese, even though Mr. Hosokawa made little progress with them.
"Mr. Hata is a very pragmatic person," Satsuki Eda, a member of the coalition and the current head of the Science and Technology Agency, said in an interview.
 
'Probably the Best Person'
 "He is a pure politician," Mr. Eda said. "That may be regarded by some people as old-fashioned, and he is typically Japanese in that he doesn't say things clearly and so on. But he's quite good at managing things. As for United States-Japan relations, be's probably the best person in this situation."
Mr. Eda, who heads a small party, added, "Mr. Hosokawa paved a very rough road. That means Mr. Hata will be able to push forward a little more easily."
Of course, no one expects instant solutions to the country's deep economic and political maladies, just greater effectivness than Mr. Hosokawa displayed. And Mr. Hata's innate conservatism suggests he would not work for bold or dramatic changes, as Mr. Hosokawa had.
The first problem is the coalition, an odd combination of Socialists and conservatives who defected last year from the Liberal Democratic Party. Bitter personal feuds almost split the party after Mr. Hosokawa said he was quitting last Friday because of financial scandals.
It is unlikely that, even if most coalition members throw their support behind Mr. Hata, the deep differences will heal quickly. Thus, any difficult issue that comes up, particularly the sensitive question of how far Japan would be willing to go to halt North Korea's suspected nuclear weapons program, could provoke a return of the paralyzing divisions.
In addition, Mr. Hata would have only until July, when the Group of Seven industrialized nations summit takes place in Naples, to come up with a satisfactory program of deregulation and market opening measures to cut Japan's trade surpluses.
Mr. Hata has never proven himself overly pliant in the hands of American trade negotiators. Indeed, he is the one who argued several years ago that Japan could not import American beef because it did not suit the unique Japanese digestive system.
But he generally favors strong relations with Washington and has demonstrated before his ability to come up with compromise agreements.

HEADLINE: Suit Over Police Beating Goes to Los Angeles Jury

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 13

 BODY:
The nation's most scrutinized police beating -- 81 seconds of violence followed by a lifetime of disability -- is worth $15 million to its victim, Rodney G. King, his lawyer said today as arguments concluded in Mr. King's civil suit against the City of Los Angeles.
The case went to the jury this afternoon after three weeks of testimony that minutely examined Mr. King's injuries and their effects, as well as the audio part of the amateur videotape of Mr. King's beating by Los Angeles police officers. 
 The city has already conceded liability in the beating, so the job of the racially mixed jury of seven women and three men will be to determine the amount of damages that would compensate Mr. King for his physical and emotional injuries.
Deputy City Attorney Don Vincent proposed a range of damages from $500,000 to $1 million, suggesting $800,000 as a fair figure. Before the trial, Mr. King had rejected the city's offer of $1.25 million plus lawyer's fees and had demanded $9.5 million.
 
Next Phase of Trial
 Once the jury makes its determination, a second phase of the civil trial will assess the liability and possible damages against 15 current and former police officers whom Mr. King is also suing.
The jury that is deliberating now is the third to ponder the meaning of the videotape, which shocked television viewers after the March 3, 1991, beating that followed a lengthy high-speed chase. Four white police officers were acquitted of assault in a state trial in April 1992, and the verdicts touched off rioting that took more than 50 lives.
In a Federal trial last year, two of the officers, Stacey C. Koon and Laurence M. Powell, were convicted of violating Mr. King's civil rights. They are serving 30-month terms in a Federal prison.
In the civil suit, more than in either previous trial, race has become a central issue, with Mr. King, who is black, insisting more confidently than in the past that he was taunted with racial slurs during the beating.
"He's a decent man that has become a symbol of a wrong to a people," said Mr. King's lawyer, Milton Grimes. "This is a race case. I don't know how you can separate the Rodney King incident from black people, from African-American people, from how we feel."
On this third judicial examination of the videotape, it was the audio part that played a major role, with witnesses and jurors straining to determine whether they could hear racial epithets amid the din of the beating and the roar of a police helicopter.
 
Analyzing Blurry Sounds
 George Papcun, an audio expert who has analyzed the blurry sounds, testified that he could hear the command, "Nigger, hands behind your back."
Mr. King testified that he had heard officers shout at him, "We're going to kill you, nigger. Run!" During the Federal trial he said he recalled similar words, but under cross-examination he said he was uncertain of his memory.
Mr. Grimes urged the jurors today: "Close your eyes and listen to the tape. You can't close your eyes and pretend that 'nigger' wasn't said on March 3, 1991, because you don't want to hear it."
The defense has countered that the tape is unclear and that the racial slurs exist only in some listeners' imaginations. David Love, the only black officer among nearly two dozen at the scene, testified that he had not heard racial epithets. "Me being African-American, it would have offended me very much," Officer Love said.
In any case, Mr. Vincent argued today, the presence or absence of racial epithets is not central to the civil suit. "If it was said, it was said at a time of passion, a time of battle," he said.
Mr. Vincent said that neither Mr. King nor his mother, Odessa King, had told the truth on the witness stand. Mrs. King had testified that her son told her about racial slurs in the first days after the beating. But another witness disputed her account.
When Mr. Vincent referred to that witness, Mrs. King cried out from among the spectators, "He lied!" Judge John G. Davies of Federal District Court ejected her from the courtroom. As she left, she turned to the judge and said, "Sir, begging your pardon, but he certainly lied."
Most of the 38 witnesses in the trial, which began on March 23, testified to the nature and extent of Mr. King's injuries as well as his character and life style. An expert testifying for Mr. King estimated that his lost potential lifetime earnings totaled $1 million, while an expert for the city set his estimate at half that sum. Mr. King was unemployed at the time of the beating.
Experts also disputed a major ambiguity of the videotape: whether the injuries to Mr. King's face were caused by a blow to the head or by a fall.
One twist on this issue came from Officer Theodore J. Briseno, one of the two officers acquitted in both state and Federal trials. In the civil suit, in which he will be a defendant during the second phase, he changed his testimony to assert that Mr. King had not been struck in the head.
His previous testimony about blows to the head had contributed to the convictions of two fellow officers. But he said that his study of an enhanced videotape had since convinced him that he had been wrong.
 
Dispute Over Injuries
 The causes of Mr. King's injuries were in dispute, but his long-term physical and emotional difficulties seemed clear. An oral surgeon, Dr. Howard Ravins, described Mr. King's pain, jaw displacement and cracked teeth, and said he drooled, had trouble chewing and often bit his cheek, which has lost its feeling.
A neurosurgeon, Dr. Dilworth Thomas Rogers, said Mr. King had complained of nightmares, fatigue and depression, and wore a bulletproof vest to his medical consultation, complaining of a fear of being attacked.
In its defense, the city sought to portray Mr. King as a violent man who drinks heavily and has had numerous run-ins with the law both before and since the beating. But even the circumstances of an earlier conviction for armed robbery were argued, with the victim, a shop owner, saying that Mr. King had attacked him with a metal bar, and Mr. King insisting that he had only thrown pies at him.

HEADLINE: Consumer Spending Eases a Bit; Prices Rise 0.3%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
Despite an early Easter, consumers spent carefully in March, Commerce Department figures showed today, strengthening a general belief that economic growth has slowed significantly this year from the unsustainable pace that prevailed in late 1993.
The rise of four-tenths of a percent in retail sales last month, to $182.26 billion, meant that sales in March were slightly lower than those of December, after adjusting for inflation. 
 "One-third of the economy treaded water in the first quarter," Irwin L. Kellner, the chief economist for Chemical Bank, said.
Separately, the Government reported that prices paid by consumers for all manner of goods and services climbed three-tenths of a percent for a second straight month. Inflation in medical care, for which prices rose two-tenths of a percent, was the lowest since 1984.
Taken together, the two sets of figures implied moderating growth of the economy and steady inflation, a combination that would usually be considered reassuring by the securities markets. But today, bonds rallied briefly on the retail sales results, which were somewhat weaker than predicted, then reversed course and finished sharply lower, dragging the stock market along.
Although there is still scant evidence of accelerated inflation, the Federal Reserve is not waiting for conclusive proof of such an outbreak and has raised short-term interest rates twice since early February.
Many analysts predict further Fed increases to push real rates -- that is, those adjusted for inflation -- firmly into positive territory after a long period during which they were essentially zero. Yet judging from the latest soundings, the economy has already slowed significantly from the unsustainable 7 percent rate of growth it posted in the final three months of last year.
"One would be hard-pressed to call today's report 'bad,' " said Laurence H. Meyer & Associates, a consulting firm in St. Louis, referring to the retail sales figures. Yet "it does go hand in hand with the notion that the surge in fourth-quarter consumer spending, which was anchored by auto sales, is beginning to wane, and the momentum is slowly eroding."
Various Federal Reserve officials now doubt consumers' ability, whatever their optimism, to increase spending in light of high debt, lagging wages, record low savings, poor liquidity and tax increases.
"I believe that the household sector poses one of the most serious risks to the continuation of this recovery," Lawrence B. Lindsey, one of five sitting Fed governors, told a Baltimore audience last month.
 
 
Decline in Nondurable Goods
 Indeed, sales of nondurable goods, about 60 percent of retail sales, showed a tiny decline that rounded to no change for March. There were gains of 1.9 percent for drugstores and variety stores, three-tenths of a percent for clothing stores and two-tenths of a percent for stores selling general merchandise. But these were offset by declines of eight-tenths of a percent at food stores, of five-tenths of a percent at gasoline stations and of two-tenths of a percent at restaurants and bars.
Sales of durable goods rose 1.1 percent, paced by a 4.1 percent surge for building materials -- a rebound from a comparable drop in February, which was attributed to severe weather. Receipts rose nine-tenths of a percent at stores selling furniture and other equipment for the home, and automobile dealers took in five-tenths of a percent more. But in both cases the gains were much smaller than in February.
The department made slight upward revisions in overall retail sales -- which are adjusted for seasonal, holiday and trading-day differences, but not for price changes -- for both January and February. Last month's sales were 8.9 percent higher than those of March 1993.
The inflation report, which was about as predicted, showed consumer prices rose three-tenths of a percent both for the total index and for the so-called core rate of inflation, which excludes the erratic food and energy components.
For a second straight month, a main contributor was higher-than-usual increases for the heavily weighted housing component, which climbed three-tenths of a percent. Homeowners' and renters' costs each rose four-tenths of 1 percent, partly offset by small declines for furniture and for maintenance and repairs.
 
 
Higher Food Prices
 Food prices edged up a tenth of a percent after two straight declines; beef climbed eight-tenths of a percent, the biggest rise in nearly a year. Apparel prices, which fell earlier in the year because of a slower-than-usual introduction of spring and summer merchandise, rose four-tenths of a percent.
Higher airline fares and increases for both new and used cars helped push transportation costs up six-tenths of a percent. But inflation in medical care eased to two-tenths of a percent as prices for drugs and medical supplies remained unchanged.
"There remains no pickup in inflation," Joseph Baggett, an economist at Paine Webber Inc., said.
Services, which account for about 56 percent of the index, rose four-tenths of a percent for the second straight month. Commodities, 46 percent of the index, rose two-tenths of a percent.
Among five major metropolitan areas, prices in New York rose at the same three-tenths of 1 percent pace as they did nationally, with Chicago, San Francisco and Philadelphia registering a bit more and Los Angeles a bit less.
The March reading of 147.2 for the Consumer Price Index means that an assortment of goods and services that cost $10 in the 1982-84 base period now costs $14.72, up 47.2 percent.

HEADLINE: It's Showdown Time for Globex

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 13

 BODY:
It is showdown time at Globex, the world's first international, round-the-clock electronic marketplace for futures and options traders.
The partnership agreement under which Reuters P.L.C., the British news and market information company, has developed the computer-based network for the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the world's two largest futures exchanges, is certain to be officially dissolved in two weeks. And the Board of Trade may decide as early as tomorrow whether to pull its contracts off the two-year-old system, which has 342 computer terminals, mostly in Europe and America. 
 A thumbs down from the Board of Trade would hurt the reputation of Globex more than its performance; trading in the board's contracts has accounted for a scant 5 percent of activity on the electronic network recently. Still, losing the Board of Trade's contracts, which include some of the world's most heavily traded futures contracts, would raise doubts about Globex's prospects at a time when it needs to overcome a track record pocked with technological setbacks, management gridlock and unforeseen market developments. The world of finance is undeniably becoming more global and electronic but not in a straightforward way.
 
Expectations Exceeded Reality
 "The expectations were out of sync with reality," said John F. Sandner, who is chairman of the Merc and chief executive of the Globex Corporation, the joint venture with the Board of Trade that oversees Globex. The new governing system, with or without the Board of Trade, will allow other exchanges like Marche a Terme International de France, or Matif, the French exchange that is Globex's biggest customer, to share in control of Globex and give all parties more freedom to make rules affecting their members and products.
"The appetite for 24-hour markets isn't really there yet," said Patrick H. Arbor, the Board of Trade's chairman. He favors staying put, but he has had trouble convincing his exchange to support changes demanded by Reuters, the Merc and Matif. Board of Trade members say they fear the changes could shift trading from their pits to Globex's screens and undermine the Board of Trade's freedom to develop other alliances.
Globex's founding premise seemed unassailable when the system made its debut with champagne and fanfare nearly two years ago: traders needed a way to deal anytime, anywhere in widely held investment products like the Board of Trade's futures and options on Treasury securities or the Merc's futures on foreign currencies and Standard and Poor's 500 stock index.
Futures are contracts to buy or sell an underlying asset, like the stocks in the S.& P. index, for a set price at a given date. Options are the right, but not the obligation, to strike such a deal. Demand for futures and options does not disappear just because an exchange that is their primary marketplace closes.
Early this month, for instance, following the Government's release on Good Friday of stronger-than-expected employment figures, investors, expecting stocks to drop sharply when trading resumed on Monday, turned to Globex in record numbers on Easter to sell S.& P. 500 futures contracts.
 
Contracts Used to Hedge Risks
 Such contracts are speculative tools for many investors, but they also serve to hedge risks in international commerce. Multinational businesses, for example, protect themselves from currency shifts when they are buying and selling goods overseas, or they may guard against interest rate swings on loans.
One unanswered question is whether off-hours demand is strong enough to attract sufficient numbers of traders to Globex in the absence of such rare events as trading on Easter. Without a reasonably strong and steady trading activity, someone who buys or sells a contract has a harder time finding an offsetting position if prices take a nasty turn and losses mount. To compensate for the added risk of thin trading, or illiquid markets, would-be buyers tend to demand lower prices and sellers higher ones, thus widening the so-called spread.
As that disparity between asking prices and bids widens, it becomes harder to complete trades. Unless Globex volume picks up, the system now seen as an investment in the future will come to be regarded as a financial sinkhole for Reuters, the trading houses that subscribe to it and the sponsoring exchanges.
 
An Experiment in Progress
 "It's an experiment that's still in progress," said Merton Miller, a professor at the University of Chicago School of Business and a member of the Merc's board of directors. "I'm not sure yet whether the market niche is there."
The Chicago exchanges originally saw Globex as a way to enhance international interest in their contracts. They also hoped it would head off efforts by exchanges in Europe and Asia to introduce competing products and stem the move by banks and other institutions to steer more of their futures and options trading to unregulated, over-the-counter transactions. They figured other exchanges would flock to Globex, willing to accept Chicago's governance and ban on competing contracts in return for the right to add the rest of their products to Globex's screens.
Reuters foresaw a lucrative new market for its trading technology, which was already prominent in stock, bond and currency markets. It has plowed an estimated $100 million into adapting technology for Globex.
Hardly anything has turned out the way Reuters and the two Chicago exchanges planned. Globex's volume has been climbing, but even at the peak, just 124,123 contracts were traded on March 2. That total dwarfed the daily average of 45,827 for February, the best month to date, but still used less than 25 percent of the system's capacity, Paul Tattersall, Globex's managing director, said.
The biggest disappointment has been Globex's slow acceptance in Asia. Only a handful of the Globex terminals on trading desks worldwide are in Tokyo or Hong Kong, and none will reach Singapore before this summer. Globex backers say they have had a hard time reaching agreements with regulators and exchanges in Asia to distribute terminals. And Globex was started in 1992, just as Japanese investors, stung by recession, retreated from international markets. No Asian exchange has joined Globex yet.
 
Competition From Singapore
 Competition has also hurt. Futures contracts on Eurodollars -- dollar deposits held outside the United States -- are one of the Merc's major products, but, so far, Asian traders prefer to trade Singapore's version of Eurodollar futures in their pits to trading the Merc's contract on a Globex screen. With more than 30,000 Eurodollar contracts trading on an average day in Singapore, compared with fewer than 2,000 on Globex, Simex, as the Singapore exchange is known, offers traders far greater liquidity.
Globex has run into technological shortcomings as well. For instance, options have become bigger than Globex's designers expected. A sophisticated options trader may track relationships among several hundred products, far more than Globex's screens can conveniently display.
Globex technologists are currently scrambling to accommodate traders who rely on complicated mathematical programs that pinpoint trading opportunities and want to use computers to execute trades electronically the instant that conditions are ripe.
Some of the surprises have been positive. The biggest has been the surge in volume following the decision by Matif to join Globex a year ago and require all after-hours trading of its major French bond contract to move to the system. Matif routinely accounts for 80 percent to 90 percent of Globex's daily volume.
"I hope the Board of Trade stays on," Mr. Sander said, looking ahead to that exchange's board of directors meeting tomorrow. "But we're moving on either way."
