HEADLINE: House Panel Given a Lesson in Hedge Funds

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
George Soros, the global high-roller whose billion-dollar currency bets have moved markets from Tokyo to New York, came to Congress today to deliver a tutorial on hedge funds to lawmakers.
Members of the House Banking Committee seemed to alternate between awe at being schooled by the man with the Midas touch and immense curiosity about the secretive world of hedge funds -- the partnerships of wealthy investors that scour the globe for often-exotic investments in currencies, bonds and stocks. The mystique of the funds seems to have been burnished -- rather than tarnished -- by tales of the wide swings they experience, including Mr. Soros's loss of $600 million in one recent currency deal. 
 Today's hearing was brought about by a strong feeling on Capitol Hill that hedge funds have become increasingly important in influencing global markets -- and may even have touched off the recent sharp drops on Wall Street. But the funds are so complex that even the lawmakers responsible for overseeing banks that lend them money were not quite sure how they worked and whether they needed to be specially regulated.
The most frequently asked question today by the committee members was: "Just what is a hedge fund?"
After noting that "the term is applied so indiscriminately that it covers a wide range of activities," Mr. Soros said that "the only thing they have in common is that the managers are compensated on the basis of performance and not as a fixed percentage of assets under management."
This approach has its dangers, he said, because if a fund is losing money, the manager "has a financial inducement to increase the risk to get back into positive fee territory rather than to retrench as he ought to." He avoids this problem, he said, because his fund managers have their own money at risk in the funds they manage.
Mr. Soros was more than happy to explain this and more to the lawmakers, but he also bluntly rebutted criticisms that hedge funds like his $10 billion Quantum Group of Funds helped foster the recent free fall of the stock and bond markets.
"Frankly, I don't think hedge funds are a matter of concern to you or the regulators," said the Hungarian-born billionaire, who has been in the hedge fund business since the 1960's.
 
Some Regulators Agree
 In some ways, the Government regulators, who also appeared at the hearing called by the committee's chairman, Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas, agreed with Mr. Soros. The officials, led by the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Arthur Levitt Jr., assured the lawmakers that virtually all of the activities of hedge funds were already highly regulated under current banking and securities laws and that nothing new was required. This was also the view of John P. LaWare, the Federal Reserve governor who heads the Fed's committee on bank supervision.
But even the regulators said they wanted to know more about how the funds operated -- to make sure they were keeping pace with the risks and strategies in which these funds are engaged.
As a general rule, hedge funds pool money from groups of very large investors, who usually have to put up at least $1 million to participate. For every dollar that the hedge fund raises it might go to a bank and borrow $10 more, so a fund that begins with a pool of $100 million in equity may actually have $1 billion to play with in the market, thanks to its bank credit. This is called leveraging, and it greatly magnifies the economic clout of these funds.
The hedge funds then take their multibillion-dollar pools of money and make a bet. For instance, they might bet that over a certain period of time the Japanese yen is going to lose value against the dollar. So they enter into a futures contract in which they agree to sell yen at a certain set rate six months from today.
 
Bet Can Be Wrong
 If in six months the yen does fall in value, the fund can reap a huge profit. But if the bet is wrong, and the yen increases in value against the dollar, the fund can suffer a huge loss.
That is what happened last fall. Several huge hedge funds, including Mr. Soros's, bet that the Japanese yen was going to fall in value. They made that bet because they believed that President Clinton and Japan's former Prime Minister, Morihiro Hosokawa were going to reach a settlement of their trade dispute last February and that such a settlement would lead the American Government to let the yen fall. The American Government had previously been encouraging the yen to rise in value as a tactic to put pressure on Japan in the trade negotiations, because if the yen is rising it makes Japanese exports more expensive and harder to sell around the world.
But Mr. Soros bet wrong. The talks between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Hosokawa collapsed, and instead of the yen falling in value, it rose. Those losses were destabilizing because as banks demanded more collateral on the money they lent to the hedge funds -- a practice known as a "margin call" -- some of the hedge funds had to sell part of their holdings to raise the cash.
In this case, to cover their bad debt, many hedge fund dealers had to sell not only some of their Japanese securities but also some of their European positions. Hedge funds make dozens of simultaneous currency bets around the world, hoping that the winners will outnumber the losers. They are "hedging their bets," hence the name hedge funds.
 
Effect Felt in Europe
 But in this case, the forced selloffs by some dealers who had stocked up on yen caused a chain reaction on the other side of the world. Some other hedge fund dealers, who were not involved in Japan at all, had been betting that German and other European interest rates were going to fall, since the high unemployment there required these European governments to stimulate their economies. So they had stocked up on European bonds, assuming that as European interest rates went down the value of their European bonds would go up.
But when the hedge funds that lost money on the yen started selling some of their European bonds, it drove down the price of bonds all across Europe as well. This forced bond issuers in Europe to effectively raise their interest rates to keep attracting buyers.
That surprise move caught more hedge fund investors. Many of them had nothing to do with speculating in Japan but had been making what they saw as a sound fundamental long-term bet that trends in European economies were toward lower interest rates. Nevertheless, they, too, then had to sell some of their European bonds to cover their own margin calls. This, in turn, caused a rush to the door all at once that ravaged European bond markets and caused even worse losses for some hedge fund dealers.
Mr. Soros said he was not opposed to sharing certain information about his operations with Government regulators -- after the fact -- in order for the Government to understand more clearly why a market might have moved the way it did.
 
Sees a Danger
 But Mr. Soros said that sharing information with the Government while he was trading could not only hurt him financially, but be dangerous. If word got out about what bets he was making on certain bonds or currencies, it could lead to a stampede of copy-cat trades that might be enormously destabilizing.
"I strongly agree that regulators should gather sufficient data to be able to supervise markets," Mr. Soros said. "However, I suggest that such disclosure to regulators should not be made public. Such a disclosure could have a tendency to encourage trend-following investment. This could lead to greater market volatility."
The 63-year-old Mr. Soros generally tried to calm Congressional fears about hedge funds, saying: "I should like to emphasize that I see no imminent danger of a market crash or meltdown. We have just punctured a bit of a bubble that has developed in asset prices."
Mr. Soros said that if there were to be any new Government regulation of hedge funds it should be focused on leveraging.
"We do use borrowed money and we could cause trouble if we failed to meet a margin call," he said. But, he added, "If regulations are to be introduced, they ought to apply to all market participants equally."
Mr. Soros said it would be wrong to single out hedge funds when many investment banks, like Bankers Trust or Goldman, Sachs & Company, engage in the same sort of speculative trading for their own accounts as hedge funds do.
 
Derivatives Are Criticized
 He pointed a finger at mutual funds, and those who trade in financial instruments known as derivatives -- investments that are linked to interest rates, currency rates, stock prices and commodity prices -- as the real culprits in the market instabilities. He said they magnified market volatility by engaging in "trend-following behavior" -- buying in response to a rise in prices, which would tend to push prices even higher, or selling in response to a drop in prices, which would tend to push prices still lower, reinforcing whatever trend is dominant in the market.
Eugene A. Ludwig, the Comptroller of the Currency, told Mr. Gonzalez's committee that in his view, hedge funds do not pose a significant risk to the nation's banking system. Mr. Ludwig said that only eight national banks and nine national banking companies have a total of only $1.04 billion in credit exposure through loans or lines of credit to the funds. "Our examiners report that those banks are adequately controlling those risks," Mr. Ludwig said.
Nevertheless, he added, no one should ignore the potential the hedge funds have for destabilizing the markets when they make the wrong investment. The combination of their leveraged positions, complex trading strategies and instantaneous, 24-hour, global trading networks "has increased the rate at which shocks spread throughout the financial system," he said.

HEADLINE: Dow Off 20.22 as Low Volume Continues

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
In the fourth straight session of unusually low trading volume, the stock market fell sharply yesterday, with many technology issues declining for the second consecutive day.
Stock traders got all the economic news that they wished for, but still refused to believe that inflation is in check and economic growth is moderate. 
 The outlook on inflation, interest rates and the level of corporate earnings are three factors that move markets. But traders yesterday managed to interpret positive signs in all three areas as reasons not to buy stocks.
Perhaps the only clear and convincing evidence for the stock and bond markets would be several months of low inflation readings. Such a process would mean the markets would not rally until well into the late spring or summer, some analysts say.
 
A Bright Spot for Traders
 If there was one bright spot for traders in yesterday's session, it was the restrained trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange of 279.4 million shares, or some 7 percent below that of a typical day.
Traders continued to sit on their hands, despite a fall by the Dow Jones industrial average of more than 50 points in afternoon trading. The 50.27-point fall led to special "circuit breaker" rules designed to slow high-speed computerized trading and thus reduce market volatility.
"Low volume is what you want to see in a corrective process," said David D. Holt, vice president, research and strategy for Wedbush Morgan Securities in Los Angeles. "It means there isn't a mass exodus out of stocks, which is what you would see in a 400-million-or-500-million-share day."
Richard E. Meyer, head of equity trading at Ladenburg, Thalmann Inc., said: "The guys who wanted to sell a lot have already sold. And the guys who wanted to buy don't want to buy until the dust settles."
For the record, yesterday's Consumer Price Index, the nation's most closely watched gauge of inflation, registered a small three-tenths of 1 percent increase and was within analysts' expectations, much like Tuesday's favorable two-tenths of 1 percent increase in the Producer Price Index. Modest inflation ought to influence the Federal Reserve Board to defer or moderate interest-rate increases.
And while some technology stocks, like Motorola, reported lower than expected first-quarter earnings during the week, the great majority reported profits that were within or exceeded Wall Street analysts' expectations.
But it was to no avail. The Dow industrials fell 20.22 points, to 3,661.47 and the broader Standard & Poor's 500 fell 1.31 points, to 446.26. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index, where many technology stocks are concentrated, fell 11.84 points, to 727.38.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.89 point, to 247.46, with declining stocks outnumbering advancers by 1,505 to 696. The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 1.74 points, to 437.95.

HEADLINE: 2 Railroads See Steep Increases in Ridership

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
During one of the worst winters in memory, the Metro-North Commuter Railroad and the Long Island Rail Road recorded steep increases in ridership in the first quarter of 1994, the railroads said yesterday.
Ticket sales rose 7.8 percent for Metro-North and 5.8 percent for the Long Island Rail Road, compared with the same period last year. 
 Officials of both railroads said the bad weather probably forced many commuters out of their cars. But they also attributed the increase in ridership to an improving economy and the railroads' own marketing efforts.
Dan Brucker, a spokesman for Metro-North, said higher ticket sales represented the payoff for a marketing campaign that included television and radio commercials and visits to suburban office parks. "This is the Good Ship Lollipop coming in for a landing," he said.
 
Seeing New Customers
 Metro-North sold an additional 349,000 tickets in the first quarter, out of 4,849,600 tickets.
The strongest category was "intermediate 10-trip tickets," which means a 10-trip pass good between two stations, neither of which is Grand Central Terminal. Those sales were up 13.6 percent, or almost 1,100 tickets. One-way, full-fare tickets were up 9.4 percent, or 175,100.
Monthly ticket sales, which have been flat for eight years, jumped 4.4 percent in the first quarter.
Arguing that Metro-North has won over new customers, Mr. Brucker said that storms generally force drivers onto the trains for a day or two at a time, but usually do not prompt them to buy monthly tickets.
He said that some riders may have been introduced to the trains by the weather, and stayed.
"Now they see the system, and see that it works well, and they like it," he said. "We think we're going to keep a number of them. How many we just don't know."
 
Off-Peak Hour Growth
 For the Long Island Rail Road, ticket sales were up 293,000, out of a total 5,350,000. The strongest increase was during off-peak hours. The number of rush-hour passengers boarding in Queens also grew.
The L.I.R.R. attributed the growth, in part, to better on-time performance, despite one storm this year that shut the line down completely. The on-time figure for 1993 was 92.9 percent, the railroad said.
"While the weather for the first two months of this year had a severe effect on the railroad and the region's transportation network," the railroad said, "on-time performance for the month of March 1994 was 91.1 percent, consistent with prewinter levels."
George F. Raed, director of marketing research at the L.I.R.R., said the economy was better, the number of off-peak trips was growing and the railroad looked more attractive than previously to people in eastern Queens. His department is conducting surveys to determine why.
The growth in off-peak travel may have come from increased part-time employment in New York City in service-sector jobs, he said.
 
Car Travel Down
 But some of the gain obviously came from weather, and was at the expense of car travel. The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority said that toll collections on its nine bridges were down 11.4 percent in January and February. (March numbers are not available yet.)
Traffic on the Henry Hudson, which connects Manhattan and the Bronx, was off 20 percent in January and 14.6 percent in February; the Triboro, which connects Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens, was down 12.3 percent in January and 9 percent in February, said a spokesman, Frank Pascual.
Mr. Pascual said that the bridges usually carry 750,000 vehicles a day. "We lost 75,000 vehicles just like that," he said.
The two railroads and the bridge and tunnel authority all have the same governmental parent, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
At New Jersey Transit, a spokeswoman, Penny Bassett Hackett, said that figures for January and February, the only two months of this year that have been compiled, would not be representative. But for the period between July 1, 1993, and the end of February, she said, total bus and train ridership was up 5.5 percent over the same period a year earlier.
The reason, she said, is an improving economy, good on-time performance, clean vehicles, heavy advertising and no fare increase or service cuts in the last three and a half years.

HEADLINE: Bigger Than Expected Budget Surplus Sets Off Fiscal Debate

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 13

 BODY:
Setting off renewed fighting over how much money the state can spend this year, the New York State Comptroller's office released a report today showing that the state finished the fiscal year that ended March 31 with a surplus of $1.5 billion.
The report also rekindled a debate over the strength of the state's economic recovery, and could further delay final agreement on the budget, now set at $33 billion, which is already 13 days late. 
 The report shows that the state's revenues were up 6.2 percent from the previous year, with business tax revenues growing by 9.2 percent and personal income tax revenues up by 5.5 percent. Some of the surplus was also the result of lower than anticipated spending by state agencies.
 
Room for a Tax Cut?
 The Republicans who control the State Senate said the numbers show that the economic recovery is robust and bolster their contention that business taxes can be cut without creating long-term problems for the state.
"The tax base is solid and growing at a rate that should encourage consideration of further tax reductions," said Senate Majority Leader Ralph J. Marino, an Oyster Bay Republican.
But Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, and aides to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said the report only reflects the previous fiscal year's cash surplus and can't be used to make rosy predictions for the coming year. Mr. Silver has warned that the Senate tax-cut proposal could cause budget deficits in future years.
The Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, echoed their concerns. "The Legislature and Governor should not see this surplus as an opportunity to start a spending frenzy," he said.
 
More Money to Spend?
 Mr. Cuomo and the legislative leaders also could not agree on whether the report showed that they now have more money to spend than they anticipated on April 1 when they reached agreement on the outlines of a $33 billion budget, when a surplus of more than $1 billion was already anticipated.
Mr. Cuomo said the report shows there is no additional money. Mr. Silver said it shows $100 million in additional revenue; aides to Mr. Marino put the number at between $100 million and $200 million.
All agreed that the additional revenue, if any, is a relatively small amount in a $33 billion budget.
"Even if there were more money than they expected, they should hold it for next year," Mr. Cuomo said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls on Speculation Fed Won't Raise Rates Soon

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most major currencies yesterday after Government reports indicating mild inflation prompted speculation that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates soon.
Currency traders sold dollars after the Commerce Department reported that domestic retail sales rose a modest four-tenths of 1 percent in March, while the Labor Department reported consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in March, in line with analysts' forecasts. 
 The reports suggest the Fed has less incentive to raise rates to head off rising inflation that usually accompanies economic expansion, traders said. Higher rates would make dollar-denominated deposits more attractive.
 
No Action by Fed Expected
 "The dollar got crushed after the economic numbers," said Tim Cunningham, a trader at American Express Bank.
Karl Halligan, a trader at ING Capital Markets, said, "Judging from these numbers, it looks like the Fed won't be doing anything with rates for the rest of this quarter."
The dollar was quoted late in the day at 1.7100 marks, down from 1.7161 marks on Tuesday. Meanwhile, gold for delivery in June slipped 40 cents, to $380.00 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Silver for delivery in May rose 1 cent, to $5.315 an ounce.
Speculation that the Bundesbank would lower German interest rates kept the dollar from falling further against the mark, traders said.
Many expect the German central bank to lower rates to revive the country's slumping economy. The Bundesbank last cut interest rates on Feb. 17, when it lowered the discount rate to 5.25 percent from 5.75 percent. The discount rate is the lowest rate banks pay to borrow from the Bundesbank.
"No one is going to sell the dollar aggressively before a Bundesbank meeting," Mr. Halligan at ING said.
 
Canadian Dollar Rises
 The dollar fell to 103.40 yen from 103.70 yen yesterday.
Elsewhere, the Canadian dollar rose against the United States dollar for a second day amid signs that the Canadian Government would further curb its deficit spending. Prime Minister Jean Chretien said yesterday that his Liberal Government will announce more budget cuts in the "millions of dollars" soon.
The Canadian dollar rose to 72.73 United States cents yesterday, from 72.58 cents in New York late Tuesday. The currency fell to a seven-year low of 71.48 United States cents on Monday.
Meantime, the British pound was little changed at $1.4765. The dollar fell to 5.8505 French francs from 5.8686 francs and weakened to 1.4405 Swiss francs from 1.4451 francs. The dollar fell to 1,630 Italian lire from 1,634 lire.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Compaq Computer wins respect in a volatile industry.

BYLINE: By Steve Lohr 

 BODY:
WITH investors suddenly skittish about technology stocks, a personal computer company whose share price has more than doubled in eight months would look ripe for a fall. And the Compaq Computer Corporation's stock has retreated from its 52-week high of $105.625 reached last Friday to $98.25, down $2.625, yesterday.
Yet analysts are surprisingly optimistic about the prospects for Compaq over the next year, an eternity in the personal computer industry, where corporate fortunes can reverse overnight. Analysts, including Lucianne Painter of Salomon Brothers and David Wu of S. G. Warburg, say Compaq's share price may well reach $120 or so over the next 6 to 12 months. 
 The consensus estimate for Compaq's first-quarter earnings, which will be reported next week , is $1.70 a share, up 38 percent from the comparable 1993 quarter, according to the First Call Corporation. For 1994 as a whole, profits are expected to be up more than 30 percent.
The reason for the upbeat prognosis is that more than any other company, Compaq has streamlined and retooled its business model, selling profitably to every slice of the competitive PC market. "Compaq has the position everybody else would like to have," said Philippe de Marcillac, director for personal computer research at Dataquest Inc.
Compaq's profit margins have held steady over the last five quarters. In the fourth quarter, for example, Compaq's operating margin -- profits as a percentage of revenue before taxes and interest expenses -- was 10.3 percent. By contrast, Apple's operating margin was 2.6 percent, AST's 4.6 percent and Dell's 3.7 percent.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Houston-based Compaq has been able to maintain a respectable profit margin, in spite of an aggressive drive to increase its market share. In 1993, its share of the worldwide personal computer market was 8.5 percent, more than double its 3.5 percent two years earlier, the International Data Corporation estimates. This year, analysts predict Compaq's sales will grow at twice the industry's rate, allowing it to surpass Apple Computer as the second-largest company in the industry, trailing only I.B.M. and closing the gap.
"What's so impressive about Compaq is that it has not yet had to sacrifice profits to increase market share," said Eric Lewis, the manager of personal computer hardware research for International Data.
Analysts point to an expected new-product announcement next week as an example of Compaq's present strength. The company will introduce new top-of-the-line models intended for business customers, called the Deskpro XL line. The move, in some ways, is similar to other manufacturers' upgrades to offer systems that use Intel's high-speed 486 and Pentium chips.
But with its research and design resources, analysts say, Compaq has overhauled everything from chip sets to exterior casings in the new line. And, they add, the company is pricing the lower-end new machines $500 or more below the models of comparable performance that they replace.
"That will intensify competition in the premium lines of personal computers and narrow the price gap between premium and midrange lines," said Mr. Lewis of International Data.
But looking out the next six months or year, there are still questions about Compaq's ability to keep up the current momentum. It will not be easy in an industry where new-product generations are measured in months, not years. Analysts have one lingering concern about the target set last year by Eckhard Pfeiffer, Compaq's chairman: become the biggest personal computer company by 1996. That is an ambitious goal; Compaq finished last year with an 8.5 percent share, compared with 11.6 percent for I.B.M.
Chasing the market-share target, analysts warn, could undermine Compaq's profits, and thus the stock price. Still, there is little evidence of that to date. "Compaq is firing on all cylinders, and the outlook is for continued strength," said Todd Bakar, an analyst for Hambrecht & Quist Inc.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
China's approach seems a winner, but the test isn't over.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
IS "shock therapy" necessary, or even useful, for curing what ails the failed socialist economies?
Boris N. Yeltsin's Russia, until recently advised by Western economists and institutions identified with the get-it-done-yesterday school of reform, has yet to take off. Meanwhile, China, which took the seemingly conservative route of grafting a free market economy onto the established planned economy, has, in the words of the economist Stanley Fischer enjoyed "the greatest increase in economic well-being within a 15-year period in all of history." 
 But before declaring the gradualists to be the winners in this great economic debate, it makes sense to look closely at whether China's success has much to say about Russia's failure. And probably the most serious effort to do just that will be published in the next issue of the European-based journal Economic Policy.
Jeffrey Sachs of Harvard and Wing Thye Woo of the University of California at Davis argue that China began with what the economic historian Alexander Gershchenkron dubbed the "advantages of backwardness." And they even speculate that the Chinese (who have yet to reach the living standards of Russians) will soon face the contradictions of their piecemeal reform.
Since economic growth means a bigger pie, everyone could be made better off by increasing the size of every slice. But the process is hardly automatic. And at the heart of the resistance to every shift from central planning to decentralized free markets -- fast or slow -- is the valid fear that there will be big losers as well as big winners.
China, Professors Sachs and Woo argue, has been able to finesse this worry with a combination of luck and political skill. In the late 1970's, reform was tried in agriculture, which had been relentlessly exploited to sustain higher levels of consumption in the cities and to finance industrial investment. Farm productivity rose so rapidly in the first few years of privatization that rural income could increase sharply without reducing the surpluses creamed off for the cities. There were virtually no losers, and thus virtually no opposition.
By the same token, private industry grew without exacting a toll on the state-owned industrial dinosaurs. The labor fueling the spectacular rise of export-oriented light industry along the south coast of China came from the vast surplus in rural areas. And much of the capital came from abroad.
Indeed, the two economists suggest, not only was there no inherent conflict between the prosperous new economy and the stagnant old one, there were also major synergies. The new demand for labor relieved some of the social pressure on rural China, which no longer had a commune system to guarantee subsistence for families that added little or nothing to output. And domestic production of higher-quality goods embodying Western technology reduced production costs for state-owned heavy industry.
What's more, prosperity in the south substantially increased the demand for currency and bank deposits, allowing Beijing to print money to keep hemorrhaging state enterprises alive without creating uncontainable inflation. This bonus from what economists call "seigniorage" is no small thing: Professors Sachs and Woo put it at about 8 percent of national income.
Contrast China's serendipitous flexibility with Russia's rigidity. Russian agriculture is heavily subsidized, so there is little prospect of short-term gain for farmers who forsake the womb of the collective. State-owned industry, construction and transport employ 52 percent of the Russian population, compared with just 19 percent in China. So the burden of keeping the inefficient state sector alive and fully manned is far greater.
Or, to put it another way: The Chinese were down so long that it all looked like up to them. Russians, with fewer prospects for rapid productivity change and much more to lose by abandoning the job-based social safety net, are trapped by their relatively high state of economic development and unrealistic short-term expectations.
Seen from this perspective, the comparison between Russia and China looks less like a test of rapid versus slow reform and more like an ironic historical joke. Russia, which for centuries has measured its success or failure by comparisons with the West, is far worse positioned to mimic Western economies.
Still, the most striking idea in the Sachs-Woo analysis is that China's prospects for no-losers growth may be running out. Beijing's ability to finance state enterprises without inflationary consequences turns on the improbable willingness of newly affluent Chinese to hold their wealth in cash rather than in tangible property. And the productivity gap between rural and urban dwellers is generating the capitalist revolution's first high-profile losers in the form of a vast migratory labor class.
The resulting social friction has yet to turn into political heat. But it may, the authors imply, unless the Government finds the will and way to reshuffle income now used to keep the peace in the state sector.

HEADLINE: Congress Loath to Finance GATT Treaty's Tariff Losses

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
After seven years of negotiations, a new global trade agreement will finally be signed Friday in Morocco. The treaty weighs 385 pounds and runs to more than 22,000 pages. It eliminates or freezes so many tariffs around the world that it is expected to stimulate some $5 trillion in new trade by the year 2005. There's a problem with it, though: It may not be ratified by the United States Congress anytime soon.
Why? No one can figure out how to pay for it. 
 The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT, involves the lowering of tariffs, which are taxes levied by governments on imports. Under the very tight pay-as-you-go budget rules in Congress, any reduction in a tax -- even one that as with the GATT agreement is expected to promote billions of dollars in new business and income tax revenue over the long run -- has to be compensated for either by a tax increase somewhere else or by spending cuts.
Since GATT is projected to cost $13.9 billion in tariff collections over the next five years, Congress and the White House are required by law to come up with an equal amount.
"We've had such a hard time trying to find the money that at one point I suggested to the Administration that maybe we could get it by raising some tariffs," said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee. "I will do my damnedest to resolve this problem, but we could genuinely end up with an embarrassment."
Everyone agrees that it is ludicrous that a multitrillion-dollar treaty should be imperiled for lack of $13.9 billion -- small change in Washington terms. But, as Senator Moynihan remarked, with the current air-tight spending limits, "We are not a very grown-up government in budgetary matters right now."
The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said his office had three independent studies that showed that in the next five years the Treasury would collect about $3 in revenue for every $1 lost in tariffs because of the GATT accord.
GATT, he said, "will contribute about a trillion dollars to our gross national product over 10 years -- that's the low end," adding, "So it's an enormous economic winner. But we can't count all that in the pay-go concept."
 
Fear of Voters
 With the budget already cut, and 1994 Congressional elections making lawmakers queasier than ever about any kind of tax increase for fear of raising voters' anger, no one knows how to get out of this budget box.
When some Clinton Administration officials broached the idea of Congress waiving the pay-as-you-go rule, it was quickly rebuffed by Republicans who do not want to give the Clinton team any precedents to use in financing health care or welfare reform. So it's back to the ledger.
"No one wants to look at something on either the spending side or the revenue side that is so controversial it undercuts the treaty getting passed," said Leon E. Panetta, director of the Office of Management and Budget. "It is my job to find a solution that doesn't cross that fine line."
Mr. Panetta said he is looking for a combination of spending cuts and fees that "are either innocuous or don't impact on major constituencies."
The latest idea floated by the White House is a royalty tax on some of the new transmission frequencies being granted to communications companies. But that has the communications industry up in arms.
The advantage that GATT has over the North American Free Trade Agreement, Mr. Panetta said, is that there is no "huge political controversy surrounding it, so the funding issue is not taking place in a heated emotional atmosphere."
 
No Shortage of Opponents
 Or is it? As the approval debate on the GATT agreement gets closer, opponents are coming out of the woodwork. For instance, Public Citizen, the consumer group founded by Ralph Nader, takes issue with the role of the newly created World Trade Organization, which will oversee GATT's operations and serve as a global referee to settle trade disputes.
Public Citizen argues that the new GATT agreement will shift decision-making over sensitive matters, such as what pesticides can be used in growing food or whether American environmental laws can protect dolphins from tuna fishermen, to a group of unelected, faceless trade bureaucrats in Geneva. This tension between the environmentalists and the GATT bureaucrats -- known as "Flipper vs. GATTzilla" -- has a certain resonance on Capitol Hill.
"The danger for Americans in GATT," said Lori Wallach, director of Public Citizen's trade section, "is that the World Trade Organization would find many U.S. health, safety and environmental laws to be illegal trade barriers, which the United States must eliminate or face sanctions. Congress must either see to it that a moratorium is put on the environmental and consumer-related parts of the World Trade Organization, or they must reject the GATT agreement. Most members have not focused on it, but when you show them the language, they say 'Holy cow!' "
 
Some Would Start Again
 Congressional Democrats make it clear that they want any GATT financing legislation to be bipartisan, so that they are not punished by voters for a tax increase while the Republicans get the credit for all the trade benefits GATT brings. But some Republicans say they do not want any credit; they want a different agreement.
In order to secure the GATT accord, the Clinton Administration agreed to demands, mostly from European nations, that they be allowed to subsidize basic and applied research of some prized high-tech industries, like the European aircraft consortium Airbus Industrie, which competes with American aircraft makers.
"For me, the big problem is this subsidies code," said Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, whose state is home to the McDonnell Douglas Corporation. "This agreement green-lights certain subsidies for research and development, and we are saying that is too big a loophole. Airbus and others can walk right through. It is too late to renegotiate the treaty, but we must reach side agreements with some key manufacturing countries that really tighten up this subsidies code."
Otherwise, Mr. Danforth said, other nations will subsidize their critical industries, and then "we have to decide whether we want to lose these industries or get into a subsidies war that involves budget problems and picking winners and losers."
"I think the arguments will be compelling either to fix this or defeat it," he added. "GATT's ratification is not a done deal."
 
Nothing's Perfect
 This sort of talk exercises Mr. Kantor. "No code that is going to be adopted internationally will ever outlaw all subsidies," he said. "The fact is, it was the production and development subsidies to Airbus that were the most pernicious, and most of those are now either greatly limited or outlawed by GATT. Only basic and applied research is now allowed, and do you know which country spends more on that than any other? The United States. No one is even close to us."
The programs that will be most protected, Mr. Kantor argued, are ones begun in the Reagan and Bush years, like Sematech, the semiconductor industry consortium that works to pool American resources to maintain dominance in the industry.
White House officials are convinced that at the end of the day, no Republican with Presidential aspirations, like the minority leader, Senator Bob Dole, will want to stand in the way of such a pro-business treaty as GATT.
Senator Moynihan said that Republican concerns about the subsidies issue could not be dismissed, but that they should not be a reason for rejecting the GATT agreement. Countries, he said, "don't get rich subsidizing their exports."

HEADLINE: Black Composers Of Classical Music: Striving for More

BYLINE: By EDWARD ROTHSTEIN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 9

 BODY:
"We are the invisible people in music," said Kevin Scott, a 37-year-old composer, echoing Ralph Ellison's phrase about the black man in society. He is part of a small but dedicated group, a minority within a minority: black musicians who compose for the concert hall.
In less formal venues, black Americans have been at the heart of musical life, the originators of ragtime, jazz, blues, gospel, soul, disco and hip-hop. But in the concert hall, black composers have been marginal. Their impact on the evolution of art music has been minimal. 
 For three days here last week, though, they were far from invisible, as 122 people -- composers, administrators, conductors, students and other interested parties -- gathered under auspices of the Detroit Symphony orchestra for a symposium on black American composers, the fifth annual event of its kind.
Beginning with a competition in which four compositions were played in an open orchestra rehearsal and then at the weekend's subscription concerts, the forum, sponsored by the Unisys Corporation, included detailed discussions of the works, along with career advice for black composers. There were also many conversations in which senior composers who have made careers against great odds traded insights with young, academically trained composers.
 
Relating Race and Music
 Composers usually assemble in groups according to shared stylistic interests. Here, the shared factor was race, and nearly everybody was examining what relationship race had to the music itself. This is precisely what administrators of the Detroit Symphony had in mind: it has turned itself into a laboratory for exploring issues of race and music.
During the last decade, the Detroit has been something of a pioneer in facing the problems that affect many American urban orchestras. Its troubles have in many ways reflected those of Detroit itself, which has gone from middle-class capital of the automobile industry to one of the country's most economically troubled cities. The symphony's white audience has moved to the suburbs and the overwhelmingly black population that remains has shown little interest in the orchestra's traditional activities.
During the 1980's, ticket income dropped, there were two strikes and, in 1989, the state legislature threatened to withhold funds unless the Detroit began to reflect the racial composition of its surrounding population. The demand was that a black musician be hired immediately, overturning the race- and sex-blind auditions that have become standard practice for American orchestras. The symphony acquiesced (to the shock of many in the music world). A black bass player, who was regularly filling in with the orchestra as a substitute, was hired, becoming the second black in the orchestra. But in 1991 the state, stricken by continuing economic problems, canceled $3.7 million in expected support anyway. This created a financial crisis, and each player accepted a cut in pay and benefits worth over $40,000.
 
A Daunting Challenge
 Against that backdrop, the Detroit's competition for black composers has become a small part of what is probably this country's most ambitious affirmative-action program to increase the involvement of black musicians, composers and listeners in the life of an urban orchestra. Not even 2 percent of symphonic musicians in the country are black, so the task is daunting. In fact, the Detroit has found no other qualified full-time black players since 1989.
But 12 of 66 members of the symphony's board are black. The associate conductor, Leslie B. Dunner, is black. All auditions, though they remain blind, must include a black applicant. There is a fellowship program in which young black performers essentially become apprentices, playing and studying with the orchestra; fellows are coached for auditions and are partially reimbursed for expenses even when trying out for other orchestras. In addition, the Detroit plays music of black composers in concert, and is making recordings of important black American compositions.
There is also a spirit of optimism among the players, despite the vast empty lots surrounding Orchestra Hall, where one is warned not to take a stroll. Some of it has to do with the success of Neeme Jarvi as music director; ticket sales have gone up at double-digit rates each year since he came in 1991, and the orchestra, with a budget of $17 million, finished last year with a surplus.
The Detroit's recording schedule has picked up; Mr. Jarvi will have recorded more than 30 CD's with the orchestra by 1996. And it has been invited to play at the Lucerne Festival in Switzerland next year. The Detroit is also one of the few orchestras still heard on radio; concerts are broadcast in 511 markets, including New York, and reach 975,000 listeners a week. (It is to play in Carnegie Hall on April 23).
 
A Larger Presence
 The affirmative-action programs have clearly contributed to the change in atmosphere. The Detroit's presence in the city's musical life has expanded. It recently played at the mayor's inaugural celebration and regularly plays at a national N.A.A.C.P fund-raising dinner here that attracts 10,000 people.
There is still no proof that an art can find devoted audiences simply on the basis of racial identification with its practitioners -- the racial composition of subscription-night concerts has not appreciably changed -- but legislators have become supporters of the orchestra, and corporations, courted by the orchestra's executive director, Mark Volpe, are becoming more involved. And people here like Nancy Malitz, a former music critic for The Detroit News who has reported on racial issues in the orchestra, sense a more favorable attitude toward the Detroit among the city's blacks.
Still, the symposium highlighted the complications of trying to increase the participation of a particular ethnic group in a particular artistic tradition. The fact is that although each of the four new compositions displayed musical gifts, none would probably have been singled out in a standard composing competition.
Donald E. Dillard's "Childhood Scenes," which won the competition, includes a narration in which the composer recalls piano lessons, baseball games and church services. Mr. Dillard, 53, an organist and choir master in the Philadelphia area, has a fine ear for orchestral color, but the music is singlemindedly and rather obviously pictorial.
Dolores White's "Celebration" is meant to recall the 1893 Chicago World's Fair, but Ms. White, who is an assistant professor of music at Cuyahoga Community College in Cleveland and "older than 50," as she put it, does not bind her occasionally spirited tonal riffs into a compelling narrative.
The most interest was in the works by the two youngest composers. Jonathan B. Holland, whose "Martha's Waltz" was inspired by "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf," is 20 and a student at the Curtis Institute of Music. His conservative piece, with its slightly awry, catchy waltz, has a verve and charm that made it a crowd pleaser.
Daniel Roumain's "Haitian Essay" -- a politically inspired evocation of Haiti's agonies -- was liked least by the judges, but it had large ambitions in its collage of violent musical effects, edgy dissonances, aleatoric noise and ruthless thrust. At 22, Mr. Roumain, a graduate student at the University of Michigan, tried for too much effect, but often did so with intelligence.
While the talents of such young composers will determine the future of black American concert music, the point of the symposium was not so much to discover major new works as to help a community take shape.
 
Trying to Define the Essence
 What makes music by a black composer black music? Alvin Singleton, 53, who delivered the keynote address, suggested in an interview that it was not the self-conscious invocation of black pop styles or jazz, but the life experience of the composer.
Some of the senior composers in attendance, like Hale Smith, who is 69, felt instead that there was an unbroken tradition. It might reach, perhaps, from such composers as Frank Johnson and Harry Lawrence Freeman, through William Grant Still and George Walker. Portia Maultsby, an ethnomusicologist at Indiana University, traced the evolution of popular black musical styles, arguing that black classical music shows similar influences.
The younger composers, like Mr. Roumain and Anthony Kelley, who won the competition last year, are actually trying to create a cross-fertilization among different genres. Mr. Roumain wants to write a "Rap Symphony," saying that there is a useful analogy to be made between rap and sprechstimme, the pitched, sliding speech used most famously by Schoenberg. The issues of self-definition kept recurring.
The symposium may mark a new stage in the evolution of this small but dedicated subculture, as Marsha Mabrey, the director of the symposium, pointed out in an interview. There was no anger this year, nor were there any accusations of tokenism like those made by Mr. Walker two years ago in a bitter lecture.
Antoinette Handy, who recently retired as director of the National Endowment for the Arts' music program, even told the participants: "Get off that bag that African-American composers do not have the opportunities of other composers. Racism exists. Of course it does. But options for African-American composers are no different from options of any other composers."
The challenges may also be similarly mundane: to be less invisible and more audible.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Anniversary Waltz

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Anniversaries of great occasions are news events that can be covered with care. Assignment editors, who rarely have the luxury of dealing with the expected, are rubbing their hands at 1994's summer of commemoration.
First: June 3, 1994, is the fifth anniversary of the bloody suppression of the peaceful demonstration in Beijing's Tiananmen Square. 
 A fitting way to mark this historic occasion is to reprise in every medium the indelible photograph of the lone man stopping the line of tanks.
The most suitable way for politicians to observe what the Chinese press delicately calls "the incident of June 3" is to accommodate the private wishes of the Chinese leaders regarding our threatened withdrawal of most-favored-nation trade status.
That surprising suggestion is based on the iconoclastic theory that Beijing is acting rationally in its recent human rights crackdown.
Inflation in China has soared to 26 percent per year. This loss of purchasing power is a source of growing anger among workers, threatening the ability of the jittery regime to avert turmoil after Deng Xiaoping dies.
How to stop rampant inflation? By slowing the economy, of course -- but that will increase unemployment. How does Beijing divert blame for austerity to foreign devils? With subtlety: by re-jailing the paramount dissident, Wei Jingsheng, thereby forcing President Clinton to suspend M.F.N.
Result: sharp reduction of Chinese exports to the U.S., which will close inefficient factories, raise productivity and curb inflation. Villains throughout the painful adjustment are the intrusive Americans and the destabilizing dissidents.
No Beijingologist has a better theory to explain why China is provoking Mr. Clinton to suspend M.F.N. If cutting off trade to spite inflation is its way of insuring both economic and political stability, we should accommodate China's desire to scuttle M.F.N. on the June 3 deadline date.
Three days later is the 50th anniversary of D-Day. American, British and other Allied forces stormed the Normandy beaches on June 6, 1944, and President Clinton will be there to remind Europeans of our recurrent repayments to Lafayette.
How best to celebrate this golden anniversary of General Eisenhower's "great crusade"? It cannot be a replay of the memorable, made-for-movies, misty-eyed spectacle at the 40th. Let Clinton be Clinton, whatever that means; realists hope it does not mean dishing out another mushy helping of last December's "partnership for peace" Pablum.
As circumstances change, so should policy. The President should use this forum to reject both regional isolationism and impotent multilateralism, and instead urge the inclusion of Eastern Europe and the Baltics into NATO's military alliance.
His return-to-Oxford speech should be more serious than sentimental, focusing on this generation's need to defeat incipient fascist or Communist movements, and on the Western democracies' responsibility to lead the inexorable march toward individual freedom.
And that's just June. The next month, on July 20, we observe the 25th anniversary of the most soul-stirring moment of the previous generation: the landing of a man on the moon.
That would be the proper moment for all the liberal deriders of "Star Wars" to take a new, nonideological look at the need for a global nuclear shield. Soon we may have to take out the plutonium plants of North Korea, thereby to prevent nuclear blackmail, which might well trigger conventional war; wouldn't the world be better off with a space-based defense against missiles that would remove the incentive in rogue states to build bombs?
Saving only one cityful of people is worth a few billion a year. To paraphrase a cliche of the past generation, if we can put a man on the moon, we should be able to put in place a defense that does not permit any unauthorized missile to get far off the ground.
Finally, the moon landing triggers the memory of another 25th anniversary, on July 19, of an accident that ended dreams of a political Restoration. But the loss of a young person's life at the Chappaquiddick bridge is best memorialized at a private service.

HEADLINE: The Federal Reserve Is Signaling A New Increase in Interest Rates

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 14

 BODY:
Federal Reserve officials say they see no signs of accelerating inflation, but the nation's central bank is signaling anew that it will raise short-term interest rates again anyway. The reason: the officials believe that low short-term rates have already encouraged too much lending, giving stimulus to an economy that no longer needs it.
The goal of the Federal Reserve, according to its papers, Congressional testimony and interviews over the last two weeks, is a so-called neutral policy rather than a stimulative one. But the Federal Reserve's definition of neutral is likely to feel like a tap on the brakes to most Americans, slowing growth as companies and individuals pay more interest on their loans and mortgages. 
 The Federal Reserve's stance means that investors, who have been trading in declining, turbulent markets the last month, may not be able to find comfort even if monthly inflation reports continue to show that current price increases are moderate, as was indicated by the data for March issued this week. Despite the positive numbers, the Federal Reserve will still be leaning toward pushing short-term interest rates higher.
The Federal Reserve's desire to slow growth slightly could also irritate the White House, which has signaled repeatedly that it sees no risk of inflation and little need for substantial increases in interest rates. The stock and bond markets fell sharply after both previous Federal Reserve increases, prompting President Clinton and other top Administration officials to reassure investors that the economy was healthy.
In an Op-Ed article in Friday's issue of The New York Times, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, who heads the President's Council of Economic Advisers, argues that inflation is in check and that "the financial markets appear to be reacting more to inflation myths than to realities." [Page A31.]
The Federal Reserve stimulates or reins in the economy by changing short-term interest rates, as it did with quarter-point increases in its target on Feb. 4 and March 22. At the time, financial markets interpreted the move as a sign that the Federal Reserve perceived incipient inflation that had somehow escaped private economists and investors.
To avoid roiling the financial markets, top Federal Reserve officials do not like to talk publicly about their plans for changing interest rates. Privately, they have let it be known that they do not see any immediate signs of accelerating inflation. But still they are signaling that they are uncomfortable with the current strong level of economic growth because it would eventually feed inflation.
Federal Reserve officials like to say that their old policy was accommodative to economic growth while the new policy is "neutral." Many people have interpreted this as meaning that the Federal Reserve is neither seeking to brake nor accelerate economic growth. But the truth now seems to be more subtle.
The Federal Reserve is really try-ing to make the economy grow at a rate that its officials consider neutral: the fastest rate possible without feeding inflation. The conviction of Federal Reserve officials is that a neutral rate of growth is equal to the growth rate of the economy's underlying capacity to produce goods and services. But such a policy implies some slowing of the economy.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, personally signaled the Fed's stance in a little-noticed remark during his last testimony before Congress on monetary policy. "We must move toward a posture of policy neutrality -- that is, a level of real short-term rates consistent with sustained economic growth at the economy's potential," he told a House Banking Committee panel on Feb. 22.
By most economists' estimates, the growth rate in the economy's underlying capacity, which depends mainly on productivity gains, is expanding nearly 3 percent a year. Most economists think the economy is growing faster than that now.
 
Consnensus on Growth
 Nobody knows for sure how fast the economy grew in the first quarter because the official figures will not be available until April 28. But the consensus estimate of prominent corporate economists is that the economy grew 3.3 percent in the first three months of the year. Lowering the growth rate to a "neutral" level below 3 percent will require higher short-term interest rates, Fed officials believe.
Economies with many unused factories and unemployed workers can temporarily grow faster than the rate of total productive capacity, by putting these factories and people to work. But once the economy is operating near full capacity and full employment, inflation begins to rise as companies bid up wages and prices for factory goods.
The main interest rate the Fed uses to influence the economy is the Federal funds rate -- the interest rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans. The Fed funds rate is currently pegged at 3.5 percent, after the two increases earlier this year, which were the first in five years. Officials refuse to say precisely how much higher the Federal funds target would have to be to bring down borrowing and spending so that the economy does not grow more than 3 percent. Private economists estimate that a Federal funds rate of more than 4 percent but less than 5 percent is needed for this to occur.
The timing of further interest rate increases has posed more of a problem for Fed officials than whether to raise rates at all. The main reason Fed officials are not raising rates more quickly right now is their worry that consumers are already financially strained and may cut back sharply on spending if rates continue to rise.
Forecasts of a Federal funds rate between 4 and 5 percent appear consistent with the reasoning of Fed officials. The Fed has paid extremely close attention in recent months to the amount by which the Federal funds rate exceeds the inflation rate. From 1955 to 1980 this gap averaged slightly less than a percentage point, and in the 1980's it tended to run several percentage points higher. Right now the difference is only half a percentage point. (The gap is used as an approximation of the real Federal funds rate, which is the amount by which the Federal funds rate exceeds investors' expectations of inflation).
Economists inside and outside the Fed have tried over the years to estimate the neutral level for this gap. The consensus is that the rate is higher than the historical average during economic recoveries and lower than the average during economic slowdowns. This suggests that the Fed will soon raise the Federal funds rate again and probably the discount rate as well, which is the rate at which the Fed itself makes short-term loans to banks.


GRAPHIC: Federal Reserve officials pay close attention to the gap between the Federal funds rate and inflation. The shrinking gap suggests to some economists that the Fed will rase short-term rates again, because a small or negative spread, if sustained during a recovery, eventually could produce inflation. The graph tracks the rate of inflation and the Federal funds rate since 1983. It also tracks the gap between the two over the same period. (Source: Lehman Brothers) (pg. D5)

HEADLINE: Leading Pickets, the Teamster Chief's Future May Also Be on the Line

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 14

 BODY:
Three years ago, Ron Carey, a bodyguard at his side, drove an old Chevrolet to teamster locals around the nation in a grass-roots campaign for the presidency of an institution that had became a national symbol of corruption and brass knuckles.
Mr. Carey, chief of a Queens local, barely won, with just under half the votes in a three-man race in which less than half the members voted. Mr. Carey is running hard again, this time to save face and win something big for a union that still does not quite accept him. 
 He is leading 70,000 teamsters in a strike against Trucking Management Inc., a consortium of 22 freight carriers, in a fight against the companies' demand to use part-time workers, the central issue in the strike that is in its ninth day.
After calls today from Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich and Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena, who expressed concern about the potential economic impact of the strike, the two sides said they would resume talks on Monday after a two-week hiatus.
Even so, Mr. Carey said he would press ahead with the strike, staging rallies and demonstrations. His credibility and his control of the nation's biggest nongovernment union are at stake, and they conspire to leave him little ground to give.
 
A Line in the Sand
 M. Carey has drawn his line in the sand on the employers' insistence on replacing full-time jobs with part-time jobs, "It's an issue that has to be taken on," he said at a news conference today, "head on."
Both Mr. Carey and Trucking Management Inc. have become entrenched. It is the teamsters' first nationwide strike in 15 years and the second ever. Before the Federal deregulation of trucking in 1980, the trucking industry and the teamsters enjoyed a cozy relationship.
Until then the Interstate Commerce Commission granted the companies highway monopolies, allocating routes among them and letting them fix rates. They charged their customers prices that insured their own profits and generous wages for the teamsters. President Jimmy Carter, who was concerned that rising teamster wages were driving up inflation, proposed legislation opening the business to all comers. Congress approved it, and as a result thousands of nonunion companies poured into the trucking business.
The companies affected most were those that load their trucks with the goods of many customers. Most of the 23 companies that make up Trucking Management contend that to survive they must bring their labor costs more into line with those of their nonunion competitors.
The teamsters who load the trucks and sort the freight are paid more than $17 an hour, plus $5 an hour in benefits -- about twice the pay of nonunion workers. Drivers, paid 43 cents a mile, can earn that much and more when they are on the road. With overtime, many drivers earn more than $50,000 a year, at least twice what nonunion drivers earn.
To cut costs, the consortium wants to hire part-time loaders, who would get $9 an hour and eventually do 24 percent of the dock work. The companies also want to cut back on the number of drivers by moving as much as 35 percent of their freight by railroads. Other unions affected by deregulation, like those of the airline workers, have made such concessions, and the heat of foreign competition has brought similar concessions from workers in many other industries.
 
'Confronting All Americans'
 But Mr. Carey disputes the companies' argument that survival requires more low-wage, nonunion, part-time jobs. Efficient employers can prosper and pay good wages, he says, and if the inefficient fold, so be it. That leaves more room for the strong ones to hire more teamsters.
"This is an issue confronting all Americans," Mr. Carey keeps proclaiming. "Part-time jobs, temporary jobs, no benefits, no pensions. I'm not going to add to the problem now by adding more part-time jobs. This is a fight about what's wrong with America."
There is also a personal issue at stake. Mr. Carey has suffered major embarrassments as head of the union. He trades on an image of living simply in a modest home in Queens and for having chopped his salary to $150,000, from $225,000. But in recent weeks he has acknowledged buying comfortable retreats in the sun, if with his own savings.
Accusations of corruption also continue to plague the union, raising questions about Mr. Carey's effectiveness in ending them. A strike he called against United Parcel Service in February crumbled in a day when some locals refused to go along. And last month the membership defeated, by 3 to 1, his proposal to raise dues by 25 percent.
Sensing weakness, officers of the old teamster regime who were defeated in races for higher office in 1991 have seized on these missteps. They cannot try to run him out of office until the next national election in 1996, and most support the strike.
But from their roosts in regional offices, they are pressuring Mr. Carey, harassing the lieutenants he sends to monitor them and assailing him by fax and press release. Mr. Carey struck back last month with a plan to shut down his opponents' outposts. He calls them inefficient, self-serving and a $14 million annual drain on the union.
The offices maintain that they provide invaluable services, helping to organize members and negotiate contracts. But Mr. Carey says his people in Washington can handle those tasks, just as they are managing the trucking negotiations.
Labor experts suspect that the consortium of trucking companies thought it could exploit the divisions within the union by letting the strike proceed. Companies in the consortium are just regaining the revenue they lost in the recession. And with their tens of thousands of rigs immobilized at terminals, not a dime is flowing into their coffers now, and small competitors are running off with their freight. As a result, the consortium has begun to fragment.
"I suspect that they thought the teamsters wouldn't stick together, and that they could split the teamsters politically," said Michael Belzer, a former teamster who is an expert in labor relations at Cornell University. "If that's so, they've miscalculated and exacerbated a conflict they will certainly lose."
 
Backing From an Opponent
 One of Mr. Carey's most outspoken critics, R. V. Durham, a regional leader in North Carolina and one of the men Mr. Carey beat for the presidency, backs his strategy in the strike.
"I have my differences with Mr. Carey," Mr. Durham said. "But basically all of us have agreed to try to get behind this effort. The employers have painted themselves into a corner."
If dividing the union to bring it around fails, the three biggest companies have another strategy. They have acquired their own low-wage, nonunion carriers. Too small yet to take over much of the business lost in the strike, they stand as a longer-term threat to teamster jobs and a way to frighten the strikers.
But that gives Mr. Carey one more reason to dig in. The richer the contract he wins, the better the case he can make in trying to organize the nonunion companies' workers.
He thinks he can show those workers that he can arrest employers' use of low-wage and part-time jobs. "I'm not negotiating a loss of the future for American workers," he told reporters today. "This is not my role here."

HEADLINE: New York Fed's Research Post

 BODY:
The New York Federal Reserve has named Frederic S. Mishkin, an economist from Columbia University's business school, as its new director of research.
Mr. Mishkin, 43, the author of the standard business school textbook on money and banking and an expert on the effects of monetary policy on domestic and international financial markets, will replace Richard G. Davis, who is retiring after 34 years at the bank. 
 The New York Fed's new president, William J. McDonough, has made it clear that he wants to raise the visibility of the research department.
Mr. Mishkin will not report to work until after Labor Day. He is spending the spring and summer as a visiting scholar at Australia's central bank.

HEADLINE: 3 Players, 3 Agendas, One 3-Way Tug of War Fate of New York Coliseum Still Uncertain

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
It is, by most accounts, one of the most valuable potential development sites in New York City.
Yet nine years after Mortimer B. Zuckerman won the right to build a giant retail, residential and office complex to replace the New York Coliseum, the fate of the site is now tangled in a complicated three-way battle involving the developer, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the Giuliani administration. 
 Although the three players say they share the goal of replacing the dreary-looking exhibition hall and office building with a new development that would generate tax revenue and jobs and brighten a corner of Central Park, the months of often bitter negotiations have made it increasingly clear that each has its own notion of how that goal is best achieved.
And looming above all the bitterness is the issue of mayoral politics and the question of whether actions by the Giuliani administration or its predecessor were made with partisan considerations.
 
Digging In His Heels
 Mr. Zuckerman, who had blamed the depressed real-estate market, dug in his heels and refused to pay the $338 million contract price that he agreed to pay years ago. Last month Mr. Zuckerman filed suit against the M.T.A., which owns the site, and the city, its partner in the transaction, claiming that the current contract is not valid. He maintains that he still wants to buy the property at 59th Street and Columbus Circle, but admits he is growing tired of the process.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, whose campaign last fall won the endorsement of Mr. Zuckerman's newspaper, The Daily News, has been pressuring the M.T.A. to agree to the developer's proposal for a price cut. The Mayor has argued that it is critical to complete the deal so the city can start reaping the tax benefits that Mr. Zuckerman's development would produce.
But the transit agency, which has tentatively agreed to a substantial price cut -- the most recent proposal is a $100 million deal for half of the original site -- has said price is not the only issue and that for the public good it cannot give in to pressure from City Hall to compromise just to get the project going.
In fact, despite the heated rhetoric of recent months, city and M.T.A. officials say Mr. Zuckerman and the agency have made progress in their negotiations and are close to agreeing on a purchase price.
 
A Monday Deadline
 Although the struggle over the Coliseum's fate had been going for for years, the battle lines have been drawn more sharply in recent days as Mr. Zuckerman approaches a deadline of April 18 -- Monday -- for closing the deal. If Mr. Zuckerman does not take advantage of an extension permitted under the contract, he will be required to close on the deal or forfeit a $33.8 million line of credit.
Last week the Giuliani administration proposed restoring $50 million in budget cuts to the transit agency in order to persuade it to "close the deal."
But after questions were raised about whether the offer was simply an effort to aid a campaign supporter, city officials withdrew it, even though they defended the move as a way of sparking economic development.
"Now, here's the city's interest in it," Mr. Giuliani said in an interview yesterday. "We need jobs, we need a construction project. It would be a real shot in the arm of the city to have a construction project."
The property in question is not just another piece of New York City real estate. Situated on a majestic corner of Central Park, any new development would be the gateway to the Upper West Side and sit above a major subway transportation hub. As a sign of the area's attractiveness, Donald Trump announced a plan last month to convert the nearby Gulf and Western tower into a luxury residential building.
Mr. Zuckerman's company, Boston Properties, is under a 1989 contract to build a 2.1 million-square-foot complex of offices, apartments, restaurants and stores at the site. After the last of a series of lawsuits from residents and environmentalists concerned that the original project was too big, Mr. Zuckerman protested that the project was no longer feasible because of the city's depressed real-estate market.
As a result, the city, Mr. Zuckerman and the M.T.A. reopened negotiations last July in an effort to strike a new deal on a scaled-down version of the project.
Despite speculation that Mr. Zuckerman is trying to back out of his commitment to building on the Coliseum site, Mr. Zuckerman said he still wants to build the project, the latest version of which envisions 700,000 square feet of office space and 150,000 square feet of retail space.
"I want to build," he said. "You don't put nine years and four months and equity into a project like this to walk away."
But he acknowledged that he is weary of the struggle. "If I had it to do over again," he said, "I don't think I would."
Yesterday, Mr. Giuliani expressed his frustration at the delays and what he felt was the M.T.A.'s unreasonable resistance to sound proposals, including having an independent appraisal of the property in an effort to settle on a fair price. He also rejected speculation that the maneuvers from City Hall have been motivated by politics.
"It has nothing to do with politics," the Mayor said. "It has nothing to do with anybody supporting anyone. This is right now, this offer is the one that has the best prospect of getting something going there in the next year."
Still, this is not the first time questions have been raised about political motivations and the Coliseum. Last December, Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Zuckerman criticized the Dinkins administration for siding with the M.T.A. in trying to force the developer to close the deal, saying it was a vindictive political move to punish Mr. Zuckerman for The Daily News's endorsement of Mr. Giuliani.
For its part, the M.T.A. has said it has resisted pressure to strike a deal to get the project under way because it views the Coliseum as a public asset whose value the agency has the chance to exploit only once.
"We are mindful of the need for development there," said Susan Fine, real estate director for the M.T.A. "But we view the Coliseum as an asset whose value will be turned into a capital subsidy for transit. We think of its worth in terms of how many subway stations we can renovate with the proceeds from the sale.
"We benefit once from this deal," Ms. Fine added. "For the city the real estate taxes go on in perpetuity."
Specifically, while the M.T.A. has indicated that it would accept $100 million, it is concerned about details like the amount of the down payment that would go with the new price and how much time it will give Mr. Zuckerman to complete the negotiation.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Development of the site of the Coliseum, center, is bogged down in a three-way tug of war between the Giuliani administration, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and Mortimer B. Zuckerman. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)
