HEADLINE: Fortaleza Journal;
Bouquets for a State as Brazil's Dust Bowl Flowers

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FORTALEZA, Brazil

 BODY:
"Fortaleza: Brazil's Miami," a Rio newspaper gushed recently, describing a beachfront city of European tourists, foreign investors, imported cars, a thriving fashion industry, a new international yacht marina and steel-and-glass shopping centers with theaters showing Hollywood's latest films.
Ten years ago there was little to envy in Fortaleza, the capital of Ceara State. This northeastern dust bowl seemed condemned eternally to export its population, hat in hand, to work in Brazil's developed south. 
 But in seven years, Social Democratic government in Ceara has cut infant mortality by a third, drawn two-thirds of Fortaleza's street children into schools and produced state economic growth rates three times the nation's average.
"It proves that the basket case of Brazil can turn itself around," said David B. Atkinson, the Inter-American Development Bank's representative for Brazil.
Now this Alabama-sized state -- small for Brazil -- is to loom large in a sharpening struggle over Brazil's future. In six months Brazilians are to elect a new President.
For more than a year, polls have indicated that the head-and-shoulders front-runner is Luis Inacio Lula da Silva, a bearded socialist whose red flags and lack of government experience unnerve the middle class.
The strongest challenger is a Social Democrat, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, an urbane Sao Paulo senator. Election rules forced him to step down on March 30 as Economy Minister. Although he governed Brazil for 10 months as de facto Prime Minister, his record is not a vote-getter. On his watch, Brazil's inflation rate increased by one-half, hitting 45 percent a month in March, so Mr. Cardoso, a sociologist, is expected to try to swivel national attention to Ceara.
Since 1987, Ceara has been a laboratory for a development formula that the Social Democrats want to implant across Brazil: an aggressive attack on social ills paired with an equally aggressive courtship of private investors.
Trimming government to the essentials, Tasso Jereissati, the first Social Democratic Governor here, dismissed one-third of the state government workers. Tax laws were enforced, and the government paid its debts.
"Ciro has done a lot for the people, and he doesn't steal," Josalito Darcy Barbosa, a 23-year-old brewery worker, said, referring to Ceara's current Governor, Ciro Gomes. In nationwide public opinion polls, Mr. Gomes consistently ranks as Brazil's most popular Governor.
The state has started health-care programs that have won international acclaim. One program, Long Live the Child, lifted Ceara from near the bottom to near the top of Brazil's 26 states in child-protection indicators: vaccinations, breast-feeding and visits to pediatricians. With an army of 7,400 health agents visiting the state's poorest households every month, Ceara has reduced childhood diseases and has virtually wiped out polio and diphtheria.
Starting last year, the government extended to three-quarters of Ceara's municipalities Long Live the Woman, a program that offers cancer testing, prenatal and gynecological care and family planning help. Increasingly an international showcase for third-world health care, Ceara's Health Secretariat now receives financial and technical aid from 16 international organizations.
"I bet that Ceara gets more international aid per capita than any other state in Brazil," Mr. Atkinson said. "They have attracted good people into their ranks, and that translates into their capacity to put together good projects fast."
The Development Bank is financing three-quarters of a $403 million road and sewer project for Ceara, one of Brazil's largest infrastructure projects. By 1996, sewer coverage in this city of 1.8 million people is to expand from 16 percent to 65 percent. This should prevent a return of cholera, which surged through shantytowns here in January.
Ceara is also courting investment. "There has been enormous amount of deregulation," said Ivan Martins, a director of a real-estate company. "You can open a company here in one day, while elsewhere in Brazil it will take one month. A friend of mine, an advertising director, left his car in the middle of a Sao Paulo traffic jam and moved up here."
With new high-rises sprouting, Fortaleza has become one of Brazil's busiest construction markets. Throwing a $9 billion state economy into high gear, $2 billion in business investment projects are under way, a third of them by foreign investors. Ceara's economy has expanded by 24 percent since 1987, while Brazil's economy grew by 8 percent.
With $500 million in tourism investments under way, Ceara officials expect the number of visitors to double to one million by the end of the decade.
Tourism officials recently arranged with local hotels and an airline to provide free air tickets and hotel rooms to a crew filming a soap opera here for Globo, Brazil's most widely watched station.
It will be worth the trouble, said Antonio de Matos Brito, president of Coditur, the state tourism agency. "Imagine what happens when your state is featured on Globo every night for eight months running."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities' Yields Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The bond market, which has focused solely on domestic issues of late, was reminded of global uncertainties yesterday as yields of Treasury securities rose to their highest levels in two weeks.
Reports that two United States Army helicopters had been shot down over northern Iraq caused bond prices to tumble and oil prices to jump at the start of trading yesterday. The market calmed down a bit after the State Department confirmed that it had been American fighters that mistakenly shot down the helicopters, and not Iraqi forces. 
 Market analysts said as events unfolded there was a flight to the shorter end of the Treasury market, with gold and crude oil gaining on the heels of heightened tensions.
 
Help From the Bundesbank
 The market was helped, however, by the announcement by the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, that it was cutting its discount rate to 5 percent from 5.25 percent and its Lombard rate to 6.50 percent from 6.75 percent. Economists believe that with the German rate now closer to the United States', it will be competitive as a result.
The price of a 30-year long bond late yesterday fell 8/32 , to 8719/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from prices, rose to 7.28 percent, from 7.26 percent on Wednesday. The price declines were by no means restricted to the long maturities, as bills and intermediate notes also fell under selling pressure.
With the bond market focused on international events and today's release of March industrial production data, the report yesterday of the number of Americans filing first-time claims for unemployment benefits had little impact. The claims report showed a rise to 348,000, from 336,000 the previous week. But analysts attributed the gain to seasonal factors.
The Government also released its report on business inventories for February, which was in line with economists' forecasts.
Ron Reuss, chief economist for Piper Capital Management, said one of the market's concerns had been capacity utilization, which if comes in today at the 83.7 percent medium estimate will not be a major concern. "In the major restructuring of U.S. corporations, we've written off a substantial amount of unproductive capital," Mr. Reuss said. "In the past, the threshold for inflationary pressures, or the number that inflation would become a problem, was about 84 to 85 percent capacity utlilization. But with globalization of markets we are no longer constrained to U.S. capacity because we can outsource products, as the automotive industry has done for years."
The Piper Capital economist sees the price of long-term Treasury securities as a bargain at the current first quarter inflation level.
"The fundamentals in the market have not looked any better in my 25 years as an economist," Mr. Reuss said. "I'm looking at the ability of the economy to grow at a 2.5 percent to 3.5 percent rate."
 
Corporate Bonds
 In the corporate bond market, MCM Corporatewatch, a new issues research and information firm, said only two deals were priced yesterday. The two issues, however, totaled $1.15 billion in junk bonds and both are related to acquisitions.
Thrifty Payless sold $550 million in junk bonds to finance the acquisition of Payless Drug Stores Northwest Inc., from the Kmart Corporation. The TCH Corporation formed Thrifty for the expressed purpose of financing the acquisition. The two-part financing was handled by underwriters led by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. In the first part, rated B2 by Moody's Investors Service and B by Standard & Poor's, $250 million of 11.75 percent senior notes due in 2003 were priced at 100. The final $300 million of 12.25 percent senior subordinated notes 2004 were also priced at par.
The senior subordinated issue rated B3 by Moody and B- by S.& P., was done as a unit offering and included the issuance of class C common shares of the Thrifty Payless Holdings Inc., the holding company. The Huntsman Corporation, a Houston- based chemical maker, which is buying the Texaco Chemical Company, Canada Texaco Inc. and certain other assets from Texaco Inc., sold $600 million in junk bonds through BT Securities yesterday.
The two-part sale included $200 million of 10 5/8 percent first-mortgage notes due in 2001 at a price of 100, and $400 million of first-mortgage notes due in 2004 at 100.
Both parts are noncallable for five years and rated B1 by Moody's and BB- by S.& P.
Market traders said that despite the rise in interest rates, the deals were critical to making acquisitions and had to be done, and noted that the Payless deal was sweetened with higher coupons and common stock to insure its sale.

HEADLINE: Gore Insists Environment Is a Trade Issue

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MARRAKESH, Morocco, April 14

 BODY:
Looking beyond a sweeping global trade agreement that will be signed here Friday, the United States said today that future trade negotiations should include discussion of environmental and labor questions, despite the opposition of many developing countries.
In an address to the closing meeting of the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, Vice President Al Gore said that the effect of expanded trade on the global environment and the well-being of workers could be debated for the first time when GATT's successor, the World Trade Organization, is created next year. 
 But with many developing countries expressing fear that these issues could offer pretexts for new forms of nontariff protectionism, Mr. Gore went out of his way to sound reassuring and nonconfrontational.
"The United States realizes that many countries fear that folding labor standards into the world trade context exposes their exports to potential forms of concealed trade restrictions," he said. "The United States will resist any effort to convert the issue of improved labor standards into a form of protectionism."
But Mr. Gore said that protection of natural resources was essential to improving world living standards. He insisted, though, that Washington opposed "green protectionism," under which nations might be denied trade benefits for environmental reasons.
The four-day conference here concludes more than seven years of negotiations on trade liberalization under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, The final ceremony Friday brings together ministers of more than 100 countries, who will take turns signing the 22,000-plus-page agreement lowering tariffs around the world.
The negotiations have been known as the Uruguay Round because they began in the Uruguayan resort of Punta del Este in 1986.
Suspicion of American motives in linking trade to labor and environmental concerns runs deep in many third-world countries, especially the large exporting nations of Asia. "We see no merit whatsoever in the attempt to force linkages where they do not exist," Commerce Minister Pranab Mukherjee of India warned on Wednesday.
Today, Pakistan's Commerce Minister, Chaudhry Ahmad Mukhtar, echoed similar concerns about what he called "a new brand of protectionism under the garb of protection of the environment or the promotion of the rights of workers in developing countries."
Trade Minister Yeo Cheow Tong of Singapore, whose Government has frequently said that Western democracies try to impose their vision of human rights on the rest of the world, also warned against "the use of trade to bring external pressure for change in countries' domestic political or social structures."
 
Wedge for Broader Campaign?
 In raising issues like child labor, slave labor and the right to collective bargaining, the United States has said that it is not trying to eliminate the competitive edge of low-wage exporters. But the third world fears that the discussion of these issues could lead to broader debate of poor working conditions in many countries.
France, which has backed the American initiative, has argued that its industries, which are burdened by high wage and welfare costs, face growing difficulty competing against those in nations where workers do not enjoy long vacations and generous pension and maternity rights.
Mr. Gore used his one-day visit here to meet privately with Morocco's King, Hassan II, and with Japan's Foreign Minister, Tsutomu Hata, who is widely expected to become his country's next Prime Minister after Morihiro Hosokawa's resignation last week.
Mr. Hata, talking with reporters before his conversation with Mr. Gore, noted that the new government was still being formed. But he pledged that the coalition would continue the reforms initiated by Mr. Hosokawa and would "pursue further market openings in Japan" to take account of its huge trade surplus.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Calmed by Cuts In 2 German Interest Rates

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was steady against leading currencies yesterday as concern about weak American stock and bond markets was offset by optimism about cuts in German interest rates.
Traders bought dollars after the Bundesbank cut its discount rate by a quarter-point, to 5 percent, and lowered its Lombard rate to 6.50 percent from 6.75 percent. The discount rate is what the German central bank charges commercial banks for loans, while the Lombard rate is what banks pay for emergency borrowing. 
 Many traders sold dollars later as United States bond prices fell and stocks languished.
The dollar was quoted late in the day at 1.7096 marks, up a fraction from 1.7091 marks the previous day. Traders often buy dollars when German rates fall because lower rates make mark-denominated deposits less attractive.
"What the dollar needs to get going is some money flowing into U.S. stocks and bonds," said Earl Johnson, foreign exchange adviser for Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. "Global pension fund managers haven't been putting money in U.S. assets."
The dollar fared better against the yen yesterday, mostly because European central banks aided the Bank of Japan and bought dollars for yen, traders said. The Bank of Japan often tries to curb the dollar's slide because a strong yen hurts Japan's manufacturers by making their products more expensive abroad.
 
Concern About Trade Talks
 The yen strengthened against the dollar in Tokyo trading amid persistent concern that United States-Japanese trade relations would suffer in the wake of the resignation of Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa of Japan a week ago.
"The dollar will remain under pressure until there's progress in trade talks," said Koichi Takenaka, assistant vice president for Industrial Bank of Japan in New York.
The dollar was quoted at 104.29 yen in late New York trading, up from 103.40 on Wednesday.
Gold prices rose yesterday. The gold contract for June delivery rose 30 cents, to $380.30 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
In other currency trading, the British pound was little changed at $1.4775. The dollar rose to 5.8505 French francs from 5.8481 francs, and strengthened to 1.4430 Swiss francs from 1.4396 francs. The dollar was steady at 1,633 Italian lire. The Canadian dollar fell to 72.48 cents (United States) from 72.72 cents.

HEADLINE: In Surprise Move, Germans Cut Both Key Interest Rates

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, April 14

 BODY:
The German central bank, in an effort to help calm turbulent financial markets, cut its two key interest rates today and set off a round of similar small cuts across Europe. The Bundesbank also held out the prospect of further gradual reductions if inflation continued to decline.
The bank has a reputation for keeping its focus on only Germany and its fear of inflation, as was the case in a crisis in 1992 that led to a rupture of the European Monetary System. So it was a little surprising for the Bundesbank president, Hans Tietmeyer, to point out that the interest-rate cuts were made with a view beyond the improvement in Germany's inflation outlook. 
 "We believe today's decision will calm the financial markets," he said, referring to recent selloffs in stocks and bonds in the United States and Europe and speculation about further increases in American interest rates.
"The Bundesbank's role," he added, "is to reassure investors that they can have confidence over the long term."
In emphasizing a desire to calm troubled markets, Mr. Tietmeyer also acknowledged that the central bank's council of rate setters had discussed the consequences of the collapse this week of a huge German commercial real estate empire after the mysterious disappearance of its chief, Jurgen Schneider, owner of its bank accounts along with his wife.
"We are watching these developments very carefully," Mr. Tietmeyer said after the central bank's meeting today, "but I don't have enough information to make a judgment on what their effect will be."
He said the Schneider company's difficulties had no effect on the bank's decision to lower interest rates.
The Bundesbank had not been expected to lower its discount rate today, yet it did so by one-quarter of 1 percent, bringing it down to 5 percent -- 3.75 percentage points lower than at the record high in the summer of 1992. The discount rate is what the central bank charges commercial banks for loans, and it has the effect of setting the floor for German money market rates.
The bank also lowered by one-quarter of a point the Lombard rate, which acts as a ceiling on German money market rates, taking it to 6.5 percent from 6.75 percent. This was a smaller cut than had been expected, since money market rates are now well below 6.5 percent.
 
Salomon Not Enthusiastic
 In a statement after the Bundesbank's announcement, Salomon Brothers International said that "the latest Bundesbank rate cuts may help foster business confidence, but are unlikely to relieve market uncertainties about the interest rate path over the next year."
The Netherlands, Belgium, Switzerland, Austria and Denmark all lowered their discount rates after the German announcement this afternoon, and in Washington, Secretary of the Treasury Lloyd Bentsen, who has repeatedly urged the Germans to keep cutting, welcomed the move as a stimulus to the German economy.
Despite the announcement, however, major European stock indexes ended the day slightly lower.
Mr. Tietmeyer warned that the Bundesbank would act cautiously. "Exaggerated interest rate reductions would risk rekindling fears of long-term inflation," he said after the decision by the central bank council, which consists of seven members of the Bundesbank's directorate and the bank's nine state presidents.
 
Further Talk of Inflation
 "The task of the Bundesbank," he said, "will continue to be to dampen expectations of inflation, and therefore to be very cautious in making interest rate reductions."
But the council noted that "the prospects of a continued reduction in the rate of inflation have improved," and said it assumed inflation would keep declining in coming months.
The bank last lowered its discount rate, to 5.25 percent from 5.75 percent, on Feb. 17.
"It was a clever move to lower it again today because nobody expected that," said Peter Pietsch, an economist at Commerzbank. "It was certainly justified because the economy is still shaky."
German inflation, which was running well above 4 percent a year ago, fell to 3.2 percent in March and will probably be below 3 percent by the end of this year, Mr. Tietmeyer said today. But with unemployment running close to 10 percent and nearly four million Germans out of work, any economic growth is expected to be modest.
In the meantime, the whereabouts of Mr. Schneider remained a mystery today, as dozens of German banks that had underwritten his commercial real estate projects with an estimated $5 billion met with the company's shocked and baffled management to discuss what to do.
Prosecutors here announced that they had started a criminal investigation of the Schneiders after a complaint by Deutsche Bank, which had the most exposure, with loans believed to total $760 million.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hans Tietmeyer, the Bundesbank president, explaining the cut in key rates yesterday in Frankfurt. (Associated Press) (pg. D17)

HEADLINE: Top Dayton Hudson Officer Retiring

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
In an announcement that was greeted with a shrug on Wall Street, Kenneth A. Macke, the Dayton Hudson Corporation's chairman and chief executive for the last decade, said yesterday that he intends to retire in July.
Robert J. Ulrich, chairman and chief executive of Target, Dayton Hudson's largest operating division, was named by the retailing company's board to succeed Mr. Macke. 
 Mr. Ulrich's appointment as chief executive is effective immediately. He will assume the additional title of chairman in July, when Mr. Macke retires.
Mr. Macke, who is 55, has long expressed a desire to take early retirement, analysts said yesterday. That may be one reason why investors scarcely reacted to the announcement. Dayton Hudson's shares closed at $75 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, up 25 cents on the day.
Analysts cited two other reasons why the announcement did not rattle investors.
Despite continued problems at Mervyn's, the California-based softgoods chain, Mr. Macke is leaving Dayton Hudson in fairly sound shape. And Mr. Ulrich, his sucessor, is widely regarded as a highly talented executive.
"Some things could have been done better," during Mr. Macke's tenure, said David A. Poneman, a senior research analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. "But he has left everything essentially healthy."
In a telephone interview, Mr. Macke acknowledged that "Mervyn's would not be one of my great success stories."
But he added that much of the chain's recent problems have had much to do with the ailing California economy, and said the company was "very optimistic" about the division's prospects this year.
Despite those problems, Mr. Macke said his decision to step down "was not the result of any disagreement with the board."
Rather, after a 33-year career at Dayton Hudson, Mr. Macke said it was time to get off what he called the corporate treadmill.
"I have spent my entire career marching to a calendar," he said. "I want to decide to do some other things where I don't have a calendar."
For the foreseeable future, he said, "my fondest wish is that I will have the willpower to do nothing."
It is not altogether surprising that Mr. Macke might want a rest.
Among other things, during his tenure, Dayton Hudson successfully repelled a $6 billion hostile takeover by the Haft family, thanks in large part to the stock market crash in October 1987. Revenues more than tripled, from $6.5 billion in 1983 to $19.23 billion last year. During the smae period however, earnings rose at a much slower pace, to $375 million last year from $246 million in 1983.
"Earnings have been less consistent at Dayton Hudson than at other retailers because they have always done things to invest in the long-term good of the company," Mr. Poneman said. "That is not true for a number of other retailing companies," whose sights are more often trained on short-term results.
Mr. Ulrich, who is 50, began his career at Dayton Hudson as a merchandise trainee in 1967, six years after Mr. Macke joined the company.
He was named president of Target in 1984 and chairman and chief executive three years later. He joined Dayton Hudson's board of directors last year. "He is a dynamic leader who has brought Target to the level it is today, elevating it to be the quality discount store in the United States," said Walter Loeb, who runs his own retail consulting firm. "Basically, Target is carrying the company.

HEADLINE: Inventories and Sales Both Rose in February

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 14

 BODY:
Business inventories rose in February for the sixth time in the last seven months, but were outpaced by sales as both indicators scored their biggest gains since November.
Analysts said today's Commerce Department figures, generally in line with economists' predictions, were a sign there was room for manufacturing expansion in the months ahead. 
 In another report, the Labor Department said the number of Americans filing first-time claims for jobless benefits jumped by a surprising 12,000 last week to the highest level in more than a month. Most economists, expecting an improving unemployment picture, had forecast a decline.
The Labor Department said new applications for unemployment insurance totaled 348,000, up from a revised 336,000 during the week ended April 2.
Also, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation reported mortgage rates declined this week for the first time in two months as 30-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 8.26 percent.
The 30-year rate was down from last week's 8.47 percent, the highest in nearly two years. This week's rate is still about one and a half percentage points above the 25-year low of 6.74 percent in October.
The Commerce Department said business inventories rose half a percentage point in February, while sales increased 1.2 percent.
The inventory increase followed a gain of two-tenths of 1 percent for January, which was previously estimated by the Government as unchanged from December. February's rise was the largest since a jump of half a percentage point in November.
 
Biggest Gain Since November
 Similarly, it was the biggest sales gain since a 1.2 percent rise in November. Sales have also increased in six of the last seven months.
Stocks held on shelves and backlots totaled a seasonally adjusted $871.4 billion, the Commerce Department said.
Sales climbed to a seasonally adjusted $617.3 billion, rebounding from a dip of four-tenths of 1 percent in January.
Michael P. Niemira, an economist with Mitsubishi Bank in New York, said even though sales outpaced inventory growth in February, "inventories are holding in line over all with sales."
Factory inventories have stayed low, he said, lagging behind increases at the wholesale and retail levels.
"The mind-set in the purchasing community is to keep those numbers down," he said. But he said in the months ahead factory inventories would likely catch up.
The inventory-to-sales ratio was 1.41 at the end of February, compared with 1.42 the previous month. That means it would take 1.41 months to exhaust stockpiles at that sales pace.
The ratio figure is viewed as a positive sign, with any further pickup in sales likely to translate into new orders to factories.
For many economists, the steady pace of inventories suggests room for expansion since businesses have been keeping their inventories lean and at historically low levels.
At the retail level, inventories rose six-tenths of 1 percent, to $273 billion, in February. They were up three-tenths of 1 percent at factories, to $380 billion, and up eight-tenths of 1 percent at wholesalers, to $218.4 billion.
February sales for retailers were up 1.6 percent, to $181.5 billion. The Commerce Department reported Wednesday that retail sales in March advanced only four-tenths of 1 percent, lower than most economists had predicted and at a pace consistent with moderate growth.

HEADLINE: Inside Art

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:

A Matisse No More
Some fakes can fool even the most seasoned experts. Sotheby's had a surprise recently when it began researching paintings from the estate of the New York collector Harriet Weiner Goodstein, which the auction house is selling next month. "Woman in an Interior," a 1943 still life of a woman in an ornately patterned room, had been attributed to Matisse ever since Mrs. Goodstein and her first husband, Leon Mnuchin, bought the painting in 1956 with Eugene V. Thaw acting as the agent. 
 "I was in my mid-20's and had a shop in the Algonquin Hotel where I sold books and lithographs," recalled Mr. Thaw, now a prominent Manhattan art dealer. "Mr. Mnuchin, who was a very smart lawyer, had his office around the corner and would come into the shop from time to time. One day he brought me a photograph of a painting, which was in a private collection in Florida, near where my parents lived. He financed me to go to Florida and get the picture."
Since Matisse had died only two years before, Mr. Thaw said, no archives yet existed where his works could be authenticated. So Mr. Mnuchin showed the painting to Alfred H. Barr Jr., who was then the head of the Museum of Modern Art and a leading Matisse expert, and to Paul Rosenberg, Matisse's dealer. Both men, now dead, identified the painting as a Matisse, Mr. Thaw said.
David Nash, the director of Impressionist and modern art for Sotheby's worldwide, said: "Over the years a lot of dealers, scholars and auction house experts saw the Matisse." He added that "nobody had any idea" there was anything wrong.
Neither did Mr. Nash, who estimated that the painting could fetch $5 million to $7 million at auction. That was before he began researching the painting for the sale's catalogue. "I did think it was strange that the painting had never been illustrated in books or in exhibitions, which is unusual for a late Matisse," Mr. Nash said.
When he approached Wanda de Guebriant, the director of the Matisse archives in Paris, she said that the archives included a photograph of the picture and a note written by Marguerite Duthuit, Matisse's daughter, saying that the work was not by her father's hand. The note was written in either 1959 or 1960, when the painting was on exhibition in Belgium. Ms. de Guebriant told Mr. Nash she had no idea where the painting had gone.
Until now. Some experts believe the still life could have been painted by Elmyr de Hory, a Hungarian-born artist who was a well-known forger of Matisses in the 1950's. The painting is a pastiche, imitating many elements characteristic of Matisse. The woman is sitting next to a table with plants and a bowl of fruit on it, nearly identical to the objects on a table in "The Lute," a Matisse of the same date.
"I'm pretty good at spotting fakes, but in this case there's a suspension of disbelief," Mr. Nash said. "When you hear about a great painting that's in a great collection, it's like walking into a museum. You presume it's right." Sotheby's has withdrawn the painting from its estate sale.
Mr. Thaw said he had not seen the painting in 35 years and hadn't heard a word about it until he learned that Sotheby's was selling works from the estate. "I feel bad, but it happened so long ago I don't think there's anything to be done," he said. "I was only acting as Mr. Mnuchin's agent, and we checked it out with the best people of the time."
 
A Move to Paris
 Leslie Waddington sees the future, and it has a French accent. Mr. Waddington, one of London's most prestigious dealers of contemporary art, recently announced plans to close one of his five Cork Street galleries and open a gallery in Paris. "I'm just beginning to look for a space," Mr. Waddington said in a telephone interview this week. "It won't happen for two years."
The dealer said that as customs barriers between France and England were removed on Jan. 1 and with Sotheby's and Christie's marshaling forces to eventually hold auctions in Paris, it is important to "go where the source material is."
Doing business in Paris has its advantages: the value-added tax on the work of living artists is 17.5 percent in London and only 5.5 percent in France, and the London contemporary-art scene is still smarting from the recession.
"London has great assets, but it doesn't have the buying base or the material anymore," Mr. Waddington said. "Not only are there more rich people going into France than London, but I can find works like Matisse drawings and Miros in Paris."
 
Fresh Air for a Winter Show
 The powers behind the Winter Antiques Show seem to have got their act together. They have named new co-chairmen for next year's Manhattan show: Louis Bowen, who heads Louis W. Bowen Wallpapers, and Arie Kopelman, the president of Chanel in the United States.
They replace Bill Blass and Paige Rense, the editor in chief of Architectural Digest. Also just appointed is Catherine E. Sweeney, a former associate publisher of two magazines -- Art and Auction, and Art and Antiques -- to be the new manager. Miraculously, everybody seems happy.
The 40-year-old event has had a long history of discontent: dealers fighting with the manager; board members of the the East Side House Settlement in the South Bronx, the show's beneficiary, fighting with the manager; dealers fighting with one another. When this year's show closed on Jan. 30, James F. McCollom Jr., its top official, and N. Pendergast Jones, its manager, abruptly resigned, citing differences with the East Side board. The dealers, meanwhile, weren't happy with the vetting process or the pre-show publicity.
By choosing Ms. Sweeney, the antiques show is trying to find someone who knows the business and can work well with both the dealers and the East Side board members.
"It's a terrific step in the right direction," said Joan Mirviss, who heads the dealers' committee. "Although we haven't met her yet, she knows about art and antiques and how to manage people."
Ms. Sweeney said she planned to "to work on upgrading the show and to bring back the loan exhibition, which was a big draw in years past."
Questions remain. Does Ms. Sweeney plan to weed out inferior dealers? Will the show continue to have European participants or become strictly an American show?
"We haven't begun to talk about dealers yet," she said. "But there will be an overall review. I think we will come up with more formal guidelines about getting into the show."

HEADLINE: Review/Film;
Crying Out for Love Where Only Money Talks

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
Peter (Vitus Zeplichal), a fanatically hard-working construction worker who bows and scrapes his way through Rainer Werner Fassbinder's sadly compelling "I Only Want You to Love Me," is one of the more poignant social casualties to be examined in the films of the great German director.
A caricature of a dutiful son and model employee, he regards the world with frightened rabbity eyes that plead for a love he is incapable of demanding out loud. Instead of verbalizing his needs, Peter tries to buy with gifts the love he craves so desperately but doesn't believe he deserves. In one scene after another, he is shown standing on a doorstep, a silent supplicant holding a wrapped bouquet of flowers. 
 The film's Manhattan engagement, which begins today at the Joseph Papp Public Theater, is the American premiere of a movie that was made in the mid-1970's but not released in the United States until now because of legal problems. Based on a true story from a German anthology called "Life Sentence," it offers a merciless view of bourgeois German society in the feverish grip of capitalism. The cost of West Germany's postwar economic miracle, it suggests, was emotionally and spiritually devastating.
The world it portrays is an environment in which the value of everything can be measured in monetary credit. Especially in the scenes of Peter's shopping sprees, the clerks have the look and body language of well-dressed mannequins guarding precious goods that have the glow of sacred icons. The credit agreements that Peter signs assume an almost religious significance. So much of the movie is devoted to detailing the financial plight of a couple living beyond their means that it might as easily have been called "Tragedy on the Installment Plan" or "Time Payment Madness."
At the same time, the story is a typically blunt and bitter Fassbinder parable of a misfit ground down by the relentless social machinery. Without delving deeply into the psychological whys and wherefores, it presents Peter as an eager, uncomplaining slave to the needs of his cold, imperious parents. The movie's opening scenes show him single-handedly building a house for them and then receiving only scant gratitude. A flashback of the young Peter being spanked suggests that the parents always confused administering discipline with giving love.
Peter shyly courts a neighbor, Erika (Elke Aberle), and then marries her in a ceremony at which the parents wear expressions of grim disapproval. After deciding to seek his fortune in Munich, which he is warned is the most expensive city in Germany, Peter takes a job on a construction site and rents a small two-room apartment. Once he has settled in with his wife, he is as desperate to please her as he was his parents. Not only does he furnish the apartment lavishly, but he also showers Erika with expensive gifts that he can't afford, going ever more deeply into debt.
The situation spins out of control when Erika becomes pregnant, and Peter is forced to buy maternity items on credit. The turning point of the drama comes when Erika insists Peter ask his parents for money, and he cannot bring himself to do it because it would be a sign of his failure. With no escape from his problems, Peter cracks up and commits an act of senseless violence against a man who resembles his father.
"I Only Want You to Love Me" looks at Peter from three distinct perspectives. The bulk of the film sees the world through his eyes. It is a cold, scary place in which everybody -- employers, store clerks, patrons in a bar -- exudes an ominous authoritarian aura, and he is the only person in the world who is unsure of his place. Periodically, the story is interrupted by documentary-style snatches of an interview with Peter by a prison psychiatrist, in which the prisoner seems merely bewildered. Now and then, the director intrudes with printed commentary expressing outrage at Peter's plight.
"I Only Want You to Love Me" is a grim Germanic variation on a classic theme that can never bear too much repeating: Can't buy me love.
 
I Only Want You to Love Me
 
Written and directed by Rainer Werner Fassbinder; based on the book "Life Sentence," by Klaus Antes and Christine Erhardt; in German, with English subtitles; director of photography, Michael Ballhaus; edited by Liesgret Schmitt-Klink; music by Peer Raben; produced by Peter Maethesheimer. At the Joseph Papp Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, East Village. Running time: 104 minutes. This film is not rated.

HEADLINE: No Giveaway on the Coliseum

 BODY:
New York City has an undeniable interest in getting the old Coliseum site at Columbus Circle developed after years of delay and neglect -- but not at the expense of the public good. That is what makes the behavior of City Hall's chief negotiator, Deputy Mayor John Dyson, so regrettable. He sounds more like an agent for Mortimer Zuckerman, the developer, than a public servant.
Even if Mr. Dyson is motivated only by his zeal to encourage development, and not by any desire to reward a political ally, he has so mishandled the negotiations that they are tainted. How could Mr. Dyson propose that the city -- through hidden tax abatements and backdoor capital budget maneuvers -- subsidize a real estate developer at a time when the Mayor is demanding sacrifice from nearly every city agency and worker? 
 Stimulating the economy is one thing, and providing tax breaks and economic incentives to businesses that create jobs, including NBC, Chase Manhattan and The New York Times, is a common economic development tactic. But the sale of publicly owned, prime real estate is especially sensitive. Valuable properties should not be sold off in a climate of favoritism, or without determining that the public is getting a premium price.
Neither the city nor the site's owner, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, knows what the site is worth today because the development community hasn't looked at it since Boston Properties was designated the developer in 1985. Mr. Zuckerman's suggestion that he pay for an independent appraisal to establish the value of the property is proof that even he recognizes the lack of market judgment. The problem with his idea is that appraisers, too, need a market competition to demonstrate value.
The most sensible course now is for the city to find out anew the market value of this property, and that cannot be accomplished through negotiations with one bidder. Monday is the deadline for closing the deal with Mr. Zuckerman. If no deal is reached, the M.T.A. should simply claim Boston Properties's $33.8 million deposit and invite new proposals. That would restore the public's faith in the negotiations, and give the city and the M.T.A., the city's negotiating partner, a more realistic sense of what the property is worth today.
In nine years, the price has gone from $455 million to today's figure of $80 million, and the plan has shrunk from 2.7 million square feet to 900,000 square feet of office and retail space, on about half the site. Is that even the best use for such a choice piece of Manhattan real estate?
It was clearly the embarrassment of press disclosures that drove the Mayor to put the brakes on Mr. Dyson's latest proposal. It would have restored $50 million in budget cuts to the M.T.A. from city capital funds.
That, and the Dyson proposal to turn over $2 million annually for 20 years from the city's income from the project, were obviously intended to win the M.T.A.'s approval of a lower selling price for the property. Both proposals would provide Mr. Zuckerman with the equivalent of city subsidies, because they would allow him to pay a lower purchase price.
Negotiations must carry the appearance, as well as reality, of high ethical standards. Mr. Zuckerman is co-publisher of The Daily News and supported Rudolph Giuliani's mayoral bid. Former Mayor David Dinkins played politics with the Coliseum site, and now it looks as though the Giuliani administration is capable of doing the same.
City Hall must not appear to be orchestrating a favorable deal on the Coliseum as a political reward to a strong supporter; that would send a signal to all developers that they can count on the political system to bail them out should their commitments turn sour.
This page has argued for moving ahead with development on the Coliseum site after so many years of delay, but only in an apolitical atmosphere of fair dealings that bring an undisputed top price and put the public interest first. Whether it be eagerness for economic development, or political intrigue, City Hall shows every sign of losing its commitment to the public good.
The Giuliani administration's obligation is clear. It is not responsible for the expenses or cash-flow situation of any developer. After so many years of delay, there is no need to rush into a sweetheart deal. The property will still be there in a few years. A rebounding economy will likely increase its value. It is wiser to walk away than stumble into a giveaway.

HEADLINE: Inflation: Myth and Reality

BYLINE: By Laura D'Andrea Tyson; Laura D'Andrea Tyson is chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Fears of accelerating inflation have haunted the financial markets just at the time when the economy has turned in its best inflation performance in decades.
In 1993, the core indexes of consumer and producer prices (which exclude food and energy) registered their smallest gains in 20 years. Favorable trends are continuing this year: the annualized increase in the core Consumer Price Index over the past three months was 2.9 percent, the same as over the 12 months beginning in March 1993. 
 The Administration, like most private forecasters, predicts an uptick in inflation in 1994, as continued growth raises the utilization of industrial capacity and reduces unemployment. We certainly recognize the critical need to remain vigilant against inflation. The building blocks for a sustained expansion -- smaller Federal deficits, stronger business balance sheets, improvements in productivity, robust investment -- are in place. It would be a missed opportunity if the expansion suffered a premature end as a result of accelerating inflation.
So far, however, there are few signs of changes in the underlying causes of inflation. Rather, the financial markets appear to be reacting more to inflation myths than to realities.
Myth No. 1: Inflation can spike upward suddenly. Some commentators contend that inflation can strike at a moment's notice. History suggests otherwise. Since 1957, the first year for which core Consumer Price Index data are available, there have been only nine years in which the inflation rate increased by more than half a percentage point.
Five were oil shock years: 1973, '74, '79, '80 and '90. Oil prices can dramatically affect overall prices: core inflation jumped six percentage points from '73 to '74, and the '79 oil shock raised core inflation by nearly three percentage points in one year.
Since 1957 there have been only four years when there was no oil shock yet inflation increased by more than half a percentage point: '66, '68, '69 and '78. The first three were Vietnam War years, when the economy was overheated: capacity utilization was well over 86 percent and the jobless rate under 4 percent. The average jobless rate was considerably higher in '78, but that year was preceded by two years of rapid wage inflation, a trend we do not see now.
In short, it takes an oil shock or a severe overheating of the economy to produce a surge in core C.P.I. inflation. Neither appears to be on the horizon. Oil prices are low and likely to remain so at least for this year. And today's capacity utilization rates, in the 82 to 85 percent range, are well below the levels at which inflation might spike upward.
Myth No. 2: Price increases for industrial goods presage higher general price inflation. The price indexes of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia and National Association of Purchasing Managers increased noticeably in February and were blamed for fueling inflationary expectations. It is true that these indexes are somewhat correlated with the producer price index for intermediate goods -- say, industrial chemicals and wood pulp -- and other measures of commodity prices. It is also true that commodity prices, severely depressed in recent years, can be expected to rebound as the economy expands.
But over the past decade, the purchasing managers' index has, unsurprisingly, been a poor forecaster of changes in C.P.I. inflation. The managers' index is based on a narrow survey that includes only industrial companies, which account for a small share of overall economic activity; in addition, that index covers only purchases of industrial commodities.
Myth No. 3: Wages will soon accelerate because we are so close to full employment. One source of inflation could be an increase in the growth rate of unit labor costs -- that is, the cost of labor required to produce a fixed amount of goods. But unit labor costs have been decelerating, not accelerating, in recent years.
During 1993, unit labor costs increased by only 1 percent, compared with increases of 1.3 percent in 1992 and 2.5 percent in 1991. Over the past half year, they have fallen as wage changes have remained roughly constant in the face of increasing productivity growth. These developments lie at the heart of the good inflation story.
But are we on the verge of accelerating wage inflation, as some observers suggest? No. Even though the economy has created about 200,000 jobs a month over the past six months, wage growth has remained slow. Average hourly earnings increased only 0.1 percent in March despite significant employment growth. Over the past 12 months, average earnings increased only 2.4 percent.
The major commercial forecasters believe that labor market pressures do not push wage inflation higher until the unemployment rate, as measured today, falls to the range of 5.9 to 6.3 percent.
The Council of Economic Advisers reached a similar conclusion in its recent review of the relation between unemployment and inflation.
These views are reinforced by the economy's most recent experience. If labor markets were truly tight, there should be signs of mounting wage growth. But wage growth has been stagnant over the last year. Even when the unemployment rate falls to the 5.9 to 6.3 percent range, it is likely that wages will begin to drift upward only gradually. And strong productivity growth will continue to moderate growth in labor costs.
Myth No. 4: Rising import prices will heat up inflation. During the past year, the dollar has depreciated against the yen and import prices of Japanese goods are up about 7 percent. But Japanese imports represent only about a fifth of total U.S. imports and only about 2 percent of our gross domestic product. The prices of imports from the rest of the world are lower than a year ago, partly because the dollar has appreciated against most other currencies. Over the past year, prices of European, Canadian and other Asian goods are down about 1 percent, and imports from developing countries are about 4 percent cheaper.
Price increases for imports other than oil remain lower than the rate of core inflation, as has been true during the past five years. It is highly unlikely that import prices will be a source of accelerating inflation any time soon.
Myth No. 5: Higher gold prices mean inflation will increase. Gold prices have rebounded from the doldrums and are at their highest levels in about three years. But we have examined the relationship between gold prices and core C.P.I. inflation, and we find that there has been no correlation between the two since 1982. Developments like gold hoarding in China and political turmoil in South Africa buffet gold prices to such a degree that any causal link between gold prices and U.S. inflation seems hard to imagine.
In the absence of an oil price shock, it takes a sustained period of strong pressures on productive capacity to ignite truly inflationary conditions. Unless capacity utilization exceeds 86 or 87 percent, or the jobless rate drops substantially below its current level for a prolonged period, these conditions are not likely to develop in the near future. Instead, the economy seems well positioned to experience a decade-long phase of steady growth and modest inflation, much as it did from the mid-50's to the mid-60's.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Flog Asians Only

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Americans keep talking about how clever the people of Asia are but keep acting as if they were dolts.
In the controversy about the caning of a young man from Ohio, somehow it does not occur to American business executives, journalists and politicians that Asians will ask why they close their eyes, mouths and hearts when the same canes scar the flesh of Asians. 
 Let's hope Singapore gives clemency to Michael Fay, now that George Bush is adding his appeal to President Clinton's. But let's also try, real hard, to grasp what Asians understand: from America the big human rights message is "flog Asians only."
The legal screws are being twisted hard against Mr. Fay. In the past five years only 14 people, all Asian, were caned for vandalism, the charge against him. But for a list of other offenses, 1,208 Singaporeans and other Asians were caned to the blood in 1987-88 alone.
Asians are not too doltish to know that Americans did not seem to give one solitary damn about that then, or now. Asians also realize that Americans still talk about Singapore as if it were some kind of Switzerland, running all neat and ticktock.
The issue is not only vicious flogging, but the other laws of which that is part and symbol: detentions without trial, administrative imprisonment and political, press and academic control, the whole nasty authoritarian collection.
None of this is any secret to Americans who have the greatest moral responsibility to speak up: those doing business in Singapore. But when it comes to Asian skin, pain and liberties, they have accepted it all without protest or complaint -- before the sentence against Mr. Fay, and since.
In China, American business accepts far worse. It accepts excruciating torture of Chinese and Tibetans. It accepts slave labor officially planned as part of the cheap labor so important to Communist growth. Compared with what goes on in China, Singapore's flogging cane looks like the torch of liberty.
I know many Americans who do business in China or hunt for it. They are people of attainment -- music lovers, art collectors, politically active Democrats or Republicans, men and women who have flowered intellectually and made their fortunes under liberty.
They would perish under the kind of government their investments support. We agree on that and many other things. But they oppose any effort to use America's tariffs and trade to try, at least try, to ameliorate tyranny, as the U.S. did in the Soviet Union and South Africa.
I wonder -- would their acceptance of Chinese atrocities change if an American businessman were arrested and given the treatment that millions of Chinese and Tibetans receive in Communist prisons?
Suppose this American had his hands kept handcuffed behind his back, ratcheted so tight that he could not clean himself after using the toilet bucket in his cell?
Suppose he were tortured by electric batons? Shackled hands and legs to a board for days, with a hole cut out for defecation? Suppose he were whipped, not once, but whenever the guards wished, 30 strokes or 50?
Pages 75-77. I told a friend in business that I would send him a book in which these tortures are just a few examples. But he can get it himself from Asia Watch, 485 Fifth Avenue in New York or 1522 K Street in Washington -- "Anthems of Defeat." That way, after he reads it, he will know where to send money.
Suppose an American were arrested and put in a cell where he could neither stand straight nor lie straight. Page 82. Suppose he were sent to a forced-labor brigade quarrying or finishing marble for export goods, where prisoners are deprived of food, sent to solitary or have their sentences extended for not meeting daily production quotas. Pages 104-111.
If that happened to an American would my friends in the China trade then agree to a little U.S. economic pressure, like removing low-tariff privileges? Would they go as a group to the Chinese foreign office to protest torture and slave labor for Chinese -- or just talk about that one American?
If that is the bottom-line message from American business -- flog Asians only -- then in China, as in Singapore, it will be treated as it deserves. Contempt will be returned for contempt.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Rwanda Will Need Its Civil Servants

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I am horrified about the situation in Rwanda and Burundi. As a World Bank project officer in East Africa, I worked about six months a year for five years in Rwanda in the 1980's. The challenges are enormous: Huge population, minuscule family plots, mountainous terrain that makes for backbreaking, primitive tilling, extreme poverty, low literacy, high infant mortality. Government efforts, and our projects, were focused on helping this population survive. 
 I worked closely with the tiny group of educated civil servants in Rwanda, the handful of men and women trained at universities in Rwanda and abroad, who made things work. These are the people who could run the computers and prepare budgets, who were trained agronomists, who staffed the rural clinics, who dealt with all the crises of a country barely afloat. They were dedicated and worked hard.
I worry about the fate of the Rwandese civil servants, among them my friends and former colleagues.
The United States should find those surviving civil servants and help them leave the country safely until a working government can be re-established. If not, I fear a whole generation of Rwanda's leadership and governing capacity will be wiped out. I also urge the United Nations, with United States support, to stay in Kigali to prevent more wholesale slaughter.
 
SUSANNA BADGLEY PLACE
Milton, Mass., April 10, 1994

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The Federal Reserve is signaling that it will again raise short-term interest rates even though it sees no signs of accelerating inflation. Fed officials believe that low short-term rates have already encouraged too much lending. [Page A1.] 
 Dozens of nuclear-warhead missiles may be recycled and sold to American companies looking for launch vehicles under a proposal being considered by the Clinton Administration. Recycling rockets from the cold war arsenal is one of several ideas the Administration is considering as part of an effort to help the United States regain leadership in commercial satellite launches. [D1.]
Business inventories rose in February but were outpaced by sales, suggesting that there is room for an expansion in manufacturing. In another report, the number of Americans filing first-time claims for unemployment benefits jumped for the week. [D2.]
 
Companies
 National Medical Enterprises is said to have reached an agreement to pay $300 million to settle fraud charges. [A1.]
Ford Motor will increase its dividend and split its stock 2 for 1, in a sign of the automobile industry's strengthening recovery. [D1.]
I.B.M. plans to manufacture Cyrix's Intel-compatible chips, challenging Intel's dominance of the microprocessor market. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Brazil in an Accord With Large Banks On Cutting Its Debt

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Brazil, the largest debtor in the developing world, completed an agreement last night with its creditor banks that reduces its $49 billion foreign debt and provides the country with lower interest rates and new longer-term loans.
Although a number of new debtor countries, most notably Russia, still need to reach agreement with commercial banks on restructuring their foreign debts, the Brazilian agreement effectively ends the international debt crisis that began in 1982. 
 The crisis started with Mexico's announcement that it was no longer able to make interest or principal payments on its foreign debt, and grew as other countries followed. The problems severely strained the world's financial system and curbed economic growth in Latin America.
But since the late 1980's, when the United States led a new effort to resolve the crisis, big debtor nations inside and outside Latin America have received a reduction in their financial burdens in exchange for changes that both opened their economies and helped curb rampant inflation. The foreign investment that has been attracted in the wake of earlier debt-reduction agreements, like that in Mexico, has played a large role in the economic revival of these countries.
Approval of the Brazilian agreement came last night, bringing to an end the tortuous negotiations that began in October 1990. The agreement was announced by Rubens Ricupero, Brazil's Minister of Finance, and William R. Rhodes, vice chairman of Citibank, Brazil's biggest bank creditor.
Mr. Rhodes, who has worked with Latin America's largest debtor nations since the crisis began, was clearly pleased to declare it over.
"It's been 11, and three and a half on this one," he said, in reference to Brazil and the number of years involved. "Now we can finally say this is over."
For Brazil, the agreement will cut its outstanding foreign bank debt to commercial banks by $4 billion, to $45 billion, and reduce interest owed by another $4 billion. The agreement is crucial to Brazil's efforts to liberalize its economy, attract foreign investment and stabilize prices.
Brazil's total debt burden, including loans from banks and from other governments, totaled $121.1 billion at the end of 1992, according to the World Bank. Mexico was second with $113.4 billion, Argentina third with $67.6 billion and Poland, which reached a debt-reduction agreement with its banks in March, fourth with $48.5 billion.
The 750 creditor banks in the Brazilian agreement include some of the largest in the United States. For the banks, the incentives for an agreement were the guarantees they receive on payments of debt and interest. In addition, the accord could provide profits for some banks by increasing the value of the debt they have on their books.
The agreement may also serve as a stabilizing force in Latin America. Since the beginning of the year, rising interest rates have hammered prices of the region's outstanding debt securities, raising questions among investors about the outlook.
"Closing this agreement will favorably affect the emerging debt markets by removing a major uncertainty," Mr. Rhodes said.
The Brazilian agreement caps five years of successful negotiations with Mexico, Argentina and other debtors that began after the Bush Administration outlined a new debt policy known as the Brady Plan, named for Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady.
Under the plan, bankers were encouraged to help debtor nations reduce their burdens, while the foreign governments were required to reduce inflation and open their economies to foreign investment. Unlike other agreements, however, the accord between Brazil and its banks was completed without an approved economic program from the International Monetary Fund.
Although many bankers were initially critical of the Brady Plan, they now acknowledge its importance in solving Latin America's debt crisis.
"The architects of the Brady Plan have never been given enough credit," said John F. McGillicuddy, former chairman and chief executive of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and, later, of the Chemical Banking Corporation. "As a result of the plan, banks were able to liquefy and recover much of what we had lent out. Without the Brady Plan, the economic circumstances of the hemisphere would be quite different."
The banks recovered much, but by no means all, of the value of their loans.
According to the Institute for International Finance, commercial banks have reduced the face value of their claims on debtor countries by about $90 billion since 1985. The Brazilian deal adds to that total.
At yesterday's closing, Brazil and its banks exchanged old loans for new bonds backed by guarantees on payment of principal and interest. Among the old debts were about $31 billion in loans that had been restructured in previous, unsuccessful efforts to resolve the country's problems. In addition, Brazil received $3.8 billion in fresh loans and the banks got $5.6 billion in unpaid interest.
Even with the debt-reduction programs instituted under the Brady Plan, Latin America's outstanding debt has continued to grow and remains highly vulnerable to a sharp run-up in short-term interest rates in the United States. Yet those who were involved in working out the debt problems of the 1980's said it was unlikely that defaults could happen again soon.
"The good part of the debt crisis is that Latin American countries very generally have introduced what most people think are much more constructive policies," said Paul A. Volcker, who as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board for much of the 1980's was an important participant in debt negotiations.
One commercial banker who was involved in the Brazilian negotiations said, "You can't rule out another debt crisis altogether." But he added that the chances today were less than 10 percent.
The banker said the chances of a recurrence would increase if short-term United States interest rates rose to levels that exceeded the inflation rate by four to five percentage points. If rates reached those levels, "we would be scared," he said. Currently, the inflation rate is widely seen at about 3 percent.
But William R. Cline, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington, said, "if there is a repetition it won't be a threat to the financial system as the last one was."
He said that the banks were "much less heavily exposed in these countries than they were in 1982 and the losses they would take, as a percentage of their capital, are much, much smaller than they were in 1982."

HEADLINE: Rural Retreat Journal;
Store Closes, and a Way of Life Is Just a Memory

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RURAL RETREAT, Va., April 15

 BODY:
In a brick pharmacy in this hollow of the Blue Ridge Mountains, a former Confederate surgeon named Dr. Charles T. Pepper dispensed patent medicines in what was then fast becoming the "Cabbage Capital of the World." At least that's how the people of this hamlet saw it.
Local legend says that Dr. Pepper also spent time mixing mountain herbs, roots and seltzer into a fizzy brew, which his assistant later mass-produced. The assistant, Wade Morrison, moved to Texas and went on to fame and fortune as the creator of a best-selling American soft drink. Dr. Pepper went on to fame, but no fortune, as the brew's namesake. 
 And the pharmacy? Despite its brush with greatness, it never became a tourist draw. Instead, while electronic cash registers and computerized gas pumps infested small-town America, Rural Retreat Drug Store remained for more than 100 years an oasis where clerks read mail to unschooled neighbors, remembered birthdays and filled prescriptions on credit until a customer's Social Security check arrived.
Tonight, the pharmacy's rusty screen door screeched shut for the last time. The owners drawled "uncle," yielding to superstores and mail order catalogues. "Nowadays, if you're not big business, you're not in business," said W. Baynard Barton 3d, Rural Retreat's last pharmacist.
The nearest competitor is a dozen miles away. But the 995 residents of Rural Retreat will miss more than the convenience of a drugstore that was a gentle stroll away from Econ-o-wash, the laundromat that doubles as a public library.
Sixty-nine-year-old Nettie Sage, for example, can't make out the labels on her medicines. So the folks at the drugstore put her pills in different-colored bottles. Mrs. Sage says that over the years all she's had to do was call up and say she was "out of the blue ones," and the druggist would know she needed her "easin' pills," as she calls painkillers.
Walter Wynn, a retired farmer known to everyone as Chubeye, has routinely brought in his mail, proudly presenting it to the pharmacy manager, Shirley Hawthorne. "Got somethin' here to read, Shirl," he'd say, and she would read aloud the latest news from his brother in Maryland.
The pharmacy's owners, the Counts family of nearby Wytheville, say they were selling just 55 prescriptions a day and figured they needed 80 to stay afloat. "This place hasn't paid its bills in some time," said Mr. Barton, the pharmacist.
But then many a down-home pharmacy seems to be going the way of spittoons and scratch cooking. The number of independent pharmacies nationwide dropped from 40,000 to about 39,000 in the last two years, according to the National Association of Retail Druggists.
Todd T. Dankmyer, the group's spokesman, attributed the decline to a number of things: the restrictions that insurance companies have imposed on the pharmacies that policyholders can use, the drug manufacturers' price breaks for large vendors, and the growing popularity of mail-order drugs.
A packing box in the back of the Rural Retreat Drug Store brims with mugs painted with the names Earl, Cecil, Kermit, Emil, Ernest and the rest of the gang that used to sip coffee around the pot-bellied stove, whittling and swapping lies. "No rules, just so they didn't talk ugly when there were women," recalled Rebecca F. Heldreth, whose father, Johnny Frye, owned the store for some 40 years.
Mr. Frye turned the plank-floored shop at the corner of Main Street and Railroad Avenue into what is known as a "jot 'em down store": if an item was on a customer's shopping list, he probably stocked it.
Mr. Frye, who was also the town's Greyhound Bus agent, worked in the store for at least 11 hours every weekday, except for the times he took off to sing at a customer's funeral, his granddaughter, Dianne H. Jonas said
Mrs. Heldreth, who owns the building, figures that a general store opened on the ground floor around 1835. The town boomed when the railroad came through in 1856. James A. Ball, the historian for Dr. Pepper/Seven-Up Companies Inc. of Dallas, said Dr. Pepper bought the store around 1872 and turned it into a thriving pharmacy.
Today, Josie Gordon, a retired garment maker who grew up on a nearby farm, watched as workers removed the store's counters. At age 71, she fears that she will outlive not only the drug store but also her hometown. "If Williams Superette closes," she said, "we'll bury Rural Retreat and not put no flowers on it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Local legend holds that the soft drink Dr. Pepper was concocted in this brick drugstore in Rural Retreat, Va., more than a century ago. The beverage lives on, but the drugstore, which dispensed folksy friendliness along with prescriptions, has just closed its doors. Some townspeople fear that the closure of the Rural Retreat Drug Store will help draw to a close a fond chapter in an American way of life. (Condy Pinkston for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Policies Under Siege

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 15

 BODY:
The latest Serb offensive against the Muslim town of Gorazde is a setback for the Clinton Administration's strategy that the limited use of NATO air power would persuade the Serbs to back down on the battlefield and make peace.
Not only have the Serbs refused to return to the bargaining table, but they have also called NATO's bluff, mounting a major new offensive against the town and daring the alliance to do something about it. 
 And the American-led peace process that had looked so promising just a few weeks ago has become complicated by a new French intiative aimed at giving the Europeans more of a voice.
In the past, credible threats of NATO military force have caused the Serbs to ease pressure on Sarajevo, but this time the pinprick air strikes by a total of four planes on Sunday and Monday were apparently not credible enough.
Mr. Clinton and his national security advisers have defined NATO's mandate very narrowly, to protect the United Nations observers and refugee officials in the town, which was declared a United Nations safe haven last year.
But the Clinton Administration also expressed confidence repeatedly throughout the week that the NATO attacks would also stop the advance by the Serbs, coax them back to the peace table and persuade them to make concessions that would produce a lasting political settlement.
Just two days ago Defense Secretary William Perry said, "My expectation is that after a pause for a few days here, which seems to be going on right now, that the Serbs and the Bosnians will come back to the negotiating table."
When asked at a news briefing today about the offensive in Gorazde, Mr. Perry seemed uninformed, saying, "That's not the information I have." He acknowledged that the Serbs had "begun a whole series of actions to harass the United Nations forces," but dismissed the attacks as a prelude to a cease-fire not only in Gorazde but all of Bosnia.
At the moment, however, that rosy scenario has not unfolded.
At the State Department, the assessment was more grim than that of the Pentagon. A senior official said the Serbs had occupied strategic locations all around the city while the Bosnian Government had withdrawn some of its forces.
Despite the death of a British peacekeeper stationed in Gorazde, senior State Department officials said tonight that Lieut. Gen. Sir Michael Rose of Britain, the commander of the United Nations military in Bosnia, had not requested a NATO air strike. But in Sarajevo there were reports that General Rose had requested the use of air power to protect the observers and halt the Serbian advance but had been overruled by the senior United Nations official in the region, Yasushi Akashi.
 
Dutch Request Refused
 General Rose has been reluctant to call in new air strikes. This was demonstrated on Thursday, when he and Mr. Akashi, the United Nations special envoy, refused the request by Dutch peacekeepers at the airport near the Muslim town of Tuzla, another United Nations safe area, who asked for air strikes after the Serbs shelled a plane that had just landed.
In the days after the NATO attacks, President Clinton and his national security advisers lauded the air strikes as the way to advance a settlement acceptable to the Bosnian Government, and vowed to repeat them if the Serbs failed to get the message.
But in the last two days, Mr. Clinton has shifted signals, making clear that he has no appetite for increasing military action in Bosnia. He and his senior advisers remain convinced that too strong a response could result in a permanent collapse in the American-led peace initiative that was frozen by the Serbian offensive against Gorazde two weeks ago.
Softening his message in the face of continued Serbian attacks this week, Mr. Clinton said that NATO should not help promote the cause of any one of the combatants.
"I have to clarify, if there is any real doubt, that the United States has no interest in having NATO become involved in this war and trying to gain advantage for one side over the other," Mr. Clinton told reporters today.
 
No Softening, U.S. Says
 He added that the United States, which last year wanted to arm the Bosnian Muslims to help them wage a "fair fight," had no intention of rolling back the Serbs' territorial gains in the two-year-old war. NATO's role, he said, was "to be firm but not provocative and not try to change the military balance."
White House officials insisted that Mr. Clinton's message, delivered on Thursday and again today, did not reflect a softening of Washington's resolve to live up to the commitments made in various Security Council resolutions, but were merely aimed at rebutting Serbian charges that NATO had become a combatant in the war on the side of the Muslim-dominated Bosnian Government.
But his statements gave the impression that the United States was once again wavering on whether the Bosnian Muslims were, as Secretary of State Warren Christopher has called them, the "aggrieved party" that deserved protection.
Later in the day, the White House press secretary, Dee Dee Myers, tried to limit the damage of Mr. Clinton's remarks by expressing concern about Gorazde and warning the Serbs that "if they endanger the lives of U.N. personnel there, we stand ready to take the same action we took last week."
The tense situation in Bosnia has also badly shaken the Europeans.
 
'Equal Footing' Proposed
 The French Government has become so convinced that the war could spin out of control and that peace talks led by the American negotiator, Charles E. Redman, have reached a dead end that Foreign Minister Alain Juppe has revived a European peace initiative that envisions the gradual lifting of economic sanctions against the Serbs.
Mr. Juppe proposed in speeches before the French National Assembly and Senate this week that the United States, Russia and the European Union work on "an equal footing" to carry out the plan, and called for an international conference to discuss it.
He said it was essential to reintroduce the idea of progressive suspension of the sanctions mandated by the United Nations against the Serbs.
In a telephone call with Mr. Juppe on Thursday, Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev of Russia warmly embraced the French approach. In a phone call Tuesday, Mr. Christopher told Mr. Juppe that he found the proposal "interesting," but premature.
