HEADLINE: Tax Forms Are Done. Tax Traps Await.

BYLINE: By SARAH MAHONEY 

 BODY:
From the amateur's perspective, investing is like ice skating: try to add a little spin and you may take a tumble. Managing your money well and then stretching too far to minimize taxes is a case in point.
Having polished off their 1993 returns, many people will resolve to do everything they can to lower their tax bills next year. In some cases, they will jump headlong at tax-advantaged investments that are doomed to fail or are completely inappropriate in their financial situation. They may even blunder when deciding on a home or paying off debt by focusing solely on the highly coveted tax break. 
 "Tax saving is not a goal," said Carl Camp, a financial planner in Fullerton, Calif. "Increasing net worth is our goal, and tax saving may be a method we use to do that. But if I make tax saving a goal, I'm just going to make stupid mistakes."
In addition to losing their perspective, people often twist the words of a professional or take advice from the wrong one on tax matters.
"When they should have been talking to their financial planner or C.P.A., they were talking to an insurance salesperson or a stockbroker," said Terry Schonhoff, a financial planner with IDS Financial Services in Knoxville, Tenn.
He and other financial advisers described some common tax-inspired gaffes.
 
The too-big mortgage. You know the pitch: "it's the only write-off you've got left." Taxpayers have gotten used to hearing their accountants extol the virtue of the mortgage interest deduction. So much so that many take on a bigger mortgage than they can comfortably carry just for the tax break.
Technically, the accountant is right -- the big loan does save money in taxes. Still, many people spend considerably more on their monthly mortgage payments than they would on rent. As a result, mortgages suck up "discretionary income," or what's left after taxes and living expenses.
"Whenever I've done an analysis, the person without a mortgage has more discretionary income," said William C. Prewitt, a fee-only financial planner in Charleston, S.C. In other words, by buying a smaller house or by renting, you can invest in something more promising than real estate -- like cattle futures.
Of course, owning a home isn't a bad idea: it may appreciate in value, home ownership can be satisfying and block parties can be fun. But don't let taxes justify housing excesses.

The home-equity loan sucker. Because the interest paid on home-equity loans is deductible, people are quick to pounce on them. Used wisely, these loans may be money savers. But too often, people take out home-equity loans to invest, and don't earn a return big enough to justify it.
"If your new investment with mortgage money doesn't earn you more than the interest rate you're paying, you'll lose money," Mr. Camp said. Interest on the average home equity loan is 7.05 percent; that may be hard to beat in this market.
A similar foul-up: using home-equity loans to pay off credit cards and other debts. Theoretically, it is a great idea, Mr. Camp said, but practically, it is often the equivalent of going on a chocolate bender before starting a diet. "People wind up in twice as much debt because they run the credit cards back up," he said. "I don't recommend it unless somebody is extremely disciplined."

Insurance lemons. The life insurance industry knows that the tax deferral of annuities is an extraordinary sales tool. For some people, annuities may be a great choice. But annuities are a tremendous mistake for people not investing the maximum in a tax-deductible retirement plan, said Michael Chasnoff, president of Advanced Capital Strategies, a Cincinnati financial planning firm. "It's inherently more expensive to invest in an annuity," he said.
Similarly, the private pension plans that insurers sell are simply overfunded life insurance policies. "You are basically buying term insurance at a very noncompetitive rate, when you don't need it, just to get the tax-deferral," Mr. Chasnoff said. "Buying an insurance product without an insurance need is not a good idea."
To make matters worse, some investors park their annuities in low-yielding money-market funds. Bryan Schmitt, an academic associate at the National Endowment for Financial Education, in Denver, said: "The idea of an annuity is for money to grow tax-deferred at a faster rate. So if you keep it in a money market, you're defeating the purpose -- you're not even going to keep up with inflation and the annuity fees."

I.R.A. delusions. The greatest gift of an individual retirement account is that the money grows tax-deferred. Yet many investors do not fully grasp that they pay absolutely zero taxes until they withdraw money from these accounts. Instead, they plow retirement funds into a low-yielding tax-free investment, like municipal bonds, deluded about some additional tax benefit.
I.R.A.'s and similar accounts should be invested for the greatest potential return, at a risk that is acceptable to the owner, financial advisers said.

Landlord blues. Owning rental property, a strategy often bandied about by self-christened tax gurus, can save you money as the property depreciates. But only as long as you earn less than $100,000 and actively participate in the management of the property. Before making a down payment, estimate your annual earnings for the next few years.
"As your adjusted gross income moves from $100,000 to $150,000, you lose the possible deductibility of any losses from rental property." Mr. Schmitt said. "If you're over $150,000, none of your losses are deductible."
And often, people look to take advantage of the low-income housing tax credit, buying property in neighborhoods where they would be afraid to park their cars. "If the value of the property is going to be continuously deteriorating, you're going to incur an economic loss," he said.

Mistaken identities. If you are in the 15 percent Federal tax bracket and are considering municipal bonds or such bond funds, accept that the rich are different. You and Oprah Winfrey may have much in common, but it stops at tax strategy.
No matter how much you hate to pay taxes, "You're just going to be better off with a taxable investment that has a higher yield," said Isabelle V. Curtiss, a financial planner and certified public accountant in Middlebury, Conn.
A taxable bond paying 10 percent will give someone in the 40 percent bracket a 6 percent return after taxes, but for someone in the 15 percent bracket, the return is a much healthier 8.5 percent. The tax-free municipal bond may not do as well.

Timing mistakes. Consider the plight of the investor who spots a winning stock early and watches it rise. After eight months, he is pretty sure the stock has hit its peak. But holding the stock for a year would mean a long-term capital gain, with a maximum tax rate of 28 percent, rather than the short-term rate, as high as 39.6 percent. So he holds on to the stock, putting his entire investment at risk for months.
"You bought something because you thought the economics were good, and now all of a sudden, you think of the tax ramifications," said David Kahn, a tax partner at Goldstein Golub Kessler & Company, in New York. "That clouds your thinking. If you believe the stock has hit its potential, you should unload it."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 28; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1007 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By Laurel Graeber 

 BODY:
THE GREAT MELODY: A Thematic Biography and
Commented Anthology of Edmund Burke
By Conor Cruise O'Brien. University of Chicago, $22.50.
This 18th-century political scholar was more than a crusty conservative. The author emphasizes Burke's stance against government tyranny, stressing his role as a champion of independence for America, Ireland and India. "Mr. O'Brien has brought back a lost treasure," John Patrick Diggins said here last year. His is "a brilliant work of narrative sweep and analytic depth." 

THE COLLECTED STORIES
By John McGahern. Vintage International, $12.
The characters in this fiction are, like the author, Irish, and they are usually bound to the rural regions of their nation by poverty and hard circumstance. But they are not without imagination, and these stories illustrate their various means of escape, whether it is comic-book fantasy or the wilds of romantic love. Last year our reviewer, Josephine Humphreys, said, "Mr. McGahern, a master of the clean, plain, powerful description, is able to convey the strange phenomenon of immanence, the presence in material things of nonmaterial significance." Ireland is also the subject of three memoirs by Alice Taylor reissued by St. Martin's Press. TO SCHOOL THROUGH THE FIELDS: An Irish Country Childhood ($8.95) re-creates the author's early years as a member of a large farming family. "Ms. Taylor's book seeks to memorialize a place utterly changed by time," Patricia Hampl said here in 1990. These girlhood experiences are continued in QUENCH THE LAMP ($8.95), in which Ms. Taylor fondly recalls rural rituals and eccentric neighbors. In 1991 one critic praised "the careful and generous eye of this gifted Irish writer." THE VILLAGE ($8.95) celebrates Ms. Taylor's life in Innishannon, County Cork, where she arrived as a bride in the 1960's and where she still lives. "What makes the story unique is Taylor's disarming style; she writes as though she were sitting next to you," one critic said last year. Contemporary Ireland is the setting of THE HEATHER BLAZING, by Colm Toibin (Penguin, $9.95). Eamon Redmond, a judge, finds that his conflicts with his son and daughter mirror the dissension within the nation, where secular social principles clash with a long religious history. Last year our reviewer, Lucy McDiarmid, said that the author "writes with the vision of an enlightened Republic of Ireland still being struggled toward in the world outside fiction." Another of Ireland's authors is seeing three of her early novels reappear in print in AN EDNA O'BRIEN READER: August Is a Wicked Month, Casualties of Peace, Johnny I Hardly Knew You (Warner, $11.99). In "August Is a Wicked Month," a London journalist separated from her husband goes to the south of France, where she takes refuge in an affair and pays dearly for it. "There is some pathos in this vacation from morals," Martin Levin said here in 1965. Another wife seeks escape in "Casualties of Peace," a novel that centers on a frail sculptor and her earthy housekeeper. In 1967 our reviewer, Eleanor Dienstag, said it "pulsates with . . . racy, exuberant, nervous prose." The last novel, originally titled "I Hardly Knew You," is about the violent end of a woman's love affair with a much younger man, her son's best friend. In 1978 our reviewer, Anatole Broyard, criticized the book but praised its "talented and worldly" author: "She has always ridden the passions as if they were a magnificent horse."
BOILING POINT: Democrats, Republicans, and the
Decline of Middle-Class Prosperity
By Kevin Phillips. Harper Perennial, $13.
The majority of Americans are still reeling from the 1980's, argues the author, who demonstrates the devastating consequences of Republican tax policies and the decline in the nation's industry. Last year our reviewer, Alan Ehrenhalt, said this book is "an impressive piece of economic analysis and a troubling moral argument."
CONTENTS UNDER PRESSURE
By Edna Buchanan. Avon, $4.99.
The author, a Miami police reporter, has created an alter ego in the form of Britt Montero, a feisty journalist who is determined to find out the truth behind the death of a retired black football player. The police claim his car crashed while they were in pursuit, but Britt has other ideas. The outcome is "undeniably vivid and disturbing," Josh Rubins said here in 1992.
AFTER TET: The Bloodiest Year in Vietnam
By Ronald H. Spector. Vintage, $13.
Written by a former marine who served in Vietnam during the 12 months following the Tet offensive of 1968, this book chronicles the many misadventures of that agonizing period. Mr. Spector shows how United States foreign-policy makers exploited the young, usually working-class Americans who were thrust into the center of the war. He has also interviewed North Vietnamese, noting that their elite were also largely absent from the conflict. Last year our reviewer, Morley Safer, said, "There is a wealth of fascinating detail in 'After Tet' that will surprise both old Vietnam hands and casual readers." He added, "This is history, at its best." The often sacrificial role of American servicemen in the war is further examined in RED THUNDER, TROPIC LIGHTNING: The World of a Combat Division in Vietnam, by Eric M. Bergerud (Penguin, $11.95). The author, writing of the 25th Infantry Division, notes that the soldiers became lures to flush out the elusive enemy. Whether such a strategy would have been tolerated if the American troops had been more middle-class "is an especially unpleasant question for the reader . . . to ponder," Russell F. Weigley said here last year.
COME TO ME: Stories
By Amy Bloom. Harper Perennial, $10.
A finalist for the National Book Award, this collection concerns families in crisis, divided by death, extramarital love affairs, mental illness or simple accident. Last year our reviewer, Anne Whitehouse, said the author's "voice is sure and brisk, her language often beautiful; the result is humorous as well as heart-rending fiction."
 LAUREL GRAEBER

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
New Hotels Attest To Cuba's Reawakening

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: HAVANA

 BODY:
IT often seems that the only new buildings in this majestic but badly moldering city are its hotels.
Glass and steel high-rises reach skyward on the Malecon, Havana's curving sea-wall boulevard. Proud landmarks like El Nacional strut their newly renovated fin-de-siecle elegance. Meanwhile, along the country's generously endowed coastline, beach resorts are cropping up like mushrooms. Downtown, in the elegant Prado area, the Hotel Plaza opened recently. Farther along is the nearly finished Cohiba, and in the mostly residential seaside quarter of Miramar are the Triton and Neptune hotels. The new hotels here and elsewhere in the country are being built and managed with the participation of foreign firms. Spain's Grupo Sol and Guitart have become two of the biggest players. 
 What is more, there are guests. Scheduled flights and charters from Western Europe, Canada and Mexico pour forth affluent visitors by the thousands, leaving reservations at many of the choicest hotels hard to get during recent winter seasons.
With severe shortages and unemployment blighting the lives of many of its citizens, it is painfully evident that Cuba has not yet found a reliable economic road map in the wake of Communism's demise. But the one sure thing that the Government of Fidel Castro has determined is that fast and good money is to be earned through mass tourism.
Before 1959, Cuba was the giant of the Caribbean's tourism business, then in its infancy. Then came the Castro revolution, which, seeing the industry as a source of corruption, exploitation and debasement, all but phased it out.
It is clear now that Cuba has reawakened. Nearly 600,000 foreigners came last year, rising from a small base and surpassing pre-revolutionary visitor records after only about five years of intensive efforts.
If most Cubans must spend their days seeking to "resolver," or make ends meet, it seems that no effort is being spared to keep foreign visitors comfortable and entertained. Havana's once-famed night life again throbs with music, in laser-light discos equipped with the latest in imported sounds and technology, or in restaurants, cabarets and at hotel poolsides where top salsa acts perform Cuban hits each night.
Elsewhere, beach hotels seem to have taken their cue from Club Med and other vacation packagers. For rates that compare favorably with most of the Caribbean vacations, visitors enjoy all-inclusive stays with buffet-style meals, local excursions and activities ranging from volleyball and tennis to deep sea fishing and scuba diving.
Winter rates at the Sol Palmeras, one of the nicest of a string of new hotels on the resort peninsula of Varadero, run $120 a night for a double. In low season, the rates fall to $100.
If Cuba is hopping with visitors, largely missing from the crush are Americans. Allowed to visit Cuba, but prohibited by law from spending money in the country -- one arm of a United States embargo that has been in place for three decades -- most Americans are effectively barred from visiting.
Even this segment of the business seems to be on the rise. Although Cuban officials decline to provide data, American accents are increasingly common in the country's restaurants and on its beaches.
Most curiosity-driven embargo runners are reaching the island from Jamaica, the Dominican Republic, the Bahamas and other neighboring Caribbean countries that offer cheap excursions. Eager for dollars, the Cubans play their part in the subterfuge by abstaining from stamping passports of United States tourists as they enter and leave the country.
While Americans are still only a fraction of the total number of tourists visiting Cuba, for those who come, the island's isolation and status as one of the world's last communist states seem part of the lure.
"Ever since I was a kid I've wanted to come here," said an American engineer from Baltimore who was visiting with his wife. "It was always so forbidden, yet so close. We were anxious to see it before it changes."

HEADLINE: HOW DO TOBACCO EXECUTIVES LIVE WITH THEMSELVES?

 BODY:
On July 23, 1992, one day after my husband's death from lung cancer, I spent a good many hours trying to persuade people at The New York Times obituary department to include the sentence, "He died of lung cancer due to cigarettes." The legal department objected to these eight words. They said there was no way to prove it; but in my grief and anger, these eight words meant more to me than the list of credits and movies my husband had made. A few days later, The Times found a way, and my husband's obituary included the sentence, "He died of lung cancer, said his wife . . . who noted that he was a heavy smoker." I felt satisfied.
A few months later, after a period of deep solitude and mourning, I decided to venture out into the world and went to the gala opening of the Matisse exhibit at the Museum of Modern Art. The first thing I saw when I entered was a large sign that said the exhibit had been underwritten by Philip Morris. It felt like a fist in the face. 
 I'd been to many cultural events underwritten by Philip Morris and it had always made me feel vaguely uncomfortable, but I'd always rationalized my discomfort by thinking, "At least they're doing some good with some of their profits." Now rationalizations didn't work anymore. Your headline said it succinctly: "They spread the amazing wealth and, with it, their grim responsibility."
Yes, my husband should have quit smoking, as millions of people have. I watched him try many times -- using hypnosis, acupuncture, electronic beepers that help you cut down, even cold turkey -- but he could never stick to it. Was he just weak? No, he wasn't. He was highly disciplined, hard working and strong willed. He was also addicted to a powerful drug that he had been using since he was 12 years old, back in the good old days when the cigarette companies were allowed to tell us how good cigarettes were for us. Did he know it was harmful? Of course he did, but like millions of others he found this drug habit very hard to break and so he rationalized, too -- until it was too late.
That night, at the museum opening, I bitterly wondered out loud if the museum would have proudly displayed a sign stating that the Matisse exhibit had been underwritten by some notorious drug lord or mafioso don. My friends gently reminded me that "drugs aren't legal and cigarettes are."
At this time, it is socially, economically and emotionally convenient to rationalize the politics of cigarettes, but only until you or someone you love is forced by circumstance to walk into a crowded oncology waiting room.
 
CAROLYN MARKS BLACKWOOD
New York, N.Y.

HEADLINE: Parks in the West

 BODY:
To the Editor: Southern Utah's remarkable redrock country ("Treks to Tackle in Rugged Utah," March 20) is besieged by two forms of development. The first is mainstream economic activity: grazing, mining, dam and road construction, and (very recently) plans to import hazardous waste and to test guided missiles in remote venues.
Over the last few decades, many concerned citizens have suggested tourism as a way to halt irresponsible development, both by building a political constituency that would work against it and by providing the region with an alternative, more environmentally benign, economic base. Sadly, tourism now poses a threat in its own right. In some places, tourist-related development has compromised the very qualities of solitude and beauty that people visit the desert to find. 
 Learning about the fragile ecology of the desert, and how to minimize one's impact upon it, is vital, and I was glad one of your articles contained a sidebar on that topic. Equally important, when we use, enjoy, and come to love an area, we should give something back by accepting responsibility for its future. The most efficient way to discharge this obligation is to contribute time and money to nonprofit wilderness protection groups.
 
SANDRA K. HINCHMAN
Canton, N.Y.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/383 Madison Avenue;
New Office Tower For Midtown?

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
EVER-louder whispers are sounding in the real estate community lately: Rents are up, concession packages are down, space is getting tight. Is the real estate recession really over?
Now even those who insist that money speaks louder than words may soon have tangible proof of recovery. Howard Ronson, the British developer, has contracted to buy 383 Madison Avenue, a long-vacant old building on a wonderful site at 47th Street, for about $57 million. He plans to raze it and put up a 24-story, 800,000-square-foot multitenant office tower. The scheduled completion date is the third quarter of 1996. 
 A lot can happen between now and then to throw that schedule off, and if Mr. Ronson can't get financing, it may not even get built. But after more than five years of virtually no office-building construction, even the idea of it has created ripples of excitement.
"It'll be a pleasure to see cranes in Manhattan again," said Basil Vasilkioti, a senior managing director at the real estate firm Galbreath Riverbank.
Mr. Ronson isn't the only developer talking about new buildings. Larry Silverstein owns two sites, both on 11th Avenue in the low 40's, that have progressed from mental cold storage to back burner. And Lewis Rudin is talking to two companies about joint ventures in which Rudin Management would build and run two new buildings in Manhattan and the partner would occupy them.
Still, in neither of those cases is new money changing hands until tenants are lined up. And most developers have other problems that must be addressed first.
"We have 600,000 square feet in downtown to rent, and I must say that's uppermost in my mind right now," said Mr. Rudin.
On the surface, the tentative plans sketched out for the new 383 Madison Avenue make it look like a can't-lose proposition. It has huge, virtually column-free floors that can accommodate the trading floors and computer bullpens needed by financial services firms and communications companies. It offers twice the amount of electricity typically available in older buildings, ample round-the-clock air-conditioning, and back-up power that tenants can tap into in an emergency. And its high ceilings leave room for a lot of cables and wires.
Moreover, the location, right by what will soon become Grand Central Terminal's northern exit, offers a plethora of Manhattan amenities and an absolute dearth of large blocks of high-tech space.
"By sometime next year there will be no major blocks of space in midtown that are designed for the 21st century," said Jerry L. Cohen, vice chairman of Cushman & Wakefield. Nor will new ones quickly fill the gap, added Stephen B. Siegel, the Edward S. Gordon Company's chief executive. "With the exception of this building, no new space will come on stream before 1996," he said.
HRO International, Mr. Ronson's New York company, is banking on that shortage. "We don't have to compete with anything new," said Larry J. Wyman, head of HRO. "In a sense, we have a monopoly."
THE sticking point, as usual, is money. The existing building's foundation is reusable, with some structural bracing, so construction costs will probably be lower than for most new buildings. And HRO seems to have a good shot at getting tax breaks from the city and favorable work rules from the building-trades union -- for example, an agreement to let HRO use several shifts of workers without incurring overtime charges.
"The general attitude of the unions and of this administration is that they want to see new construction in New York," said Steven Spinola, head of the Real Estate Board of New York, who has acted as intermediary between HRO, the city and the labor leaders.
Still, people close to the project say that the building will cost at least $200 million to put up and that customizing space for tenants will probably add $50 a foot to costs.
To cover those kinds of costs, HRO will have to charge at least $52 a square foot in annual rent, a figure that can cause sticker shock in a city where space in even the finest buildings rents in the $40's.
"Tenants are just not yet ready to pass the $50 mark," said David Elovitz, senior managing director of Williams Real Estate. "But then again, six months ago you couldn't get these people to think beyond $38 or $42."
If the market continues its recovery, space in prime buildings may well be going for more than $50 a foot several years from now. But HRO needs its commitments now, and Mr. Wyman concedes that no one wants to be the first tenant to write an over-$50 lease.
Thus, the race is against the clock. HRO says it expects to take title from First Boston Corporation in early autumn. G. Ware Travelstead, once First Boston's partner in the 383 Madison site, has fought a long-running legal battle involving the use of air rights from Grand Central Terminal at the site. After lower courts found against his suit, Mr. Travelstead has taken it to the United States Supreme Court. HRO is banking that the Court will refuse to hear the appeal.
Other problems are more immediate. HRO is unlikely to have signed leases any time soon. And in today's risk-averse climate, HRO is unlikely to get financing without at least 40 percent of the building preleased.
"It's a great building in a great location, but getting a tenant will be essential to its success," said Peter L. Malkin, chairman of W & M Properties, a development firm.
Of course, Mr. Ronson could take on partners. "There's so much capital out there he could get this off the ground on a high equity deal," said Mr. Siegel of Edward S. Gordon.
And HRO itself has a clean fiscal slate. By 1991 Sanwa Bank had foreclosed on Financial Square, HRO's 1.2-million-square-foot building downtown. HRO had returned title to Broad Financial Center, its 400,000-square-foot downtown building, to the Bank of Nova Scotia. And it had sold 380 Madison Avenue, across the street from the new building.
"WE were among the first to go into workouts with lenders, and it was embarrassing," Mr. Wyman said. "But by the time 1991 ended we had gone through the pain."
Still, the building's future seems to hinge on finding tenants. Mr. Wyman has made sales presentations to more than two dozen potential tenants. And he is trotting around prospective floor plans and lobby layouts to groups of brokers as well.
Despite the building's address, its lobby is planned for Vanderbilt Avenue, in part to avoid traffic problems that can be caused by the bus lane on Madison. A second lobby can still be created on Madison Avenue to serve a large tenant that wants its name on the building. For now, the building sports the geographically nonsensical but prestigious-sounding name Park Avenue Place.
In his presentations, Mr. Wyman is making a big point of the building's economies, noting how much tenants will save by having 24-hour air-conditioning, back-up generation and the like included in the base rent.
"Overtime air-conditioning alone can rack up $7 a foot extra every year," he said.
He has converted numerous brokers. Several say they have tenants almost ready to commit to space. Not surprisingly, many of those tenants are foreign-based and are paying well over $52 a foot in Tokyo, London or other overseas financial centers.
"New York is good value to outsiders," said Cushman & Wakefield's Mr. Cohen.
But timing considerations can still squelch deals. Potential tenants who are already bursting out of their current space cannot wait several years to move. Others, whose leases are running out, could probably negotiate extensions with their landlords, but that would be predicated on a firm date for Park Avenue Place, something that anyone who has had exprience with new construction is unlikely to count on.
Even at this early stage, the timetable is causing problems. Mariyon I. Robertson, executive managing director of the real estate firm of Joseph Hilton & Associates, has an Asian client whose current lease expires next year and who is very interested in taking 160,000 square feet at Park Avenue Place.
"They might extend that lease, but they'd need a definite time that they could move," Mr. Robertson said. He is prepared to negotiate contingency plans with HRO so that the client comes out whole if the building falls behind schedule, but the issue is troublesome enough that he gives it only a "50-50 chance" that the talks will result in an actual lease.
Still, despite all the possible kinks and what-ifs, most real estate insiders think that, in the end, the building will be built.
"This is a perfect location," said Larry Silverstein, head of Silverstein Properties. "I have little doubt that you can build a first-class building there and find a large enough user to get the financing."

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 3076 words

HEADLINE: Lincoln Square: Growth and Doubts

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
SOMETIMES these days, the developer Philip E. Aarons sits in his office at Broadway and 67th Street, gazes out his fifth-floor windows and thinks of the Eiffel Tower.
Just across Broadway, and just outside his windows, Lincoln Square, his $250 million, 47-story combination of rental apartments, condominiums, seven-level health club, movie multiplex and commercial space, is nearing completion. The building has been criticized for its height, its bulk, the increased pedestrian and vehicular traffic it will bring and, most especially, for the two-tone brick in shades of burnt sienna and burnt umber with which it is clad. 
 Even some of the building's champions, who with one breath declaim how wonderful it and neighboring development will be for the West Side, with the next declare the brickwork "hideous." And Joseph B. Rose, the new City Planning Commissioner, said in an interview that the building was "out of scale with the traditional character of the Upper West Side."
But sitting in his office, his new tower looming behind him, Mr. Aarons was quick to cite the Paris landmark in coming to the defense of his edifice. "People hated the Eiffel Tower when it was first built," he said. "Now it's considered one of the great monuments of the world."
Mr. Aarons, who is in partnership with Christopher M. Jeffries in the Millennium Partners development firm, does not put Lincoln Square in the same category as M. Eiffel's structure. "But I would warn people against judging the building before it's finished," he said. "I think it is looking better all the time. I think when the entire thing is done and the scaffolding is off people will have a much more positive view."
That, of course, remains to be seen. But what is clear is that the 545-foot-tall building, as it towers above many of its high-rise neighbors, stands as a symbol for the pluses and the minuses of the major development that is occurring on the West Side of Manhattan, and specifically in what is called the Special Lincoln Square District in the area around Lincoln Center.
The development, which is unmatched these days anywhere else in New York City, includes two other Millennium buildings on neighboring sites that are to form an "urban entertainment center."
The construction has been hailed by developers and other real-estate people as the continuation of a West Side renaissance. But it has also been strongly criticized by opponents who see the increased density and potenial strain on resources it will bring with it as a serious threat to the livability of the neighborhood. The opponents warn that further development could turn Broadway into a dark valley surrounded by faceless towers and forever change the nature of West Side.
ADDING to the concern over density is the large-scale development begun or planned for the outskirts of the Lincoln Square district, including Donald Trump's huge Riverside South development from 59th to 72d Street near the West Side Highway; Manhattan West, the million-square-foot, 1,000-apartment residential complex scheduled to be completed in the summer of 1995 between 61st and 64th Streets on the west side of West End Avenue; the remodeling by Mr. Trump and his associates of the former Gulf and Western Building at Columbus Circle into a $200 million-plus luxury apartment tower, and the plans for Columbus Center across the street on the former New York Coliseum site, which are currently the subject of negotiations involving Mortimer Zuckerman, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the city.
A report prepared for Landmark West, a community organization that seeks stricter controls on development, found that 2,895 new residential units were likely to be constructed within the special district and 10,000 new residential units were likely to be built adjacent to it in the near future. "Proposed and potential development points to a massive number of units likely to be constructed at the periphery of the district," concluded the report, prepared by Buckhurst Fish Hutton Katz & Jacquemart, Manhattan urban-planning consultants.
Within the Special Lincoln Square District itself, the three projects currently under way, or about to be, are all being developed by Millennium Partners. On the Lincoln Square site, and on two neighboring ones, Mr. Aarons and his partners are putting up what he describes as an "urban entertainment center," an idea that seemed appropriate to him given the proximity to Lincoln Center and to the headquarters and studios of Capital Cities/ABC.
The three Millennium sites will contain about 540,000 square feet of commercial space, at, above and below street level, and about 600 rental or condominium apartments in the buildings' towers.
The first that will be completed, the Lincoln Square building, bounded by Broadway, Columbus Avenue, 67th and 68th Streets, will include a seven-level sports and fitness club called Reebok Gymnaseum, a Reebok store, a Coconuts music and video store, a 10-theater, five-story Loews multiplex, and the Ansonia Post Office. Mr. Aarons said the building was to open in stages, with the theaters and some apartments to be ready in early fall and the retail stores "hopefully by Christmas."
The building contains both rental and condominium apartments. The top 11 floors contain 83 condominium units, which have unobstructed park views, will be reached through a separate entrance and are to go on sale late in May. They are priced at about $700 a square foot, or more than $1 million for a 1,500-square-foot corner two-bedroom. Those apartments were sold in bulk to a partnership that includes the Zeckendorf Company, Sumitomo Real Estate Sales and Goldman, Sachs and that is to resell them as condominiums.
To enhance its looks, the Lincoln Square building will also have, on the Columbus Avenue side, a large 100- by 46-foot mural. "We are considering a number of proposals from artists," Mr. Aarons said. "It will be a commissioned fine-art piece in glass." (Mr. Aarons has denied that the artwork, which was not in the building's original plan, was a result of community complaints about the building's uninterrupted brick facade.)
The second building, one block south in what is now a large hole in the ground, will be 315 feet and about 30 stories high and will include a 60,000-square-foot Barnes and Noble superstore. It is scheduled to be completed in August 1995, with a price tag of about $100 million.
The third, on the west side of Broadway between 66th and 67th Streets, will replace the building where Mr. Aarons how has his offices and which now houses a Tower Records store and a Tower Video store. A building of 350,000 to 400,000 square feet is planned, at a cost of about $100 million, with a residential tower of no more than 30 stories above a commercial base. It is to include a new 40,000- to 50,000-square-foot Tower Records store, three times the size of the current Tower Records emporium. The building now on the site is to be demolished in early 1995, with completion of the new building scheduled for fall 1996.
THE second building is smaller than the first, and the third will be too, because of community protests over the size of the Lincoln Square building. That project is being constructed "as of right," meaning that no public hearings or special permissions were required because all aspects of it conformed to the rules of the Special Lincoln Square Zoning District.
The district, which runs from 60th to 68th Street and from Amsterdam Avenue east to the boundary of the Upper West Side-Central Park West Historic District, was created in the late 1960's specifically to encourage development in the neighborhood, with the idea that the neighborhood remain mixed-use residential, entertainment and commercial.
When some community groups realized what Millennium had wrought with the Lincoln Square building, they unsuccessfully tried to stop the project. In reaction to the community protest in an area that had seen 18 new buildings in 30 years, the city's Department of Planning earlier this year adopted new zoning regulations for the Special Lincoln Square District that limited commercial floor space and movie theaters in the northern part of the district and limited the height of buildings by requiring that 60 percent of their interior space be below 150 feet. The new rules should result in squatter new buildings about 25 to 30 stories tall.
Neighborhood organizations, however, had sought even tougher limits. Amid rhetoric comparing the ambiance of the neighborhood to the 10 plagues of Egypt, Community Board No. 7, which covers the area, voted for an outright height limit of 275 feet and a rule requiring public review of each new proposed building. That suggestion was rejected, and many neighborhood groups are still angry.
"The previous zoning led to an unexpected result," said Elizabeth Starkey, the community board chairwoman. "We woke up one day to find that the Upper West Side had become an 'urban entertainment center.' That was a great shock to everyone. It's not exactly what we had in mind. I think all of us, Lincoln Center and the various developers and owners, need to look at this together and effect some kind of change."
VICTOR CALIANDRO, an architect and a consultant to Landmark West, said the development would have an immediate impact on the sidewalks, on pedestrian congestion and on the 66th Street subway station.
"Lincoln Square, according to a Department of City Planning report, is going to be adding 41,500 person trips per day to the neighborhood," Mr. Caliandro said. "The other two Millennium buildings are going to be adding even more. You have to consider the effect of the three buildings together. And we don't even understand the impact the buildings will have on vehicle traffic in an already tremendously congested area."
Some say the problem lies in the concept of the special zoning district itself. "The thinking that created it dates from the late 1960's," said Edward C. Wallace, Landmark West's lawyer, "when there was a vision of the city as large towers and broad expanses, and a vision of unlimited growth."
"We've learned a lot since then about the nature of the city," Mr. Wallace said. "We no longer think of vast towers in superblocks and agglomerations of towers but rather buildings that are more modest, that are more known and understandable."
Mr. Wallace said that the new Millennium buildings would "overwhelm what should be the center of attention, Lincoln Center."
"It's like putting La Defense," the huge French residential and commercial high-rise complex, "in the middle of Paris rather than on the outskirts," he said.
"What's happening here is that you're compounding the errors of the past," he said. "The huge Ascap building across from Lincoln Center was never supposed to be there. There was supposed to be a mall down to Central Park. But that didn't happen, and everyone agrees that Ascap is too big in contrast to the low-rise Lincoln Center. Now it's happening again, and from a visual perspective Lincoln Center is going to be in the bottom of a valley that's darkened and closed in."
Developers and brokers, of course, disagree with Mr. Wallace's perception.
"Actually, I think it's all very positive," said Alan Rogers, managing director of Douglas Elliman, a major brokerage and management company. "From both a residential and commercial point of view the Millennium buildings will be a very good anchor, pulling everything together. It will have a positive effect on rental, retail and commercial space in the neighborhood. Things like the Reebok health club and the Barnes and Noble are very good for the quality of life in New York and wonderful amenities for the people on the West Side."
AND Nathan Leventhal, president of Lincoln Center, expressed his delight at the development. "I think the Millennium developments are perfectly appropriate and will enhance the area," Mr. Leventhal said. "This neighborhood is one of the few in the city that is seeing an enormous amount of private investment, and I don't want to do anything to discourage that concept."
In addition, he said, he certainly was "not going to complain, having built a huge tower myself." Mr. Leventhal was referring to the center's Samuel B. and David Rose Building and the privately built 45-story 3 Lincoln Center condominium that sits atop it at 66th Street and Amsterdam Avenue and was finished in 1990. The combined structure, which includes a separate 18-story dormitory for the Juilliard School and the School of American Ballet, towers 575 feet above sidewalk level and was built despite much community opposition.
But Mr. Leventhal added that when it came to future development, he felt that "a more coherent" plan was needed. "Additional thought needs to be given as to whether there should be future rules on how much more development the area can absorb and at what further restrictions might be appropriate," he said.
Mr. Rose, the Planning Commissioner, said that as far as future construction was concerned, there were "real issues in terms of transportation capacity and sewage capacity," specifically the ability of the North River Sewage Treatment Plant to handle a large increase in load. He said he was committed to "look at the issue of whether a broader area of the Upper West Side does warrant rezoning."
But he said he suspected "there may well be the capacity for additional density" and that in terms of the special district, he was "not inclined" to "move to a further downzoning of an area that was just rezoned."
The traffic in the neighborhood, especially at 8 o'clock curtain time, has always been congested, and concern has been expressed that the new moviehouses and health club will make things worse. As part of the zoning change, the Planning Department agreed to begin a traffic study of the neighborhood this month.
Kevin Davitt, a department spokesman, said that financing had been obtained for the study and estimated it would take three to six months to complete it.
MR. AARONS of Millennium said that he did not believe the increase in pedestrian or vehicular traffic would be damaging. "I don't think we will be in a position where we will make conditions considerably worse," he said. "I think the amenities the building will provide will absolutely offset any negatives."
In addition, he said, the Transit Authority is planning to upgrade the 66th Street subway station on the Nos. 1 and 9 lines and add additional exits to help handle any increase.
Mr. Aarons added that the fact that movie theaters and not legitimate theaters were involved would help ameliorate any problems. "Unlike Lincoln Center, where everything has to start at 8, movies have a great deal of timing flexibility," he said. "And in terms of pedestrian congestion, the theaters will have the most extensive interior waiting areas of any complex in the city."
The ticket selling lines, he said, "are way inside, and the waiting areas are upstairs."
"There will be a lot to do and a lot to see, so that people won't be hanging around on the sidewalks queuing up to buy a ticket or queuing up to get in," he said. "There will be a bookstore and a music store, so even if you get there an hour and a half early you're not going to be waiting with nothing to do. You're going to go into the bookstore or the music store. It's part of our thinking to keep people inside and active."
As part of its rezoning study, the Planning Department identified other sites in the Lincoln Square zoning district it felt were "soft," or ripe for development. These included the area by the Regency Theater, on the west side of Broadway at 67th Street; an ABC site on 66th Street between Columbus and Central Park West; the Saloon restaurant site on the east side of Broadway between 64th and 65th Streets, and the Mayflower Hotel and the empty lot behind it, from Central Park West to Broadway from 61st to 62d Street.
None of these sites, brokers and developers said, are likely to be developed immediately. Mr. Aarons said he was not interested in developing any of them. "Our activities are largely finished with the three-building complex we're planning," he said. "I think that's enough for one neighborhood."
Michele de Milly, a spokeswoman for the Park Summit Realty Corporation, owner of the Mayflower and its empty lot, said that "there is no specific intention at this time" to develop the site, although thought was certainly being given to the idea.
Ms. de Milly said, however, that the rezoning of the district had probably increased the possibility of something's being done sooner rather than later. The architect Cesar Pelli and his office are "looking at what potentially might go there," she said, with the notion of creating "a mixed-use commercial and hotel project."
"It's really years away," she said. "Though we used to talk about 5 or 10 years and now it's closer to the five-year frame for the project to come to reality."
THE idea, she said, is to take a look at what else is happening in the immediate vicinity. "With a slow economic turnaround over the next several years, that site might be very ripe for development," she said.
The question of development on the West Side, and specifically in the Lincoln Square district, is likely to remain a contentious one.
"Over the long term," said Arlene Simon, president of Landmark West, "what it is about is the quality of life. Quality of life is worth something, and you lose so much by destroying it. And it is also about being a good neighbor. A good neighbor enhances the location, and real estate, after all, is location."
Mr. Aarons said that he understood the criticism, that it came with the mixed-use nature of the territory. "By definition, the mixed use is going to create some level of conflict between the various components," he said. "When ABC wanted to expand, the neighbors complained. When Lincoln Center wanted to put up its new building, the neighborhood complained. It's all part of the diversity, of having different people with different views. We shouldn't be surprised when the people who live on 67th Street say the Lincoln Square building's too tall. I understand that."
He understands, but he does not agree. In fact, he even said he liked the brick. "But," he added with a laugh, "we have selected a totally different type of brick for the next building."

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

'LA FRONTERA' EXHIBIT
The Neuberger Museum at Purchase College has turned to the Mexican border as the source of its new exhibition: "La Frontera/The Border: Art About the Mexico-United States Border Experience." It opens today and runs through June 26 for its only East Coast showing. 
 Drawn across 1,952 miles, the border has been as much a ribbon of violence and aggression as a symbol of two cultures meeting and mixing. It is that intersection of cultural, historical and political movements that this exhibition seeks to portray.
The work of 35 artists has been mounted with the cooperation of the Centro Cultural de la Raza and the Museum of Contemporary Art in San Diego.
It includes painting, sculpture, photography, mixed media, drawings, installations and video art. Images of Tiajuana night life, political statements on the state of border hostilities, daily life, awesome landscapes and touching portraits will find their mark.
In conjunction with the exhibition, the museum has begun assembling personal stories by people who immigrated to the United States or who can relate the experiences of others. A team consisting of the Westchester Hispanic Coalition, La Casa del Pueblo and El Centro Hispano is collecting the stories in the New York City and southern Connecticut areas.
The results will be published in English and Spanish by the college's Center for Editions and Clifton Meador and titled "Border Stories," available for purchase by June 12, when the museum will hold a Community Day celebration. Although the time for submitting stories is limited, those wishing to participate should call 948-8466.
The exhibition can be seen Tuesdays through Fridays from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. and Saturdays and Sundays from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is by donation, and the number for museum information is 251-6100.
 
'OLDER AND BETTER'
 Dr. Joyce Brothers, the psychologist whose buoyant personality has earned her a niche in the media, will be the keynote speaker at the 18th yearly Aging Awareness Day at Westchester Community College in Valhalla on Wednesday.
She will speak on "Celebrating Life: Older and Better" at 9:30 A.M. after a registration period beginning at 8:45.
Later a panel discussion with Janet T. Langsam, executive director of the Westchester Arts Council, Christine Mastrangelo, chairwoman of the college's department of finance and computer information services, and other members of the college staff will deal with the subject of lifelong learning.
Afternoon workshops will focus on resources and services for caregivers, the family in dramatic literature, health and wellness, getting a center for the elderly started and other subjects of interest to older men and women. For free reservations, call 785-6793. Reservations may also be made for a buffet lunch at $10.
 
DINOSAUR FOLLIES
 Huge puppets named Willie Mammoth, Smiley the Saber-Toothed Tiger, Bessie the 22-foot Apatosaurus, Tony and Trixie Triceratops and 20 or so additional characters will cavort in "The Mammoth Dinosaur Follies" at the Tarrytown Music Hall today at 2 P.M.
As the latest creations of Lois Bohovesky's Hudson Vagabond Puppet Company, the creatures in this musical extravaganza explore the complexity of life in prehistoric times with amusing dialogue, song and choreography that tests the strength of the floor. The 14--year-old troupe is known for its unusual and unusually large puppets and its imaginative scenarios.
Tickets, thanks to a grant from the Nynex Corporation, are only $3.50. Call 359-1144 for reservations. The theater is at 13 Main Street.
 
RUNNING FOR THE Y
 The sixth yearly Rye Derby, a five-mile road race, steps off today at 1:30 P.M. from the corner of Purchase Street and Theodore Fremd Avenue, ending at the Rye Y.M.C.A., 21 Locust Avenue. A one-mile family run begins at 1 P.M. at the Y.
Winners in nine categories will share $1,500 in prize money, and first finishers will also receive inscribed trophies of silver and crystal.
Registration will be held at the Y from 10 A.M. to 12:30 P.M., with entrants in the five-mile race paying a fee of $14, while running the one-miler costs $8. Rye Derby ribbons will be awarded to the one-mile winners.
Awards will be presented by Eamon Coghlan, who broke the Masters four-minute mile in Boston in February, finishing at 3:56.5. He will lead off the five-mile race. Proceeds will help finance the Y's children's programs. For more information, call 967-6363.
 
LITERARY LUNCH
 Three notable writers will preview their latest work at the Westchester Library System's Book and Author Luncheon on Tuesday from noon to 2 P.M. at the Tarrytown Hilton.
Murray Kempton, a 1985 Pulitzer Prize winner for commentary, has spent 40 years as a newspaperman and written nearly 10,000 columns, formerly for The New York Post and now for New York Newsday. His new book, "Rebellions, Perversities and Main Events," due this month from Times Books, will be the subject of his talk.
Mary Higgins Clark's "Remember Me," a suspense novel set on Cape Cod, will be published next month by Simon & Schuster, joining the 25 million copies of her books in print in the United States alone. Her popular mystery novels, some of which have been made into movies and television dramas, include "A Stranger Is Watching" and "Where Are the Children?"
The third speaker will be Hilma Wolitzer, whose "Tunnel of Love" is being readied for publication next month by HarperCollins. Ms. Wolitzer writes about human relationships, and her books have been Literary Guild and Book-of-the-Month Club selections.
Tickets at $35 can be reserved by calling 592-8214. Tickets at $50 include a copy of "Reading Rooms," an anthology of works by prominent American writers.
 
FISHING WISELY
 Ecological preservation and the rainbow and brown trout fishing potential of the Neversink River might seem like contradictory topics, but Robert Ewald, proprietor of the fly shop on the Eosopus River, will present a slide lecture on how the two issues can be joined. Speaking before the Croton Watershed Chapter of Trout Unlimited on Tuesday at 7:30 P.M., he will discuss access to the river, little-known fishing spots and newly acquired property, which the state can use to improve and maintain water quality and fishing stock.
Trout Unlimited, a national nonprofit organization, is dedicated to the preservation of natural resources, which in turn permits ecologically sound fishing practices to flourish.
Regular monthly meetings, including this one, are held at the Fox Lane Middle School on Route 172 in Mount Kisco. Visitors are welcome free of charge. For more information about the lecture and the organization, call 666-5727.
 
A SECURITY THREAT?
 Peter G. Peterson, Secretary of Commerce during the Nixon Administration and now chairman of the Blackstone Group, a private investment bank based in Manhattan, will speak before a joint meeting of the Forum for World Affairs and the World Trade Club of Westchester on Wednesday at 7 P.M. His subject will be "Economic Weakness as a National Security Threat: Redefining the National Security Agenda."
The event will be held at the Thornwood Conference Center, at 500 Columbus Avenue, beginning with cocktails at 6:15 P.M., followed by the lecture and a question-and-answer period and ending with coffee and dessert at 8 P.M. It is open to the public for a fee of $20. Reservations can be made by calling the Forum office in Stamford at (203) 356-0340. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
In a Cliffhanger, A Junk Deal Is Finally Sold

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
SOMETIMES one troubled deal can take on almost mythical proportions on Wall Street, as onlookers gather to see whether buyers can be found at any price. So it was in the junk bond market the last few weeks, as a big West Coast drugstore merger appeared in jeopardy as investors balked.
Finally, the deal was done last week, bringing a sigh of relief. "It says the high-yield market is still alive," said Max Holmes, the junk bond strategist at Salomon Brothers. "This was a very tough deal." 
 It was tough because Thrifty Drug Stores, which is buying the Payless chain from Kmart, is run by Leonard Green, a leveraged buyout artist with a mixed record and some resentful bond holders. And it was tough because the junk bond market has been tumbling, a victim of the general bond market selloff. Underwriters led by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette had to push interest rates on the bonds as high as 12 1/4 percent and throw in stock in the company.
The Thrifty-Payless deal says a lot about the state of the junk bond market. In one way, it is reminiscent of the highly speculative deals of the late 1980's. Mr. Green and investors in his fund bought Thrifty less than two years ago for $50 million in cash from Pacific Enterprises, a California gas utility that had made a bad diversification move. As part of last week's financing Mr. Green and friends are taking out $88 million in cash, meaning they have a clear cash profit long before it is clear whether or not they have turned around the business.
On the other hand, the finances of Thrifty-Payless are not nearly as bad as in some of the old deals that gave junk a bad name in the late-1980's. That this deal was a hard sell is indicative of the fact that the rankest speculation in the 1990's, unlike the prior decade, has not been in giving credit to dubious risks.
Instead, that speculation has taken the form of bets that the bull markets in stocks and bonds will continue indefinitely. That is the significance of Procter & Gamble's embarrassment, in which the fact it used derivatives for its speculation is less significant than the fact company officials evidently saw little risk in betting that interest rates would not rise sharply either here or in Germany. And it is the significance of the fact that Northwest Airlines was able to sell stock to the public but had to withdraw its planned companion offering of junk bonds.
Mr. Green, once a partner in Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen, has a mixed record in retailing. One supermarket buyout he sponsored, of Almac's in Rhode Island, is bankrupt. Another, Kash N' Karry in Florida, is in trouble and has cut back on inventory purchases to conserve cash.
That scared off some buyers, but the biggest problem was that junk mutual funds are running out of cash due to redemptions. Fortunately, these seem to have eased. But if they resume, funds will have to start selling bonds when other funds are not buying, a decision that could push prices down sharply until other buyers appear. But for now, the market has survived Thrifty-Payless, and that is cause for relief.

HEADLINE: Business Diary: April 10-15

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring 

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
In the Great Tobacco War, The Generals Go to the Front Lines
Battles have long raged in the trenches -- in offices, restaurants and hospitals, in tirades by lobbyists and activists. And last week, the pitch rising daily, the generals themselves faced off. The subject was tobacco. Industry leaders had come to Capitol Hill to answer charges of manipulating nicotine levels to fine-tune smokers' addiction. Yes, they said, nicotine levels change, but that's to enhance flavor. Is smoking addictive? A chorus of "no"s. Does it cause lung cancer? "It may," said James Johnston of R.J. Reynolds. But Andrew Tisch of Lorillard said, "I do not believe that." At one point Mr. Johnston lashed out, "If cigarettes are too dangerous to be sold, then ban them." Next to the executives, their host, Representative Henry Waxman, had placed a placard that read, "One American dies every 80 seconds from tobacco use." If so, then 270 died in the hearing's six hours. 

Small but Shocking Health Crisis
The charges leveled against National Medical Enterprises were so appalling that, by comparison, the rest of the health care system just seemed to have a bad cold: that it held psychiatric patients against their will until their insurance ran out, that it got patients by giving kickbacks to doctors. Last week the company, flooded with lawsuits, tried to get on with its life, but given the grisly nature of the charges, it cost plenty: a reported $300 million-plus. That would be the largest settlement ever between the Government and a health care provider. Now all it has to do is persuade patients that its primary concern is their bodies and minds, not their money.
 
Not Good Enough at Motorola
Sometimes investors aren't satisfied with anything short of miracles. Last week Motorola reported quarterly earnings up nearly 50 percent, but the stock market -- conditioned by analysts' even-rosier predictions -- wanted more. In what one analyst called "a crisis of expectations," the stock plunged and kept falling all week, ending at $89.875, down from $106 at the beginning of the week.
 
Storming Intel's Fortress
Intel has long dominated a lucrative market -- microprocessors that do the thinking for personal computers. It also once had a powerful ally in I.B.M., but in January I.B.M. ended the 13-year pact, deciding not to make Intel's latest chip, the Pentium. And last week Intel got another blow when I.B.M. teamed up with Cyrix to make Intel-compatible chips. This "could well be Intel's worst nightmare," one observer said, and Intel's stock took a beating, while Cyrix's shares shot up. For consumers, all this competition for the mighty Intel could well mean lower prices.
 
Ford Shares the Wealth
At least one American auto maker is sharing the spoils. Last week Ford raised its quarterly dividend to 45 cents, from 40 (it's payable June 1 to holders as of May 2). And to pound in the point that it's feeling downright jolly about the future, it also said it would split its stock, 2 for 1, in July. Ford must have been in the mood for a spring tidying-up, for it also announced the sale of First Nationwide, its troubled savings and loan, and the purchase of the last 26 percent of Hertz. So, now that Ford will be paying a 3.09 percent dividend, perhaps Chrysler (1.57 percent) and General Motors (1.37) will cough up a bit more.
 
Diapers and Finance Don't Mix
Maybe this is the true danger of those fancy financial bets. Mysterious traders with powerful computers juggle billions as if they were puzzle pieces, and eventually mere mortals want to play too. Last week Procter & Gamble said it had taken a $102 million hit on a high-risk interest-rate bet gone sour. But what was a staid corporate treasurer doing mixing diapers with exotic investing? Not clear. But the treasurer has been replaced, and P.& G. is considering legal action against Bankers Trust -- the bank it worked with -- though Bankers Trust denies being at fault.
 
ECONOMY
 
Fed Fights to Stay in 'Neutral'
The Federal Reserve doesn't want inflation any more than the rest of us. It wants an economy firmly in "neutral," which it defines as annual growth a shade under 3 percent -- no more, no less. Its message now: we had it too good with those rock-bottom interest rates -- they got things hopping a bit too fast. So, yet again, it may have to nudge short-term rates higher -- even though it spies no inflation. And, no, there's none to be seen, with the newest evidence being a report that consumer prices in March rose just 0.3 percent.
 
Mr. Soros Goes to Washington
Yes, the House panel said it wanted to talk to George Soros last week out of concern that hedge funds disrupt markets. But let's be honest: Lawmakers like to be on top of things, and they couldn't make head nor tail of these odd funds. The underpaid public servants clearly wanted a glimpse of a man who could roll the dice on global currencies, lose $600 million in a shot and live to bet a billion another day. Mr. Soros was glad to oblige. But did all become clear? Not likely. What, they asked, is a hedge fund anyway? "The term is applied so indiscriminately," Mr. Soros said, "that it covers a wide range of activities." Should we worry? "I don't think hedge funds are a matter of concern." Class dismissed.
 
Los Angeles, Back in the Saddle
California is a land of extremes -- great sun, awful air, soaring peaks, nasty disasters. And the nation's busiest freeway, the Santa Monica, which reopened last week, a remarkable 84 days after toppling in January's earthquake. But even as gleeful drivers resumed their crawl, word came that, well, the road could be safer and some patching would be done. But one thing's clear: the state's economy is bouncing back -- partly because the quake brought a boom in construction jobs.
 
Act of God, or of the L.I.R.R.?
We've got no one to blame but nature for this winter's trial by snow, right? Wrong, says a report out last week blasting the Long Island Rail Road. On Feb. 11, said the report by the M.T.A.'s Inspector General, the railroad seemed to do everything wrong as a foot of snow fell: it ignored forecasts, let trains get trapped, even told passengers there'd be buses -- but forgot to order buses. Finally, the railroad sputtered to a halt. The report raised the possibility of dismissing the railroad's president, but the M.T.A.'s head called the shutdown "an isolated incident." Metro-North, though, ran just fine during the storm.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
After 7 Years, a Trade Pact
Believe it or not, those endless GATT talks came to an official end last week when 109 nations signed a broad pact on world trade. The projections are stunning: an average 40 percent cut in tariffs, a $235 billion increase in annual global income. But even as GATT gives way to a World Trade Organization, there's unfinished business. Al Gore wants to link trade to environmental protection, and there's always the issue of where China fits in. This subject's never really closed.
 
On the Lam in Germany
When American developers overextend themselves, they tend to hire lawyers and to bully creditors into digging them out. In Germany, a big developer has found a simpler solution: disappear. When the news broke that Jurgen Schneider had vanished a week ago, his empire, with dozens of unfinished projects throughout Germany and billions in debts, ground to a halt, sending stocks down sharply. Mr. Schneider was roundly blasted, as even his father said, "My son is a coward." Where is he now? "He told me he was going to Tuscany," one colleague said. "I assume that means he is definitely not in Tuscany."
 
Tigers and Rhinos and Sanctions: Getting Tough With Taiwan
At the turn of the century, roughly 100,000 tigers roamed the world; now there are fewer than 6,000. In 1970, there were 65,000 African black rhinoceroses; now there are about 10,000 rhinos of all types. Where have they gone? For one thing, it's common in Asia to grind their bones for medicines and aphrodisiacs, and Taiwan, for one, does a thriving business in the bones. But those statistics alarmed the Clinton Administration, and last week it imposed trade sanctions on Taiwan for its deeds, though a tiny $25 million of its $25 billion trade with the United States is affected.
