HEADLINE: Mission of Hope -- A special report.;
Poverty Raises Stakes for Catholic School

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
For all the risky places Brother Paul Beaudin passes each morning in East Harlem, none holds as many uncertainties, as many gambles, as his destination: a grammar school.
He could discover that crack addicts have once again pried open the windows at St. Francis de Sales & St. Lucy Academy and made off with what little audio-visual equipment remains. He could find that the boiler has given out, and stare again at the numbers in his budget. Or, as is usual a few times a week, he could be told that a teacher will be absent. 
 So Brother Paul, the principal, will again forgo hiring a substitute and go to the blackboard himself. There he faces perhaps his greatest risk: shaping the minds and values of a troubled community's youth in the hope that they will reshape their own world.
And, as he discovered during an eighth-grade religion class in a discussion of free will, the worries of this world are never too far from the promises of the next. Inside the classroom, whose windows framed a morning landscape of housing projects and vacant lots, Christina Rivera pondered a hypothetical question far removed from the logic-twisting riddles familiar to Catholics of another age. She wondered what happened when wills collided.
"If someone points a gun at your head," Christina asked, "do you still have free will?"
Brother Paul asked the two dozen students how many of them had seen a gun in their neighborhood. All raised their hands. How many had seen someone shot? Most hands stayed raised. How many of them were related to someone who had been shot?
A quizzical voice piped up from the sleepy-eyed crowd.
"A victim or a suspect?"
Brother Paul improvised a homework assignment on the spot: discuss free will and the freedom of choices that really exist in the neighborhood.
The students wrote it down and toted it home, past the brick walls occasionally painted over with the words "Rest In Peace."
Parents in many poor neighborhoods say Roman Catholic schools are the only alternative to the public schools, which may offer some novel programs but cannot give their children a sense of safety or belonging. While studies show inner-city Catholic schools have the best academic results with impoverished minority children, parents say they care just as much about the education in values.
Catholic educators admit they do not reach the poorest of the poor -- tuition exceeds $1,000 a year, and scholarships are limited -- but their students live in the same housing projects, face the same challenges and have the same problems as their public school counterparts.
Perhaps because of the similarities between both sets of families, Catholic educators find themselves struggling to keep their schools afloat. Aging buildings and shrinking diocesan subsidies have forced schools to raise funds creatively.
But some educators see the lack of money as a boon. Alicia Vazquez, a second-grade teacher, calls the school "the little house on the prairie," disciplined and no-frills, dictated as much by resources as by pedagogy. The school is its own little world, where the principal knows each child's name and family and where teachers grew up nearby.
For Brother Paul, a member of the Confraternity of Christian Brothers, which has educated generations of the area's children, recent decisions have been difficult. Over the last two years Brother Paul, whose flowing black cassock accents his slender build and stern demeanor, has merged two financially troubled schools, rearranging classes, expanding preschool and after-school programs while increasing parental accountability and developing an "academy" that stresses math and science. He says that while his school's future, and the neighborhood's, are far from assured, he would rather gamble and lose than do nothing and vanish.
So when he looks at the children who walk past blocks of drug dealers, arriving from broken homes or families struggling mightily to get by, he sees his school as an incubator of hope for them and their community.
"I encourage my teachers to expect great things of every child," he said. "Our mission in these urban schools is that we have some sense of social responsibility and invest in people and places that are there."
 
Needs
Schools and Pupils Face Hard Times
 The European immigrants who were in East Harlem decades ago, in brick walkups overflowing with children, have been replaced by black and Hispanic families facing an economy and neighborhood that are even less accommodating. Among the few constants are their churches and schools, well-trodden paths to American middle-class life.
This continuity came at a cost, as many inner-city parishes battle shrinking resources, crumbling buildings and a decline in religious vocations.
The urgency felt by many Catholic educators soon dominated Brother Paul's thinking after he was appointed principal of St. Lucy's two years ago, inheriting a school with dwindling enrollment in its early grades and the threat of being closed.
One problem, Brother Paul said, is that working parents want preschool classes and after-school programs. Hoping that a preschool would feed pupils into later grades and an after-school program would increase revenue, he asked the Archdiocese to let him take over St. Francis de Sales, a school on East 97th Street operating below capacity.
Last September, the merged school opened with 16 lay teachers and 4 members of orders, teaching some 460 students, about 60 more than before. The student body reflects the neighborhood: about two-thirds are Hispanic, with about one third black and a smattering of Asian and white children. One-third are not Catholic. More than half come from single-parent homes or are being reared by grandparents, with 60 families on welfare.
Despite the social conditions, Brother Paul said he refused to feel sorry for the children or expect any less of them.
"We're not social workers," he said during a break in classes recently. "We empathize with the plight of the kids, but we don't waste class time. We don't have encounter groups and we don't say, 'It's a shame, these poor Hispanic and black kids from the inner city,' because in the end, we'd be ignoring their education and give them nothing."
 
Methods
Few Frills Or Excuses
 Father Francis Amodio weaved through the narrow rows of desks in his fifth-grade classroom, which he and his 25 students jokingly call the penthouse, not just because it is on the top floor.
"We're high class," the students giggled, including Melissa Vega, a 10-year-old with sparkling eyes that peeked out from her dark bangs. A voracious reader, she is one of the school's two spelling bee champions.
Her day is spent in the "penthouse," where Father Francis teaches them everything from religion to mathematics during the nonstop school day. He relies on few frills, save for an overhead projector and an occasional religious videotape for sing-alongs. But he pushes his students, using sixth-grade reading texts and advanced math.
"It's a lot of fun," Melissa said one morning as her mother dropped her off at school. "A lot of work. The teacher is really nice. Father Francis is funny and creative."
Her mother, Lisa, nodded in agreement.
"You should see some of the stuff he's doing with them," Mrs. Vega said. Last year, she said, Melissa tested at a ninth-grade reading level.
 
An Eye to the Future
 Brother Paul said the emphasis on advanced material, especially in the upper grades, was done with an eye to the future. "In junior high school you set them on a track," he said. "You give them that so they go to high school a little more confident than the kids who are not from an academic background."
Compared with public school students in their area, pupils at St. Lucy's scored mostly higher on state-mandated measures of minimum competence in reading and math, with public schools outdistancing them in social studies. Similar results were found at St. Francis de Sales last year, when it was run by a different administrator.
The school's own analysis indicated that three-quarters of the students at St. Lucy's were at or above grade level in math, and that on average, students in grades 5 through 8 were one and a half to three and a half years ahead of their grade level in language skills.
"They're very educated, intelligent and motivated for learning," said Father Francis. "People think because they're Hispanic they can only learn some of it. That's racist. They can learn as much as any other kid."
Father Francis conceded that some days the pace is wearying and long. Many of his students look forward to staying late, asking him if he needs help with classroom chores.
During a mathematics class, as the children scribbled out the solutions to multiplication problems, a steady stream of students went up to him to ask a simple question or just to show their answers.
"They want you to be with them, listen to them because they have no one to listen to them," he said.
 
Alternatives
Escaping Bullying Of Public Schools
 For some students and their parents, it's what doesn't happen that matters. Jason Medina, an elfin 10-year-old who transferred from a public school two years ago, said he no longer had to worry about bullies.
"At public school, every day after school you go outside wanting to go home happy but you had to witness fights going on for no good reasons," he said. "At lunch you'd see everybody stepping into each other's face."
His mother, Helen Medina, said the chaos she saw in her son's public school was a big reason for enrolling Jason -- as well as his brother, Daniel, and sister, Diana -- in Brother Paul's school. "When they stepped out of the school there was no control," she said. "Here, you see Brother Paul outside the school, controlling it. There's a fact that you can't get away with things here that they do in public school."
Just as important to her was her opposition to the New York City Board of Education's "Rainbow Curriculum," which included teaching tolerance of alternative family types, including homosexual parents.
"What they were going to expose them to, at their age they're not ready," she said.
There is almost an obsessive orderliness to the school, where boys and girls line up separately to descend the stairs to the cafeteria in near total silence. When the murmuring reaches a certain level, a teacher will stop, stare and, with nary a word, the children will go silent.
 
'I'm a Project Girl'
 Zoraida Hernandez, an eighth-grade teacher who grew up in one of the housing projects in the neighborhood, says she makes it clear that she knows all the tricks. "I'm a project girl," she reminds them. "I didn't get away with it, and neither will you."
With a booming, rapid-fire delivery, she calms down her class with a sly joke or a quiet word, patterning her approach after the brothers and nuns who taught her as a child. So strong was their influence on her life, she keeps a few tiny snapshots of them near her desk.
"They had compassion and never made me feel like I was a poor person," she said. "You don't put them down. You tell them they can do better and are better, and that you don't expect them to act like that."
The school prohibits corporal punishment -- even the threat of it -- and stresses discipline that does not heighten tensions.
"These children have to be handled gently," said Brother Jude Catalano, the dean of discipline. "Yelling, screaming and confrontation are not going to work. We have to learn to defuse."
It doesn't always work, Brother Paul acknowledged. He has had to expel some half a dozen students this year for infractions that ranged from cursing at a teacher to being caught in school with a box cutter. All but one, who was learning disabled, were sent to other Catholic schools nearby.
"Every kid," he said, "deserves a second chance."
 
Subsidies May Run Out
 Whether his school has a chance of survival remains to be seen. At the current tuition of $1,250 per student and actual costs at $2,000 per student, he needs to raise enrollment by 90 pupils to break even. Two businessman have been enlisted as patrons, and he plans to use their donations to upgrade the dimly-lighted cafeteria. The Archdiocese makes up the rest of the shortfall, but these subsidies may be eliminated soon.
Salaries are low: he and four teachers from his religious order are paid only $15,000 annually. The 16 other teachers, all lay, receive salaries starting at $23,000 on average.
Finances and fund raising are never far from his mind. One day last year, a parent tipped him off that some crack dealers in the park were selling bookbags with the school's name. He strode to the park, realized that someone had stolen several dozen book bags and flagged down a police car.
Although riled, he grew even angrier when he learned the dealers were selling the bags for $2 apiece. "They were $8 bags," he said. "You could have made six more dollars."
 
A Difficult Choice
 While he could raise the tuition, he knows that such a move would put the school even further out of reach for parents who hold down two jobs. It is a difficult choice for someone who entered the religious life to teach the poor.
Attracting more members to his order is unlikely considering the dwindling number of vocations since the 1960's and a steady drifting away from teaching.
Crayon-colored flame-shaped cutouts dangled from the light fixtures in Brother Joseph Payne's first-grade classroom. Each one bore words like "joy" and "courage," representing each child's request for a gift of the Holy Spirit. A flame inscribed with "faithfulness" dangles near the blackboard, close to Brother Payne.
"I need to be faithful to my call," he said. "I know I want to be a brother. But there are times when I want to stop."
Nearly all the men who entered the religious life with him have since left. Some have married; others found themselves unsuited to the rigors of life among the poor. Some orders have pulled out of inner-city schools, focusing on better-off suburban parishes. Such an option is unthinkable to Brother Payne.
"I don't want us to die," he said. "But if we're going to die, we die with dignity. I don't want us to go out clawing. We die with the poor, if we're going to die."
 
Advancement
A Flat Promise: 'I'll Get You In'
 With broad smiles and nervous titters, dozens of students huddled around Brother Paul in the cafeteria one recent morning, each one clutching letters of acceptance -- or rejection -- from Catholic high schools based on the citywide Cooperative Entrance Exam. Each student is expected to apply to three schools, and most are accepted by at least one.
"I want to take it and put it on my wall," said Nicole Graham, waving her acceptance letter to St. John's Prep in Astoria. "Every night I'll look at it. I made it this far."
The students also take the test for the city's selective public high schools, and a few are accepted. But teachers discourage them from applying to most public high schools.
"We don't let them go to any old school," said Mrs. Hernandez. "There's nothing going on there. No discipline, no teaching going on. The teachers are too busy dealing with the unruly characters in class."
The eighth graders returned to their classrooms, and Brother Paul sat in the empty cafeteria and scanned his notes. In neat script he kept a list of acceptances and rejections, noting which high schools to call later to plead a special case. Each child, he insisted, will get into a Catholic high school.
Quietly, a sad-faced girl trudged into the cafeteria, her eyes moist. She had been rejected by her three schools.
"Don't cry," Brother Paul softly counseled. "It's one of those things; you don't test well. How's your mother feeling? She still going through chemo?"
He read the rejection letters.
"Keep this to yourself," he said, writing down the school names. "If your friends ask you, you were accepted to all three schools. What's your first choice?"
She told him.
"I'll get you in," he said. "I don't want you to be upset."
She walked away.
Brother Paul soon followed, slipping into his office with his list.
There were calls to be made.

HEADLINE: Connecticut: Testing Ground For Communications Future

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, April 15

 BODY:
Connecticut, home of the nation's first telephone switchboard 116 years ago, is about to become a laboratory again for innovation and competition in communications.
A combination of forces is at work, some driven by technology, some by the politics of economic development and some by the odd quirks of how the old Bell system broke up 10 years ago. Everything points, communications experts say, to a call to battle between the old telephone companies, the new cable television companies and the even newer wireless empires of the cellular era. The one certainty is that thousands of Connecticut residents will have communications choices -- from the availability of interactive television to the source of their local dial tone -- sooner than their neighbors. 
 "For whatever reason, maybe karma, Connecticut seems to the place where competition is coming to a focal point," said Tad Diesel, a spokesman for TCI Connecticut, the state's largest cable television company, which is building a system that could provide combined video, voice and data services within two years.
The capstone is a bill in the state legislature, supported by both political parties and expected to pass shortly, that would open all types of telephone service to competition beginning July 1.
Southern New England Telecommunications, which serves the vast majority of homes and businesses in Connecticut, would lose its 80-year monopoly. That means any enterprise could apply to bring a telephone line or a wireless link into homes or offices. In exchange, SNET, as it is known, would be regulated under a new formula the company believes will be fairer than the system now in place.
"This will give Connecticut a more liberal and enlightened regulatory climate than any state in the region and any state we know of," said Paul Karoff, a spokesman for A.T. & T. "We would expect to take advantage of it to the maximum extent."
 
Unanswered Questions
 What all this means for consumers is extremely fuzzy. Dozens of fundamental questions are still unanswered, not least what will happen to telephone rates. Industry officials generally predict that business telephone costs will go down (because of price competition) and that residential rates will go up (because of price deregulation).
The next battlefield -- assuming that the competition bill passes the House and Senate and is signed into law by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., as expected -- will be how much, how soon. That would be played out over the next 18 months before the state Department of Public Utility Control.
"The question is not whether rates will go up, but whether they will go up fairly or unfairly," said John F. Merchant, the state's Consumer Counsel, who represents rate payers before the utility commission. Mr. Merchant said his goal in the new era was to get the best out of what he feared could otherwise be a bad new deal for small businesses and homeowners. "This gives a shot at fairness," he said of the competition legislation.
Many other states, New York and New Jersey among them, have authorized some competition for phone service. This is mostly in urban business districts, where big-volume dialers like stock brokerage houses already can bypass the old local telephone companies and connect directly to the long-distance carriers.
 
An Aggressive Agenda
 New York also has an aggressive agenda in development to foster greater competition, proposed last year by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. In New Jersey, Bell Atlantic is building a fiber-optic system that is to be completed in about 2010.
But Connecticut would be the first state in the region, and one of only a handful in the country, to make open competition -- from the home telephone to the biggest multi-line corporate system -- the official state policy. And communications experts say the peculiarities of this market, including Connecticut's compact size, will hasten and compound that change.
 
Video, Voice and Data
 SNET, in anticipation of deregulation, announced earlier this year that it would completely rewire Connecticut over the next decade with $4.5 billion of fiber-optic cable. That will allow video, voice and data to move in and out of homes and businesses with a scale and quality now impossible.
Interactive television, including movie rentals over the television set, is already being tested in Hartford's suburbs. By next year, residents in West Hartford are expected to be among the first in the nation to have not only access to 300 or more channels but also a choice of which carrier to bring them into the home. Three cable systems, including one operated by SNET, will be in contention.
SNET, unlike other big communications companies in the region, such as Bell Atlantic in New Jersey and Nynex in New York, was never part of the old American Telephone and and Telegraph Company. It was never barred -- as the Baby Bells were -- from competing directly with companies like A.T. & T. and Sprint to provide long-distance service. This week SNET made the leap, gaining approval from regulators. It is apparently the first local telephone company in the nation to offer long-distance dialing anywhere in the world.
 
Every Bet Is a Guess
 Telephone experts also say that competition will probably first seek the markets where the best profits loom: in the business centers like Stamford and Hartford. MFS Communications of Omaha has already signed a contract to wire 23 buildings in Hartford and West Hartford this summer. Smaller business and home telephone competition would probably follow, but with the technology changing so rapidly, every bet is a guess.
A spokeswoman for MCI, for example, which has announced its intentions to fight for a share of the local telephone market nationally, said that Connecticut would become a "friendly," state, but that no plans could be announced. Mr. Karoff at A. T. & T. said his company had ruled out competing for local service here, but predicted that competition for long distance -- the company's core business -- would heat up dramatically. Nynex, the dominant player in New York, also applauded the legislation, but a spokesman declined to declare any new goals.
Some questions echo the days of telephone competition before 1913, before telephone service became a monopoly.
Will you need a phone book for every telephone provider? If you change your telephone company, can you keep your number? If telephone companies still have to provide basic service to poor households and in rural areas -- as the new legislation requires -- does basic service mean what it does now? Will the more sophisticated technologies available in fought-over markets become the new level of basic service required to be available for all?
And what happens to today's regulated monopolies? The tiny Woodbury Telephone Company, for instance, has lived under the shadow of SNET for decades in quiet obscurity, serving 17,400 customers, most of them rural, in Woodbury, Southbury and Bethlehem.
"We may need to apply more energy toward being competitive, because we never have had to be competitive before," said Brian D. Ward, Woodbury's commercial and regulatory manager. "The only thing for sure is that it will encourage competition."
SNET now serves nearly every Connecticut resident except Woodbury's customers and the 23,000 that Nynex serves in Fairfield County. Company officials said they had long since concluded that the growth of cable and wireless phone systems made competition for their old base inevitable.
 
Predictions? Impossible
 "It became a matter of whether you fight it in the state of Connecticut, or whether you recognize the reality and ask yourself, 'are we in a position to compete?' " said Michael P. Phelan, the company's director of public policy and regulatory planning. "We decided we were."
Mr. Phelan said he believed that with the market, the regulatory structure and the technology all changing so rapidly, predicting the future was impossible. He believes that some services and areas that now lose money, could, with the right creativity, be repackaged and become profitable, while other areas that look so tempting now could wither.
"Open your mind up," he said. "Anything is possible."

HEADLINE: Trump to Seek Federal Help to Get Riverside South Under Way

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
Though the financing for most of Riverside South, Donald J. Trump's long-delayed residential and commercial complex on Manhattan's West Side, has not yet been fully arranged, the developer will seek Federal help for at least the first stage of the $1.9 billion project.
Within 90 days, the Trump Organization will apply to the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development for Federal mortgage insurance, said Michelle de Milly, a spokeswoman for the developer. 
 If the application is approved, Ms. de Milly said, Mr. Trump would be allowed to sell tax-exempt bonds -- through the city or the state -- that are insured by the Federal Housing Authority. The money from the bonds would be used to build the first four of Riverside South's 16 residential buildings. Riverside South would then also become eligible for the state's 421(a) program, which provides tax abatements for 20 years to developers who build low-income housing.
Mr. Trump would be required to make 20 percent of the 1,600 units in those first four buildings low-income rental housing. That is already part of his agreement with the city that calls for him to build affordable housing at the site, the former Penn Yards between 65th and 69th Streets.
A decision is expected to take about a year. The department will also set the rents and the means test for qualifying for the units.
 
Occupancy in 1997
 Ms. de Milly said that construction of the four Riverside South buildings would take about two years, with occupancy expected to start in 1997. Ms. de Milly did release final estimates for the cost of constructing the buildings.
City Councilwoman Ronnie Eldridge, an opponent of Riverside South, has introduced legislation that would require applications for the state's 421(a) program to be subject to case-by-case approval by the city. She said she was angered that the Riverside South buildings would be required to have low-income housing only for the life of the abatements.
"The 80-20 program is the only program available to generate affordable housing in the city," said Ms. de Milly. "And, most importantly, it is consistent with one of Riverside South's principal goals, which is to create an economically integrated development."
Riverside South is a scaled-down version of Mr. Trump's earlier proposal for the site: Trump City, which was to have been a 14.5 million-square-foot development that was to include the world's tallest building. The plan was abandoned in 1990, after complaints from nearby residents.
Plans, which have been approved by the city, include 5,700 apartments, 375,000 square feet of retail and office space and 25 acres of parkland and open space. Philip Johnson will be the architect.
Mr. Trump bought the property, which stretches along the Hudson River on land from 59th to 72d Streets, in 1985.
The approximate $250 million mortgage on the property came due last June, but the bank that holds it, Chase Manhattan, has held back from foreclosing while Mr. Trump looks for someone to buy the mortgage at a discount from Chase in exchange for an equity stake in the project.
In January, Mr. Trump said that he was close to securing financing for the mortgage with a new backer, whom he declined to identify.

HEADLINE: Brazil Reaches Accord With Large Banks to Cut Debt

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Brazil, the largest debtor in the developing world, completed an agreement last night with its creditor banks that reduces its $49 billion foreign debt and provides the country with lower interest rates and new longer-term loans.
Although a number of new debtor countries, most notably Russia, still need to reach agreement with commercial banks on restructuring their foreign debts, the Brazilian agreement effectively ends the international debt crisis that began in 1982. 
 The crisis started with Mexico's announcement that it was no longer able to make interest or principal payments on its foreign debt, and grew as other countries followed. The problems severely strained the world's financial system and curbed economic growth in Latin America.
But since the late 1980's, when the United States led a new effort to resolve the crisis, big debtor nations inside and outside Latin America have received a reduction in their financial burdens in exchange for changes that both opened their economies and helped curb rampant inflation.
The foreign investment that has been attracted in the wake of earlier debt-reduction agreements, like that in Mexico, has played a large role in the economic revival of these countries.
Approval of the Brazilian agreement came last night in New York, bringing to an end the tortuous negotiations that began in October 1990. The agreement was announced by Rubens Ricupero, Brazil's Minister of Finance, and William R. Rhodes, vice chairman of Citibank, Brazil's biggest bank creditor.
Mr. Rhodes, who has worked with Latin America's largest debtor nations since the crisis began, was clearly pleased to declare it over.
"It's been 11, and three and a half on this one," he said, in reference to Brazil and the number of years involved. "Now we can finally say this is over."
For Brazil, the agreement will cut its outstanding foreign bank debt to commercial banks by $4 billion, to $45 billion, and reduce interest owed by another $4 billion. The agreement is crucial to Brazil's efforts to liberalize its economy, attract foreign investment and stabilize prices.
Brazil's total debt burden, including loans from banks and from other governments, totaled $121.1 billion at the end of 1992, according to the World Bank. Mexico was second with $113.4 billion, Argentina third with $67.6 billion and Poland, which reached a debt-reduction agreement with its banks in March, fourth with $48.5 billion.
The 750 creditor banks in the Brazilian agreement include some of the largest in the United States. For the banks, the incentives for an agreement were the guarantees they receive on payments of debt and interest. In addition, the accord could provide profits for some banks by increasing the value of the debt they have on their books.
The agreement may also serve as a stabilizing force in Latin America. Since the beginning of the year, rising interest rates have hammered prices of the region's outstanding debt securities, raising questions among investors about the outlook.
"Closing this agreement will favorably affect the emerging debt markets by removing a major uncertainty," Mr. Rhodes said.
The Brazilian agreement caps five years of successful negotiations with Mexico, Argentina and other debtors that began after the Bush Administration outlined a new debt policy known as the Brady Plan, named for Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady.
Under the plan, bankers were encouraged to help debtor nations reduce their burdens, while the foreign governments were required to reduce inflation and open their economies to foreign investment. Unlike other agreements, however, the accord between Brazil and its banks was completed without an approved economic program from the International Monetary Fund.

HEADLINE: Sexual Harassment Thrives In the New Russian Climate

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 16

 BODY:
The advertisement for a secretary in a Moscow newspaper listed computer skills, typing, English and German as necessary qualifications. It also specified that applicants should be 18 to 25, 5 foot 7 and have long hair. "There will be a contest," it said.
The advertisement was just one of scores placed every day that list youth and sex appeal as job requirements. It was also among the more courtly. Some Russian employers include another prerequisite in their advertisements: "bez kompleksov," or "without inhibitions." Everyone in Russia knows what that means. 
 In Moscow's bustling new business community, it is usually not frowned upon to grope the secretary, to require that the new office manager be single, long-legged and blond, or to offer to discuss a filing clerk's raise after work in a hotel room -- and dismiss her if she refuses.
Sexual harassment in the workplace is rampant in today's Russia, and the sexism that thrived under the Communists is growing worse, aggravated, feminists say, by the new lawlessness that rules the business world.
The new Russia is known for its violence. There is also a heady sense of permissiveness fed by pornographic videos, sexy advertising, nightclubs, casinos, beauty contests, nude pinups and open prostitution. This has helped spawn a workplace climate of sexual swaggering and bullying that is no longer imaginable in the United States after figures like Anita Hill and Robert Packwood made the term "sexual harassment" part of the national lexicon.
"Women view their bodies as a way of furthering their careers -- that's just the way it is," said Igor M. Bunin, the author of a study on the "new Russian businessmen" published this month. "Sexual harassment is absolutely not a real problem in Russia."
"I assure you," he added, "there is no opposition on the part of women to this."
Many women do not see it his way. Irina, 23, a graphic designer who did not want her last name used, said she quit her job at a Moscow publishing house after her boss kept grabbing her and pressuring her to sleep with him. "I can understand that men want to look," she said. "But they shouldn't be allowed to do something to me that I don't want."
A gradual awakening is occurring in some parts of the country.
Without publicity or fanfare, the first known sexual harassment case went to court in Russia this year in Barnaul, a city in southern Siberia.
Sexual harassment, which in Russian law is defined as a boss demanding sexual favors from subordinates, is a criminal offense, as it was in the former Soviet Union. But the statute was so rarely enforced that prosecutors in Barnaul and Moscow could not cite a single precedent.
Tatyana L. Smyshlayeva, 35, a general practitioner at a municipal clinic, complained that her boss, the 62-year-old chief physician, repeatedly grabbed and groped her in his office, threatening to dismiss her if she resisted his advances. He had previously dismissed two other women for the same reason, she said.
Even though she had tapes and witnesses, the city's health care administrators ignored her. Russian newspapers did not cover the case. Most in her community told her she was crazy.
 
The Case Is Dropped
 "Unfortunately," Dr. Smyshlayeva said, "around here even husbands think this kind of behavior is normal." But her husband supported her, as did the district prosecutor, who opened an investigation in January. The case against the doctor was dropped before trial, however, under the general amnesty in February that freed Aleksandr V. Rutskoi, a leader of the October insurrection against President Boris N. Yeltsin.
Dr. Smyshlayeva remains employed by the clinic, as does her former supervisor, although he was suspended from his position as chief.
The feminist movement in Russia remains small, and if anything, it is in decline; its few active members complain that the status of women has only deteriorated since the demise of Communism.
On average, women in 1991 earned 75 percent as much as men, according to the Center for Gender Studies in Moscow, but now that figure has dropped to 40 percent. Unemployment is three times higher among women than among men. Though there are no reliable statistics, women's groups say domestic violence is soaring. The first registered rape recovery center and a crisis hot line for abused women recently opened in Moscow.
Most Russian men dismiss the issue of sexual harassment as yet another silly Western hang-up. Most women say the problem exists, but shrug it off as just another unpleasant fact of life. The demeaning jokes and salacious remarks that are increasingly considered a form of harassment in the United States are so commonplace in Russia that they do not register as harassment.
 
'That Macho Feeling'
 Valentina Konstantinova, a researcher at the Center for Gender Studies, noted that while in Communist times, bosses preyed on employees with impunity, democracy has mainly freed the male libido. "Before the view of Russian men were as creatures without willpower who drink too much. Now they have the ability to make money, they want everything in this life. They have that macho feeling."
One of the few Russians to take up the battle against sexual harassment is a man. Valery V. Vikulov, 31, says he set up an underground organization, the Diana Fund, to assist women who have lost their jobs as a result of sexual harassment. He said that in the last year and a half he has quietly collected money or helped find work for 117 women and compiled a black list of 95 companies where he contends sexual harassment is severe and widespread.
While most of the cases he has handled involve the loss of promotions, bonuses or jobs by women, a few are more extreme. Mr. Vikulov said he had helped one 19-year-old woman, a part-time worker selling advertisements for a Moscow radio station, who said she was gang-raped by her employers after a dinner they held to celebrate her promotion.
He noted that he had heard of some American businessmen who behaved toward Russian employees in a way they dared not treat their American counterparts. But he had not received many formal complaints. "The pay at Western companies is so much higher," he said, "that most women just smile and bear it."
 
No Feminist Newspapers
 There are no feminist newspapers, and only one women's magazine, the monthly, distinctly unglossy "Female Worker." But a Russian edition of Cosmopolitan, a magazine known more for advising women on the arts of seduction than on how to fight off an amorous boss, is scheduled to hit the stands at the end of the month.
Its publisher, Derk Sauer, who also owns The Moscow Times, described his project as a service to newly prosperous Russian women. "The magazine will not just be about fashion," he said. "It's about relationships and careers and sex."
And sexual mores have changed.More and more women, feminists say, freely trade sexual favors for salary and perks because good jobs are scarce and employers can more easily replace recalcitrant or older employees than they could under Communism. Job seekers who do not wish to sleep with their employers attach a postscript to their advertisements, "intim nye predlagat," "no intimate relations."
The current hedonism repels Dmitri O. Babich, a young reporter for the daily Komsomolskaya Pravda. He was so appalled by a recent television advertisement for office equipment that depicted a secretary leaning over her leering boss, her breasts exposed, that he put his phone number in an article and asked women who had experienced sexual harassment to call. "A fourth of the calls were from men thinking it was an ad for phone sex," he said.
His editors were equally confused about the article he planned. "They scheduled it for an erotic supplement," he said. He dissuaded them. His article ran last week under the heading, "School of Survival."
 
A Gallery Owner's Way
 Such articles are extremely rare in the Russian press.
"When I first heard Americans using the expression 'sexual harassment' I was utterly baffled -- I thought it was some kind of custom, like karaoke." said Larisa M. Manotkina, 35, who started her own travel business, Charisma Travel. Now, she said, she sees the term everywhere.
Her best friend, Natalya E. Bykona, who owns her own chic art gallery, the NB Gallery in downtown Moscow, revealed her own way of handling sexism. She said that her own businesslike demeanor is off-putting to Russian men. To put them at ease, she takes her sexy and flirtatious assistant with her to business meetings as a decoy.
"Everyone knows the flirting and seduction is a game," Ms. Bykona said, "but it is the rule."
The Moscow Women's Bank is not quite a bank, and not exactly a feminist enterprise. Alla G. Udalova, the deputy director, said the company does some banking and also other kinds of business, including hiring waitresses for a nightclub. She said sexual harassment and discrimination were not issues at the company.
Her boss, Yaroslav A. Angelyuk, agreed. "If a woman working for me gets married," he explained cheerfully, "I fire her."

Manhotkina, and a client in her gallery in Moscow. (Gleb Kosorukov for The New York Times) (pg. 8)

HEADLINE: Out of the Ashes;
More Derelict Factories Are Returning to Productive Use

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
From the outside, it looks like one more decrepit multi-story brick factory building left for dead. The inside, however, is alive with the sound of screaming band saws and the smell of fresh sawdust. The former 19th-century rope factory on the Brooklyn waterfront in Greenpoint has been broken up into dozens of smaller spaces for woodworking shops and artisans.
"It would be much easier for me to operate in Pennsylvania," said Eric Seibel, a cabinet maker with five employees. "So if a place like this didn't exist, I definitely wouldn't be in New York." 
 Mr. Seibel and his crew are part of the ambitiously named Greenpoint Manufacturing and Design Center. The venerable building was acquired from the city last month by a nonprofit enterprise that plans extensive renovation.
Twenty miles west, in depressed Paterson, N.J., a defunct textile plant has found new life as well. The bottom two floors of the factory, started in 1919 and finally shut down three years ago, reopened in January as a community health center. The top two levels of the building, in the Great Falls Historic District, now contain apartments for low- and moderate-income people.
For decades cities across the Northeast have witnessed an unending industrial exodus. Thousands of manufacturing firms have gone out of business. Thousands more have left for less expensive locations in the outlying suburbs and in other regions, leaving abandoned industrial shells behind them.
Despite costly government attempts to stimulate economic development in urban industrial wastelands, only a few such buildings have been recycled. That usually happened where a popular location and striking architecture allowed developers to create trendy shopping arcades like the South Street Seaport in lower Manhattan. Indeed, probably the region's most successful revival of an old factory district -- the rebirth long ago of SoHo -- was done largely in flagrant violation of land-use laws.
But today -- even with such daunting obstacles as waste contamination, rigid zoning laws and byzantine financing barriers -- more such relics of the region's industrial heyday are being returned to productive uses.
"Paterson isn't stylish like Philadelphia or Boston," George McLoof Jr., president of the Longstreet Development Corporation, said. His organization managed the renovation of the Cooke Mill Complex, the first new project in Paterson's old factory district since revitalization efforts stalled a decade ago. "This is a gritty, grimy meat-and-potatoes industrial city," he said. "But don't write it off."
So far, these salvage operations are mostly isolated enterprises. Many rely on quirky individuals, often driven more by zeal than by a desire to make money. There is nothing like the massive government-sponsored efforts to reclaim derelict industrial lands that are under way in London, Tokyo, Paris, Toronto and elsewhere. Several factors underlie the growing potential for redeveloping industrial sites. The collapse of the 1980's building boom in suburban offices and shopping malls has forced many real-estate developers to turn elsewhere. Much of the cheapest, most accessible land in the region now lies in run-down manufacturing zones and along industrial waterfronts. For instance, space in an inner-city factory in New York City can run as low as $3 to $5 a square foot, while new factory space in the outlying suburbs is at least twice that.
Restrictions that once discouraged developers are being relaxed. Harsh liability and environmental standards once made the cleanup of old industrial sites so risky and expensive that they actively encouraged abandonment, contributing to urban sprawl. That, in turn, raised even greater threats to the surrounding environment. In reaction, New Jersey was one of the first among several governments to make cleanup regulations less onerous.
And local politicians -- who once trusted in urban planning projects that imposed strict separation between industrial, commercial, and residential districts -- are prodding zoning officials to relax the rules so that more mixed-use redevelopments can take place.
 
In With the New
 In some cases, the only viable choice for abandoned or underused sites will probably be to replace their lost industries with expanding service businesses like health care organizations or big retailers like Home Depot. Along the water, upscale housing is another option favored by many developers and planners. Whatever happens, many industrial areas, if not most, will never again hum as they once did with traditional factory activity.
Yet cities may still be able to save a lot of the remaining jobs in production and other kinds of hands-on, blue-collar work that have long been considered to be on their way to oblivion, regional planners say. Last year New York City officially lost just 2,000 manufacturing jobs, by far the smallest decline in the last decade. Almost 300,000 remain on the books, and many more survive in the underground economy.
"We all know that the traditional manufacturing firms have moved out of our cities," said Robert D. Yaro, executive director of the Regional Plan Association in New York. "But what is harder to see is that there is still a strong demand for a different type of business: smaller, more trend-oriented makers capable of quick turnaround on customized products. With some creative adaptation, many of them can fit well into our older industrial locations."
That trend is reflected in the breakup of industrial establishments once filled by one big employer into those containing many smaller firms. In New Haven, for example, where the sprawling Winchester gun works once employed more than 2,000 workers, owners of the bleak inner-city site near Yale University had been working for more than a decade to remake it as an incubator for new businesses.
Today, with fresh funds from its original public and private sponsors, the complex known as Science Park is home to some of the most promising industrial ventures in Connecticut. One company, started by an engineering graduate fresh from Yale, is working to create a less expensive, pollution-free process for spraying thin films on metals and other surfaces. A rapidly expanding biotechnology company is testing new drugs for immunological disorders. And yet another company is doing research on catalytic combustion to reduce engine emissions while improving efficiency.
In all, almost 1,000 people now work at roughly 100 companies within the complex. Moreover, after threatening to pull up stakes entirely, the Olin Corporation is building an up-to-date Winchester rifle factory on the grounds. It will employ more than 500 people, many from the poor neighborhood around the plant.
 
Redevelopment in Red Hook
 In New York City, there are signs of activity in even some of the most dilapidated districts.
Without any help from the New York City government, Gregory O'Connell, a Brooklyn developer, is renovating two red-brick warehouses, dating from the Civil War, along the Red Hook waterfront. He started 10 years ago with one empty building, Pier 41 at the end of Van Dyke Street in one of the city's poorest and most isolated areas. Its strongest asset may be the stunning view of the Statue of Liberty and the Wall Street skyline. It is now 75 percent occupied.
Last year, Mr. O'Connell bought another nearby pier from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which he is also painstakingly restoring, installing lines for sewage, gas and electricity, replacing structural beams and preserving the black steel shutters that cover most of the windows.
Between his two buildings, of two stories each, is a four-story city-owned warehouse that is largely going to waste. On a nearby pier is a rusting sugar refinery that closed in the early 1980's.
"This is a labor of love," said Mr. O'Connell, "but we're also here because I think this is a great business opportunity. There is a tremendous need for niche-type businesses to find low-cost work space."
Today roughly 20 businesses are operating there, ranging from Flickinger Glassworks, a maker of custom glass that plans to open a retail shop in the front of its workshop, to VIP Yachts, which caters meals for the Royal Princess, a harbor cruise ship.
 
Change of Heart
 The city's recently adopted waterfront zoning plan envisioned replacing much of the Red Hook industrial district with housing. But community groups believe that ventures like Pier 41 are more likely to help revitalize the area than grandiose planning documents, so they are preparing their own alternative that calls for allowing residential, light manufacturing and commercial activities to coexist.
In striking contrast to the past, city officials say they welcome the community effort.
"Our zoning has clearly been overly rigid," said Joseph Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission. "There are many areas like Red Hook where we shouldn't have to make these either-or choices in some government office downtown."
The private market alone cannot support most such ventures, but government officials are learning that they often have more success when they apply a lighter touch.
 
Uncommon Devotion
 David Sweeny and Daniel Dray, who both used to work for city economic development offices, are the prime force behind the Greenpoint project. With 360,000 square feet of space on six floors in eight inter-connected buildings, they are planning to invest up to $6 million over the next five years to bring the manufacturing center up to code.
If the city had tried to do the project itself, Mr. Sweeny said, it would have cost at least $12 million. Instead, the city's Economic Development Corporation provided a $1 million grant to start reconstruction, leaving the Greenpoint operators to raise the rest from other sources.
"Together, we can do a lot of things that couldn't be done separately," Mr. Dray said.
Still, keeping the center alive requires uncommon devotion. Mr. Sweeny -- who is married to Isabel Hill, a maker of documentary films whose "Made in Brooklyn" is an impassioned plea to retain manufacturing in New York City -- acknowledges that it has been an uphill battle.
"It is very tough to put a deal like this together," he said. "If I knew then what I know now, I doubt that I would have tried it in the first place."

HEADLINE: Sheriff Faces Off Vigilante Group in Montana

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: JORDAN, Mont., April 16

 BODY:
Amid the sagebrush and jack rabbits of rural Montana, a sheriff and his posse are in a showdown with their vigilante neighbors over whose law will prevail.
The Garfield County Freemen, vigilantes who hold that established government is illegitimate, are dismissed as "kooks" by some residents of this town of 500 people. But Sheriff Charles Phipps takes the vigilantes' threats seriously. 
 "They have threatened to come into town and shoot seven of us and retreat," said Sheriff Phipps. While he said he thought the threat was just for show, he now carries a gun when he used to go unarmed.
The vigilantes are led by Ralph Clark, who says his constitutional rights were violated when a bank foreclosed on his 960-acre wheat farm north of town.
The sheriff said he was told he would be hanged from a bridge if convicted by a vigilante jury of "common law crimes" in the foreclosure.
Sheriff Phipps is not the only villain in the eyes of Mr. Clark, who is accused of posting a bounty for the "arrest" of the sheriff, a prosecutor and a judge who processed the paperwork to foreclose on the farm where he was born.
 
Clark Fleeing Arrest
 Mr. Clark was ordered to appear in court last Thursday to face charges of solicitation of kidnapping. He defied the order, and Judge Joe L. Hegel of District Court issued a warrant for his arrest. On the same day, Mr. Clark's farm was auctioned to settle $37,864 in arrears on $710,000 in mortgages.
The courtroom was almost deserted at the five-minute hearing. Adjacent offices of the county treasurer and court clerk were filled with members of a posse the sheriff had recruited to keep order in case of trouble.
Several of Mr. Clark's supporters face misdemeanor charges of impersonating public officials for claiming to be a justice of the peace or a constable. The vigilantes are friends, even relatives, of many of the county's nearly 1,600 residents.
"I grew up on a ranch 10 miles from the Clarks," the sheriff said. "We were neighbors."
Here in town, where a handful of businesses line the few paved streets and modest houses and mobile homes are on dirt roads, few take the vigilantes seriously.
"People think they're a bunch of kooks," said JoDe Watson, a tax preparer.
 
'Just Went too Far'
 Lynn Olson, eating a pizza at the Rancher's Bar and Cafe, said he belonged to a related group for about a year, but quit. "I think they're doing something that needed doing, but they just went too far with that bounty deal," he said. "I've got friends on both sides."
The Garfield County Freemen are part of a movement active in pockets of Montana whose members are known generally as "constitutionalists." Based on vague interpretations of the Constitution, they believe established government is illegitimate because they say it has violated their rights.
"These people are essentially defying the system," said Lance Tonn, a lawyer who made the their bounty list by representing the bank that foreclosed on Mr. Clark.
"I think it started out with everyone thinking it was a bit humorous," Mr. Tonn said. "But when you have someone about to suffer an economic loss, as they are, and some who seem to have lost touch with reality, you have a bad combination."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%); 

STATE: MONTANA, USA (95%);

HEADLINE: Ukraine's Opportunity: Western Suspicions of Russia

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine

 BODY:
Ukraine, barely de-Sovietized and economically unreformed, is hoping to take advantage of new strains in the American-Russian relationship by promoting itself as a bulwark against any potential Russian imperialism.
Ukrainian officials and senior Western diplomats here discern growing mistrust and disillusionment between Moscow and Washington, where the Clinton Administration is being pushed to regard the Russians as rivals instead of partners, as Senator Richard G. Lugar, the Indiana Republican, recently put it. 
 In Moscow, it is increasingly fashionable to speak in nationalist terms and to regard Western promises of aid as derisory or even subversive. In Washington, where policy toward the former Soviet Union is no longer bipartisan, all Russian behavior now seems to be viewed through the prism of neo-imperialism.
The Ukrainian President, Leonid M. Kravchuk, the former chief ideologist of Soviet Ukraine and a noted survivor, is happy to take advantage of the altered mood as he seeks more Western aid, greater executive powers and the cancellation of presidential elections scheduled for June.
Despite its lack of any real economic reform, its high inflation and a steadily ambivalent attitude toward nuclear disarmament, Ukraine is now regarded as a bulwark of Western policy toward Russia, senior Western diplomats and Ukrainian officials say.
 
Nuclear Issue Cited
 So the West is considered less likely to criticize Mr. Kravchuk than before or to wish to see him out of office, particularly since he is considered the crucial guarantor of Ukraine's incompletely ratified promise to become a non-nuclear state. Now that elections have produced a regionalized legislature with a big leftist and neo-Communist bloc, Mr. Kravchuk seems even more important.
After nearly two years of isolating Ukraine over its nuclear inheritance, President Clinton has met Mr. Kravchuk twice, the last time in early March in Washington. There, American aid to Ukraine was increased sharply from $175 million in denuclearization funds and $155 million in economic aid to $350 million in each category. Defense Secretary William J. Perry, on a much-publicized trip here two weeks ago, signed three agreements on dismantling missiles and military conversion that covers some $100 million of the new aid.
[An agreement announced in Washington that the United States will help Ukraine replace the 1,700 megawatts of energy produced from the Chernobyl power plants, so the remaining reactors may be shut down, is another example of a more varied relationship.]
Zbigniew Brzezinski, a former national security adviser, seemed to summarize Ukraine's new importance in a recent article in Foreign Affairs when he wrote, "Russia can be either an empire or a democracy, but it cannot be both." And how to define empire? Mr. Brzezinski was nearly as categorical: "Without Ukraine, Russia ceases to be an empire, but with Ukraine suborned and then subordinated, Russia automatically becomes an empire."
 
Even-Handed Policy Urged
 Mr. Brzezinski urged a more "even-handed treatment" of Russia and Ukraine, including more aid and assurances about Ukraine's security. Whether Mr. Brzezinksi is right or wrong about Russia, his words carry weight in Washington, especially among Republicans looking for cracks in the Clinton White House.
As Mr. Kravchuk contemplates asking a new Parliament for increased presidential powers in the name of efficiency, stability and "reform," he can be confident that Washington and the West will be slower to criticize him now than in the days when a democratic, Westernized, free-market Russia seemed to some just a short and relatively painless interval away.
"Washington's in a real bind," a senior Western diplomat said. "For its own reasons, and for regional stability, it has to support Ukraine. Yet it needs to push them toward denuclearization and more Western-style reform, and even pay them for it. The question is how much? Certainly Kravchuk knows this."
Mr. Kravchuk sees himself as a chess player and tactician in a difficult time, his advisers emphasize. But he is said to understand Ukraine's new importance to Washington. "He sees that Ukraine's value to the world is so clear in the long run that the West will cave in," a diplomat said. "I fully expect him to try to use the nuclear card again to try to get more economic aid."
 
Neglect of Economy Charged
 But some officials concede that Mr. Kravchuk has offered no clear vision of what an independent Ukraine should be, concentrating instead on the symbols of statehood -- the flag, the army, the summit meetings -- while the economy burns.
Some officials worry that the increasing regional strains in Ukraine, between the more nationalist west and the Russified east, apparent in recent elections, will increase the country's larger ambivalence about where its future lies: with a Slavic, Moscow-dominated alliance or a Western-oriented Eastern and Central Europe eager to join the European Union and NATO.
"Independent Ukraine is in the midst of an identity crisis," a senior Western diplomat said. "Is Ukraine the border between Orthodox Russia and Europe, or is that border somewhere in the middle of Ukraine itself?"
This choice between Russia and Europe, which fewer Russians these days would regard as a false choice, has been made more complicated, the diplomat said, "by a fitful, uncertain and less than welcoming West," which concentrated for two years on Ukraine's nuclear weapons to the exclusion of a broader relationship.
 
A Broader Relationship
 That relationship has now begun to broaden, American officials and Kravchuk advisers say. But it is almost sure to be tested further if Mr. Kravchuk takes more presidential powers, fails to begin reform and tries to use the nuclear card again to win more aid from Washington.
Mr. Kravchuk, well aware of the growing nationalism within Russia, is increasingly concerned about the fissures it creates in Ukraine, too, especially as the unreformed economy wallows in devalued money.
Ian J. Brzezinski, a Kiev-based security official with Parliament's Council of Advisers, says Mr. Kravchuk is torn, believing in the need for market reform but fearing its consequences.
"Real reform would tear away the old elite's control over the economy," he said. "And Kravchuk sees major security problems with economic reform. The potential of Russian pressure combined with internal strains in eastern Ukraine, which would bear the weight of economic reform, is a real concern."
Mr. Brzezinski, Zbigniew's son, sees much of Kiev's weakness as home-grown, but agrees with his father about Ukraine's importance to the West.
"Ukraine is in a downward spiral, and its leadership is unwilling to grit its teeth and take the risks associated with consolidating statehood," he said. But he added, "As Moscow seems more threatening, Ukraine looks more attractive," so more varied Western aid has begun to flow despite the lack of economic reform.
As for the United States Congress, he and the diplomats said, there seems to be a new understanding that a Russia policy is not a satisfactory substitute for a European policy.
That gives Mr. Kravchuk more breathing room, the diplomats agreed. "But he must be careful, even so," one said. "He may buy off Washington with only promises of reform. But he's unpopular now, and even Ukrainians have a limit to their patience."

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Paying More Low-Earners for Working, I.R.S. Survey Finds

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16

 BODY:
Perhaps enticed by news of expanded benefits to come, lower-income workers flocked this year to claim the earned income tax credit, which can bring Government checks of more than $2,000 to married parents who work and rear children.
Unlike most other credits, which are limited to reducing tax liabilities, this one generally brings money to supplement the wages of the working poor. 
 According to an unpublished survey by the Internal Revenue Service, claims for the credit through March were 20 percent higher than in the comparable period last year, suggesting that more than 2.5 million Americans will become new participants in the program this year.
It has been one of the few social policies that both Democrats and Republicans can agree on, and it will be expanded next year by the budget enacted last year. The program's broad political appeal is based on its incentive for people to work, and its name makes it more politically palatable than welfare. Most economist think it is better policy than raising the minimum wage, which they say discourages employers from hiring marginal workers.
 
'Proponents Are Encouraged'
 But officials have long worried about the failure of large numbers of eligible Americans to claim the credit, which involves filling out what a former Tax Commissioner has called one of the most "obscenely complex" parts of the tax forms.
"Proponents are encouraged by what they're hearing," said an aide to Representative Timothy J. Penny, a Minnesota Democrat and longtime backer of the program, speaking of the rising number of Americans filing for the credit.
New York, with 800,000 beneficiaries for the 1992 tax year, ranks fourth behind California, Texas and Florida.
While the credit was raised substantially in the legislation signed by President Clinton last August, the improvements do not take effect until the 1994 tax year. That could mean that some claimants will get less than they expected or might not be eligible for the program.
The new law will give most eligible families significantly larger benefits, and workers with very low incomes and no children will become eligible for the tax credit for the first time. The maximum a family can receive for 1993 -- payment starts to shrink when income exceeds $12,000 -- is $2,364. For those with two or more children, this rises to $2,528 in 1994, $3,033 in 1995 and $3,370 in 1996.
Working single people and couples without children can receive a maximum of 7.65 percent of the first $4,000 earned or $306.
 
Retroactive Claims Possible
 Claims may be filed retroactively for the past three years, provided that no income tax returns were filed for those years.
While the proportion of returns claiming the credit rose this year to 19.3 percent from 16.1 percent, the I.R.S. has had very little success in promoting an advance payment option on the tax credit. Under the option, workers can arrange with employers to receive part of the credit throughout the year on their paychecks. Less than one-tenth of 1 percent of taxpayers are using it, according to the I.R.S. survey.
The survey and other data supplied by the agency also indicated that for the first time this year more Americans paid somebody to fill out their forms than did it themselves.
Through March this year, with tens of millions of the more difficult tax returns still to be filed, paid preparers had signed 46.7 percent of the returns, the I.R.S. said. But of the more difficult Form 1040's, paid prepares had filed 62.6 percent, with millions more of these forms to be filed.
Paid preparation passed 45 percent in 1984, 48 percent in 1991 and reached an estimated 50 percent for the 1992 tax year.
 
Pay for Preparations
 The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a group active on behalf of the poor, estimated that people claiming the earned income credit paid at least $345 million for tax preparation last year.
Other trends and practices disclosed by the survey showed:
*Support continues to dwindle for the Presidential Election Campaign Funds, with only 17.7 percent of returns having at least one "yes" box checked, (one for the wife and husband, with each box designating $3) down from 20.5 percent through March last year. This implied slightly more than $25 million in campaign money, down from $41 million in the peak year of 1981.
*Just over 3 percent of returns this year reflected contributions to an individual retirement account, compared with 15.9 percent in 1985 when these were deductible for people of all incomes.
*Use of the I.R.S. mailing labels dropped to about 40 percent, reflecting the rise in electronic filing and professional preparation as well as the persistent notion that the label invites an audit.
*About 2 percent of filers through March managed to come out even, neither owing as much as $1 nor seeking a refund. Most of them were thought to have achieved this precision through their final quarterly payment of estimated tax, which was due Jan. 15.
But one thing changes little: The overwhelming number of taxpayers are willing to make costly interest-free loans to the Government to make sure they receive refunds. Of all returns filed through March, 89.9 percent claimed a refund.
The average size of the refunds through April 9, the I.R.S. calculated, is $1,025, up from $972 in the comparable period last year.

HEADLINE: Fudging the Budget

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 16

 BODY:
When asked why the state budget for the fiscal year that began April 1 is now more than two weeks late and not close to final passage, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and state legislative leaders point to ideological disputes over school aid, health care and tax cuts.
But the coarser reality about the budget fight is this: it's mostly about protecting incumbents. 
 "The issues that keep this budget from closing have less to do with good public policy than what's good for an individual lawmaker's election," said Cynthia B. Green, deputy research director of the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit fiscal watchdog group.
This is, after all, an election year when Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat, and many of the Legislature's 211 members face challenges. But it is also the first year since 1991 that the state's economy has been sufficiently robust to justify significant new spending or tax cuts -- as much as $1 billion worth.
That potent combination has created a negotiating atmosphere that Mr. Cuomo has likened, in effect, to an all-you-can-eat buffet for the starving. "They're working with two hands to feed themselves from the trough and they're bumping into one another and they're getting a little greedy," he said of the Legislature last week.
 
Waiting for Best Deal
 Within that setting, lawmakers seem more compelled to wait for the best deal rather than to reach quick agreement. The result: wrapped inside almost every policy debate is a raw political fight over money for some constituency.
"A surplus is politically more difficult to deal with than a deficit," explained Assemblyman John J. McEneny, an Albany Democrat. "With a deficit, people can accept no new spending. But when people hear about a large surplus, everybody feels a sense of entitlement."
Nowhere is the haggling over state dollars more bare-knuckled than in the school aid arena. The issue stirs large blocs of voters because state aid to local schools can relieve property taxes. Not surprisingly, the Legislature has increased its contribution to local school budgets every year since 1945 except once: in 1991, during a grinding recession.
This year school aid will increase by about $400 million to $9.5 billion, the largest increase in four years. But while that might seem reason for celebration, negotiators have been locked in a testy battle over how much of the pot New York City should receive.
Mr. Cuomo and the Democrats who control the Assembly, both dependent on urban voters, say the city should get 35.2 percent. But the Republican-led Senate, whose leaders represent rural upstate towns and Long Island, says the city's share should be 34.7 percent. That might sound close, but the difference is worth about $50 million.
 
Medicaid Aid Fight
 "We disagree on the shares," said the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, a Nassau County Republican. "Under the Democrats' configuration, the upstate would get shortchanged."
A fight over "shares" has also blocked agreement on a plan to have the state assume part of the Medicaid costs now borne by county governments.
Medicaid represents the fastest growing portion of most county governments' budgets, and there is bipartisan agreement in Albany that the state should relieve some of that burden. But while the Democrats favor a plan that would give almost three of every four Medicaid takeover dollars to New York City, the Republicans have advanced a proposal that would require the state also to assume some of county governments' share of pre-kindergarten special education services.
Where are those special education costs rising the fastest? Not by coincidence, on Long Island, home of the Senate's leadership.
Name the issue and similar battles are under way in closed-door negotiations. Capital construction? Senate Republicans want to build minor league baseball stadiums upstate and an Olympic-quality swimming pool and soccer stadium on Long Island. Assembly Democrats want that money used for repairing schools in and around New York City. Mr. Cuomo wants a portion for opening a special school for gifted high school students.
 
Budget 'Solvable'
 Tax cuts? The Senate Republicans want more for businesses; the Assembly Democrats want more for low-income families. Mr. Cuomo wants some of both.
"This budget is eminently solvable," said Mary Ann Crotty, Mr. Cuomo's director of policy management. "But having more money is making it more difficult."
The lawmakers have also lost what was once their most compelling reason to pass the budget quickly: an annual rite known as spring borrowing in which the state sold short-term bonds to pay for the previous year's school aid. Those bonds could not be sold without a final budget, so pressure from school districts often cajoled lawmakers to settle their differences.
But in hopes of improving the state's low bond ratings, the Legislature and Mr. Cuomo ended spring borrowing this year. Now, most school districts will not feel a budget pinch until mid-June.
The Legislature has also passed the portion of the budget that pays the salaries of most state workers, so that the government can continue operating.
The legislative leaders advance their own theories on why the other side will not close. Mr. Marino contends that Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, is blocking the Senate's efforts to cut taxes. Mr. Silver argues that Mr. Marino wants to make the budget as late as possible to embarrass Mr. Cuomo, perhaps by discouraging Wall Street investment rating firms from upgrading the state's bonds.
Except for a few barbed outbursts, Mr. Cuomo has refrained from attacking the Legislature, perhaps because he, too, needs some of the "goodies" in the $33 billion budget for his re-election effort.
Among those goodies are $68 million in Liberty Scholarships for needy college students. Mr. Cuomo championed the program in 1988 only to cut it from his 1991 budget because of the recession, calling it a painful sacrifice to fiscal responsibility. Now Mr. Cuomo is poised to unveil the scholarships in time for election, offering a firm rebuttal to critics who say he has not done enough for poor children.
The very lateness of the budget has offered its own political opportunities to those willing to seize them.
H. Carl McCall, the State Comptroller, has issued repeated statements sharply criticizing Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature for their tardiness. Having been appointed to fill a vacancy last year with Mr. Cuomo's help, Mr. McCall is now running for a full term, and his closeness to Mr. Cuomo has become a campaign issue. To many, his budget statements have been viewed as an effort to distance himself from Mr. Cuomo.
