HEADLINE: Democrats Need Money and a Message to Rebuild

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 14

 BODY:
The last time the New Jersey Democratic Party lost the governorship and both chambers of the Legislature, the telephone company threatened to pull out the phones and the party's headquarters building had to be sold.
Things are not quite that bad now, only the second time since the adoption of the State Constitution in 1947 that the Democrats have been more spectators than players around the Capitol. 
 But the Democrats have their work cut out if they hope to return to power. Not only must their party rebuild its finances, Democrats and Republicans agree, but it also must find a new message in the wake of voter rebellion against defeated Gov. Jim Florio's record tax increases and voter support for Ross Perot's anti-government campaign.
After Republicans won control of both legislative houses three years ago and followed by electing Christine Todd Whitman Governor last November, the Democratic Party chose as its new chairman a 39-year-old financial consultant with a limited political background but a familiar New Jersey name. He is Brendan Thomas Byrne 2d, the son of the former Democratic Governor who served two terms between 1974 and 1982 and whose name graces the basketball arena at the Meadowlands.
 
'We're Not There Yet'
 The younger Mr. Byrne, who is known as Tom, is aware of the financial troubles that dogged the party after William T. Cahill, a Republican, won the governorship in 1969 in the biggest landslide in a governor's race up to that time. Mr. Cahill also pulled Republican majorities into the State Senate and Assembly with him.
"We're not there yet," Mr. Byrne said, referring to the nearly bankrupt condition of the party before his father recaptured the governorship and restored Democrats to legislative control four years later. "But if we aren't successful raising money, the staff will be spending a few weeks on the beach in August."
Mr. Byrne estimated that he would need $300,000 to run the party for a year, including staff salaries, rent and money to support candidates in important local races.
The party in power in Trenton can easily raise $1 million annually, but nothing turns piles of cash into small change more quickly than a statewide campaign that includes the governorship and all 120 seats in the Legislature. And when there is a change in party control, especially in the governor's office, there is a sharp decrease in political contributions to the deposed party.
Thomas V. O'Neil was executive director of the party during the early 1970's when bills were piling up and the building on Willow Street had to be sold to whittle away at the debt.
"In those days when things got really tough, Sal Bontempo, the chairman, would call about 20 institutional party loyalists and get the money to keep us going," he said. "Today, that would be much more difficult with all the personal PAC's siphoning off the money that would have gone to the party."
Mr. Byrne tends to his money management business in his Princeton Township home in the mornings and then goes on the road, often meeting with local party officials through dinner and into the evening.
 
'Following the Hughes Model'
 "He's doing things we've needed to do for a long time," said Thomas G. Hartmann, a Rutgers University journalism professor and an adviser to Democratic leaders. "He tells people he is following the Hughes model, when former Governor Hughes [Richard J. Hughes], and Thorn Lord, the Mercer County Democratic chairman, went to living rooms all around the county to revive the party by asking people what had to be done and requesting their help."
Mr. Byrne, a former Princeton Township Democratic chairman, said the party must be recast "in a slightly more fiscally conservative image" without revising its traditional positions on social issues. "We have to show that we can be as careful with a buck as the Republicans, and we can do that," he said.
At a recent meeting with municipal and county Democratic leaders in Union County, Mr. Byrne said he found some lingering animosity toward former Governor Florio. "They think he hurt the party, and that's understandable," Mr. Byrne said. There is no question that the election reverses in 1991 through 1993 flowed from the enactment of Mr. Florio's $2.8 billion tax program, he said.
"But we not only have to overcome that, we must reverse a 10-year slide in our fortunes," Mr. Byrne said, referring to the years when a booming economy helped Thomas H. Kean become one of the state's most popular governors and enabled him to pull in a Republican State Assembly. "And that job won't be done until the term 'Reagan Democrats' is no longer part of the political lexicon."
Mr. Byrne has abandoned his idea of forming a "shadow government," complete with its own cabinet, to monitor the performance of the Whitman administration. That, he said, would be too cumbersome. Instead, he plans to release periodic position papers -- dressed up with Ross Perot-style graphics -- on state issues to define the party and invite comparison with the policies of the Republican administration.
Mr. Byrne did not seek it, but interviews with Republicans brought some words of advice. Dean R. Armandroff, executive director of the Republican State Committee, said that if the Democratic Party hoped to rebuild, it "must focus on local races that were lost in 1990-91 in town council, mayoral and freeholder races."
"Just as there was a Watergate class of Democrats elected to Congress in the 1970's, there was very much a Florio class of Republican candidates swept into office in 1991 and 1992 when we began to win control of town councils," he said.
Mayor Bret Schundler of Jersey City, a Democrat turned Republican, said that when most Americans believed that big government could solve their problems, the Democratic Party was in good shape. "But that policy has clearly failed," he said, "and people are now mad at both parties, but more so at Democrats.
"The traditional Republican notion of lower taxes and less government is the wave of the future," he said. "The Democrats have got to fight for people again and have got to learn to keep the special interests at bay."

GRAPHIC: Photo: With Republicans in control, the mission of Brendan Thomas Byrne 2d, the new head of New Jersey's Democratic Party, is to find a message to appeal to voters. (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Not-So-Perfect Garden

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Lena Williams wrote a fascinating article on the success of Madison Square Garden. Of course, I could do a lot better myself if I could get the type of favorable tax breaks the Garden has received. I have a great idea! Why don't you do a story on how much in taxes Madison Square Garden hasn't paid and then find out how much that money could have helped New York City and its people -- especially those who are soon to be unemployed, left without medical care or suffer from the downgrading of services, like park maintenance and street cleaning, because of the city's huge budget gap.
 
ELI GANIAS
Manhattan, March 30

HEADLINE: Is U.S. Really Taking a Wrong Turn?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "As Capitalism Wins, the U.S. Drops Out" (Viewpoints, March 27), Theodore J. Forstmann sets up a number of strawmen, then proceeds to knock them down to prove the United States is slipping away from capitalism while many other countries are embracing it. 
 He has a particular dislike for President Clinton's proposed health care reform package. But even here he is disingenuous, arguing that he travels to countries everywhere that "are privatizing industry" only to return home "to a country that is about to nationalize health care."
There are no bills in Congress to nationalize health care. Even the single-payer bill wouldn't do this, and it is, perhaps, the most sweeping proposal. It would only nationalize the collection of revenues to pay for care, negotiate regional rates for health services and pay the bills.
Had Mr. Forstmann traveled to Western Europe, he would have found each country with either national health insurance or a national health service. In Southeast Asia, he must have bypassed China and Japan because they also have national health systems dominated by national governments.WILLIAM ARTIS Manhattan, March 28
The writer is assistant to the president of the National Union of Hospital and Healthcare Employees.

HEADLINE: Is U.S. Really Taking a Wrong Turn?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In his passionate defense of laissez-faire capitalism, Theodore J. Forstmann seems unaware of how ahistorical his views are. How someone who ignores so much American history can hope to predict the future is a mystery. 
 The Government has always intervened to help capitalism, from Alexander Hamilton's "Report on Manufactures," through land grants to railroads to 20th century support for all businesses inherent in massive Federal and state outlays for highways, shipping, railroads and air transportation. Have such governmental interventions in the free market made the United States the statist society Mr. Forstmann so fears?
Finally, the dialectical absolutism of his article might make good copy for an opinion editorial, but it does not reflect reality. He ignores the reality of "individuals acting on their own interests" and polluting our air, our waterways, our land and all the while exploiting labor -- children included.
If businessmen had been more ethical and socially responsible much of the government intervention Mr. Forstmann rues would not have been necessary. While praising democracy, he implicitly criticizes the United States for its response to cupidity and excess. The irony here is that the government response usually came after many years of abuse and after persistent democratic pressure.
 
JOHN E. HILL
Quincy, Mass., March 31
 
The writer is a professor of politics and history at Curry College in Milton, Mass.

LENGTH: 179 words

HEADLINE: Is U.S. Really Taking a Wrong Turn?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Theodore J. Forstmann points out that American statism has "increased ignorance while spending more on education" and "increased racial tensions while trying to engineer equality." How true. 
 Free of the stifling egalitarianism of government, the private sector could educate deserving students with superb efficiency, wasting no resources on unworthy children, who could be used as inexpensive manual laborers.
And before the Government, starting with Lincoln, began meddling in race relations, the "genius of the marketplace" had produced the lucrative slavery system under which racial tension as we know it was minimal.
And Mr. Forstmann need not fret about health care under Bill Clinton being given over to "probing government hands." It seems far move likely that it will be given over to the largest insurance companies, which will doubtless enable Mr. Forstmann and other "risk takers" to turn a tidy profit.
 
GEOFFREY GRINSTEIN
Yorktown Heights, N.Y., March 31
 
The writer is a physicist who works in the computer industry.

HEADLINE: Banks of New York: What They Offer, What It Costs

BYLINE: By JESSE McKINLEY 

 BODY:
Here is a look at the types of accounts and services offered by a selection of local banks.
Most banks offer free checking if requirements for a minimum balance are met. The requirements are based either on an average of the daily balances during the statement period (generally about a month) or on a minimum daily balance (in which there is a charge if the balance drops below the required level at any time during the statement period). 
 In some cases, free checking also means free use of automatic teller machines -- locally and in worldwide networks. And in many cases, balances in checking accounts can be linked to, or combined with, savings, C.D.'s and other deposit accounts to meet the requirements.
When averages aren't met and banks charge, they charge a monthly fee as well as a fee for each transaction (for a withdrawal or deposit through a teller or A.T.M., for example, or for a check paid). Some banks charge for use of their own A.T.M.'s, and almost all charge for use of those of other banks.
Many banks offer budget checking accounts, in which they charge low fees for minimum monthly activity. Starting July 1, state law will require all banks to offer this service.
Some banks also offer accounts for large-balance customers, providing special packages of services.
 
CITIBANK
 CHECKING ACCOUNTS: Regular and interest-bearing. Either can be linked to savings, C.D.'s, I.R.A.'s and mutual fund accounts.
Requirements for free checking: For regular, $2,000 average monthly balance in checking alone or $6,000 in linked accounts. For interest-bearing, $5,000 alone or $10,000 linked.
Charges if balances aren't met: For regular, $9.50 a month plus 35 cents for each transaction. For interest-bearing accounts, $12 a month and the same transaction charges.
BUDGET BANKING: Yes. $4 a month. Six free transactions and then 75 cents for every transaction thereafter. No minimum to open.
Charge for using another bank's A.T.M.: $1, regardless of balance.
OTHER CHARGES: Bounced check, $15; deposited check returned unpaid, $10; stop payment, $15; certified check, $9.50.
A.T.M. SERVICES: Deposits, withdrawals, transfers among accounts, mutual fund transactions, inquiries on balances and 90-day account activity, payments and cash advances on Citibank Visa or Mastercard accounts and, for $3.50 a month, other bill payments.
A.T.M. LANGUAGES: English, Spanish, Chinese, Korean and Greek.
LARGE-BALANCE PACKAGE ACCOUNTS: Citigold. Requires $100,000 in combined accounts. Provides investment services, allows $2,000 a day in A.T.M. withdrawals and gives preferred rates on mortgage and loan rates. $125 a year.
Services by phone or computer: All basic services except deposits and withdrawals by phone or computer.
BRANCHES, A.T.M. NETWORKS: 213 branches, in all five boroughs. A.T.M.'s linked to Cirrus, Honor, Presto, SAM, The Exchange, Metroteller, Nyce and Plus.
Phone: (212) 627-3999
 
CHEMICAL
 CHECKING ACCOUNTS: Regular and interest-bearing. Either can be linked to savings, C.D.'s, I.R.A.'s and mutual funds.
Requirements for free checking: For regular, an average monthly balance of $3,000 alone or $6,000 in combined deposit accounts. For interest-bearing, $5,000 alone or $7,500 in combined accounts.
Charges (effective May 2) if balances aren't met: Regular, $9.50 a month plus 50 cents a transaction. Interest-bearing, $12 a month, same transaction fees.
BUDGET BANKING: Yes. $4 a month for 10 or fewer transactions. For more than 10 transactions, fees for regular checking apply.
Charge for another bank's A.T.M.: $1.
OTHER CHARGES: Bounced check, $15; deposited check returned unpaid, $10; stop payment, $15; certified check, $9.50.
A.T.M. SERVICES: Deposits, withdrawals, transfers among accounts and inquiries.
A.T.M. LANGUAGES: All in English and Spanish and some locations in Russian, Chinese, French and Korean.
LARGE-BALANCE PACKAGE ACCOUNTS: Select Banking. Requires $25,000 in checking. Provides a personal banker to monitors accounts and give advice; free Chemical Mastercard or Visa; free traveler's checks; preferred loan and C.D. rates. $18 a month.
Services by phone or computer: 24-hour automated and live service over the phone for transfers and basic account inquiries. Computer banking only for businesses.
BRANCHES, A.T.M. NETWORKS: 330 branches, in all five boroughs. A.T.M.'s linked to NYCE and Cirrus.
Phone: (212) 935-9935

CHECKING ACCOUNTS: Regular and interest-bearing. Can be linked to savings accounts, C.D.'s, I.R.A.'s, mutual funds.
Requirements for free checking: For regular, $3,000 average monthly balance alone or linked. For interest-bearing, $5,000 average monthly balance alone or linked.
Charges if balances aren't met: Regular, $9.50 a month, plus 25 cents for every transaction. For interest-bearing, $12 a month and the same transaction fees.
BUDGET BANKING: Yes. $4 a month. 10 free transactions, then 75 cents for each additional transaction. $1 to open.
Charge for another bank's A.T.M.: $1.
